instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Cracked Software Being Used as Victim Bait
A report from Sophos looks at the techniques used by some Malware as a Service (MaaS) offerings that provide droppers capable of delivering multiple different payloads.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Users searching for cracked software
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Multiple
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** User execution of downloaded dropper
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Multiple
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See Mitre Attack Framework below.



# Overview

Users searching for cracked software are the targets of some Malware as a Service (MaaS) offerings that provide droppers that deliver multiple payloads. SEO techniques are used to promote links in search results that point to a bait page, the bait pages have typically been hosted on WordPress sites. The bait pages have a download button for the cracked software the victim was seeking. If the button is clicked, the request is passed through intermediary sites which carry out a number of checks such as operating system and geolocation are carried out, with the victim finally being provided a download link which leads to the dropper. The dropper is usually contained in a password-protected .zip file which is contained in another .zip file along with a text file that contains the password to decrypt the dropper .zip file. The droppers can deliver multiple payloads which Sophos have observed to include clickfraud bots, cryptomminers, information stealers, and the Conti and STOP ransomware. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127095/Cracked%20Software%20Being%20Used%20as%20Victim%20Bait%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1630551629183&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/09/01/fake-pirated-software-sites-serve-up-malware-droppers-as-a-service/>



# Mitre ATT&CK Framework

 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.004 - Server  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: AR20-259A - Iranian Web Shells
CISA has published a malware analysis report, AR20-259A, describing recent samples of web shells tied to an Iranian-based threat actor.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: AR20-259A - Iranian Web Shells
CISA has published a malware analysis report, AR20-259A, describing recent samples of web shells tied to an Iranian-based threat actor.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Web Shell, Backdoor




# Overview

CISA published AR20-259A, a malware analysis report of Iranian web shell samples. The threat actor targets information technology, government, healthcare, financial, and insurance organizations across the United States. The initial infection vector in their attacks is through the exploitation of vulnerabilities in Pulse Secure virtual private network (VPN), Citrix NetScaler, and F5 devices. After successfully exploiting one of these vulnerabilities, the attackers were observed deploying various webshells onto the system. These included the ChunkyTuna, Tiny, and China Chopper web shells. Capabilities provided with these web shells installed include the ability to execute commands, enumerate directories, download and execute additional payloads, and exfiltrate data. Two additional tools were also discovered in use, FRP and KeeThief. FRP is an open source project allowing tunneling of network connections, which the researchers believed was used by this threat actor to tunnel Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) sessions. KeeThief is another open source tool that is used to decrypt and steal credentials stored in the KeePass password manager. These credentials could then be used to move laterally. For more information, see the CISA report in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar20-259a>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: An Analysis of APT29's Backdoor - MiniDuke
The newest variant of the backdoor known as MiniDuke has been analyzed by a researcher at CyberGeek.tech. This backdoor has been in use for a long time, but this is the first time this variant from 2019 has been fully analyzed publicly.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: An Analysis of APT29's Backdoor - MiniDuke
The newest variant of the backdoor known as MiniDuke has been analyzed by a researcher at CyberGeek.tech. This backdoor has been in use for a long time, but this is the first time this variant from 2019 has been fully analyzed publicly.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** APT29 (G0016), ITG11
  *  **Targets:** Government Entities
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** MiniDuke (S0051)
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

A researcher at Cybergeeks.tech has analyzed a new variant of the MiniDuke malware that is currently being used by APT29. APT29 is a threat actor known by many names including Cozy Bear, CozyDuke, Cozys, Dark Halo, Duke Group, Hammertoss, Minis, Office Monkeys, Pitty Tiger, Spikerrush, StellarParticle, TEMP.Monkey, TEMP.Noble, The Dukes, TG-4127, UNC2452, and Yttrium. IBM X-Force tracks NOBELIUM as ITG11. They are associated with Russia's Foreign Intelligence service and are believed to be behind the high-profile SolarWinds compromise in 2020. MiniDuke is a backdoor generally used by APT29 as a second-stage backdoor, with the newest version being seen in 2019. The analysis mainly focuses on the communications between the malware and the C2 server, and details three different modes of communication. If the machine does not have internet access, the malware will open a named pipe and use it to connect to another machine in the network which does have internet access and use this as a proxy to exfiltrate data. There is a command for an instance of MiniDuke to set up a named pipe and listen for connections if another machine in the network requires it. If it does have internet access, the malware can exfiltrate data via either POST or PUT requests. On top of exfiltration, the malware can receive commands to manipulate files and processes and has been used as a dropper in past campaigns. ATP 29 has previously used this malware in attacks on government entities in different countries in Europe and the United States. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129834/An%20Analysis%20of%20APT29%27s%20Backdoor%20-%20MiniDuke%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633695923433&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use application control where appropriate (M1038).



# References

  * <https://cybergeeks.tech/how-to-defeat-the-russian-dukes-a-step-by-step-analysis-of-miniduke-used-by-apt29-cozy-bear/>
  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/ESET_Operation_Ghost_Dukes.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.005 - Indicator Removal from Tools  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1012 - Query Registry  
T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1016.001 - Internet Connection Discovery  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1614 - System Location Discovery

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: CISA Alert AA20-258A
Observations of the Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) cyber threat actors reveal the use of public information source and well-known TTPs, states CISA in a new alert (AA20-258A).

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: CISA Alert AA20-258A
Observations of the Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) cyber threat actors reveal the use of public information source and well-known TTPs, states CISA in a new alert (AA20-258A).

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability, Cyber Threat




# Overview

The Cybersecurity and Information Security Agency has issued an alert detailing the suspected actions of Chinese Ministry of State Security-affiliated cyber threat actors. These actors are using publicly available information and well-known TTPs in order to target U.S. government agencies. Additionally, the actors use easily obtained exploit kits to infiltrate target networks. In addition to the targeting of the U.S. Government, the actors have also been observed targeting various other industries including high-tech manufacturing, medical devices, civil and industrial engineering, business, education, gaming software, and others. Through the use of open-source tools, it is suspected the actors have low-complexity capabilities. The actors have been mostly successful in the infiltration of networks that are misconfigured or have a weak password management profile. Further information can be found in the alert listed within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/30769168/CISA%20Alert%20AA20-258A%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1600107390523&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa20-258a>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: TimeTime Ransomware
Researchers at Minerva Labs analyzed a new, simple ransomware family named TimeTime attempting to receive ransomware via prepaid vouchers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type** : Ransomware
  *  **Targets** : Unknown
  *  **Ransomware Family** : TimeTime
  *  **RaaS Operation** : No
  *  **Initial Infection Vector** : Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions** : Data encryption



# Overview

Minerva Labs published their analysis of a new ransomware named TimeTime. This ransomware is very unsophisticated, with a low ransom demand, simple encryption routine, and no obfuscation. Upon execution, volume shadow copies are deleted to inhibit recovery. Then the encryption process begins, with the name of every file encrypted being added to a custom registry key. The ransom note dropped on the system requests that victims purchase a prepaid voucher from Paysafecard in order to retrieve their files. The purchased voucher codes are requested via a decryption utility that is also dropped by the ransomware. The researchers point out that while the ransom note claims victim data was also stolen and will be leaked if the ransom is note paid, there is no evidence that the ransomware payload is capable of performing exfiltration. For more information, see the Minerva Labs blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056432/TimeTime%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1640628198948&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blog.minerva-labs.com/meet-the-timetime-ransomware-the-ransomware-that-asks-for-100-via-paysafecard>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Recent NtpClient Mining Activity
Researchers at 360CERT observed new activity by NtpClient, a Linux mining Trojan that exploits public-facing services to gain access to victim hosts.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Cryptominer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** NtpClient
  *  **Targets:** Vulnerable Linux servers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of public-facing applications
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining



# Overview

360CERT published a blog post analyzing recent NtpClient activity. NtpClient is a Linux mining Trojan. The infection chain begins with exploitation of a remote code execution vulnerability. NtpClient has been observed exploiting several different vulnerabilities for access, such as those affecting Drupal, Confluence, WebLogic, MongoDB, and more. Regardless of the specific vulnerability leveraged, the exploit ultimately uses wget to download a shell script. Upon execution, the script performs various clean up tasks to kill competing miners. The NtpClient payload is then downloaded and executed in order to start mining Monero cryptocurrency. For more information, see the 360CERT blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130424/Recent%20NtpClient%20Mining%20Activity%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634322772761&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://cert.360.cn/warning/detail?id=59fb5cdc6fe68ddab7b24b975d97694b>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking

  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining



# Overview

360CERT published a blog post analyzing recent NtpClient activity. NtpClient is a Linux mining Trojan. The infection chain begins with exploitation of a remote code execution vulnerability. NtpClient has been observed exploiting several different vulnerabilities for access, such as those affecting Drupal, Confluence, WebLogic, MongoDB, and more. Regardless of the specific vulnerability leveraged, the exploit ultimately uses wget to download a shell script. Upon execution, the script performs various clean up tasks to kill competing miners. The NtpClient payload is then downloaded and executed in order to start mining Monero cryptocurrency. For more information, see the 360CERT blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130424/Recent%20NtpClient%20Mining%20Activity%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634322772761&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://cert.360.cn/warning/detail?id=59fb5cdc6fe68ddab7b24b975d97694b>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: An Investigation Into Lazarus Initial Access Methods
NCC Group has published an article going into detail about the initial access methods used by the threat group Lazarus. Along with the various methods, the researchers also analyze some of the malware seen in these breaches.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Downloader
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Lazarus
  *  **Associated Payloads:** LCPDot
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Malware Download



# Overview

NCC Group has been tracking the North Korean threat group, Lazarus. This group uses many tactics to gain access to victim networks, which have been summarized by the researchers. These methods rely heavily on the use of social engineering, with members of the group impersonating LinkedIn profiles to persuade victims to follow up on false job opportunities. This would end in a malicious document being sent to the victim which will execute a malicious DLL. The researchers also found a variant of the LCPDot downloader malware, which uses several evasion techniques and is set as a daily scheduled task. The file size is large to avoid anti-virus scanning, and the process masquerades as a Java process. Once installed, the downloader registers the victim to the C2 server and requests a payload to execute. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://research.nccgroup.com/2022/05/05/north-koreas-lazarus-and-their-initial-access-trade-craft-using-social-media-and-social-engineering/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

#### Tactics and Techniques:

  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566.003 - Spearphishing via Service  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036.004 - Masquerade Task or Service  
T1070.006 - Timestamp  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1029:** Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Weaponizing An Antivirus Driver
While conducting an incident response investigation involving the Cuba ransomware, researchers from Aon discovered a new technique in the Cuba toolset that is used to bypass security controls.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Weaponizing An Antivirus Driver
While conducting an incident response investigation involving the Cuba ransomware, researchers from Aon discovered a new technique in the Cuba toolset that is used to bypass security controls.

Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Ransomware
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Operators of the Cuba ransomware
* **Associated Payloads:** Cuba ransomware and toolset
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** File encryption
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Researchers from Aon discovered a new technique in the Cuba ransomware toolset that is used to bypass security controls. The technique involves the use of a legitimate driver, in this case, Avast's Anti Rootkit kernel driver, to terminate a number of AV and EDR processes. Three variations of the technique were observed by Aon, all of which involve installing the driver and then using either an executable or PowerShell script that calls the DeviceIoControl API to terminate specific AV and EDR processes. The Aon report notes that the most recent version of the Cuba toolset contains a list of 110 processes to terminate if found. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* [https://www.aon.com/cyber-solutions/aon\_cyber\_labs/yours-truly-signed-av-driver-weaponizing-an-antivirus-driver/](https://www.aon.com/cyber-solutions/aon_cyber_labs/yours-truly-signed-av-driver-weaponizing-an-antivirus-driver/ "Follow link")

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
   T1059.001 - PowerShell  
 T1106 - Native API  
 T1204 - User Execution  
   T1204.002 - Malicious File  
 T1569 - System Services  
   T1569.002 - Service Execution  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
   T1574.010 - Services File Permissions Weakness  

**Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
 T1055 - Process Injection  
   T1055.002 - Portable Executable Injection  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
   T1027.001 - Binary Padding  
   T1027.002 - Software Packing  
 T1036 - Masquerading  
   T1036.005 - Match Legitimate Name or Location  
 T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
 T1211 - Exploitation for Defense Evasion  
 T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
 T1562 - Impair Defenses  
   T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1057 - Process Discovery  

**Mitigations:**

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1019:**  Threat Intelligence Program - A threat intelligence program helps an organization generate their own threat intelligence information and track trends to inform defensive priorities to mitigate risk.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1039:**  Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1044:**  Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1048:**  Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1050:**  Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1052:**  User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Attempts to Exploit Spring4Shell to Deploy Cryptominers
Trend Micro has published a report that analyzes an attempt to exploit the Spring4Shell vulnerability (CVE-2022-22965) in order to install cryptominers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Attempts to Exploit Spring4Shell to Deploy Cryptominers
Trend Micro has published a report that analyzes an attempt to exploit the Spring4Shell vulnerability (CVE-2022-22965) in order to install cryptominers.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Webshell, Cryptominer.
  *  **Targets:** Systems vulnerable to exploitation of CVE-2022-22965.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unnamed
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Spring4Shell vulnerability CVE-2022-22965.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A report that provides an analysis of an attempt to exploit the Spring4Shell vulnerability (CVE-2022-22965) to install cryptominers has been published by Trend Micro. If the exploitation attempt is successful, a webshell is deployed which is then used to install a cryptominer. The execution flow depends on the operating system of the exploited computer. If it is a Windows machine, a PowerShell script is downloaded and executed. The script carries out a number of operations including disabling the firewall, killing other cryptominers, stopping processes listening on ports 3333, 4444, 5555, 7777, and 9000, and then downloading and executing the cryptominer binary in a hidden window. If the exploited system is running Linux, a shell script is used to kill other cryptominers, then download and deploy the cryptomining binary. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/d/spring4shell-exploited-to-deploy-cryptocurrency-miners.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1595.001 - Scanning IP Blocks  
T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.004 - Exploits  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.001 - Malware  
T1588.002 - Tool  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.004 - Disable or Modify System Firewall  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
T1564.003 - Hidden Window  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Attempts to Exploit Spring4Shell to Deploy Cryptominers
Trend Micro has published a report that analyzes an attempt to exploit the Spring4Shell vulnerability (CVE-2022-22965) in order to install cryptominers.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Webshell, Cryptominer.
  *  **Targets:** Systems vulnerable to exploitation of CVE-2022-22965.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unnamed
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Spring4Shell vulnerability CVE-2022-22965.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A report that provides an analysis of an attempt to exploit the Spring4Shell vulnerability (CVE-2022-22965) to install cryptominers has been published by Trend Micro. If the exploitation attempt is successful, a webshell is deployed which is then used to install a cryptominer. The execution flow depends on the operating system of the exploited computer. If it is a Windows machine, a PowerShell script is downloaded and executed. The script carries out a number of operations including disabling the firewall, killing other cryptominers, stopping processes listening on ports 3333, 4444, 5555, 7777, and 9000, and then downloading and executing the cryptominer binary in a hidden window. If the exploited system is running Linux, a shell script is used to kill other cryptominers, then download and deploy the cryptomining binary. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.

 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: ICS-CERT Advisories February 04 2021
The ICS-CERT has published two advisories that affect Luxion KeyShot and Horner Automation Cscape.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: ICS-CERT Advisories February 04 2021
The ICS-CERT has published two advisories that affect Luxion KeyShot and Horner Automation Cscape.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
 Further information is available from the advisories, which are summarised below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-035-01 - Luxion KeyShot  
** CVE-2021-22647 - The affected product is vulnerable to multiple out-of-bounds write issues while processing project files, which may allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-22643 - The affected product is vulnerable to an out-of-bounds read while processing project files, which may allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-22645 - The affected product is vulnerable to an attack because the .bip documents display a “load” command, which can be pointed to a .dll from a remote network share. As a result, the .dll entry point can be executed without sufficient UI warning.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-22649 - The affected product has multiple NULL pointer dereference issues while processing project files, which may allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-22651 - When loading a specially crafted file, the application, while processing the extraction of temporary files, suffers from a directory traversal vulnerability, which allows an attacker to store arbitrary scripts into automatic startup folders.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-035-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-035-02 - Horner Automation Cscape  
** CVE-2021-22663 - The affected application lacks proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing project files. This could lead to an out-of-bounds read. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to execute code in the context of the current process.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-035-02>

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/40370250/ICS-CERT%20Advisories%20February%2004%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1612759233765&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Operation EmailThief
A targeted spear-phishing campaign led Volexity researchers to uncover a threat actor exploiting a zero-day cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the Zimbra email platform for remote code execution.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Exploit
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** TEMP_Heretic (likely a Chinese APT)
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unknown
  *  **Targets:** European government and media
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing link leading to exploitation of XSS vulnerability in Zimbra
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Email data theft, arbitrary JavaScript execution



# Overview

Volexity published a blog post analyzing a spear-phishing campaign targeting European government and media organizations. The threat actor exploits a zero-day cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the Zimbra email platform to carry out their ultimate goal of steal email data. An initial wave of phishing emails was observed seemingly being used go identify valid email addresses to be used in the second wave. The second wave used more sophisticated content using a variety of themes, and some were targeted while others were not. If a user clicked the link while signed into a Zimbra via the web browser, the attacker was able to execute arbitrary JavaScript. This actor specifically used the exploit to run code that iterates over the victim's inbox and sent folders and exfiltrate the email content and attachments via an HTTP POST request. At the time of writing, no patch is available for this vulnerability. For more information, see the Volexity blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058285/Operation%20EmailThief%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644253196184&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.volexity.com/blog/2022/02/03/operation-emailthief-active-exploitation-of-zero-day-xss-vulnerability-in-zimbra/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1589.002 - Email Addresses  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.004 - Exploits  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1114 - Email Collection  
T1114.002 - Remote Email Collection  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: SteamHide Malware
Steganography is a known method of distributing malicious code in seemingly legitimate files. G DATA discovered malicious image files being hosted via Steam profile pictures.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

G DATA published a blog post analyzing malicious images distributed via Steam profiles. Steganographic techniques were used to embed malicious code inside various images. These images were then set as profile pictures on attacker-controlled Steam accounts. The Steam app is not required to be installed on a victim system but is simply a method of hosting the malware. In order to extract, decode, and execute the malicious payload, a downloader is required on the victim system. Once executed, the payload performs anti-VM checks, escalates privileges, establishes persistence via a Registry Run key, and retrieves its C2 server via Pastebin. Due to how the the malware is hosted, by updating the Steam profile picture the attacker can also update the malware on the system. At the time of this research, development of SteamHide appears to be in progress with limited malicious functionality provided. Unused code indicates future implementation of vulnerability scanning, metamorphic capabilities, C2 communication via Twitter, and more. For more information, see the G DATA blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.gdatasoftware.com/blog/steamhide-malware-in-profile-images>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Fox Kitten Ransomware Campaign
ClearSky has published a whitepaper detailing cyberattacks against Israeli companies using ransomware. It is believed that Fox Kitten, an Iranian APT group, is responsible for the attacks that began in the July to August timeframe.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, APT, Campaign



# Overview

ClearSky's new whitepaper describes a ransomware campaign that targets Israeli companies and is believed to have the Iranian APT group Fox Kitten behind it. The infection vector for the attacks has been well-known application vulnerabilities. Besides encrypting systems on a successfully compromised network, the data that resides on the systems is also leaked to public social media platforms. After analyzing the tools used by the Pay2Key threat actor with those of Fox Kitten, ClearSky decided that there were overlaps between the two. Both groups exploit vulnerabilities in VPNs used by their victims. After infection, the methods for gaining privilege escalation and persistence overlapped. Command and control communication and data exfiltration were again similar. To learn more about the details that ClearSky used to tie Pay2Key to Fox Kitten, review the link in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35718841/New%20Fox%20Kitten%20Ransomware%20Campaign%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1608588635258&api=v2)



# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35718841/New%20Fox%20Kitten%20Ransomware%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1608588624568&api=v2)



# Protection

## IBM

  * CVE-2019-11510: HTTP_PulseSecure_DotDot
  * CVE-2019-19781: HTTP_Citrix_Gateway_Exec
  * CVE-2020-5902: HTTP_F5_BigIP_TMUI_Exec



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.clearskysec.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Pay2Kitten.pdf>

ClearSky's new whitepaper describes a ransomware campaign that targets Israeli companies and is believed to have the Iranian APT group Fox Kitten behind it. The infection vector for the attacks has been well-known application vulnerabilities. Besides encrypting systems on a successfully compromised network, the data that resides on the systems is also leaked to public social media platforms. After analyzing the tools used by the Pay2Key threat actor with those of Fox Kitten, ClearSky decided that there were overlaps between the two. Both groups exploit vulnerabilities in VPNs used by their victims. After infection, the methods for gaining privilege escalation and persistence overlapped. Command and control communication and data exfiltration were again similar. To learn more about the details that ClearSky used to tie Pay2Key to Fox Kitten, review the link in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35718841/New%20Fox%20Kitten%20Ransomware%20Campaign%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1608588635258&api=v2)



# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35718841/New%20Fox%20Kitten%20Ransomware%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1608588624568&api=v2)



# Protection

## IBM

  * CVE-2019-11510: HTTP_PulseSecure_DotDot
  * CVE-2019-19781: HTTP_Citrix_Gateway_Exec
  * CVE-2020-5902: HTTP_F5_BigIP_TMUI_Exec



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.clearskysec.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Pay2Kitten.pdf>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Salfram Crypter Campaigns
Several email campaigns have been observed by Cisco Talos, all sharing one commonality: the use of a crypter, dubbed Salfram, on the first stage payloads.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Cisco Talos reports on a series of email campaigns distributing various malware families, all encrypted with the same crypter, named Salfram. The initial emails in each campaign are sent via business' website contact forms, increasing the chance it will be opened by the recipient. The content of the message claims that there are images hosted on the website that violate copyright and request the recipient review a document hosted at a provided link for more information. To send the form submissions, the operators leveraged proxy servers and automated scripting to generate and submit the lure. With regard to the links in the emails, most point to a document hosted on Google Drive. The document is a macro-emedded file that, if downloaded and executed, will begin infecting the system. Some infection chains led to the installation of various payloads, while others only delivered a single malicious payload. Regardless of the full infection chain and malware family in use, the initial payload leveraged the Salfram crypter to obfuscate its content. The crypter seems to have evolved over the course of the campaigns. Some differences include the actual code used for similar function calls. However, many similarities can be seen, such as the use of a large number of jumps and fake API calls. Ultimately, the payload is unpacked and run on the system. The researchers note that the crypter is quite advanced outside its inclusion of a string in the DOS stub that is highly trackable. For more information, see the Talos blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2020/09/salfram-robbing-place-without-removing.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: OnePercent Group Ransomware IoCs
The FBI has issued a FLASH with coordination from DHS-CISA. The FBI has identified that the OnePercent Group has been using Cobalt Strike to distribute ransomware against US companies since November 2020.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: OnePercent Group Ransomware IoCs
The FBI has issued a FLASH with coordination from DHS-CISA. The FBI has identified that the OnePercent Group has been using Cobalt Strike to distribute ransomware against US companies since November 2020.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** US **** Companies
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Not Specified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing Emails with Malicious Zip Files
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Spoofed Phone Calls, Ransom Demands, 
  * **Additional TTPs:** N/A
  *  **Additional Tools Dropped:** Cobalt Strike, IcedID, AWS S3 Cloud, PowerShell, Rclone, Mimikatz, SharpKatz, BetterSafetyKatz, SharpSploit



# Overview

A group known as the OnePercent Group has gained unauthorized access to networks through phishing emails, reports the FBI and DHS-CISA. The phishing emails contain a malicious zip file attachment. The attachment is either a Microsoft Word document or Excel spreadsheet containing macros that allow for the installation of the IcedID banking Trojan. IcedID is then used to install and execute Cobalt Strike on the network for the purposes of lateral movement with PowerShell remoting. Rclone is used for data exfiltration. It has been observed the attacker remains on the victim network for about a month before deploying ransomware. Upon successful deployment, the victim receives phone calls from spoofed numbers with the callers demanding a ransom and are provided with an email address for further communications and negotiation. Other tools employed include AWS S3 cloud, Mimikatz, SharpKatz, BetterSafetyKatz, and SharpSploit. The attacker persistently threatens the release of the stolen data should the ransom not be paid. Further details can be found in the FLASH report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [.txt](/download/attachments/62357994/OnePercent%20Group%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=2&modificationDate=1630004870089&api=v2)



# Recommendations

The following recommendations are from the FBI FLASH report.

  * Back-up critical data offline.

  * Ensure administrators are not using “Admin Approval” mode.

  * Implement Microsoft LAPS, if possible.

  * Ensure copies of critical data are in the cloud or on an external hard drive or storage device. This information should not be accessible from the compromised network.

  * Secure your back-ups and ensure data is not accessible for modification or deletion from the system where the original data resides.

  * Keep computers, devices, and applications patched and up-to-date.

  * Consider adding an email banner to emails received from outside your organization.

  * Disable unused remote access/Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) ports and monitor remote access/RDP logs.

  * Audit user accounts with administrative privileges and configure access controls with least privilege in mind.

  * Implement network segmentation.

  * Use multi-factor authentication with strong passphrases.




# References

  * <https://www.ic3.gov/Media/News/2021/210823.pdf>



# Mitre ATT&CK Framework

 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1040 - Network Sniffing  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
  
 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1591 - Gather Victim Org Information  
T1592 - Gather Victim Host Information  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1595.001 - Scanning IP Blocks  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1072 - Software Deployment Tools  
T1129 - Shared Modules  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1072 - Software Deployment Tools  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: RansomEXX Linux Malware Analyzed
Researchers at Profero have detailed how the Linux version of the ransomware used by RansomEXX functions, and have developed their own decryption tool to avoid potential reinfection from the attacker's own tool. They have also provided guidance on what to do when the decryption fails due to file corruption.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actor:** RansomEXX
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** RansomEXX
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

The Profero IR team has been witnessing a rise in ransomware attacks following the disappearance of the REvil ransomware operation. A large portion of these attacks are carried out by a group known as RansomEXX. This group is notable for using custom malware for each target, as well as leaking the identities of any victims who refuse to pay the ransom. The malware affects both Windows and Linux machines, and the Profero team has analyzed the Linux version and written their own decryption tool. The malware is hard to characterize, as each instance is specifically compiled for each attack. There is no persistence mechanism enabled and the tool runs as a standalone command-line tool executed on the victim's machine as part of a multi-stage attack. The ransomware works by recursively encrypting files in a given directory using symmetric encryption. The key used for this encryption is regenerated every 0.18 seconds to prevent a key from being taken from memory and used to decrypt all files. Each key is then appended to the relevant file and further encrypted with an RSA public key. Because of the risk of the decryption tool being malicious, the researchers have written their own decryption tool, which is able to extract the config file from the attacker-provided decryption tool and decrypt the files using this file. Further information can be found in the report located in the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.

  * Where possible, only permit execution of signed scripts (M1045). 
  * Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise (M1053). 
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 



# References

  * <https://medium.com/proferosec-osm/ransomexx-fixing-corrupted-ransom-8e379bcaf701>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1518.001 - Security Software Discovery  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

They have also provided guidance on what to do when the decryption fails due to file corruption.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Daxin - Malware Designed For Espionage In High-Security Networks
Symantec has published a report detailing what they call the most advanced piece of malware used by a China-linked actor. This is the espionage tool called Daxin which has been used as recently as November 2021.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown China-linked Group
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Daxin, Owprox 
  * **Targets:** Government, Telecommunications, Manufacturing, Transportation
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Espionage



# Overview

Symantec has analyzed the stealthy backdoor Daxin and has described it as the most advanced tool they have seen being used by a China-linked actor. This malware is designed to operate within highly secure environments. It's very stealthy and allows communication with the threat actors even when direct internet connectivity isn't available via network tunneling. These channels can be used to form a communications channel spanning multiple networks. The developers have put effort into ensuring communications blend in with normal traffic and will use existing services to avoid starting its own network services. This malware has been deployed in government, telecommunications, transportation, and manufacturing organizations. The researchers have linked this activity with China-linked groups with high confidence, but are unable to link it with a specific threat group. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/81134112/Daxin%20-%20Malware%20Designed%20For%20Espionage%20In%20High-Security%20Networks%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1646411173564&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/daxin-backdoor-espionage>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.006 - Kernel Modules and Extensions  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.006 - Kernel Modules and Extensions  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation  
T1090.001 - Internal Proxy  
T1104 - Multi-Stage Channels

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Bandidos Campaign Primarily Targets Venezuela
A campaign distributing the Bandook malware was discovered by ESET, which they named Bandidos. The campaign has been operating since 2015 and primarily targets corporate networks in Venezuela as well as other Latin American countries.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Bandidos Campaign Primarily Targets Venezuela
A campaign distributing the Bandook malware was discovered by ESET, which they named Bandidos. The campaign has been operating since 2015 and primarily targets corporate networks in Venezuela as well as other Latin American countries.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Campaign




# Overview

A campaign primarily targeting corporate networks in Venezuela was discovered by ESET. The campaign distributes the Bandook malware and was named Bandidos by ESET. Bandook is a RAT that dates back to 2005. It was first documented being used by organized groups in espionage campaigns in 2016. Bandook may be the product of a malware as a service (MaaS) operation. While the Bandidos campaign targets Latin American countries, some ninety percent of its victims are located in Venezuela and span a number of industry sectors. ESET notes that the campaign has been active since 2015 but had remained undocumented. The campaign uses emails with a malicious PDF attachment to distribute Bandook. A shortened link within the PDF file leads to a password-protected RAR archive, usually hosted on a public cloud storage service. The archive contains an executable file which, when executed, injects the Bandook payload into Internet Explorer. A registry key is used to achieve persistence. Additional DLLs may also be downloaded and loaded into memory. One of the functions of the additional DLLs is to create install a malicious extension for the Chrome web browser. Data sent to the Bandidos C&C servers is typically encrypted using AES in CFB mode but, in some cases, is sent in cleartext. Bandidos is likely a cyberespionage operation. It shares some overlaps with other known campaigns such as Operation Manul and Dark Caracal. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/07/07/bandidos-at-large-spying-campaign-latin-america/>

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Bandidos Campaign Primarily Targets Venezuela
A campaign distributing the Bandook malware was discovered by ESET, which they named Bandidos. The campaign has been operating since 2015 and primarily targets corporate networks in Venezuela as well as other Latin American countries.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Campaign




# Overview

A campaign primarily targeting corporate networks in Venezuela was discovered by ESET. The campaign distributes the Bandook malware and was named Bandidos by ESET. Bandook is a RAT that dates back to 2005. It was first documented being used by organized groups in espionage campaigns in 2016. Bandook may be the product of a malware as a service (MaaS) operation. While the Bandidos campaign targets Latin American countries, some ninety percent of its victims are located in Venezuela and span a number of industry sectors. ESET notes that the campaign has been active since 2015 but had remained undocumented. The campaign uses emails with a malicious PDF attachment to distribute Bandook. A shortened link within the PDF file leads to a password-protected RAR archive, usually hosted on a public cloud storage service. The archive contains an executable file which, when executed, injects the Bandook payload into Internet Explorer. A registry key is used to achieve persistence. Additional DLLs may also be downloaded and loaded into memory. One of the functions of the additional DLLs is to create install a malicious extension for the Chrome web browser. Data sent to the Bandidos C&C servers is typically encrypted using AES in CFB mode but, in some cases, is sent in cleartext. Bandidos is likely a cyberespionage operation. It shares some overlaps with other known campaigns such as Operation Manul and Dark Caracal. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/07/07/bandidos-at-large-spying-campaign-latin-america/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: SolarMarker SEO Campaigns
Sophos has published a report that provides information on SEO campaigns that were used to distribute the SolarMarker malware that were carried out place throughout 2021.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Infostealer.
  *  **Targets:** Users searching for specific phrases.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** SolarMarker
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious SEO links.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

The SolarMarker malware, also known as Jupyter and Polazert, is an information stealer that emerged in 2020. A report from Sophos provides an analysis of SolarMarker and SEO campaigns that were used to distribute it throughout 2021. The SEO operations were, according to Sophos, were very effective with the results for their search phrases appearing high in the Google search results. To achieve the results the campaigns used three main methods, web pages and PDF documents hosted on compromised sites, and Google Groups discussions where the campaign operators would create fake conversations with between 500 and 600 entries. From the initial pages, a victim would be redirected to another site that has been known for hosting malware for some years. The victim would eventually be delivered an MSI installer that contained two files, a malicious PowerShell script, and a decoy executable. The decoy file was typically a legitimate installer for Wondershare's PDFelement or Adobe's Acrobat Pro DC. The SolarMarker payload is embedded in the PowerShell script, it is base64-encoded and encrypted. When the script is executed it carries out a number of operations including dropping the payload in the form of a DLL, establishing persistence, and creating a smokescreen directory that contains a large number of randomly named junk files, and a randomly named file which the payload is copied to. An LNK file is used to ultimately begin the process of decrypting the payload which is a DLL and then reflexively loading it. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058107/SolarMarker%20SEO%20Campaigns%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1643853764700&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2022/02/01/solarmarker-campaign-used-novel-registry-changes-to-establish-persistence/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1584.004 - Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.004 - Drive-by Target  
T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1104 - Multi-Stage Channels  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography  
T1573.002 - Asymmetric Cryptography
