instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Google Play Apps That Delivered Out of Context Ads
In a blog posting, the White Ops Satori Threat Intelligence and Research Team reports on more than 240 apps the team located on the Google Play store which deliver out of context ads to users. They are were typically based on Nintendo (NES) emulators from legitimate sources, and were collectively downloaded more than 14 million times.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malicious Apps




# Overview

Malicious apps can make their way onto the Google Play store if they manage to bypass security protocols. A number of apps that used various versions of the Tencent Legu packer to hide their malicious code were discovered on the Play store by the White Ops Satori Threat Intelligence and Research Team. The number of apps discovered exceeded 240 and collectively the apps were downloaded some 14 million times and at peak, the apps generated some 15 million ad impressions, per day. The apps were mainly based on Nintendo (NES) emulators which the authors of the malicious apps obtained from legitimate sources. The ads delivered to the users were made to appear to come from applications and social media platforms such as Youtube and Chrome. The apps tracked the device's screen on and off times in an effort to deliver ads when the user was more likely to see them. Once an app had contacted its C&C server, an ad would be displayed around every 10 minutes. The C&C server located by the White Ops team was running on what appears to be a legitimate, but compromised server. The malicious apps discovered by White Ops have been removed from the Play store. Further details are available from the blog posting linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.whiteops.com/blog/somewhere-over-the-rainbowmix>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: TrickBot Takedown Operation
A joint effort between ESET, Black Lotus Labs, Microsoft, FS-ISAC, and other led to the takedown of TrickBot botnet. A court action led to the interruption of the notorious bot.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: TrickBot Takedown Operation
A joint effort between ESET, Black Lotus Labs, Microsoft, FS-ISAC, and other led to the takedown of TrickBot botnet. A court action led to the interruption of the notorious bot.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet, Ransomware, Credential Theft




# Overview

A joint effort by several major cybersecurity companies and firms was responsible for the takedown, albeit temporarily, of the TrickBot botnet. Trickbot has been around since at least 2016 and is one of the most prolific and dangerous botnets seen. This effort was not the first attempt in taking down TrickBot. Weeks prior to this effort, bots were receiving configurations to replace C2s with reserved IPs. In doing so, the bots were unable to connect to the actual C2s; however, new infections were still occurring. This takedown attempt was allegedly operated by U.S. Cyber Command. The latest attempt involved the efforts of several agencies sharing technical information about the botnet with law enforcement. Unfortunately, the actors behind the botnet had options to allow them to maintain the botnet as well as recover lost, infected computers. One such fallback is the ability to contact a C2 and download a list of secondary C2 servers. Additionally, the C2 servers were able to control plugins and exfiltrate stolen data. It is hypothesized by the U.S. government that the botnet could pose a significant threat to the 2020 election cycle. These attacks could lead to the holding of voter information, stealing sensitive data, election results, and impact the election system at large. For more information, please see the links located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.lumen.com/a-look-inside-the-trickbot-botnet/>

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/trickbot-botnet-targeted-in-takedown-operations-little-impact-seen/>
  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2020/10/12/eset-takes-part-global-operation-disrupt-trickbot/>
  * <https://blogs.microsoft.com/on-the-issues/2020/10/12/trickbot-ransomware-cyberthreat-us-elections/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Critical Vulnerability Affects Drupal Core
A Security Advisory for Drupal, SA-CORE-2021-001, addresses a critical vulnerability in the PEAR Archive_Tar library, which is used by the Drupal core.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Critical Vulnerability Affects Drupal Core
A Security Advisory for Drupal, SA-CORE-2021-001, addresses a critical vulnerability in the PEAR Archive_Tar library, which is used by the Drupal core.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

The Drupal Security Advisory, SA-CORE-2021-001, provides an update for various versions of Drupal core to address a remotely exploitable vulnerability. The vulnerability is rated as critical by Drupal. A directory traversal vulnerability exists in the PEAR Archive_Tar library that could allow an attacker to upload compressed packages containing symbolic links. This could allow potentially allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code. Instances of Drupal which allow the upload of .tar, .tar.gz, .bz2, or .tlz files are vulnerable. The vulnerability is addressed in versions 7.78, 8.9.13, 9.0.11, and 9.1.3. Further details are available from the advisory linked to in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-36193




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.drupal.org/sa-core-2021-001>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New PoetRAT Campaigns
PoetRAT is continuing to evolve their malware in while targeting Azerbaijan public and private sector organizations. Cisco Talos reports on two campaigns and how they differ from previous PoetRAT activity.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

Cisco Talos has published a blog post analyzing two recent PoetRAT campaigns. Both campaigns, one occurring in September 2020 and the other in October, leverage a malicious Azerbaijan government-themed Word document. The researchers believe that victims receive a spear phishing email with a link to download the document. These documents contain malicious macros with embedded payloads that will be dropped on the system. In the first campaign, a Python interpreter and the PoetRAT payload are dropped. Unlike previous versions of PoetRAT, obfuscation is performed using pyminifier. Additionally, the malware is split into several different files. Finally, and most notably, PoetRAT now uses HTTP for C2 communication instead of FTP. The second campaign differs in its use of a Lua payload and interpreter as opposed to Python. The macro drops a ZIP archive containing these files. The Lua script attempts to download and execute a malicious payload from a remote server, but researchers were unable to obtain a sample at the time of research. Despite the changes to the payload itself, targeting is still focused on Azerbaijan and the same types of organizations. Cisco believes that these campaigns are performed for espionage purposes as the geopolitical tensions in the region grow. parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
New PoetRAT Campaigns
PoetRAT is continuing to evolve their malware in while targeting Azerbaijan public and private sector organizations. Cisco Talos reports on two campaigns and how they differ from previous PoetRAT activity.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

Cisco Talos has published a blog post analyzing two recent PoetRAT campaigns. Both campaigns, one occurring in September 2020 and the other in October, leverage a malicious Azerbaijan government-themed Word document. The researchers believe that victims receive a spear phishing email with a link to download the document. These documents contain malicious macros with embedded payloads that will be dropped on the system. In the first campaign, a Python interpreter and the PoetRAT payload are dropped. Unlike previous versions of PoetRAT, obfuscation is performed using pyminifier. Additionally, the malware is split into several different files. Finally, and most notably, PoetRAT now uses HTTP for C2 communication instead of FTP. The second campaign differs in its use of a Lua payload and interpreter as opposed to Python. The macro drops a ZIP archive containing these files. The Lua script attempts to download and execute a malicious payload from a remote server, but researchers were unable to obtain a sample at the time of research. Despite the changes to the payload itself, targeting is still focused on Azerbaijan and the same types of organizations. Cisco believes that these campaigns are performed for espionage purposes as the geopolitical tensions in the region grow. For more information, see the Cisco Talos blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: WordPress Plugin Vulnerabilities Disclosed
The Wordfence Threat Intelligence team issued information on three vulnerabilities affecting the WordPress plugin, Ultimate Member.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: WordPress Plugin Vulnerabilities Disclosed
The Wordfence Threat Intelligence team issued information on three vulnerabilities affecting the WordPress plugin, Ultimate Member.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Three vulnerabilities in the Ultimate Member plugin for WordPress have been identified by the Wordfence Threat Intelligence team. All three vulnerabilities can allow for, if successfully exploited, escalation of WordPress user privileges. The first is an Unauthenticated Privilege Escalation via User Meta and is rated as Critical with a CVSS score of 10. This plugin is used to enhance user registration and account control on WordPress sites. The vulnerability exists due to some missing checks on user submitted data. The second vulnerability is an Unauthenticated Privilege Escalation via User Roles. This is also rated as Critical with a CVSS score of 10 and is related to the previous vulnerability. A lack of filtering on the role parameter that could be exploited during registration. Should an attacker provide a role parameter, those privileges would be granted. The final vulnerability is an Authenticated Privilege Escalation via Profile Update. This vulnerability is rated as Critical with a CVSS score of 9.9. If exploited, an attacker could create new roles and grant secondary roles for all users. A lack of checks on profile update can allow an attacker access to these functions. An updated version of the plugin, Ultimate Member 2.1.12, has been issued by the vendor and should be applied immediately. Further information can be found in the link located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * None Available




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.wordfence.com/blog/2020/11/critical-privilege-escalation-vulnerabilities-affect-100k-sites-using-ultimate-member-plugin/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Backdoor Shell Dropper Deploys CMS-Specific Malware
Sucuri reports on a Turkish dropper that injects malware onto websites based on the CMS running on the system.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor, Web Shell




# Overview

Sucuri has published a blog post analyzing a dropper used to install additional payloads to various CMS platforms. A notable feature of the sample analyzed is the fact that it downloads additional payloads depending on the CMS in the environment. Regardless of which CMS is in use, the malware begins by changing permissions on certain system files and downloading additional code from Pastebin. It then checks for various system files that are specific to either WordPress, Joomla, Opencart, and Prestashop. After determining which platform is in use, it proceeds with its infection chain. Depending on the platform identified, even more code obtained from Pastebin is written to a text file on the system. Additional payloads are also downloaded from shellx[.]org. In the case of Joomla, the researchers observed two ZIP archives being downloaded, one containing a file uploader backdoor and the other the An0n_3xPloiTeR shell. Sucuri notes the present of Turkish language comments in the code. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/10/backdoor-shell-dropper-deploys-cms-specific-malware.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Purple Fox Using New Initial Access Methods
Trend Micro has been tracking Purple Fox since it first was seen in 2018. They have analyzed the newest version, which uses a new arrival vector and early access loaders. Details have been published in a report.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Purple Fox Using New Initial Access Methods
Trend Micro has been tracking Purple Fox since it first was seen in 2018. They have analyzed the newest version, which uses a new arrival vector and early access loaders. Details have been published in a report.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Rootkit
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown **  
**
  * **Associated Payloads:** Purple Fox
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Software Installers 



# Overview

Purple Fox malware has been active since 2018. Trend Micro has been keeping track of the changes of this malware as it improves its infrastructure and adds capabilities. Recently, the researchers observed the malware using a new initial access vector and early access loaders. The malware is distributed using disguised software packages that contain the first-stage loader. The installer name contains a character that indicates which payloads are to be downloaded and installed from the C2 server. The second stage payloads can be tracked using upload times on the server and show that these payloads are being continually updated by the attackers. The payloads showed a range of capabilities for evading security software, including disabling agents and using stolen certificates. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/c/purple-fox-uses-new-arrival-vector-and-improves-malware-arsenal.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: State-Sponsored Actors Using Ukraine Invasion For Espionage
Checkpoint researchers have collated a list of APT groups who are using the Russa-Ukraine war as an opportunity for cyber espionage. These groups include El Machete, Lyceum, and SideWinder.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Cyber-Espionage
  *  **Targets:** Latin America, Pakistan, Middle East
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Various, Loki RAT
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Espionage



# Overview

The war in Ukraine has given many actors increased opportunities for cyber attacks. Checkpoint researchers have detailed the activities of some actors using this opportunity for cyber-espionage. The first group is El Machete, a group that targets Latin America. They have been using spear-phishing emails to financial organizations with an attachment about the alleged Nazi regime in Ukraine. The article is a real article written by the Russian ambassador to Nicaragua, but the document is malicious and contains a macro to infect a machine with the Loki Backdoor. The second group is Lyceum, which is an Iranian group that is targeting energy companies with a similar tactic. The suspected Indian APT group SideWinder has also been using Ukrainian-themed phishing lures to target organizations in Pakistan. The researchers note that although they have only listed three examples, it is likely that more groups will be taking advantage of the current events in phishing lures. For more information, please view the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2022/state-sponsored-attack-groups-capitalise-on-russia-ukraine-war-for-cyber-espionage/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1059.006 - Python  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Google Chrome Browser Update Addresses Multiple Vulnerabilities
Google has released an update to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux, that provides fixes for ten security issues. One of the vulnerabilities addressed in the update that could allow for remote code execution, is being actively exploited in the wild.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Google Chrome Browser Update Addresses Multiple Vulnerabilities
Google has released an update to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux, that provides fixes for ten security issues. One of the vulnerabilities addressed in the update that could allow for remote code execution, is being actively exploited in the wild.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
Google has released an update, version 86.0.4240.183, to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux, that provides fixes for ten security issues. The most serious of the vulnerabilities addressed in the update is rated by Google as High. Successful exploitation of the vulnerabilities could potentially allow for the remote execution of arbitrary code. One vulnerability, CVE-2020-16009, which could allow for remote code execution, is being actively exploited in the wild. Further information is available from the links in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/32147283/Google%20Chrome%20Browser%20Update%20Addresses%20Multiple%20Vulnerabilities%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1604380263280&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://chromereleases.googleblog.com/2020/11/stable-channel-update-for-desktop.html>

  * <https://twitter.com/benhawkes/status/1323374326150701057>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: QBot and REvil Ransomware
A report from Advanced Intelligence links two recent ransomware attacks to cooperation between the QBot and REvil ransomware operators.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

QBot started life as a banking Trojan but has since been developed into a modular malware that can steal information and is frequently used to install ransomware. According to Advanced Intelligence, the QBot operators are known to have cooperated with the operators of the Egregor, LockerGoga, Mount Locker, and ProLock ransomware operations. instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Attacks Targeted Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs
A report from Lumen Technologies looks at a series of attacks that began in October 2021 and targeted Russia's Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type: Malware, Espionage**
  *  **Targets: Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs**
  *  **Malware Family/Families: Konni RAT**
  *  **Initial Infection Vector: Fake phishing portals, Phishing emails with malicious attachments and links.**
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions: Data collection and exfiltration.**
  *  **Additional TTPs: See the MITRE ATT &CK Framework below.**



# Overview

Lumen Technologies' Black Lotus Labs has published a report that provides an analysis of a series of attacks that began in October 2021 and targeted Russia's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MID). The attacks began with phishing emails that linked to a number of fake portals that were themed to appear as legitimate MID portals. In November, phishing emails that used COVID-related lures contained links that led to malicious files that purported to be from the Department of Health and Health Service. According to Lumen's report, one of the malicious files installed a fake version of the Russian COVID vaccination registration software which was in actuality a loader used to deploy other malicious files. In December, a MID email account that had been compromised by the attackers was used to send emails with an archive file attached. The archive contained a malicious screensaver that downloaded an agent which began the first stage of the infection chain. The objective of the attacks is believed to be espionage. The malware deployed by the attackers was the Konni RAT which has in the past been associated with the North Korean state-sponsored cyber espionage group APT37. IBM X-Force tracks APT37 as ITG10. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056677/Attacks%20Targeted%20Russian%20Ministry%20of%20Foreign%20Affairs%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641530730640&api=v2)

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Android Malware TeaBot Targets Banks in Europe
Cleafy provides a report on a new Android-based banking Trojan dubbed TeaBot. This Trojan does not appear to be related to any other banking Trojan families.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Android Malware TeaBot Targets Banks in Europe
Cleafy provides a report on a new Android-based banking Trojan dubbed TeaBot. This Trojan does not appear to be related to any other banking Trojan families.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan




# Overview

TeaBot (aka Anatsa) is a Trojan banking app in the Android landscape. Upon analysis by the researchers, this Trojan does not appear to be related to any other banking Trojan family. TeaBot is used to steal credentials and SMS messages for fraudulent actions against more than 60 banks. Interestingly, the trojan allows for a "livestream" view of the victim device as well as providing the ability for interacting through Accessibility Services. Injections were first observed in March 2021 against Italian banks. In May 2021, injections were seen against Belgium and Netherlands-based banks. At present, the trojan appears to be in early development. Other capabilities seen include key logging, stealing Google Authentication codes, and full remote control over an Android device. Anti-analysis techniques are implemented, such as junk code, a dynamic 2nd stage, and partially encrypted network communications using an XOR algorithm. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
  * Only install applications from trusted App Stores.



# Reference

  * <https://www.cleafy.com/documents/teabot>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: TA551 Campaign Switches from Valak to IcedID
TA551 campaigns have previously been observed distributing Ursnif and Valak. Recently, however, Palo Alto researchers have observed campaigns delivering IcedID instead.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Stealer 




# Overview

Palo Alto has published a blog post analyzing a change in the payload distributed by TA551 campaigns. TA551 is the designation given to a malspam distribution campaign aimed at delivering information stealing malware. The infection chain is similar regardless of the final payload. It begins with a password-protected ZIP archive attached to an email. Inside the ZIP archive is a Word document containing malicious macros designed to download an installer DLL. Finally, the main binary is downloaded by the installer DLL, persistence is established, and post-infection traffic begins. In 2019, the final payload was Ursnif. In early to mid-2020, ZLoader and Valak were both seen being distributed. Most recently, TA551 has been delivering IcedID. Even since the introduction of IcedID as the final payload, minor changes have been made to IcedID campaigns, such as the file names and paths and the run method for DLLs. For more information, see the Palo Alto blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/ta551-shathak-icedid/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Obfuscation Techniques in Ransomweb “Ransomware”
Investigation of a supposed ransomware attack against a client led Sucuri to discover a failed attempt at locking victims out of their files.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Sucuri published a blog post regarding a supposed ransomware payload that failed to successfully encrypt files. After being hacked, the victim website displays a message claiming the victim's files are locked, but, unlike most ransomware, no instructions for paying a ransom are given. All files are appended with the extension .xploiter and now contain unreadable binary data. The researchers were able to uncover an associated "unlocker" file, which is not uncommon with ransomware. This provides the victim the ability to decrypt their files after paying the ransom to retrieve the decryption key. Further analysis of this unlocker code, however, revealed that no encryption functionality was actually implemented. Rather, gzdeflate was used to obfuscate and compress each file. The use of gzdeflate means that the files can easily be restored using gzinflate. While some files also required a password to deobfuscate, the code was written in a way that the password could easily be bypassed or set to the victim's choice. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.




# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2021/01/obfuscation-techniques-in-ransomweb-ransomware.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Magniber Ransomware Exploiting PrintNightmare Vulnerability
The Magniber ransomware has been observed by CrowdStrike targeting users in South Korea and exploiting the PrintNightmare vulnerability.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Ransomware Family:** Magniber
  *  **Targets:** Users in South Korea
  *  **Ransom Demand:** Unspecified
  *  **Intrusion Vector:** Unspecified, possibly malvertising.
  *  **Data Exfiltrated:** Unspecified
  *  **Data Encrypted:** Yes
  *  **Data Published:** Unknown



# Overview

The Magniber ransomware originally targeted users in South Korea but later widened its scope to include other countries in the Asia Pacific region. In early 2021, CrowdStrike observed Magniber targeting South Korean users and exploiting an Internet Explorer vulnerability, CVE-2020-0968. CrowdStrike is reporting that Magniber is still targeting South Korean users but in July was observed exploiting the PrintNightmare vulnerability, CVE-2021-34527. While the delivery method is not specified in CrowdStrike's report, in the past Magniber is known to have been distributed through malvertising. Once the PrintNightmare vulnerability has been successfully exploited, a loader is used to inject the ransomware payload that handles file traversal and encryption into a process. The ransom note directs the victim to a .onion site for information on the ransom amount and obtaining a decryption key. Further information is available from the CrowdStrike report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/62357527/Magniber%20Ransomware%20Exploiting%20PrintNightmare%20Vulnerability%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1629340203603&api=v2)



# Mitre ATT&CK Framework

  * Impact (TA0040, T1486)
  * Execution (TA0002, T1203, T1204)
  * Defense Evasion (TA0005, T1027, T1055, T1055.001)
  * Discovery (TA0007, T1083)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/magniber-ransomware-caught-using-printnightmare-vulnerability/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Bitcoin Scam Leads To Millions For Threat Actors
ZDNet's investigation revealed a progressive Bitcoin campaign, leading to massive monetary gain for threat actors and a loss in money, data, and trust for its end-users.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing




# Overview

  
ZDNet reported on a resurgence of Bitcoin attacks, as threat actors capitalize on vulnerabilities within Electrum's application backend infrastructure, allowing threat actors to create false servers, using them as bait for users of the original application. This simple, yet well-orchestrated scheme, combines human error and phishing tactics, enticing users of the application to install a malicious version of the original app. Users are then duped into providing a requested one-time passcode after receiving notification for an update. If threat actors are successful up to that point, there is a high chance users of Electrum's wallet application have given approval for the malicious wallet to transfer all of their funds to an attacker's account. Electrum, understands the impact of malicious servers and have applied preventative measures to reduce the tempo of attacks such as: a server blacklisting system and updates preventing servers from showing HTML formatted popups to end users.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.




# References

  * [https://www.zdnet.com/article/bitcoin-wallet-trick-has-netted-criminals-more-than-22-million/](https://www.zdnet.com/article/bitcoin-wallet-trick-has-netted-criminals-more-than-22-million/)

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.

I have encountered the following information: Potential Russian Threats To US 2020 Election
Recorded Future has published a whitepaper on their predictions of Russian involvement in the US 2020 election based on past events.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * APT, Malware, Ransomware



# Overview

Recorded Future is predicting, based on Russian involvement in the US elections in 2016 and 2018, that we can expect similar involvement coming from Russian in the 2020 election. In 2016, three APT groups (APT28, APT29, and the Main Intelligence Directorate / Main Directorate Unit 74455, tracked as Sandworm) targeted the DNC, DCCC, and other election-related individuals and organizations. 2018 saw the DNC being targeted and mass dissemination of disinformation in order to destablize opinions on domestic social media being performed. The Senate, a political think tank, and a political non-profit organization were victims of spearphishing campaigns during this time. While Recorded Future has not discovered any direct intrusion activity by these state-sponsored APT groups, they have noted the groups developing malware that could potentially be used to target election-related targets. instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Spammers Get Better at Impersonating Banking Services to Con Victims
Threat actors continue to exploit and leverage the current COVID-19 pandemic, as analysts witnessed a surge of phishing and malspam campaigns posing as online banking services, according to the Bitdefender Antispam Lab.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing, Spam




# Overview

  
Threat actors took advantage of the current COVID-19 pandemic and online Black Friday sales to launch phishing and malspam campaigns, targeting prominent banks in the financial sector, according to the Bitdefender Antispam Lab. Researchers at the Bitdefender Antispam Lab noticed singular tactics integrating social engineering and phishing techniques. Furthermore, researchers uncovered several phishing attempts associated with the campaign from banks world-wide like Bank of America, Standard Bank, Wells Fargo, La Banque Postale, and HSBC Bank, as well as the money transaction services PayPal and Western Union. According to researchers, the most intriguing of all phishing attacks is the one involving the La Banque Postale, where 97.69% of incoming emails associated with the bank were marked as spam. Scammers attempted to dupe the end-user into accessing a malicious link, allowing them to listen in on communications received from the bank. In conclusion, the increase in digital transactions, online shopping, and the management of an individual’s finances online have created new avenues of approach for threat actors and cybercriminals alike. For more information, see the Hot For Security article in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://hotforsecurity.bitdefender.com/blog/spammers-get-better-at-impersonating-banking-services-use-lingo-and-legit-layouts-to-con-victims-24805.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Tax-Based Phishing Campaign(s)
Tax season is upon us and, with that, threat actors are ramping up their campaigns to gather information from unsuspecting victims regarding their "tax debts." Fortinet takes a look at some of the latest campaigns seen.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Using old techniques such as phishing emails, threat actors are targeting individuals with threats of bogus tax bills, changes in regulations due to COVID, and other schemes. In examples obtained by Fortinet, indicators of invalid emails are apparent such as misspellings, titles that do not exist, and, perhaps most importantly, emails from the IRS. The IRS does not send emails to citizens. The only IRS-initiated correspondence is in the form of mailed letters. The emails in question have attachments and/or links just as most other phishing emails. In using keywords such as taxes and COVID, the actors hope to entice victims into downloading a malicious Excel binary workbook which, in turn, attempts to download and execute a DLL. This method has been used by the Trickbot group. During the same week, a second email was analyzed. This email contains a link to download a "full text" document. This email contains both spelling and grammar mistakes as most do. The link redirects several times before using a script to download a zip file from a legitimate judicial domain of the U.S. government. The zip file contains a VBS file that is malicious in nature but attempts to appear as junk code. The file attempts to connect to a C2 that is no longer active which could indicate the campaign has ended. More information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/did-you-file-your-taxes-yet>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: PerSwaysion Campaign Uses Legitimate Services to Trick Users
Group-IB Threat Intelligence team has published a timeline of a phishing campaign using an up-trending technique whereby they use legitimate file-sharing sites to guide victims to the phishing site. After compromise, the attacker uses the email account to send out further phishing emails.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Targets:** Financial Services, Legal, Consulting
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Group-IB Threat Intelligence team has been tracking a new phishing campaign using a phishing technique that is becoming more common. The technique uses Microsoft file-sharing services, such as Sway, Sharepoint, and OneNote. This property is why the campaign is being called PerSwaysion. This campaign has been seen in multiple countries across North America, Europe, and Asia. Phishing emails in this campaign typically work in 3 phases. The first phase is an email with a PDF attachment claiming to be an Office 365 notification that a file has been shared with the victim. If the user clicks on the link in the PDF, they are then taken to a file hosted on a legitimate file-sharing site, such as Sway. The attacker abuses Sway's default borderless view and a specially crafted presentation page to make it seem as if the user has landed on a valid Office 365 login page. The link on this page directs the user to the final phase, which is a false login page on the attacker-controlled infrastructure. Once the user's details are entered, the attacker receives a notification email and the victim is served an 'access denied' page. After the credentials have been stolen, the attackers log into the compromised email account and dump all of the available emails. They then use the victim's details to generate new phishing PDFs that will seem legitimate, before sending them out to external targets on the victim's contact list. These targets are generally hand-picked to be high-profile members of businesses other than the victim's organization. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155151/PerSwaysion%20Campaign%20Uses%20Legitimate%20Services%20to%20Trick%20Users%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637762050748&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction (M1017).
  * Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc (M1021).
  * Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries (M1031).



# References

  * <https://blog.group-ib.com/perswaysion>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1591 - Gather Victim Org Information  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1586 - Compromise Accounts  
T1586.002 - Email Accounts  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment

Apple published a security advisory addressing eleven vulnerabilities affecting iOS and iPadOS.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 These include information disclosure, out-of-bounds write, out-of-bounds read, memory corruption, and use after free vulnerabilities. The worst of these, if successfully exploited, may allow an attacker to perform arbitrary code execution. Apple has patched these vulnerabilities in iOS 14.3 and iPadOS 14.3. We recommend reviewing the advisory in the Reference section for further details and applying any applicable updates as soon as possible.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Patchwork APT Infects Self With Own RAT
A report from Malwarebytes Labs looks at a recent campaign carried out by the Indian APT group known as Patchwork who also infected themselves with their own RAT.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Espionage.
  *  **Targets:** Researchers involved in molecular medicine and biological science.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Ragnatela RAT.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious documents attached to spear-phishing emails.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below for the TTPs typically used by Patchwork.



# Overview

The Indian APT group known as Patchwork has been active for many years, typically attacking Pakistani targets. According to Malwarebytes Labs, Patchwork typically uses spear-phishing as their infection vector, and their most recent campaign was carried out between late November and early December 2021 using malicious documents themed to appear to be from Pakistani authorities. The targets of the attack were researchers involved in molecular medicine and biological science, this campaign was the first time Patchwork has been observed targeting personnel in these fields. The document analyzed by Malwarebytes exploited a vulnerability in the Microsoft Equation Editor. The payload was the Ragnatela RAT which is a variant of the BadNews RAT. The objective of the campaign was cyberespionage. However, the actors also managed to infect themselves with their own RAT which allowed Malwarebytes to obtain screenshots and keystrokes from Patchwork's own systems. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056704/Patchwork%20APT%20Infects%20Self%20With%20Own%20RAT%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641787700177&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017)



# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2022/01/patchwork-apt-caught-in-its-own-web/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.002 - Code Signing Certificates  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.002 - Tool

T1189 - Drive-by Compromise

T1559.002 - Dynamic Data Exchange  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism  
T1548.002 - Bypass User Account Control  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.001 - Binary Padding  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1027.005 - Indicator Removal from Tools  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1036.005 - Match Legitimate Name or Location  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion

T1197 - BITS Jobs  
T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
T1553.002 - Code Signing  
T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1518.001 - Security Software Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.001 - Remote Desktop Protocol  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging

 **Command and Control - TA0011**

T1132 - Data Encoding  
T1132.001 - Standard Encoding

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Tax Rebate Smishing Campaign Targeting the UK
An smishing campaign is using tax rebate lures to target victims in the UK. The phishing sites the URLs in the SMS messages lead to have a rather interesting workflow, according to BleepingComputer.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing, Smishing




# Overview

BleepingComputer has published a report on a smishing and phishing campaign that is targeting victims in the UK. SMS messages sent to victims inform them that they are eligible for a tax refund, a link to claim the refund is included in the message. The link leads to a .com domain hosting phishing pages crafted to look like a UK government site. Multiple steps are involved in the phishing operation. The victim is first asked to enter their name and postcode and then click a button to sign which results in a page that tells them they are eligible for a refund. The amount of the refund is reported to be a random figure between £200 and £400. A button is provided to start the refund process. This time, the phishing site requests a significant amount of information from the victim including financial information, and most importantly in this operation, bank account number and the bank's sorting code. The next step leads the victim to a bank phishing page, crafted to appear to be the bank for which the victim entered the sorting code. The campaign has web pages for fifteen different banks. Certain fields within the various phishing pages even have validations checks carried out. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/hmrc-smishing-tax-scam-targets-uk-banking-customers/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: SeaFlower Activity Targets Mobile Devices To Steal Crypto Seed Phrases
Researchers from Confiant have identified a cluster of activity that is targeting mobile devices. The activity modifies web3 wallets with code that will steal the seed phrase, which will give the attacker access to the victim's crypto wallets.
output:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Infostealer
* **Associated Threat Actors:** SeaFlower
* **Associated Payloads:** Unnamed iOS and Android Trojans
* **Targets:** Cryptocurrency Wallets
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Search Engine Poisoning
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

Confiant Researchers have identified a new cluster of activity, which they have named SeaFlower. This Chinese-speaking group was detected in March 2022 and is targeting web3 users. The main objective of this group is to modify crypto-wallets with backdoor code, which will exfiltrate the seed phrase. Seed phrases are used to recover lost crypto wallets, so the attackers would be able to access victim funds. The backdoored wallets are spread using fake cloned websites of legitimate wallet software. To infect iOS devices, the attackers are provisioning profiles that sideload the backdoored apps onto the device. The researchers note that the attackers are using search engines to display the malicious sites to the victims, with the Baidu search engine being noted as a focus. The campaign appears to be focused on targeting Chinese speaking individuals, as the majority of search engines affected were for this demographic. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://blog.confiant.com/how-seaflower-%E8%97%8F%E6%B5%B7%E8%8A%B1-installs-backdoors-in-ios-android-web3-wallets-to-steal-your-seed-phrase-d25f0ccdffce>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

#### Tactics and Techniques:

**Initial Access - TA0027**  
 T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  

**Defense Evasion - TA0030**  
 T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
 T1478 - Install Insecure or Malicious Configuration  

**Discovery - TA0032**  
 T1426 - System Information Discovery  

**Collection - TA0035**  
 T1533 - Data from Local System  

**Command and Control - TA0037**  
 T1436 - Commonly Used Port  
 T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol  

**Exfiltration - TA0036**  
 T1436 - Commonly Used Port  
 T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol  

#### Mitigations:

**M1005:**  Application Vetting - Enterprises can vet applications for exploitable vulnerabilities or unwanted (privacy-invasive or malicious) behaviors. Enterprises can inspect applications themselves or use a third-party service. Enterprises may impose policies to only allow pre-approved applications to be installed on their devices or may impose policies to block use of specific applications known to have issues. In Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) environments, enterprises may only be able to impose these policies over an enterprise-managed portion of the device. Application Vetting is not a complete mitigation. Techniques such as Evade Analysis Environment exist that can enable adversaries to bypass vetting.  
**M1006:**  Use Recent OS Version - New mobile operating system versions bring not only patches against discovered vulnerabilities but also often bring security architecture improvements that provide resilience against potential vulnerabilities or weaknesses that have not yet been discovered. They may also bring improvements that block use of observed adversary techniques.  
**M1011:**  User Guidance - Describes any guidance or training given to users to set particular configuration settings or avoid specific potentially risky behaviors.  
**M1012:**  Enterprise Policy - An enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM), system can be used to provision policies to mobile devices to control aspects of their allowed behavior.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New Hive0097 Activity
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence uncovered malicious activity (tracked by X-Force as Hive0097) that is potentially being carried out by Cloud Atlas, a Russian state-sponsored APT.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Hive0097 Activity
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence uncovered malicious activity (tracked by X-Force as Hive0097) that is potentially being carried out by Cloud Atlas, a Russian state-sponsored APT.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

In mid-November 2020, IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence uncovered a malicious document mimicking a legitimate English-language article from the Russian-language Azeri newspaper, the Daily Sabah. This led to the further discovery of several malicious, military and policy-themed document files dating back to early-2019, as well as tactics, techniques, and procures (TTPs) that are consistent with the APT group Cloud Atlas. Cloud Atlas has been active since at least 2014, with the most recently available public reporting published in August 2019. Although firm attribution cannot be made, it is suspected that the activity X-Force tracks as Hive0097 is likely the APT group Cloud Atlas, suggesting the group has remained active throughout 2020. This is based on both X-Force analysis and alignment with established TTPs and uncovered documents files attributed to Cloud Atlas. The full story, including indicators of compromise, is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Indicators of compromise are available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more and see the indicators at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/4a3a685b-5070-484d-b012-7d47e9aaff7e>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Xenomorph - A New Android Banking Trojan
ThreatFabric researchers have released an article on a new Android banking trojan. This is being called Xenomorph due to its ties with another banking trojan, Alien. It is currently being distributed on the official Google Play store.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Banking Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Xenomorph, Alien, Gymdrop
  *  **Targets:** European Banks
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious App on Legitimate App Store
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Harvesting, Credential Theft



# Overview

ThreatFabric researchers have analyzed a new Android banking trojan. This was discovered in February 2022, and appears to be related to the trojan known as Alien. This malicious app is being distributed on the official Google Play store and is targeting users from 56 different European banks. The app poses as a cleaning tool to speed up a device and has over 50,000 downloads at the time of reporting. Xenomorph is part of the Gymdrop dropper family. The app harvests information from the victim's device including text messages. With this, it can steal potential 2FA passwords used in bank logins along with its ability to perform overlay attacks. The researchers speculate that this may be an early version of the malware and that it is under heavy development. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74059371/Xenomorph%20-%20A%20New%20Android%20Banking%20Trojan%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645722906211&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).

  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).



# References

  * <https://www.threatfabric.com/blogs/xenomorph-a-newly-hatched-banking-trojan.html>




# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1475 - Deliver Malicious App via Authorized App Store  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0029**  
T1401 - Device Administrator Permissions  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0031**  
T1409 - Access Stored Application Data  
T1411 - Input Prompt  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages  
  
 **Collection - TA0035**  
T1417 - Input Capture  
  
 **Impact - TA0034**  
T1448 - Carrier Billing Fraud  
T1582 - SMS Control

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Prison Phone Service Exposes Inmate and Contact Details
Breach/Leak Notification: An app designed for prison inmates to send messages and make calls had its database exposed. Comparitech details information exposed and actions prison officials and the app maker took in response.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Breach




# Overview

An application owned by a telephone company used by prison inmates to message and call family members suffered a breach due to an exposed database revealing private messages and personal information. The database was not password-protected. Among the data exposed was tens of millions of call logs, private messages, and personal information about the inmates and their contacts. The unsecured database was immediately reported to the parent telecommunications company. A spokesperson for the application company stated: "Telmate, a GTL subsidiary immediately locked down the server as a precaution upon being made aware of a vulnerability in the data system due to the actions of one of our vendors. This vulnerability was swiftly corrected, the data security team was immediately supplemented with the assistance of third-party consultants and we continue to work closely with law enforcement authorities as we conduct further inquiry into this incident. Based on the current facts of the investigation, no medical data, passwords, or consumer payment information were affected. We continue to speak with and notify necessary parties, including the affected Telmate customers – a small subset of all GTL customers – about the incident and the actions we have taken to safeguard data. The security of the data we keep is of the utmost importance to us, and we are committed to doing everything we can to keep it safe." Contained within the database were three indices with 228 million messages, 11 million inmate records, and 79 million admin records, including login details for the app's dashboard. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.comparitech.com/blog/information-security/prison-phone-service-exposes-millions-inmate-records/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Prynt Stealer Is New Malware Being Advertised On Cybercrime Forums
Cyble research labs have discovered a new infostealer named Prynt Stealer which is being sold on cybercrime forums. The stealer can steal credentials and financial information from several browsers and claims to be fully undetectable.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Stealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Prynt Stealer
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown **  
**
  * **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Cyble research labs have written an analysis on a new stealer malware called Prynt Stealer. The stealer is able to steal from many different browsers, as well as VPN, FTP, Messaging and Gaming apps. In addition to this, it can perform financial theft using keylogger functionality. The developer of the malware claims it is undetectable by security software. The malware is encoded using a rot13 cipher and executes in memory rather than dropping a payload. Upon execution, the malware first searches for files and steals them before stealing data from browsers. It can steal from almost all Chromium-based browsers, as well as MS Edge and Firefox-based browsers. It then moves onto other applications such as Telegram and Steam. All of this data is collated, along with system information and screenshots and is compressed into a folder. The stealer uses Telegram to retrieve the remote server IP and sends the compressed folder. The malware also contained unused functionality, such as a keylogger. This could be controlled using a builder which was provided by the TA, and allows customization of the malware. For more details, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2022/04/21/prynt-stealer-a-new-info-stealer-performing-clipper-and-keylogger-activities/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1497.001 - System Checks  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1528 - Steal Application Access Token  
T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1614 - System Location Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

Prynt Stealer Is New Malware Being Advertised On Cybercrime Forums
Cyble research labs have discovered a new infostealer named Prynt Stealer which is being sold on cybercrime forums. The stealer can steal credentials and financial information from several browsers and claims to be fully undetectable.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Stealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Prynt Stealer
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown **  
**
  * **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Cyble research labs have written an analysis on a new stealer malware called Prynt Stealer. The stealer is able to steal from many different browsers, as well as VPN, FTP, Messaging and Gaming apps. In addition to this, it can perform financial theft using keylogger functionality. The developer of the malware claims it is undetectable by security software. The malware is encoded using a rot13 cipher and executes in memory rather than dropping a payload. Upon execution, the malware first searches for files and steals them before stealing data from browsers. It can steal from almost all Chromium-based browsers, as well as MS Edge and Firefox-based browsers. It then moves onto other applications such as Telegram and Steam. All of this data is collated, along with system information and screenshots and is compressed into a folder. The stealer uses Telegram to retrieve the remote server IP and sends the compressed folder. The malware also contained unused functionality, such as a keylogger. This could be controlled using a builder which was provided by the TA, and allows customization of the malware. For more details, please see the link in the reference section.
