instruction:
I have encountered the following information: TeamTNT Chimaera Campaign
TeamTNT is a threat group that compromises systems for the purpose of credential stealing and cryptomining. AT&T has discovered a new campaign, dubbed "Chimaera," involving both new and previously-used tools to target multiple operating systems and applications.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Stealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** TeamTNT
  *  **Associated Payloads:** XMRig Cryptominer, IRC bot, AWS Stealer, Lazagne
  *  **Targets** : Non-specific
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Stolen credentials
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining, credential theft



# Overview

AT&T published a blog post analyzing a new TeamTNT campaign called "Chimaera." The group is implementing new tools alongside their existing toolset. Targeted platforms include Windows, Alpine Linux, AWS, Docker, Kubernetes, and more. The threat actors created a website that provides statistics tracking the number of machines infected as part of the campaign. After initial access, a series of bash or batch scripts is used for the infection process. The scripts are able to perform defense evasion and implement persistence. The researchers detail several tools used by the group as part of this campaign. One of the open-source tools used is Lazagne, a program capable of retrieve passwords stored on machines from various applications. Cryptomining is performed using an XMRig miner. TeamTNT also has their own IRC bot, which now include additional functionality. Finally, an AWS stealer is used to gather various sensitive information from AWS systems, such as access keys, session tokens, and credentials. All stolen data is uploaded to a C2 server using curl. For more information, see the AT&T blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127561/TeamTNT%20Chimaera%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1631540030936&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://cybersecurity.att.com/blogs/labs-research/teamtnt-with-new-campaign-aka-chimaera>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1212 - Exploitation for Credential Access  
T1528 - Steal Application Access Token  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts

 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1037 - Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job

 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
T1569 - System Services

 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services

 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1219 - Remote Access Software

 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Unexpected Sign-In Attempt Phishing
Several companies across the US, England, and Scotland are reporting a targeted phishing campaign attempting to obtain corporate email account credentials. Cofense reports on their analysis of this campaign.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Unexpected Sign-In Attempt Phishing
Several companies across the US, England, and Scotland are reporting a targeted phishing campaign attempting to obtain corporate email account credentials. Cofense reports on their analysis of this campaign.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense has published their analysis of a phishing campaign seen targeting organizations in English-speaking countries. The phishing emails are customized using the organization's name in various aspects to appear more legitimate. It is used in the "From" field as part of the sender address, the subject line and in various parts of the email body. The email claims that there was a sign in attempt from a suspicious location and points to an attached file that can be used to review that activity. Opening the attached HTML file leads to a fake sign in page for the company's mail portal, requesting their email address and password. Cofense notes that the images and CSS styles are pulled from a remote website. Entering the credentials results in a POST request to an attacker-controlled URL. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/101-credential-phishing-for-observant-employees/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Parker County Court System Impacted by Security Breach
Parker County officials are still unsure of the haphazard security incident involving the court system that resulted in a site and court shutdown.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Parker County Court System Impacted by Security Breach
Parker County officials are still unsure of the haphazard security incident involving the court system that resulted in a site and court shutdown.

# Threat Type

  * Malware 




# Overview

On October 16, Parker County Texas officials notified the public that the computer systems involving the county’s court system had been compromised by an indefinite security breach. According to the Parker County District Clerk Sharena Gilliland, there isn’t a definite answer on the duration of the outage and its effects  just yet.  However, the District Clerk’s Office remains agile, providing alternate solutions to their temporary issue for attorneys, such as access to the state’s E-File system, allowing them to keep date/time record as well as a contact number for any questions or concerns.  For more information, see the blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://blog.texasbar.com/2020/10/articles/courts/parker-county-court-system-impacted-by-computer-security-incident/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Operation Twisted Panda Targets Russian Defense Institutes
A report from Check Point provides information on an espionage operation they have named Twisted Panda. The operation has been targeting Russian defense institutes and is believed to be the work of a Chinese APT group.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, espionage.
  *  **Targets:** Russian defense institutes.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** An unnamed loader, and a new backdoor named SPINNER.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing emails with malicious documents.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Twisted Panda is the name given by Check Point to an espionage operation that has been targeting Russian defense institutes, and possibly another located in Belarus. Check Point attributes the operation to an unnamed Chinese APT group. The operation uses spearphishing emails that are sent to the defense institutes which have malicious documents attached and additionally, a link to a site that mimics the Russian Health Ministry. The lures used in the email subject line relate to sanctions imposed on Russia by other countries. If opened, the documents will download templates from a remote server which results in the deployment of an unnamed loader. The loader is used to deploy a new backdoor that Check Point has named SPINNER. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2022/twisted-panda-chinese-apt-espionage-operation-against-russians-state-owned-defense-institutes/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1589.002 - Email Addresses  
T1591 - Gather Victim Org Information  
T1591.001 - Determine Physical Locations  
T1591.004 - Identify Roles  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1106 - Native API  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1132 - Data Encoding  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Operation Twisted Panda Targets Russian Defense Institutes
A report from Check Point provides information on an espionage operation they have named Twisted Panda. The operation has been targeting Russian defense institutes and is believed to be the work of a Chinese APT group.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, espionage.
  *  **Targets:** Russian defense institutes.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** An unnamed loader, and a new backdoor named SPINNER.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing emails with malicious documents.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Twisted Panda is the name given by Check Point to an espionage operation that has been targeting Russian defense institutes, and possibly another located in Belarus. Check Point attributes the operation to an unnamed Chinese APT group. The operation uses spearphishing emails that are sent to the defense institutes which have malicious documents attached and additionally, a link to a site that mimics the Russian Health Ministry. The lures used in the email subject line relate to sanctions imposed on Russia by other countries. If opened, the documents will download templates from a remote server which results in the deployment of an unnamed loader. The loader is used to deploy a new backdoor that Check Point has named SPINNER. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2022/twisted-panda-chinese-apt-espionage-operation-against-russians-state-owned-defense-institutes/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1589.002 - Email Addresses  
T1591 - Gather Victim Org Information  
T1591.001 - Determine Physical Locations  
T1591.004 - Identify Roles  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1106 - Native API  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1132 - Data Encoding  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: ShellX Backdoor Highlights ITG01’s Renewed Activity
X-Force Threat Intelligence (XFTI) analysts have discovered new malware samples belonging to ITG01, also known as APT10, including a new backdoor we have dubbed ShellX.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor, APT




# Overview

 These new malware samples, discovered by X-Force in VirusTotal, share the same DLL hijacking technique and bear many coding similarities to the HelloEx backdoor, leading us to also attribute these new samples to ITG01 (aka APT10, Stone Panda, and MenuPass). The discovery of these new samples bolsters our assessment that ITG01 has reactivated operations with new malware after maintaining a low profile in 2019 and 2020 following public revelations of their “Cloud Hopper” campaign against Managed Service Providers (MSPs). The full story, including indicators of compromise, is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

Indicators of compromise are available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.   


# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more and see the indicators at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/8fdaea0d-68e6-43c3-9a91-eef6f2712725>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Russian GRU Conducting Global Brute Force Campaign
A joint advisory from CISA, the FBI, NCSC, and NSA, provides details of a global brute force campaign being conducted by the Russian General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU).

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Brute-force




# Overview

Beginning in mid-2019 and probably ongoing, the Russian General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU) has been conducting a brute force campaign. The private sector has typically attributed the GRU activity to the well-known names APT28 or Fancy Bear, though a number of other names including Group 74, Iron Twilight, Pawn Storm, Sednit, Snakemackerel, Sofacy, Strontium, Swallowtail, Tg-4127, Threat Group-4127, Tsar Team, are also associated. IBM X-Force tracks the activity under ITG05. While the campaign has principally targeted Europe and the U.S., it is global in nature. The targeted entities include defense contractors, energy companies, government and military organizations, higher education institutions, law firms, logistics companies, media companies, political consultants and party organizations, and think tanks. The attacks are carried out using a Kubernetes cluster. The primary service targeted in the attacks has been Microsoft Office 365 cloud services, though other service providers and on-premise email servers are also targeted. If credentials are obtained they are typically used to gain an initial foothold before attempts are made to escalate privileges and move laterally. The attackers are also known to exploit vulnerabilities such as CVE-2020-0688 and CVE-2020-17144 for remote code execution or to further lateral movement within an environment. To anonymize the attacks, they are usually routed through Tor or VPN services, including those provided by CactusVPN, IPVanish, NordVPN, ProtonVPN, Surfshark, and WorldVPN. In some cases, the attacks have come directly from the Kubernetes cluster. Once an organization has been compromised, the attackers will attempt to gain a persistent foothold and exfiltrate data. Further information is available from the advisory linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Detection

  * A Yara rule can be found here:



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://media.defense.gov/2021/Jul/01/2002753896/-1/-1/1/CSA_GRU_GLOBAL_BRUTE_FORCE_CAMPAIGN_UOO158036-21.PDF>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Expanded Targeting of the COVID-19 Cold Chain Supply Chain
In early December 2020, X-Force Threat Intelligence analysts published a blog detailing a global spear phishing campaign targeting individuals, organizations and supranational entities having potential involvement in the safe distribution and transportation of COVID-19 vaccines. Continued research led to additional evidence and insight, which has been provided in an updated threat activity report.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

In early December 2020, X-Force Threat Intelligence analysts published a blog detailing a global spear phishing campaign targeting individuals, organizations and supranational entities having potential involvement in the safe distribution and transportation of COVID-19 vaccines. Continued research led to additional evidence and insight. Specifically, analysts uncovered evidence revealing an expanded targeting scope associated with the phishing campaign aimed at organizations likely associated with Gavi Alliance’s Cold Chain Equipment Optimization Platform (CEEOP) program. Based on command and control (C2) infrastructure, file attributes, and additional emails, analysts discovered several related HTML files with a pre-populated login box for harvesting credentials. While direct association between the additional artifacts and the original campaign cannot be conclusively determined, the overlap of multiple artifacts indicates that the activity is highly likely associated with the previously reported phishing campaign. The full story, analysis, and indicators of compromise are available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.c
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/79103732-d7ef-4799-82be-849ad5e3d51b>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: XAMPP Servers Hosting Agent Tesla and Formbook
A report from RiskIQ provides information on the use of Internet-facing XAMPP servers to host malware such as Agent Tesla and Formbook.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Malware Family/Families:**[Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331/), Formbook
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Servers running XAMPP are being used to host malware.



# Overview

XAMPP is an Apache distribution containing MariaDB, PHP, and Perl that is intended to make installation simple but is not intended to be used for production deployments. A report from RiskIQ provides information on the use of Internet-facing XAMPP servers that are being used to host malware such as Agent Tesla and Formbook. It is not clear from the report if the XAMPP servers have been set up by the actors behind the malware, or whether the servers have been compromised by the actors. A number of the hosts observed distributing the malware used dynamic DNS names. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/59539651/XAMPP%20Servers%20Hosting%20Agent%20Tesla%20and%20Formbook%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1628643059745&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date ([M1049](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1049/)).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs ([M1031](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1031/), [M1035](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1035/), [M1037](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1037/)).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level ([M1051](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1051/)).



# References

  * <https://community.riskiq.com/article/40000d46/description>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: IBM QRadar Network Security Affected by NTP Vulnerabilities
A Security Bulletin for IBM QRadar Network Security has been published to address vulnerabilities in NTP which could allow for denial of service conditions.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability 




# Overview

A Security Bulletin for IBM QRadar Network Security has been published to address vulnerabilities in NTP which could allow for a denial of service condition. The vulnerabilities (CVE-2020-11868 and CVE-2020-13817) could allow a remote attacker to send spoofed packets to an affected device and potentially prevent synchronization, change a device's time, or cause the NTP daemon to crash. QRadar Network Security 5.4.0 and 5.5.0 are affected. Updated versions of firmware, 5.4.0.12 and 5.5.0.7, are available to mitigate the vulnerabilities.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35717289/IBM%20QRadar%20Network%20Security%20Affected%20by%20NTP%20Vulnerabilities%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606795274234&api=v2)  




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.




# Reference

  * <https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/6373164>

I have encountered the following information: ICS-CERT Advisories February 23 2021
The ICS-CERT has published 3 advisories that affect Rockwell Automation FactoryTalk Services Platform, Advantech BB-ESWGP506-2SFP-T, and Advantech Spectre RT Industrial Routers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarised below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-054-01 - Rockwell Automation FactoryTalk Services Platform**  
CVE-2020-14516 - There is an issue with the implementation of the SHA-256 hashing algorithm with FactoryTalk Services Platform that prevents the user password from being hashed properly.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-054-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-054-02 - Advantech BB-ESWGP506-2SFP-T**  
CVE-2021-22667 - The affected product is vulnerable due to the use of hard-coded credentials, which may allow an attacker to gain unauthorized access and permit the execution of arbitrary code.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Kimsuky APT Continues Targeting South Korean Government with AppleSeed Backdoor
While monitoring Kimsuky APT activity, Malwarebytes observed the group targeting South Korean government entities with the AppleSeed backdoor.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Kimsuky APT Continues Targeting South Korean Government with AppleSeed Backdoor
While monitoring Kimsuky APT activity, Malwarebytes observed the group targeting South Korean government entities with the AppleSeed backdoor.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT, Backdoor




# Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post analyzing recent Kimsuky APT activity. Specifically, the group has continued its targeting of South Korean government agencies, along with universities and companies in the region. An extensive phishing infrastructure exists to harvest email credentials and includes scripts to block certain IPs and detect the language and device type in order to customize the displayed page. Any credentials obtained are then used for the more targeted spear phishing attempts. In one case observed by the researchers, the victim received a ZIP file containing a JavaScript file masquerading as a PDF. This JavaScript file drops a decoy PDF file on the system while subsequently dropping the AppleSeed DLL. Encoding, encryption, and packing are used across the various payloads to reduce the risk of detection. Once executed, the payload establishes persistence via a Registry Run key. Privilege escalation is also attempted. Multiple threads are created to perform each key functionality of the backdoor. These threads include keylogging, screen capture, USB monitoring, and file stealing modules. Gathered data is exfiltrated in an encrypted ZIP archive via an HTTP POST request. Additionally, instructions can be issued by the C2 server for executing commands, gathering system information, and deleting files. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-analysis/2021/06/kimsuky-apt-continues-to-target-south-korean-government-using-appleseed-backdoor/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ICS-CERT Security Advisories - November 17th, 2020
ICS-CERT has released four security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in various ICS-related devices and software.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview



ICSA-20-324-01 addresses an improper authorization vulnerability in Johnson Controls Sensormatic Electronics American Dynamics victor Web Client and Software House C•CURE Web Client. If successfully exploited, an unauthenticated attacker on the network could execute an HTTP API method bypassing authentication. This could be used to cause a denial-of-service condition in some cases.

ICSA-20-324-02 addresses two buffer overflow vulnerabilities in Paradox IP150 devices. The first, a stack-based buffer overflow vulnerability, if successfully exploited, could allow an unauthenticated attacker to perform remote code execution. The second is a classic buffer overflow vulnerability that could allow an authenticated attacker to remotely execute code.

ICSA-20-324-03 addresses a stack-based buffer overflow vulnerability in Real Time Automation EtherNet/IP source code. Potential impacts, if successfully exploited, include denial-of-service and remote code execution.

ICSA-20-324-04 addresses nine vulnerabilities in Schneider Electric Interactive Graphical SCADA System (IGSS). Types of vulnerabilities included are improper restriction of operations within the bounds of a memory buffer and out-of-bounds read and write vulnerabilities. All addressed vulnerabilities, if successfully exploited, could allow for remote code execution.

We recommend reviewing the advisories in the Reference section for patches and mitigation advice.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33982775/ICS-CERT%20Security%20Advisories%20-%20November%2017th%2C%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1605640520732&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-324-01>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Exploit Kits Targeting of Chrome
The developers of the Magnitude and Underminer exploit kits created exploit chains targeting Google Chrome, according to a report from Avast.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Exploit Kits Targeting of Chrome
The developers of the Magnitude and Underminer exploit kits created exploit chains targeting Google Chrome, according to a report from Avast.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Exploit Kits.
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Magnitude, and Underminer.
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Various.
  *  **Targets:** Users of Google Chrome.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Various vulnerabilities in Google Chrome.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unspecified.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Exploit kits, in terms of web browsers they exploit, have typically focused on Internet Explorer. Avast discovered that the developers of the Magnitude kit were testing exploits targeting Google Chrome. A month later, Avast observed the Underminer kit developers following suit. Both sets of developers were targeting the vulnerabilities CVE-2021-21224 and CVE-2021-31956 while the Underminer developers also targeted CVE-2019-0808, CVE-2020-1020, CVE-2020-1054, and CVE-2021-21224. The Magnitude developers appear to have discontinued the use of Chrome exploits while Underminer has continued though Avast notes that only around twenty percent of Underminer exploit attempts target Chrome. Considering Chrome appears to have sixty percent or more of the browser market share, this is a relatively low number. Avast notes that while both sets of developers were able to successfully create Chrome exploits, they were not very successful in the number of victims exploited. Perhaps one reason for this is the frequent and automatic updating of Chrome. Avast also notes that other Chromium-based browsers may be more at risk due to less frequent updating or the use of aged Chromium forks or vulnerabilities in their own codebases. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057027/Exploit%20Kits%20Targeting%20of%20Chrome%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642474148075&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/janvojtesek/exploit-kits-vs-google-chrome/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.004 - Drive-by Target  
T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Lil' Skim Malware
With the recent discovery of the Lil' Skim malware, Malwarebytes published a blog post identifying infrastructure related to the skimmer.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post analyzing the Lil' Skim malware, with a focus on its infrastructure. While only recently discovered by researchers, evidence indicates that it has been active for over a year. Much like the Magecart malware, this skimming code attempts to mimic well-known companies with the domains its registers. Lil' Skim was spotted using domain names that attempt to mimic Google, jQuery, Facebook, Cloudflare, and even the Tidio chat application. Interestingly, the attackers also registered domains related to those of sites they compromised in order to host the skimming code. The researchers discovered two IP addresses in particular hosting these domains. Furthermore, the ASN associated with the IP addresses contains numerous malicious hosts tied to Windows payloads, Android malware, and phishing kits. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/cybercrime/2021/06/lil-skimmer-the-magecart-impersonator/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Black Kingdom Ransomware
The Black Kingdom ransomware first surfaced in 2019. According to Kaspersky, it was more recently observed being installed onto systems after exploitation of the Exchange ProxyLogon vulnerabilities.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

While the Black Kingdom ransomware functions similar to other ransomware, it is described by Kaspersky as being amateurishly written. It is written in Python and compiled into an executable file using PyInstaller. It has been observed being installed into systems compromised by exploiting vulnerabilities in Pulse Secure and Microsoft Exchange. In the case of compromised Exchange servers, a webshell was installed, which was in turn used to install Black Kingdom. Before encrypting files, PowerShell is used to terminate processes that have "sql" in their name. During the encryption process, Black Kingdom disables the system's mouse and keyboard. Due to amateurish mistakes, in cases where a hard-coded encryption key is used, the files may be recoverable. As Black Kingdom does not check if files are encrypted prior to running its encryption process, it is possible that files may be encrypted multiple times, potentially making them unrecoverable. The same Bitcoin address is used in all Black Kingdom ransom notes. Kaspersky notes that at the time of writing its report, only two transactions were showing on the account. Further details are available from Kaspersky's report which is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/black-kingdom-ransomware/102873/>

  *  **Ransomware Family:** BlackByte
  *  **RaaS Operation:** N/A
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** ProxyShell Vulnerabilities
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Lateral movement, Credential dumping, Data collection, and exfiltration, Deployment of Cobalt Strike, **** Encryption of files.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.
  *  **Leak Site:** N/A



# Overview

Exploits and malware for the ProxyShell vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-34473, CVE-2021-34523, and CVE-2021-31207) keep coming. The latest includes BlackByte ransomware exploiting the vulnerabilities. According to Red Canary's analysis, the initial infection vector follows previous ProxyShell exploitation techniques. Once on the victim's system, web shells are deployed and used to drop Cobalt Strike beacons for added functionality. Wuauclt.exe being executed with no command-line parameters allow a detection opportunity as the process is typically executed with parameters. The attackers then use Cobalt Strike to dump credentials from the compromised system. AnyDesk is installed on the compromised systems and, in turn, Cobalt Strike beacons are installed within the Admin$ folders on compromised domain controllers. BlackByte is executed with a command-line argument of "-single" followed by an SHA-256 hash. The Task Manager and Resource Monitor are deleted and an obfuscated PowerShell command is used to disable Windows Defender. BlackByte is injected into regedit.exe and is thought to communicate back to its C2 server though this cannot be confirmed. Privilege escalation and lateral movement are accomplished with BlackByte as opposed to the more common usage of Cobalt Strike. Data from the compromised servers that is of interest to the attackers is compressed using WinRAR and exfiltrated to anonymous file-sharing sites. The ransomware encryption begins by first deleting shadow copies, deleting the scheduled task "Raccine Rules Updater" which is associated with the Raccine ransomware protection binary, and the actual encryption process. A ransom note in the form of an .hta file is left on the encrypted systems, the ransom note is also sent to a compromised device's connected printers and is executed by a scheduled task, and then executed at the top of every hour. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74055833/BlackByte%20Ransomware%20Leveraging%20ProxyShell%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638887894304&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts. (M1018)
  * Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc. (M1021)
  * Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts. M1022)
  * Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry. M1024)
  * Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques. (M1028)
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking. (M1038)
  * Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise. (M1053)



# References

  * <https://redcanary.com/blog/blackbyte-ransomware/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1112 - Modify Registry  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
T1562.004 - Disable or Modify System Firewall  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Online Contact Forms Used to Distribute BazarLoader
The online contact forms of some companies were observed by Abnormal Security being used in attempts to distribute BazarLoader between December 2021 and January 2022.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Unspecified
  *  **Lure:** Contact through a company's online contact form.
  *  **Payload:** BazarLoader
  *  **Compromised Data:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-compromise Actions:** C&C communications.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Beginning in December 2021 and continuing through to January 2022, Abnormal Security observed a threat actor using a company's online contact forms as a phishing lure. The actor posed as an employee of another company and was seeking a quote. Such a method makes the initial contact appear less suspicious than an unsolicited email. When contacted by a representative of the target company, the actor replied and said they would send details of their requirements in a separate email. That email would contain a link to a file on a public file sharing service which the actor would attempt to have the representative download. The file was an ISO file that contained two files that appear to the victim as a shortcut to a folder and a Windows log file. If the victim clicks on the shortcut, it opens a terminal window and uses regsvr32.exe to run the log file which is actually a DLL. The DLL is actually BazarLoader and using process injection, svchost.exe is used to begin communicating with its C&C servers. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://abnormalsecurity.com/blog/bazarloader-contact-form>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**

T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.001 - Dynamic-link Library Injection

T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: MontysThree - An Espionage Toolset
Kaspersky reports on an unknown toolset they called "MontysThree" that has been used in espionage attacks since 2018.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Espionage, Stenography



# Overview

In a report on a previously unknown malware toolset, Kaspersky describes their latest find. Called "MT3" by the malware authors, Kaspersky has dubbed the malware as "MontysThree". This is an espionage toolset believed to have been in operation since 2018. A series of C++ modules comprise the toolset that provide the attacker with persistence, pulling data from images using steganography, and decryption of configuration tasks. Sent via spear-phishing emails, the loader for this malware is attached as a self-extracting RAR file. The archive name gives an indication that the attachment is related to an employees' phone list, a technical document, or possibly medical test results to trick the user into opening the attachment. The attachment appears to the user to be a PDF or DOC file, based on the extension the user sees, but it is actually an executable. The toolset includes the Loader (in charge of stenography), Kernel (decrypts the configuration file and executes contents), HTTPTransport (command and control communication module that utilizes public cloud services), and LinkUpdates (provides persistence by modifying existing LNK files to invoke the loader). For full technical details, please see the Kaspersky link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/32145762/MontysThree%20-%20An%20Espionage%20Toolset%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1602530496809&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/montysthree-industrial-espionage/98972/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Pharma Spam Using Hexadecimal IP Addresses
A spam campaign using Hexadecimal IP addresses to evade spam detection systems has been analyzed by researchers from Trustwave. The campaign is distributing emails containing information on medications, typically referred to as pharma spam.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Spam




# Overview

Researchers from Trustwave recently identified a pharma spam campaign that is using links containing Hexadecimal IP addresses in an effort to avoid detection by spam detection systems. Aside from the familiar dotted-decimal format of IP addresses, many browsers will also accept IP addresses in DWORD (Integer), Hexadecimal, and Octal formats. How the addresses in the links appear to the victim varies depending on the email client being used. Clicking on one of the links leads, via 301 and 302 redirections, and proxying through a legitimate online retail and affiliate service, to the final landing pages. The use of the Hexadecimal IP addresses began in July and has increased since then, domains used in the campaign have been recently purchased. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trustwave.com/en-us/resources/blogs/spiderlabs-blog/evasive-urls-in-spam/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Skimmers Being Spread By Cloud Video Platform
Palo Alto has published a report analyzing a skimmer that is being hosted by a cloud video platform. When the video is used by a site, it becomes infected with the skimmer. The skimmer is currently affecting over 100 real estate websites.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Skimmers Being Spread By Cloud Video Platform
Palo Alto has published a report analyzing a skimmer that is being hosted by a cloud video platform. When the video is used by a site, it becomes infected with the skimmer. The skimmer is currently affecting over 100 real estate websites.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Skimmer
  *  **Targets:** Real Estate Sites
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown **  
**
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Supply Chain Attack
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Personal Information Theft
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Palo Alto researchers have discovered a skimmer attack that is affecting over 100 real estate sites. They have determined that the source of this attack was a supply chain attack, where the attackers have leveraged a cloud video platform to allow them to reach a greater number of victims. The attackers injected malicious JavaScript into a specific video hosted on the cloud platform. Any site importing this video will also be infected, without the attackers having to perform any further attacks. The researchers also observed the attackers modify the script and re-upload it, which was then propagated to all previously infected sites. This is far more efficient than manually updating the skimmer on each site. The researchers retrieved the code from a compromised site and found that it was highly obfuscated to deter manual code analysis. Furthermore, the script includes code to detect if the code is being debugged and stops if the browser console is open. The end goal of this script is to steal any entered personal details such as names, emails, phone numbers, and credit card details and send them to a collection server. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056799/Skimmers%20Being%20Spread%20By%20Cloud%20Video%20Platform%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641899384488&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021)
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 



# References

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/web-skimmer-video-distribution/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1584.006 - Web Services  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1195 - Supply Chain Compromise  
T1195.002 - Compromise Software Supply Chain  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.003 - Web Portal Capture

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Satori Botnet Targeting Vantage Velocity Field Unit RCE Vulnerability
Palo Alto discovered a Mirai botnet variant, Satori, exploiting a Vantage Velocity field unit RCE vulnerability in order to spread itself.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet




# Overview

Palo Alto published a blog post analyzing Satori, a Mirai botnet variant, and its exploitation of a Vantage Velocity field unit RCE vulnerability. This vulnerability, CVE-2020-9020, was discovered in 2020 and is rated as critical due to a low attack complexity resulting in remote code execution. The exploit attempt observed by Palo Alto researchers tries to call wget on the target host in order to download a file from a remote server and subsequently executes it. The same server hosting this malware is believed to be the C2 server for the Satori botnet. Once on the system, the malware spawns and detaches multiple child processes. A brute force attack is performed against port 23 on random hosts, and multiple hardcoded commands are executed to spread the botnet infection to new victim devices. A patch for this vulnerability has been released by Vantage Velocity and should be applied as soon as possible. For more information, see the Palo Alto blog post in the Reference section.  


# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/satori-mirai-botnet-variant-targeting-vantage-velocity-field-unit-rce-vulnerability/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: TA505 and CL0P
A posting on the Deutsche Telekom blog looks at the relationships between TA505 and the operators of the CL0P ransomware, along with some of their activities throughout the past year.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, APT




# Overview

A posting on the Deutsche Telekom blog looks at some of the activities of TA505 and the operators of the CL0P ransomware throughout the past year. TA505 is also known as CHIMBORAZO, Evil Corp, GOLD TAHOE, Graceful Spider, Sector J04, and Temp.Warlock. The group known as FIN11 may also be TA505 or a subgroup of TA505. IBM X-Force tracks TA505 as ITG19. According to Deutsche Telekom, the operators of the CL0P ransomware may also be a subgroup of, or managed by, TA505. Another group known as Silence appears to have some form on relationship with TA505. These subgroups may also be simple clients of TA505 as TA505 tends to focus on gaining access to targets. They may then sell access to the victim's network or hand off to a subgroup or client who conducts further operations, such as the deployment of the CL0P ransomware. Deutsche Telekom noted three waves of spam from TA505 in 2020. The first wave ran January through February, the second June until September, and the last run in early December. TA505 spam is typically sent during weekdays, whereas the CL0P deployments more often occurred on a Friday or Saturday. The emails may contain a link or an HTML attachment, which lead the victim to a malicious document. If the document is opened and macros are enabled, the infection chain begins. CL0P ransoms tend to be based on the revenue of the victim company and a victim's sensitive data will have been exfiltrated prior to the ransomware being executed. The ransom notes are customized to the victim and the CL0P operators maintain a portal where victims can negotiate or pay ransoms. If a victim does not pay the ransom, their sensitive data will be made public on the portal. Further details are available from the Deutsche Telekom blog posting linked to in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.telekom.com/en/blog/group/article/inside-of-cl0p-s-ransomware-operation-615824>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New AsyncRAT Delivery Technique
A new delivery technique identified by Morphisec researchers is being used to install AsyncRAT on victim hosts.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** RAT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** AsyncRAT
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing email with HTML attachment
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Remote command execution



# Overview

Morphisec published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign using a novel technique to deliver AsyncRAT to victims. The initial phishing email is simplistic and claims the attachment is a receipt for a recent order. Opening the attached HTML file leads to the download of an ISO file that is generated based on a file blob object embedded in the HTML code. When the ISO is mounted, it contains either a .bat or .vbs file responsible for downloading and executing the next stage payload from a remote server. The downloaded PowerShell code establishes persistence via a scheduled task, drops and executes a VBS file, and injects an embedded .NET module into memory. The scripts also detect AV software, perform a UAC bypass, and disable Windows Defender notifications to evade detection. Eventually, the final payload, AsyncRAT, is installed on the system to provide attackers with remote access to the host. For more information, see the Morphisec blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057997/New%20AsyncRAT%20Delivery%20Technique%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1643733380565&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://blog.morphisec.com/asyncrat-new-delivery-technique-new-threat-campaign>

 **Initial Access - TA0001**

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Hiding Web Skimmers in CSS Files
Web skimmers are being used in a wide variety of ways, mainly through JavaScript libraries. ZDNet has reported on a new variation of hiding a web skimmer, CSS files.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Hiding Web Skimmers in CSS Files
Web skimmers are being used in a wide variety of ways, mainly through JavaScript libraries. ZDNet has reported on a new variation of hiding a web skimmer, CSS files.

# Threat Type

  * Web Skimmers




# Overview

Credit card theft through web skimming is one of the largest operations in the hacking world. Threat actors have employed JavaScript libraries, live chat windows, icons, logos, and other means to hide web skimming code. A new method of hiding the skimming code is through the use of cascading style sheets (CSS). Typically, CSS is used to format elements of a web page such as colors, font settings, and other items. CSS has evolved to include more functionality in its usage and that evolution has led to the inclusion of allowing JavaScript code within CSS. Threat actors are now able to hide web skimming code directly in CSS in order to avoid detection. This method is previously unseen and represents a new threat against online retailers, adding one more facet of code retailers must examine in order to keep customers' data safe from prying eyes. For more information, please see the link located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.zdnet.com/article/hackers-hide-web-skimmer-inside-a-websites-css-files/>
