instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Golang RAT
Bitdefender researchers identified a new Golang RAT being delivered via exploitation of CVE-2019-2725, an Oracle WebLogic RCE vulnerability.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT, Exploit




# Overview

Bitdefender has published a blog post analyzing a new Golang RAT. This malware uses CVE-2019-2725, an Oracle WebLogic RCE vulnerability, as an initial infection vector. Although WebLogic servers typically should not be public facing, when the vulnerability was identified so were tens of thousands of exposed servers, many of which remain unpatched. Using this CVE, a Golang payload is downloaded to the system. This payload is responsible for downloading, executing, and updating the RAT. For updating, it monitors a remote URL to identify when changes have been made and the new version should be downloaded. Persistence is established using a startup script created by this initial payload. Additionally, it regularly checks that the RAT is still running and restarts it if not. The RAT payload sends a check-in message to its C2 that contains system information, such as the OS, hardware details, and IP address. It supports two commands, one to execute shell commands and the other to download and run a binary. Although there are only a couple available commands, they allow for extensive capabilities, and the malware still appears to be in early development stages. Based on infrastructure and code overlap, Bitdefender believes this campaign is related to the previously reported PowerGhost campaign. For more information, see the Bitdefender blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.bitdefender.com/2020/10/theres-a-new-a-golang-written-rat-in-town/>

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
New Golang RAT
Bitdefender researchers identified a new Golang RAT being delivered via exploitation of CVE-2019-2725, an Oracle WebLogic RCE vulnerability.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT, Exploit




# Overview

Bitdefender has published a blog post analyzing a new Golang RAT. This malware uses CVE-2019-2725, an Oracle WebLogic RCE vulnerability, as an initial infection vector. Although WebLogic servers typically should not be public facing, when the vulnerability was identified so were tens of thousands of exposed servers, many of which remain unpatched. Using this CVE, a Golang payload is downloaded to the system. This payload is responsible for downloading, executing, and updating the RAT. For updating, it monitors a remote URL to identify when changes have been made and the new version should be downloaded. Persistence is established using a startup script created by this initial payload. Additionally, it regularly checks that the RAT is still running and restarts it if not. The RAT payload sends a check-in message to its C2 that contains system information, such as the OS, hardware details, and IP address. It supports two commands, one to execute shell commands and the other to download and run a binary. Although there are only a couple available commands, they allow for extensive capabilities, and the malware still appears to be in early development stages. Based on infrastructure and code overlap, Bitdefender believes this campaign is related to the previously reported PowerGhost campaign. For more information, see the Bitdefender blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.bitdefender.com/2020/10/theres-a-new-a-golang-written-rat-in-town/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: An Analysis of FIN12 and its Activity
Mandiant has published a report on the activities and TTPs associated with the financially motivated threat group Mandiant refers to as FIN12.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: An Analysis of FIN12 and its Activity
Mandiant has published a report on the activities and TTPs associated with the financially motivated threat group Mandiant refers to as FIN12.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Organizations with revenue of at least $300 million USD.
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Ryuk (S0446), Conti (S0575)
  *  **RaaS Operation:** N/A
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Typically through initial access providers.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, Privilege escalation, Lateral movement, Data exfiltration (in some cases), Data encryption.
  *  **Additional Malware:** Anchor, Beacon, Bloodhound, Daveshell, Empire, Grimagent, Grunt, Icecandle, Maltshake, SystemBC, Weirdloop, Whitedagger. **  
**
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

According to a report from Mandiant, FIN12 is a financially motivated threat actor. FIN12 victims exist in many sectors, however, close to 20% of FIN12's victims are in the healthcare industry. Other industry sectors targeted by FIN12 includes business services, education, finance, government, manufacturing, retail, and technology. Historically, the vast majority of FIN12’s victims have been located in the United States but in the first half of 2021, a significant increase in the number of victims in other countries was noted. The countries include Australia, Colombia, France, Indonesia, Ireland, the Philippines, South Korea, Spain, the United Arab Emirates, and the United Kingdom. This may be due to a shift in FIN12’s regional targeting, working with additional initial access providers, or avoiding the attention of the United States government. Mandiant notes that FIN12 relies heavily on initial access providers, rather than directly compromising systems, and has close relationships with the actors associated with Anchor, BazarBackdoor, BazarLoader, and Trickbot. Unusually, FIN12 does not typically use the double extortion technique to extort their ransomware victims though this has occurred in some cases. It is thought that FIN12’s target selection may be based on the revenue of a potential victim as the typical FIN12 victim has revenue of at least $300 million USD. Further information is available from Mandiant's report which is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129955/An%20Analysis%20of%20FIN12%20and%20its%20Activity%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633934443318&api=v2)



# Detection

  * A list of Yara rules can be found here: [ Yara Rules.txt](/download/attachments/64129955/An%20Analysis%20of%20FIN12%20and%20its%20Activity%20Yara%20Rules.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633934456132&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.mandiant.com/resources/fin12-ransomware-intrusion-actor-pursuing-healthcare-targets>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: The BackdoorDiplomacy APT Group
ESET has published a report on an APT group they have named BackdoorDiplomacy. The group has been active since at least 2017 and primarily targets diplomatic organizations located in Africa and the Middle East.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

According to a report published by ESET, BackdoorDiplomacy is an APT group that primarily targets diplomatic organizations located in Africa and the Middle East. The group is also known, to a lesser degree, to have targeted telecommunication companies in the aforementioned geographies. BackdoorDiplomacy typically exploits vulnerabilities in Internet-accessible web-based applications and the management interfaces of network equipment to gain initial access to an environment and install a webshell. Examples of the vulnerabilities exploited by the group include an F5 BIP-IP vulnerability (CVE-2020-5902), unspecified Microsoft Exchange server vulnerabilities, and a misconfigured Plesk server. The webshell is used to install the group's principle backdoor which ESET refers to as Turian. The group's preferred method for installing Turian is to hijack DLL search orders. There are Windows and Linux versions of Turian and ESET notes that Turian is likely to be an evolution of the Quarian backdoor which has been previously used in attacks against diplomatic entities. Another binary installed by the group is used to detect removable media and copy their contents to the recycle bin on the system's main drive. Once a foothold has been established, a number of well-known tools are used to facilitate reconnaissance and lateral movement. The toolset is known to include EarthWorm, Mimikatz, SafetyKatz, Nbtscan, NetCat, PortQry, SMBTouch, EternalBlue, DoublePulsar, EternalRocks, and EternalSynergy. There are noted similarities between the TTPs used by BackdoorDiplomacy and a number of other Asian groups. The technical details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/06/10/backdoordiplomacy-upgrading-quarian-turian/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: An Unusual Trickbot Launcher
A report from Huntress Labs looks into an unusual Trickbot launcher. It is an obfuscated DOS batch (.bat) file.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

An obfuscated DOS .bat file, which is actually a Trickbot launcher, is the subject of a report from Huntress Labs. The first line of the .bat file assigns "set" to the variable "wjdk, "set wjdk=set". This allows the file to use "wjdk" in place of "set" throughout the rest of the script. The second line of the file creates another variable "gwdoy" and assigns a space to it, "%wjdk% gwdoy= ," and is also used throughout the rest of the script. A number of variables are created and various characters are assigned to them, for example "%wjdk%%gwdoy%ximgny%ipatx%App". The last line of the file concatenates all the variables together to create the command to execute the Trickbot executable. As per the Huntress example, this is "start C:\Users\\****\AppData\Roaming\Identities1603031315\ulib8b4.exe". According to Huntress, this technique could prevent detection of the .bat file by EDR or signature based antivirus systems. The actual Trickbot executable "ulib8b4.exe" is detected by 58 out of 70 engines on VirusTotal. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.huntresslabs.com/tried-and-true-hacker-technique-dos-obfuscation-400b57cd7dd>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Message Quarantine Campaign with Overlay Technique
A phishing campaign leveraging a message quarantine theme has been spotted by Cofense. The researchers highlight the use of an overlay technique on the phishing landing page.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Message Quarantine Campaign with Overlay Technique
A phishing campaign leveraging a message quarantine theme has been spotted by Cofense. The researchers highlight the use of an overlay technique on the phishing landing page.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense researchers have published their analysis of a recent phishing email and associated landing page. The initial email leverages a message quarantine theme. It spoofs the victim company's help desk and claims that the recipient has emails that need to be validated via a provided link prior to receiving. If a user falls victim to this lure, they are directed to a phishing site. The site's background is a copy of the victim company's legitimate website. Overlayed on the page is an input box claiming your login timed out and requests you re-enter your password. Parameters in the link from the email are used to identify the recipient email address. This address is in turn auto-filled into the overlay and used to determine the background image that should be displayed. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Trickbot masrv Module
Trickbot has been continuously evolving despite efforts to shut down the botnet. Kryptos Logic uncovered one of its most recent developments, a module that incorporates Masscan for network scanning.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Kryptos Logic posted their analysis of a new Trickbot module named masrv. The module is delivered as a DLL and executed via its Start and Control export functions. The available commands allow for configuration settings to be obtained, a required library to be installed, and results to be sent to the attacker. Masscan is the open-source tool incorporated to perform the scanning activities. It is able to perform scans based on IP address and port ranges. If the required Npcap library is not present on the victim host, it is downloaded from the C2 server. The researchers were unable to pull down the configuration used by the attacker at the time of research. The blog post notes that there was a function and hard coded IP addresses located in the module's code that indicate a connection to Anchor and Bazar, although it is not necessarily surprising to see a threat actor sharing code between their tools. For more information, see the Kryptos Logic blog post in the Reference section. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Protection

## Yara Rule
    
    
    rule Trickbot__masrvDll  
    {  
    meta:  
    id = "4kWjG0InTDyHiur8cCzPeG"  
    fingerprint = "3e91c19602340a43e026ffdb23b1d6a0c4e186d67f743e962c75aa51ea0c4d1c"  
    version = "1.0"  
    first_imported = "2021-01-29"  
    last_modified = "2021-01-29"  
    status = "RELEASED"  
    sharing = "TLP:WHITE"  
    source = "KRYPTOS LOGIC"  
    description = "Detects Trickbot masrvDll module"  
    category = "MALWARE"  
    malware = "BOT"  
      
    strings:  
    $a = "<http://127.0.0.1:8080/gid/uid/pcap.exe>"  
    $b = "c:\\\\temp\\\\maserv.txt"  
    $c = "Send cmd to server: %s\\r\\n"  
    $d = "HTTP message success: URI=%s DATA=%.*s\\r\\n"  
      
    condition:  
    all of them  
    }

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.kryptoslogic.com/blog/2021/02/trickbot-masrv-module/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Turkey Dog: Cerberus and Anubis Banking Trojans Target Turkish Speakers
Following up on research published in early 2020, RiskIQ reports on a series of campaigns they refer to as Turkey Dog targeting Turkish Android users with the Cerberus and Anubis banking Trojans.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Turkey Dog: Cerberus and Anubis Banking Trojans Target Turkish Speakers
Following up on research published in early 2020, RiskIQ reports on a series of campaigns they refer to as Turkey Dog targeting Turkish Android users with the Cerberus and Anubis banking Trojans.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Banking Trojan




# Overview

RiskIQ has published an article analyzing multiple campaigns targeting Turkish Android users with the Cerberus and Anubis banking Trojans. They refer to this cluster of activity, which has been going on since at least April 2020, as Turkey Dog. Two major lures have been used to convince users to download malicious APKs. The first and earlier one offers free Internet service to users. The more recent ones offer free cash payments, many of which mention it being related to COVID relief efforts. The payloads have been observed being hosted both on attacker-controlled domains and on legitimate services, such as Discord. Some of these links were shared on Twitter, although the exact purpose of this distribution point is unknown. Tracking scripts and the use of HTTrack website copier allowed the researchers to uncover extensive infrastructure leveraged by the attacker. If a user falls victim to the lures and installs the associated APK, they are infected with the the Cerberus or Anubis banking Trojan. These Trojans allow attackers to steal sensitive data, send SMS messages, download additional applications, and more. For more information, see the RiskIQ article in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://community.riskiq.com/article/85b3db8c/description>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: US and Canadian Bank Customers Targeted by Credential Stealer
Threat actors are targeting U.S. and Canadian banking customers with a credential stealer, reports Trend Micro.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Data Theft, Phishing




# Overview

A campaign distributing credential stealers has been observed by researchers from Trend Micro since mid-December 2020. Infection is accomplished via multi-stage processes beginning with a malicious Excel file. The file contains an AHK script compiler executable, a malicious AHK script file, and a VBA AutoOpen macro. The malware communicates with C2 servers in the U.S., the Netherlands, and Sweden and specifically targets U.S. and Canadian customers. The compiler is a legitimate application and is used to compile and execute an AHK script. The script is used for persistence, profiling victims, and downloading and executing the AHK script on a victim system. The downloader creates an auto-run link for the executable in the startup folder. The script then profiles victims by generating a unique ID based on the serial number of the C drive. An HTTP GET request is sent every five seconds and is used to serve as the request path to the C2 server as well as retrieve and execute the AHK script on the infected machine. Other AHK scripts can be employed against the victim depending on information obtained by the initial script. At present, the only commands seen have been 'deletecookies' and 'passwords'. The stealer portion is written in AHK and harvests credentials from browsers, then exports those credentials to the attacker. Instructions within are written in Russian on usage of the script. Browsers scanned include Microsoft Edge, Google Chrome, Opera, Firefox, and Internet Explorer. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/20/l/stealth-credential-stealer-targets-us-canadian-bank-customers.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: SMAUG Ransomware as a Service
A relatively new Ransomware as a Service (RaaS) offering, SMAUG, is discussed in an analysis by SentinelOne researchers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: SMAUG Ransomware as a Service
A relatively new Ransomware as a Service (RaaS) offering, SMAUG, is discussed in an analysis by SentinelOne researchers.

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

SentinelOne published their analysis of the SMAUG RaaS offering. It has some interesting characteristics not commonly seen with other RaaS offerings. It first appeared in the threat landscape at the end of April 2020. Similar to other ransomware services, a percentage of the profit made by the purchasers is provided to the operators in order to receive the payload and services. Additionally, the operators charge a registration fee, one that is quite a bit higher than those charged by competitors (.2 BTC or $1,800). One of the most unique features of SMAUG is its multi-platofrm support, allowing encryption of Windows, Linux and macOS systems. Additionally, when building the malicious payload, an option is provided to allow a single encryption key to be used across all victim hosts in a single company. Anti-analysis, offline execution, customizable campaigns are all features advertised in their forum posts. The payloads are generated via a web-based management interface as opposed to the more common offline builder. This web portal also allows victims to decrypt a single file for free. The generated payloads for Windows are obfuscated Go binaries. On Windows, persistence is established via the LoadAppInit_DLLs Registry key. A ransom note is dropped in all folders containing encrypted files. The researchers also note that the SMAUG portal provides detailed walkthroughs for victims and affiliates. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/multi-platform-smaug-raas-aims-to-see-off-competitors/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Tech Support Scam Campaign Abuses XSS Vulnerability
While scammers typically use malvertising to lead users to their tech scam site, Malwarebytes has observed a new campaign that uses Facebook as a distribution point and cross-site scripting (XSS) for redirection.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Tech Support Scam Campaign Abuses XSS Vulnerability
While scammers typically use malvertising to lead users to their tech scam site, Malwarebytes has observed a new campaign that uses Facebook as a distribution point and cross-site scripting (XSS) for redirection.

# Threat Type

  * Scam




# Overview

Malwarebytes has published a report detailing a new tech support scam campaign leveraging a cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability to carry out their malicious actions. The first link is a bit.ly shortened URL that is being distributed via Facebook. This shortener then redirects users to a secondary website that contains an XSS vulnerability allowing for open redirects. In particular, the XSS vulnerability is used to load JavaScript from a remote attacker-controlled domain. The purpose of the JavaScript is to perform the malicious redirect to a browlock landing page. Assuming the IP address of the visitor is based in the US, the browlock landing page identifies the browser version and shows an animation indicating the victim's computer is infected and requests they call a tech support center to avoid data loss. While Malwarebytes did not investigate past this point, it is likely the fake call center will try to scam users out of money or personal data. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/cybercrime/2020/10/xss-to-tss-tech-support-scam-campaign/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New ReverseRat Malware Used in Campaign Against Government and Power Utilities in India and Afghanistan
Lumen’s Black Lotus Labs have picked up on a new remote access trojan (RAT) they're calling ReverseRat that was deployed in parallel with an open-source RAT called AllaKore. The threat actor has been targeting government and energy organizations in India and Afghanistan.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New ReverseRat Malware Used in Campaign Against Government and Power Utilities in India and Afghanistan
Lumen’s Black Lotus Labs have picked up on a new remote access trojan (RAT) they're calling ReverseRat that was deployed in parallel with an open-source RAT called AllaKore. The threat actor has been targeting government and energy organizations in India and Afghanistan.

# Threat Type

  * Trojan, Malware, Backdoor




# Overview

 They assessed that the operational infrastructure was hosted in Pakistan. There were three components observed. The first was a zip file downloaded which contained a Microsoft shortcut file (.lnk) and a benign PDF file. When the shortcut is clicked it will display the PDF but also retrieve a malicious HTA file. The second component uses the HTA file to inject a 32-bit shellcode into a running process to help launch a program called preBotHta.pdb which the actor has been seen using in the past. preBotHta.pdb initiates several actions, the last of which starts execution of ReverseRat. The third component is executed from the previous HTA file and is an open-source RAT called AllaKore. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.lumen.com/suspected-pakistani-actor-compromises-indian-power-company-with-new-reverserat/>

Oracle has released their quarterly Critical Patch Update (CPU) for October of 2020. Included are updates that fix 329 security vulnerabilities across the Oracle product line.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
 The main CPU document provides details on affected products and the CVSS scoring details for each vulnerability addressed. A description of each vulnerability, and the CVSS vector string, are available from the risk matrices in the verbose version of the CPU. In addition, Oracle has also released its Solaris Third Party Bulletin which addresses vulnerabilities in third party software that is provided with Oracle Solaris. instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Cring Ransomware Techniques
Cring is a ransomware family that appeared on the threat landscape in 2021. Trend Micro has published a blog post detailing the techniques used by threat actors to deploy this payload.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Finance, Transportation
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Cring
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** RDP, Vulnerability exploitation
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Steal credentials, move laterally, deploy ransomware payload
  *  **Additional TTPs** : Use of Mimikatz and Cobalt Strike



# Overview

Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing the techniques used in Cring ransomware infections. Initial access is obtained through either exposed RDP services or vulnerability exploits, such as those in Adobe ColdFusion and FortiGate VPN. When the threat actor has obtained access, they leverage Mimikatz to steal account credentials, which are used to move laterally via Cobalt Strike. Cobalt Strike is further leveraged to distribute batch scripts. These batch scripts are used to download, execute, and delete the Cring ransomware payload. Like many ransomware families, Cring disables services and processes, deletes backup files, and performs encryption. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64128862/Cring%20Ransomware%20Techniques%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632855232253&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/i/examining-the-cring-ransomware-techniques.html>

T1078.002 - Domain Accounts

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**

T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools

 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials

 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery

 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer

 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1090 - Proxy  
T1090.003 - Multi-hop Proxy  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer

 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1489 - Service Stop  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: MyloBot Botnet Being Used To Send Extortion Emails
MyloBot is a sophisticated and highly evasive botnet that was first seen in 2018. Minerva Labs researchers have analyzed the newest version of this malware and discovered that it is currently only being used to send extortion emails. The changes seen in the malware have been published in the following report.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Botnet
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** MyloBot **  
**
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Extortion Email



# Overview

Minerva Labs have analyzed the latest version of the MyloBot botnet. This malware was first seen in 2018, and is known for using many sophisticated evasion techniques to avoid detection and analysis. In the latest version, it appears that some of these evasion techniques are no longer in use. The first stage of this malware uses anti-debugging techniques using custom exception filters to avoid analysis, and loads an encrypted executable into memory and decodes it. It performs further anti-virtual machine checks and attempts to disable any other malware that may be using the registry for persistence. The malware then gains persistence using the registry and continues the attack. The final stage payload is used to send extortion emails from the victim machine, asking for $2732 in bitcoin. Although this is currently all the campaign is doing, the final stage also seems that it can download additional files, meaning that the botnet may be used as a backdoor in future attacks. for further information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058891/MyloBot%20Botnet%20Being%20Used%20To%20Send%20Extortion%20Emails%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645025808043&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing (M1045). 
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blog.minerva-labs.com/mylobot-2022-so-many-evasive-techniques-just-to-send-extortion-emails>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1543.003 - Windows Service  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Instagram Users Targeted with Copyright Infringement Scam
Users of the social media platform Instagram are being targeted with a copyright infringement scam designed to obtain credentials. A report from Sophos' Naked Security provides further information on this attack.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Instagram Users Targeted with Copyright Infringement Scam
Users of the social media platform Instagram are being targeted with a copyright infringement scam designed to obtain credentials. A report from Sophos' Naked Security provides further information on this attack.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Instagram Users
  *  **Lure:** Copyright Infringement Claim Notices
  *  **Payload:** Bogus Link
  *  **Compromised Data:** Credentials of Users



# Overview

A campaign targeting Instagram users employing a copyright infringement claim in an effort to force users to disclose credentials has been observed by researchers from Sophos' Naked Security. Potential victims receive an email stating Instagram has received a copyright infringement claim from another user when, in fact, there is no claim. Typical of phishing emails, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors, and spoofed links are included in the campaign. The email states a copyright claim has been filed against the target and an "Appeal As (Username)" is included as a clickable link. The link is actually a shortened URL that redirects to a realistic looking representation of the target's page with another link to an appeal form. The image contained on this page is typically the second to last image posted by the victim in order to some semblance of realism. The domain looks vaguely legitimate and asks for the user's password. By entering the password, the user is presented with a password error message designed to force the user to re-enter their password. Presumably, this is done to prevent the victim from keying in random letters and numbers to deceive an attack. The second attempt provides a realistic notification that the appeal has been successfully submitted. The attacker then redirects the victim to the legitimate copyright claim page. Further information can be found in the post located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056548/Instagram%20Users%20Targeted%20with%20Copyright%20Infringement%20Scam%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641319183327&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction. (M1017)
  * Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc. (M1021)
  * Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries. (M1031)
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior. (M1040)
  * Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses. (M1047)
  * Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates. (M1054)



# References

  * <https://nakedsecurity.sophos.com/2021/12/30/instagram-copyright-infringment-scams-dont-get-sucked-in/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

  
 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1586.001 - Social Media Accounts  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Fake PoC Exploit Delivers Cobalt Strike Beacon
A report from Cyble provides an analysis of fake Proof-of-Concept exploits that deliver Cobal Strike beacons and may be part of a campaign targeting the Infosec community.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Fake PoC Exploit Delivers Cobalt Strike Beacon
A report from Cyble provides an analysis of fake Proof-of-Concept exploits that deliver Cobal Strike beacons and may be part of a campaign targeting the Infosec community.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Possibly the Infosec community.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Cobalt Strike
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake PoC exploit.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unspecified
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below



# Overview

Fake Proof-of-Concept exploits that have been available on Github may be part of a campaign that is targeting the Infosec community, according to a report from Cyble. The two PoCs mentioned in Cyble's report were both available from the same Github account. When executed, the fake PoCs deliver fake messages while in the background, PowerShell is used to deploy the payload, a Cobalt Strike Beacon. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2022/05/20/malware-campaign-targets-infosec-community-threat-actor-uses-fake-proof-of-concept-to-deliver-cobalt-strike-beacon/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Possibly the Infosec community.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Cobalt Strike
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake PoC exploit.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unspecified
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below



# Overview

Fake Proof-of-Concept exploits that have been available on Github may be part of a campaign that is targeting the Infosec community, according to a report from Cyble. The two PoCs mentioned in Cyble's report were both available from the same Github account. When executed, the fake PoCs deliver fake messages while in the background, PowerShell is used to deploy the payload, a Cobalt Strike Beacon. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2022/05/20/malware-campaign-targets-infosec-community-threat-actor-uses-fake-proof-of-concept-to-deliver-cobalt-strike-beacon/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Amazon Japan Credential Phishing
A high-volume Amazon Japan themed phishing campaign was identified by Proofpoint researchers and reported on in a recent blog post.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Proofpoint has published their findings on an Amazon phishing campaign targeting Japanese users. In terms of the sender, the threat actors initially exploited randomly generated email addresses for distribution; but they have since pivoted to using lookalike domains and addresses, in order to increase legitimacy. The body and subject of the email are: written in Japanese, use legitimate Amazon logos, and request that the recipient provide information to update or unlock their account. In most cases, the URL is linked to an IP address, but in some cases, random domain names were used. The phishing page is also, geofenced and checks whether the user is in Japan before proceeding. If they are not, they are redirected to the legitimate Amazon Japan login page. If they are located in Japan, they are directed to a fake login page. Submitting credentials redirects users to, two additional forms, one requesting various pieces of personally identifiable information and another requesting credit card information. After the forms are complete, victims are redirected to the real Amazon Japan homepage, leaving the attackers with all of the provided information. Proofpoint gives credence to the fact that, this campaign is unique to other Amazon phishing campaigns. This is due to, the volume of emails sent, with an average of several hundred thousand distributed per day. Leading researchers to believe, a botnet is being used to automate the distribution of the emails based on the quantity. For more information, see the Proofpoint blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/geofenced-amazon-japan-credential-phishing-volumes-rival-emotet>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Egregor Ransomware Discovered
Appgate announced the finding of a new family of ransomware dubbed "Egregor." Based on the article, Egregor not only encrypts a victim's files but also allows the attackers use extortion to force the victim to pay the ransom.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Egregor Ransomware Discovered
Appgate announced the finding of a new family of ransomware dubbed "Egregor." Based on the article, Egregor not only encrypts a victim's files but also allows the attackers use extortion to force the victim to pay the ransom.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, Extortion



# Overview

Appgate's report indicates that the threat-actors behind Egregor first hack into a potential victim's network, exfiltrate sensitive data, and then execute Egregor on the system to encrypt all of the victim's files. The ransom note left behind gives the victim three days to pay the ransom or the stolen data will be published to the Internet. The analyzed sample not only had obfuscated code, but the payload was packed as well as an anti-analysis prevention technique. Should the victim pay the ransom within the time provided, not only will their files be decrypted, but the threat-actors will also provide their recommendations to secure the victim's network against future attacks. At the time of the article, at least thirteen companies had fallen victim to Egregor and were listed on the threat-actor's website in their "hall of shame".

  
IBM X-Force researchers dove deeper into a sample of the malware. What they found agreed with Appgate's assessment that Egregor seems to be a fork of the Sekhmet ransomware. The sample analyzed was compiled on September 22, 2020. Out of sixty-seven anti-virus products on VirusTotal, forty-nine were able to detect this malware. Defensive measures used to evade detection and analysis include masquerading, virtualization and sandbox evasion, process injection, obfuscated files or information, and DLL side-loading. Persistence is gained through DLL side-loading and boot or logon scripts. Lateral movement is through remote services, RDP, SMB, Windows admin shares, SSH, and VNC. Data collection is accomplished from local drives, removable media, network shares, direct input capture, keylogging, and GUI input capture.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ 2 IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/32145556/Egregor%20Ransomware%20Discovered%202%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1602087719134&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.appgate.com/news-press/appgate-labs-analyzes-new-family-of-ransomware-egregor>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Campaign Targeting Cryptocurrency Users
Intezer discovered a campaign targeting cryptocurrency users that they estimate began in early 2020. A new RAT associated with the campaign has been named ElectroRAT by Intezer. It is written in Golang and can run on Linux, MacOS, and Windows.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

A campaign that targets cryptocurrency users was discovered by Intezer in late 2020. Intezer estimates the campaign began around January 2020. Three Trojanized applications (DaoPoker, eTrade, and Jamm) built using the Electron framework are used in the campaign to deliver a RAT that has been named ElectroRAT by Intezer. The applications have been promoted through fake user accounts on social media and online forums that focus on cryptocurrency, and are hosted on websites created for the campaign. ElectroRAT uses raw Pastebin pages to determine its C&C address and Intezer estimates, from the number of pages views, that there may be several thousand victims. While ElectroRAT can log keystrokes, take screenshots, upload and download files, and execute commands, its primary goal is to obtain access to the victim's crypto wallets. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/research/operation-electrorat-attacker-creates-fake-companies-to-drain-your-crypto-wallets/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Adobe January 2021 Updates
Adobe has released seven security bulletins covering seven of their products.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

 A total of eight vulnerabilities were patched in these releases.  
  
Security updates available for Adobe Photoshop - APSB21-01   
Adobe has released updates for Photoshop for Windows and macOS. These updates resolve a critical vulnerability. Successful exploitation could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of the current user.   
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/photoshop/apsb21-01.html>   
  
Security Updates Available for Adobe Illustrator - APSB21-02   
Adobe has released an update for Adobe Illustrator 2020. This update resolves a critical vulnerability that could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of current user.   
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/illustrator/apsb21-02.html>   
  
Security updates available for Adobe Animate - APSB21-03   
Adobe has released an update for Adobe Animate. This update resolves a critical vulnerability. Successful exploitation could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of the current user.   
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/animate/apsb21-03.html>   
  
Security updates available for Adobe Campaign Classic - APSB21-04   
Adobe has released security updates for Adobe Campaign Classic. These updates address a critical server-side request forgery (SSRF) vulnerability that could result in sensitive information disclosure.   
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/campaign/apsb21-04.html>   
  
Security Update Available for Adobe InCopy - APSB21-05   
Adobe has released a security update for Adobe InCopy. This update addresses a critical vulnerability. Successful exploitation could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of the current user.   
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/incopy/apsb21-05.html>   
  
Security hotfix available for Adobe Captivate - APSB21-06   
Adobe has released a security hotfix for Adobe Captivate. This hotfix addresses an important vulnerability. Successful exploitation could lead to privilege escalation in the context of the current user.   
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/captivate/apsb21-06.html>   
  
Security Updates Available for Adobe Bridge - APSB21-07   
Adobe has released a security update for Adobe Bridge. This update addresses critical vulnerabilities that could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of the current user.   
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/bridge/apsb21-07.html>

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35719957/Adobe%20January%202021%20Updates%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1610552663285&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://helpx.adobe.com/security.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Jian -  A Replica of an NSA Exploit
Check Point has published a report on an exploit named Jian, the creation of which had previously been attributed to APT31. Check Point was able to demonstrate that Jian is actually a replica of an Equation Group exploit, EpMe, that was created some two years prior to EpMe becoming public in the Shadow Brokers leak.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Exploit Analysis, APT




# Overview

While investigating recent Windows privilege escalation exploits that have been attributed to Chinese actors, researchers from Check Point analyzed an exploit that had been named Jian. The exploit had previously been attributed to the Chinese group known as APT31 or Zirconium. Check Point was able to demonstrate is that Jian was actually a replica of an Equation Group exploit, EpMe. What is most interesting is that Jian was engineered by APT31 at least two years before EpMe was made public in the Shadow Brokers leak. This suggests that the 32 and 64-bit versions of EpMe were either captured in the wild while being used by the Equation Group in an operation or through an attack on Equation Group infrastructure. Further details, including information on the vulnerabilities and exploits, are available from the Check Point report which is linked in the reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2021/the-story-of-jian/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Donot Team Campaigns and Malware
ESET has published an analysis of variants of malware used in Donot Team campaigns that ESET has named DarkMusical and Gedit.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Espionage.
  *  **Targets:** Government and military organizations, and individuals, located in South Asian countries.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Various
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing emails with weaponized documents attached.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, Lateral movement, Data collection, and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Two campaigns that are attributed to the Donot Team have been analyzed by ESET. Their report notes that Donot is known for attacking government and military organizations, and individuals, located in a small number of South Asian countries, primarily Bangladesh, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka. However, Donot may also attack the embassies of the countries they target in any location. The group, also identified as APT-C-35 and SectorE02, has been active since 2016, and its objective is espionage. Donot typically use spearphishing as the infection vector with one of three functionally different documents attached to the emails. One variant is macros is Excel, PowerPoint, and Word files which use macros to deliver the payload. Another variant is RTF documents with a .doc extension that exploit the Equation Editor vulnerability, CVE‑2017‑11882. The last variant uses RTF template injection to download another document that exploits the Equation Editor vulnerability. Of the malware analyzed in the report, the malware used in the Gedit campaign was first observed used in attacks in September 2020 with DarkMusical malware being first used in June 2021. Both are variants of the yty malware framework. In some cases, another malware framework named Jaca was used. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057297/Donot%20Team%20Campaigns%20and%20Malware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642740969674&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/01/18/donot-go-do-not-respawn/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.005 - Exploits  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1036.005 - Match Legitimate Name or Location  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1534 - Internal Spearphishing  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1025 - Data from Removable Media  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol  
T1048.003 - Exfiltration Over Unencrypted/Obfuscated Non-C2 Protocol  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Espionage.
  *  **Targets:** Government and military organizations, and individuals, located in South Asian countries.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Various
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing emails with weaponized documents attached.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, Lateral movement, Data collection, and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Two campaigns that are attributed to the Donot Team have been analyzed by ESET. Their report notes that Donot is known for attacking government and military organizations, and individuals, located in a small number of South Asian countries, primarily Bangladesh, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka. However, Donot may also attack the embassies of the countries they target in any location. The group, also identified as APT-C-35 and SectorE02, has been active since 2016, and its objective is espionage. Donot typically use spearphishing as the infection vector with one of three functionally different documents attached to the emails. One variant is macros is Excel, PowerPoint, and Word files which use macros to deliver the payload. Another variant is RTF documents with a .doc extension that exploit the Equation Editor vulnerability, CVE‑2017‑11882. The last variant uses RTF template injection to download another document that exploits the Equation Editor vulnerability. Of the malware analyzed in the report, the malware used in the Gedit campaign was first observed used in attacks in September 2020 with DarkMusical malware being first used in June 2021. Both are variants of the yty malware framework. In some cases, another malware framework named Jaca was used. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057297/Donot%20Team%20Campaigns%20and%20Malware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642740969674&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/01/18/donot-go-do-not-respawn/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.005 - Exploits  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1036.005 - Match Legitimate Name or Location  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1534 - Internal Spearphishing  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1025 - Data from Removable Media  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol  
T1048.003 - Exfiltration Over Unencrypted/Obfuscated Non-C2 Protocol  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: FBI Alert for Disinformation Spreading on 2020 Election
The FBI and CISA have issued an alert (I-092220-PSA) for foreign threat actors disseminating disinformation on 2020 election results.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Alert




# Overview

The FBI and CISA have issued Alert I-092220-PSA in an effort to raise awareness of potential threats related to the spread of disinformation regarding results of the 2020 elections. In order to certify elections, state and local officials take several days to ensure the validity of votes cast for accuracy. Due to COVID-19, usage of mail-in ballots is expected to be higher than in previous years. As a result, the possibility exists for fraudulent ballots. This process could slow election results past election night and cause a delay in announcing election race winners. By disseminating disinformation, foreign threat actors could affect voter turnout, voter suppression, cyber attacks on the election infrastructure, ballot fraud as well as other tactics intended to interfere with the 2020 election results. With proper protective measures in place, these types of disasters can be avoided. The alert contains information on ensuring accuracy in the election process. Details can be found in the alert located within the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.ic3.gov/media/2020/200922.aspx>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Babax Stealer Rebrands to Osno Ransomware
According to analysts, the malware Babax steals information by targeting login credentials saved on web browsers. Recently, the threat actors behind the malware revamped their marketing and advertising approach by increasing the price of this malware while also adding new capabilities into their malware and ransomware, making it a popular asset amongst cybercriminals.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Babax Stealer Rebrands to Osno Ransomware
According to analysts, the malware Babax steals information by targeting login credentials saved on web browsers. Recently, the threat actors behind the malware revamped their marketing and advertising approach by increasing the price of this malware while also adding new capabilities into their malware and ransomware, making it a popular asset amongst cybercriminals.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware 




# Overview

Analysts discovered Babax Stealer being sold on forums at higher prices with a repertoire of new features for the ransomware Osno like: Opensource Rootkit r77, lateral movement via SharpExec, Anti-AV, evasion of Windows Defender via allowlist, AnarchyGrabber and microphone records. According to analysts, although the malware’s capabilities have extended, it's nothing of vital concern due to the activation process of tools such as: rootkit and the anti-AV, which are only functional after the malware accesses the targeted system and gains administrative privileges. The same activation process was seen within the lateral movement phase of the attack, which heavily relies on the download of an external tool. Initially, the main purpose of Babax stealer is to steal saved credentials and propagate via the network. To avoid detection of the malware, it is encrypted. Analysts note, however, defenders have high visibility and are privy to the malware’s features, making it harder for the malware to go undetected. As such, multiple workarounds constructed into the ransomware, with more on the way, exist according to analysts. For more information, see the blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.gdatasoftware.com/blog/2020/11/36459-babax-stealer-rebrands-to-osno-installs-rootkit>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Dridex Trojan in Amazon Gift Card Offers
Cybereason is reporting on a scam in which the Dridex banking Trojan is being sent with Amazon gift card offers. With COVID-19 forcing more online shopping, the threat actors behind these campaigns are continuing to target online shoppers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Dridex Trojan in Amazon Gift Card Offers
Cybereason is reporting on a scam in which the Dridex banking Trojan is being sent with Amazon gift card offers. With COVID-19 forcing more online shopping, the threat actors behind these campaigns are continuing to target online shoppers.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan




# Overview

Since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, threat actors have ramped up efforts to take advantage of the online shopping boom. Actors are leveraging this increase in online shopping for financial gain. Using the most popular platforms, threat actors are attempting to increase their foothold into unsuspecting users' computers. Infection methods differ greatly amongst these threats. Currently, phishing emails with attached Microsoft Office documents are promising Amazon gift cards as the hook for these victims. Within the documents are malicious macros, self-extracting SCR files (known as a Dridex technique), and a VBScript (also a well-known Dridex technique). Upon downloading the infected file, victims are redirected to a legitimate Amazon page in order to garner credibility. Typically, the documents contain "Gift Card" in the title. Once the file is opened, the VBScript is executed using a PowerShell script. A secondary method is the delivery of screensaver (SCR) files. The icons are those of Amazon, again lending credibility to the ruse. The file leads to several actions, including dropping files in order to further infect the victim's computer using scripts and other methods. Finally, the use of VBScript is another infection vector using a bundled archive containing the Dridex Trojan. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35718994/Dridex%20Trojan%20in%20Amazon%20Gift%20Card%20Offers%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1609174905464&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.cybereason.com/blog/amazon-gift-card-offer-serves-up-dridex-banking-trojan>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Evil Corp Ransomware Mimicking PayloadBin
A new ransomware family, PayloadBin, was discovered by BleepingComputer. Although it attempts to mimic the Babuk group, researchers have attributed it to Evil Corp.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

BleepingComputer discovered a ransomware sample submitted to VirusTotal that appends the extension ".PAYLOADBIN". The Babuk gang recently rebranded and created a site called "payload bin," making it seems like this new ransomware may be related to the same actors despite their claims about leaving the ransomware game. Further malware analysis, however, revealed that this was instead the rebranding of WastedLocker, an Evil Corp ransomware family. BleepingComputer believes the purpose of mimicking the Babuk group is because due to sanctions against Evil Corp, they are less likely to receive payments from ransomware negotiation firms. For more information, see the BleepingComputer article in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/new-evil-corp-ransomware-mimics-payloadbin-gang-to-evade-us-sanctions/>
