instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Phishing Campaign Harvests Credentials with GDPR Lure
A phishing campaign using a GDPR lure to entice victims to provide credentials was discovered and reported on by Area 1 Security researchers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing, Credential Stealing




# Overview

Area 1 Security has published a blog post detailing a GDPR-themed phishing campaign targeting multiple organizations. Analysis of the emails revealed that some were being sent from a VPS while others were sent from compromised servers. The body of the email uses graphics and a mix of formatting to pass itself off as legitimate. It spoofs the victim organization, specifically claiming to come from the security department, and requests that the recipient login to their account in order to follow steps related to GDPR compliance. The provided link leads to a login form hosted on a compromised WordPress site. If a user falls victim and enters their credentials, the data is exfiltrated to the attacker using a script hosted on the same domain. The researchers note that the phishing page has since been removed from the site but it is likely the attackers will simply compromise another site to host their content and continue their campaign. For more information, see the Area 1 Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.area1security.com/blog/gdpr-compliance-phishing/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Latest Version of IceXLoader Analyzed
The malware loader IceXLoader is now at version 3.0, and Fortinet has written an article discussing the technical details of its behaviors. It has been seen dropping cryptocurrency miner malware and infostealer malware.
output:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Loader
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
* **Associated Payloads:** IceXLoader 3.0
* **Targets:** Windows Users
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Load Malware
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

Fortinet has analyzed the latest version of IceXLoader. Now in its third version, the loader has been previously spread using phishing emails with the malware in a zip attachment. The malware sets itself to run on startup to gain persistence and seems to have incomplete functionality. This allows IceXLoader to set up mutexes to ensure only one instance will load on startup, but this function is not yet working. IceXLoader attempts to evade detection by using in-memory patching of AMSI.DLL and uses PowerShell to disable Windows Defender. The malware is also added to the Windows Defender exclusion list. In the example studied by researchers, the Loader was observed dropping unknown malware that may have been a RAT or info stealer. This would additionally deploy a Monero crypto-miner. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/new-icexloader-3-0-developers-warm-up-to-nim>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Resource Development - TA0042**  
   T1587.001 - Malware  

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
   T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  

**Execution - TA0002**  
   T1059.001 - PowerShell  
   T1204.002 - Malicious File  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
   T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
   T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
   T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
   T1016.001 - Internet Connection Discovery  
 T1057 - Process Discovery  
 T1082 - System Information Discovery  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  

#### Mitigations:

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1025:**  Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1039:**  Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1043:**  Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
**M1044:**  Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Latest Version of IceXLoader Analyzed
The malware loader IceXLoader is now at version 3.0, and Fortinet has written an article discussing the technical details of its behaviors. It has been seen dropping cryptocurrency miner malware and infostealer malware.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Loader
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
* **Associated Payloads:** IceXLoader 3.0
* **Targets:** Windows Users
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Load Malware
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

Fortinet has analyzed the latest version of IceXLoader. Now in its third version, the loader has been previously spread using phishing emails with the malware in a zip attachment. The malware sets itself to run on startup to gain persistence and seems to have incomplete functionality. This allows IceXLoader to set up mutexes to ensure only one instance will load on startup, but this function is not yet working. IceXLoader attempts to evade detection by using in-memory patching of AMSI.DLL and uses PowerShell to disable Windows Defender. The malware is also added to the Windows Defender exclusion list. In the example studied by researchers, the Loader was observed dropping unknown malware that may have been a RAT or info stealer. This would additionally deploy a Monero crypto-miner. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/new-icexloader-3-0-developers-warm-up-to-nim>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Resource Development - TA0042**  
   T1587.001 - Malware  

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
   T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  

**Execution - TA0002**  
   T1059.001 - PowerShell  
   T1204.002 - Malicious File  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
   T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
   T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
   T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
   T1016.001 - Internet Connection Discovery  
 T1057 - Process Discovery  
 T1082 - System Information Discovery  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  

#### Mitigations:

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1025:**  Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1039:**  Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1043:**  Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
**M1044:**  Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Transportation and Government Targeted by Tropic Trooper
A report from Trend Micro provides details of the targets, and the TTPs used by the APT actor that is known as Tropic Trooper which Trend Micro now refers to as Earth Centaur.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Espionage
  *  **Targets:** Transportation sector, and government departments that deal with transportation.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Backdoors and RATs - ChiserClient, Gh0st, HTShell, Lilith, Nerapack, Quasar, and SmileSvr.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Vulnerabilities in IIS and Exchange (ProxyLogon)
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, Credential dumping, Lateral movement, Data collection, and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Tropic Trooper is believed to be a Chinese-speaking APT actor that according to a report from Trend Micro appears to have been targeting the transportation sector, and government departments that deal with transportation. The objective of Tropic Trooper is believed to be espionage. Tropic Trooper is now referred to as Earth Centaur by Trend Micro but is also known as KeyBoy, and Pirate Panda. Tropic Trooper typically exploits vulnerabilities in Internet-accessible services, vulnerabilities in Microsoft's Internet Information Services (IIS) server and Exchange server are mentioned in the report as being exploited to provide the initial toehold in an environment. When an initial compromise has been achieved, a variety of RATs or Webshells are installed to provide persistent access to the compromised host. The actor then carries out reconnaissance activities, dumps credentials, and will attempt to move laterally. A number of tools are used in the process. Rclone is usually downloaded, installed, and used to exfiltrate data to multiple cloud storage providers. Trend Micro believes that the actor may widen its target scope to include other industry sectors which have relationships with transportation. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056212/Transportation%20and%20Government%20Targeted%20by%20Tropic%20Trooper%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639635545650&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software, operating systems, and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/l/collecting-in-the-dark-tropic-trooper-targets-transportation-and-government-organizations.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Credential Access - TA0006**

 **Discovery - TA0007**

Multiple vulnerabilities in the IBM Runtime Environment Java (version 8.0.6.11) used by the IBM Security SiteProtector System have been addressed in a Security Bulletin.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
 Successful exploitation of the most serious of the vulnerabilities could potentially allow an unauthenticated remote attacker to access sensitive information. SiteProtector versions 3.0.0 and 3.1.1 are affected by the vulnerabilities. The vulnerabilities are fixed in versions 3.0.0.25 and 3.1.1.22. Further information is available from the SiteProtector bulletin which is linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-2590, CVE-2020-2601, and CVE-2020-14577




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Tower Semiconductor Experiences Cyber Security Incident
Breach Notification: Tower Semiconductor has published a statement notifying the public of a cyber security incident resulting in some of its systems and operations being shut down.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Breach




# Overview

The following statement was issued by Tower Semiconductor on September 6th, 2020 in response to a cyber security incident impacting certains systems and operations:

"Tower Semiconductor (NASDAQ/TASE: TSEM), today announced that the Company’s IT security systems identified a security incident on some of its systems as a result of a cyber event. As a preventive measure, the Company halted certain of its servers and proactively held operations in some of its manufacturing facilities, and has done so in a gradual, organized manner.

Tower has notified relevant authorities and is working closely with law enforcement organizations and with a leading team of worldwide experts, coordinated with its insurance providers, in order to recover the impacted systems as soon as possible. The Company has implemented specific measures to prevent the expansion of this event. At this point there is no assessment as to the actual effect on the Company."

Details on the nature of the attack have not been provided.

# Reference

  * <https://towersemi.com/2020/09/06/09062020/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Four Severe Vulnerabilities Patched in Ninja Forms
Wordfence published a blog post detailing four severe vulnerabilities that they discovered in the Ninja Forms WordPress plugin.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 The first vulnerability is related to the SendWP plugin and could allow for the disclosure of a secret key. If successfully exploited, an attacker with low-level access could monitor all data sent via forms on the victim website or trigger a password reset for an administrator's account. The second vulnerability is in the Add-on Manager and could allow an attacker with low-level access to establish an OAuth Connection with the victim site given a successful social engineering attempt. The third vulnerability is an open redirect vulnerability that could allow an attacker to redirect an administrator to a malicious website. Lastly, a cross-site request forgery vulnerability in the Add-on manager may allow an attacker to disconnect OAuth connections. All of the vulnerabilities are pending CVE assignment. Ninja Form has released updates that fix all of the issues. For more information, see the Wordfence blog post in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * Pending




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.wordfence.com/blog/2021/02/one-million-sites-affected-four-severe-vulnerabilities-patched-in-ninja-forms/>

APSB20-52: A security update for Adobe InDesign. This update addresses multiple critical vulnerabilities. Successful exploitation could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of the current user.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: AR20-268A - Federal Agency Compromised by Malicious Cyber Actor
CISA has issued alert AR20-268A to warn the public of a recent cyberattack against a federal agency, detailing the TTPs leveraged by the threat actor.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

CISA responded to a cyberattack against a federal agency in which a threat actor established persistent remote access to the victim environment. Initial access was obtained using Microsoft O365 credentials. The stolen credentials were used to log into a user's O365 account which was then used to download a file from a SharePoint site. The actor also connected to the organization's VPN server, which CISA believes may have been done via exploitation of CVE-2019-11510, a Pulse Secure VPN vulnerability. Reconnaissance activities included searching emails and files, using Windows command line tools to map the network and system, and enumerating Active Directory and Group Policy. Persistence is established via a few methods including a SSH tunnel/reverse SMB SOCKS proxy, a multistage malware, and a locally mounted remote share. The SSH tunnel and SOCKS proxy had related scheduled tasks created to ensure that the machine would be reinfected if needed. Exfiltration of data from an account directory and server directory was performed using tsclient. The possibility of further exfiltration exists based on the fact the actor collected files and directories inside a ZIP archive. Further details can be found in CISA's report in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar20-268a>

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
AR20-268A - Federal Agency Compromised by Malicious Cyber Actor
CISA has issued alert AR20-268A to warn the public of a recent cyberattack against a federal agency, detailing the TTPs leveraged by the threat actor.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

CISA responded to a cyberattack against a federal agency in which a threat actor established persistent remote access to the victim environment. Initial access was obtained using Microsoft O365 credentials. The stolen credentials were used to log into a user's O365 account which was then used to download a file from a SharePoint site. The actor also connected to the organization's VPN server, which CISA believes may have been done via exploitation of CVE-2019-11510, a Pulse Secure VPN vulnerability. Reconnaissance activities included searching emails and files, using Windows command line tools to map the network and system, and enumerating Active Directory and Group Policy. Persistence is established via a few methods including a SSH tunnel/reverse SMB SOCKS proxy, a multistage malware, and a locally mounted remote share. The SSH tunnel and SOCKS proxy had related scheduled tasks created to ensure that the machine would be reinfected if needed. Exfiltration of data from an account directory and server directory was performed using tsclient. The possibility of further exfiltration exists based on the fact the actor collected files and directories inside a ZIP archive. Further details can be found in CISA's report in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar20-268a>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Magento 2 PHP Credit Card Skimmer Saves to JPG
The compromise of a Magento 2 website led Sucuri researchers to skimmer code that saves stolen details to a JPG as an exfiltration method.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Skimmer




# Overview

Sucuri published a blog post analyzing a Magento 2 skimmer that saves stolen information to a JPG. The injected PHP code begins by creating a, seemingly, benign image file in a folder on the server that can easily be accessed and downloaded by the attacker in the future. During checkout operations on the website, the Magento getPostValue function is used to capture data from the Customer_ POST parameter. Furthermore, if a user is logged in during checkout, their login email address is also captured. This information is then base64-encoded and XORed before being saved to the previously created JPG file. Information stolen includes names and addresses, credit card details, phone numbers, and browser User Agent strings. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2021/03/magento-2-php-credit-card-skimmer-saves-to-jpg.html>

In a new report from Kaspersky, there is a cyber attack which attempts to extort money from companies using the threat of a bomb having been planted.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Extortion, Threat




# Overview

A new cyberthreat has emerged in the form of a bomb threat against companies in an elaborate extortion ruse. Using email as a delivery mechanism for the threat, the actors involved demand a ransom of $20,000 US in Bitcoin in exchange for their "mercenary" to remove the device. The bomb threat email states any suspicious activity will result in the detonation of the device. In these cases, the bomb is merely a hoax in an attempt to cause a knee-jerk reaction and payment of the ransom. Most of the emails seen in this campaign are written in German but some are in English. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Google Mail Merge Impersonation
A recent phishing campaign detected by Abnormal Security attempts to steal Outlook credentials through a Google Mail merge lure.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Abnormal Security published a brief report on a recent phishing campaign targeting Outlook credentials. The initial lure claims that there is an attempt to merge a new email address into the recipient's Google account and that the recipient should decline the request if they don't recognize the email address. Visiting the decline request link leads to a convincing Google page asking the user to validate the activity. Following through on this prompt leads to the final landing page, a fake Outlook Web App login page, which will exfiltrate gathered credentials to the attacker if submitted. For more information, see the Abnormal Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://abnormalsecurity.com/blog/google-mail-merge-impersonation/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Active Cryptomining Campaign by Romanian Threat Group
A likely Romanian threat group has been actively performing cryptoming campaigns since 2020. Bitdefender reports on the group's toolkit, which includes a previously unreported SSH bruteforcer.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

Bitdefender published a blog post detailing an active cryptomining campaign carried out by a threat group they believe is based in Romania. The initial infection vector used by the group is brute forcing of SSH credentials. A limited number of source IPs for these brute force attacks indicates that compromised systems are not being used for spreading to other victims in a wormable fashion. Bitdefender found the group's full toolset when they discovered a C2 server hosting an open directory containing loader observed in a cryptomining attack. Along with loaders, this directory contained a Demonbot variant and bash scripts for propagating it, a Perl IRC bot, reconnaissance tools, and more. The loaders are obfuscated using a shell compiled (shc) and use Discord for C2 communication. Another tool that is highlighted by Bitdefender is a previously unreported SSH brute forcer written in Golang. The use of an API key to execute the tool suggest is operates on an "as-a-service" model. The attackers implement various persistence mechanisms, including a service, cron job, new sudo users, and adding SSH keys to the authorized_keys file. Ultimately, the threat actors use their access to deploy a cryptominer, specifically the XMRig Monero miner. For more information, see the Bitdefender blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.bitdefender.com/blog/labs/how-we-tracked-a-threat-group-running-an-active-cryptojacking-campaign>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: ICS-CERT Advisories May 11 2021
The ICS-CERT has published fifteen advisories that affect Omron CX-One, Mitsubishi Electric GOT and Tension Controller, and a number of Siemens products.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarized below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-131-01 - Omron CX-One**  
CVE-2021-27413 - The affected product is vulnerable to a stack-based buffer overflow, which may allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-131-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-131-02 - Mitsubishi Electric GOT and Tension Controller**  
CVE-2021-20589 - An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to cause a denial-of-service condition in the MODBUS/TCP server communication function of GOT2000 series, GOT SIMPLE series, SoftGOT2000 and Tension Controller.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.9 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-131-02>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-131-03 - Siemens Linux Based Products**  
CVE-2020-25705 - A flaw in ICMP packets in the Linux kernel may allow an attacker to quickly scan open UDP ports. ICS-CERT Advisories May 11 2021
The ICS-CERT has published fifteen advisories that affect Omron CX-One, Mitsubishi Electric GOT and Tension Controller, and a number of Siemens products.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Phishing and Malspam with Leaf PHPMailer
PHP scripts hosted on compromised sites are one method of carrying out mass sending of malspam emails. Sucuri has observed the Leaf PHPMailer being used for this purpose in malspam and phishing campaigns.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Phishing and Malspam with Leaf PHPMailer
PHP scripts hosted on compromised sites are one method of carrying out mass sending of malspam emails. Sucuri has observed the Leaf PHPMailer being used for this purpose in malspam and phishing campaigns.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing, Malspam




# Overview

Sucuri has published a blog post analyzing a hacktool being used for the mass distribution of phishing and malspam emails. This tool, Leaf PHPMailer, is being installed by attackers on compromised web servers. Once installed, an attacker can configure a number of fields, such as the spoofed sender email address and name, the subject, the body of the email, and the list of recipients. With these fields configured, the emails, which may be phishing or malspam, are sent to the list of recipients. Leaf PHPMailer also includes a blacklist checker tool to ensure that the compromised web server hosting the mailer has not appeared on any common blacklists. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section. 

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2021/01/phishing-malspam-with-leaf-phpmailer.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Mirai's New Variant Called Katana
Avira's IoT research team has identified a developing botnet based on Mirai they have labeled "Katana."
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet



# Overview

In 2016, the source code for the malware Mirai was released. Since then, a number of variants have emerged based on the work of enterprising hackers. Avira's IoT research team has identified a variant they have labeled "Katana". Functionality of this variant includes "layer 7 DDoS, different encryption keys for each source, fast self-replication, and secure C&C." Avira also indicates that a link to an HTTP banking botnet may be on the horizon. Exploitation attempts on LinkSkys and GPON routers are based on remote code execution and command injection vulnerabilities. Avira discovered that URLs that required authentication to access, the mere act of adding "?images" allowed the hacker to bypass authentication and gain control of the device. In some LinkSys attacks, a vulnerable CGI script, tmUnblock.cgi, that contains multiple security vulnerabilities that was the focus of the attack. In other cases, where the RealTek SDK was used to create the miniigd deamon, command injection attacks were used on the UPnP SOAP interface. For full technical details, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/32146729/Mirai%27s%20New%20Variant%20Called%20Katana%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1603898736144&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.avira.com/en/blog/katana-a-new-variant-of-the-mirai-botnet>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Chimera's Abuse of Cloud Services
Chimera is a threat actor focused on stealing sensitive data from victim networks, often maintaining a presence for extended period of time. Fox-IT reports on the group's abuse of cloud services in recent campaigns.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

Fox-IT has published a report focusing on Chimera's use of cloud services in recent campaigns against semiconductor and aviation organizations. There are consistent tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) used by the threat actor across all their intrusions, including their method of initial access. The actor begins by using compromised usernames and passwords in a password spraying attack against remote services, such as webmail. Once valid credentials are identified, they are used to access a remote access service, such as a VPN to obtain a foothold in the victim network. Password spraying attacks continue against administrator accounts identified on the victim host. Finally, with an administrator account compromised, a Cobalt Strike beacon is installed to be used for remote access instead of the initial remote access service that was abused. Scans are performed for network discovery, such as identifying proxy settings, hosts, services, and shares. Lateral movement occurs to compromise other hosts of interest, such as domain controllers, and obtain domain administrator credentials. On each victim host another Cobalt Strike beacon is installed; however, no persistence mechanism exists, so if the system is rebooted, the Cobalt Strike beacon will quit. Once lateral movement is complete, data of interest, such as intellectual property, emails, and personally identifiable information, on each host is identified and prepared for exfiltration. In some cases exfiltration occurs via the Cobalt Strike beacon, but in most cases the data is compressed with WinRAR and uploaded to an attacker-controlled cloud storage account, such as OneDrive. After the initial exfiltration, the attacker will periodically return to identify new files and accounts of interest and perform the same process. For more information, see the Fox-IT blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.fox-it.com/2021/01/12/abusing-cloud-services-to-fly-under-the-radar/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: XLL Malware Techniques
After observing a spike in the use of Microsoft Excel add-in (XLL) files to drop malware on systems, HP has published a report detailing various techniques used to develop these droppers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Dropper
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Non-specific
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unknown
  *  **Targets:** Non-specific
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious XLL file
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Install malware



# Overview

HP has published a blog post analyzing the use of Microsoft Excel add-in (XLL) files to install malware on victim systems. There are three methods they identify being used to develop such malware. The first method observed involved the sale of a builder on underground forums. Purchase of the builder allows its user to specify a payload to embed or download along with a decoy file to display. The second method and, most used in the analyzed samples, is the use of Excel-DNA, a legitimate software project. .NET-developed code is stored in a resource and used to download and execute a malicious payload. Lastly, some samples used custom-generated add-ins as opposed to a builder or the use of Excel-DNA. The details of how the custom code operates can be found in the blog post. Eventually, API functions are used to download and execute a remotely hosted payload. For more information, see the HP blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057160/XLL%20Malware%20Techniques%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642609237073&api=v2)



# Protection

## Yara Rule
    
    
    {  
      meta:  
        description = "XLL Custom Builder"  
        author = "patrick.schlapfer@[hp.com](http://hp.com)"  
        date = "2022-01-07"  
      
      strings:  
        $str1 = "xlAutoOpen"  
        $str2 = "test"  
        $op1 = { 4D 6B C9 00 }  
        $op2 = { 4D 31 0E }  
        $op3 = { 49 83 C6 08 }  
        $op4 = { 49 39 C6 }  
      
      condition:  
        uint16(0) == 0x5A4D and all of ($str*) and all of ($op*) and filesize < 10KB  
    }

# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Perform endpoint scans using the provided Yara rules.



# References

  * <https://threatresearch.ext.hp.com/how-attackers-use-xll-malware-to-infect-systems/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1137 - Office Application Startup  
T1137.006 - Add-ins

        $op1 = { 4D 6B C9 00 }  
        $op2 = { 4D 31 0E }  
        $op3 = { 49 83 C6 08 }  
        $op4 = { 49 39 C6 }  
      
      condition:  
        uint16(0) == 0x5A4D and all of ($str*) and all of ($op*) and filesize < 10KB  
    }

# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Perform endpoint scans using the provided Yara rules.



# References

  * <https://threatresearch.ext.hp.com/how-attackers-use-xll-malware-to-infect-systems/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1137 - Office Application Startup  
T1137.006 - Add-ins

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR21-055A
A Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency malware analysis report, AR21-055A, has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System. The report provides information on the webshell which is designed to be uploaded to an Accellion File Transfer Appliance (FTA) server.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR21-055A
A Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency malware analysis report, AR21-055A, has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System. The report provides information on the webshell which is designed to be uploaded to an Accellion File Transfer Appliance (FTA) server.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Webshell




# Overview

This Malware Analysis Report (MAR) analyzes a malicious Hypertext Preprocessor (PHP) webshell file submitted to CISA for analysis. The webshell is designed to be uploaded to an Accellion File Transfer Appliance (FTA) server, a secure file transfer application used by customers to send large files. The webshell leverages a Structured Query Language (SQL) injection vulnerability to install itself onto the impacted FTA server. The webshell provides threat actors with the ability to locate files, obtain file metadata, and download files stored on the Accellion FTA server.

This webshell has been used in recent cyberattacks targeting users of Accellion FTA. For more information on these attacks, refer to Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA21-055A.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 
  * IoCs can also be download in STIX format from CISA: <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/sites/default/files/publications/MAR-10325064.r1.v1.WHITE_stix.xml>



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-055a>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Google Ads Used to Steal Cryptocurrency
MetaMask users are finding Ethereum cryptocurrency is disappearing in a phishing scam using Google Search ads. BleepingComputer has the latest on this emerging threat.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing, Cryptocurrency




# Overview

MetaMask, a cryptocurrency wallet company, has found itself on the receiving end of an attack on its users. A phishing attack using Google Search ads is making the rounds on unsuspecting users. The site offers Ethereum users a cryptocurrency wallet in a web browser plugin from which funds are disappearing. The attack uses a Google ad that masquerades as an advertisement for the MetaMask site. At present, it is unclear how many users have been affected. Some users have found their cryptocurrency wallets completely empty. These losses for some totaled in the thousands of dollars. The campaign is still ongoing and new domains are being promoted by these Google search ads. MetaMask posted a Twitter message to users to stay away from sponsored search ads. Upon visiting the sponsored ad, users are presented with a prompt to install the browser extension from "MetaMask," which gives the option to import a current wallet or open a new wallet. If the user chooses to create a new wallet, they are redirected to the legitimate MetaMask site since there is no money to steal. If the user imports a wallet, they're asked to enter their existing key phrase. This information is sent to the attacker which then allows the attacker to steal some or all currency in the specified wallet. The only difference between the spoof site and the legitimate site is the writing on the button for obtaining the extension, unnoticeable by most users. More information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/metamask-phishing-steals-cryptocurrency-wallets-via-google-ads/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: QRadar SIEM Security Bulletin Addresses Apache ZooKeeper Information Disclosure Vulnerability
A Security Bulletin for IBM QRadar SIEM addresses an information disclosure vulnerability in the version of Apache ZooKeeper distributed with QRadar.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
A vulnerability, CVE-2019-0201, in the version of Apache ZooKeeper distributed with QRadar could potentially allow a remote attacker to obtain sensitive information. The vulnerability is caused by the failure of the getACL() command to check certain permissions and can be exploited using a specially-crafted request. Further details, including affected versions and updates, are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/30769839/QRadar%20SIEM%20Security%20Bulletin%20Addresses%20Apache%20ZooKeeper%20Information%20Disclosure%20Vulnerability%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1600833371696&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/6335235>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Winter Vivern Campaign
A Lithuanian-language document led DomainTools researchers to discover a campaign, dubbed "Winter Vivern," targeting users in a variety of countries with a malicious PowerShell script.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Winter Vivern Campaign
A Lithuanian-language document led DomainTools researchers to discover a campaign, dubbed "Winter Vivern," targeting users in a variety of countries with a malicious PowerShell script.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

DomainTools published a blog post analyzing the infrastructure and malware behind a maldoc campaign dubbed "Winter Vivern." Their findings began with a Lithuanian-language document that leverages XLM 4.0 macros. The document masquerades as a contact sheet for Lithuanian government organizations. The macros within the document, when enabled, retrieve a PowerShell script from a remote server. The PowerShell script, in turn, is executed via a scheduled task file. The script is responsible for sending system information to its C2 server and checking for commands to be executed. The attacker could hypothetically use this to download a next-stage payload onto the system for further malicious activities. By pivoting on the C2 domain used by this malware, the researchers were able to find additional documents targeting a variety of countries, including Azerbaijan, Cyprus, India, Italy, Lithuania, Ukraine, and the Vatican. Two separate C2 domains were identified with one registered in December 2020 and the other in April 2021. These dates align with the dates the malicious documents were first seen. For more information, see the DomainTools blog post in the Reference section. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.domaintools.com/resources/blog/winter-vivern-a-look-at-re-crafted-government-maldocs>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: P.A.S. Fork v. 1.0
A blog from Sucuri has an analysis of the P.A.S. Fork V. 1.0, a PHP web shell that originally appeared in 2013.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: P.A.S. Fork v. 1.0
A blog from Sucuri has an analysis of the P.A.S. Fork V. 1.0, a PHP web shell that originally appeared in 2013.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Sucuri has published a blog with information on P.A.S. Fork V 1.0. A version of the PHP web shell has been making the rounds since at least late 2016 when DHS and the FBI issued a joint report (linked below) on the malware with several IoCs for detection of the web shell. The initial version of the web shell was retired in 2013 due to accusations made against the authors of the shell. The latest variant was first seen in January 2020 in a new thread on a forum. Interest in the P.A.S. web shell was renewed after disclosure of new capabilities. These capabilities were mainly related to evasion tactics to avoid detection from web application firewalls and IDS systems. First verifiable usage of the new version came in March 2020 on a compromised website. Other changes included a different packer/obfuscator and the addition of random ASCII characters, which makes the PHP code difficult to read without proper editing tools. By removing the added strings, analysis could more easily be performed. Other modifications exist and can be seen by comparing older versions with the newest in a side-by-side editor. Backdoor commands are contained within the attacker's HTTP request as cookies. Hash values are set to facilitate obfuscation and are applied to a string containing the server IP and backdoor file. Hashed passwords can also be encoded. Further details can be found in the blog post located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/10/p-a-s-fork-v-1-0-a-web-shell-revival.html>

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/sites/default/files/publications/JAR_16-20296A_GRIZZLY%20STEPPE-2016-1229.pdf>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Ficker Stealer
Ficker Stealer is an information stealing malware that appeared in 2020. Quick Heal has published a brief blog post detailing an analyzed sample and its infection chain.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Ficker Stealer
Ficker Stealer is an information stealing malware that appeared in 2020. Quick Heal has published a brief blog post detailing an analyzed sample and its infection chain.

is an information stealing malware that appeared in 2020. Quick Heal has published a brief blog post detailing an analyzed sample and its infection chain.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Infostealer




# Overview

Quick Heal published a blog post analyzing the  malware family. This information stealer has been observed being distributed via a number of techniques, such as email attachments, online advertisements, crack tools, and as a payload for the Hancitor malware. The sample analyzed for this blog post was an Excel spreadsheet, likely delivered via phishing email. Inside this XSLM file was a XLS macro that, once enabled, is used to create a new folder and download a remote payload to that folder. The downloaded executable is the main Ficker stealer payload. The payload is decrypted and executed in memory. Once on the system, the victim IP address is obtained and the C2 address is contacted. Commands are retrieved from the C2 to steal sensitive data and exfiltrate it to the attacker. This data can include browser credentials, Putty session information, messaging accounts, cryptocurrency wallets, and more. For more information, see the Quick Heal blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.quickheal.com/ficker-an-info-stealer-malware-that-tricks-people-to-get-their-passwords/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: REvil Sideloading DLL
The REvil ransomware has been using a legitimate Microsoft binary that sideloads a malicious DLL to carry out file encryption according to a report from McAfee Labs.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

McAfee Labs has located samples of a REvil dropper that has two PE files embedded in the resource section. One of the files, MsMpEng.exe is a legitimate, signed Microsoft binary. The second file is a malicious DLL that is sideloaded using MsMpEng.exe. The ransomware config is encrypted using RC4. The language and keyboard layout are checked against a list of mostly eastern European countries and if a match is found, files are not encrypted. The config contains a list of services and processes, if found, the matching services are deleted and processes terminated. Files are then encrypted using the Salsa20 algorithm and the system's backdrop is set to display instructions to locate the ransom note left on the system. Further details are available from the report in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.mcafee.com/blogs/other-blogs/mcafee-labs/revil-ransomware-uses-dll-sideloading/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Povlsomware Ransomware
Povlsomware markets itself as a proof-of-concept (POC) ransomware designed to test security vendor products. Trend Micro reports on some interesting capabilities associated with the malware.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing the Povlsomware ransomware. This ransomware is open-source, hosted on GitHub, and advertises itself as a proof-of-concept (POC) designed to test security vendor products. It operates much like most ransomware families, deleting backups, encrypting user files while avoiding system directories, and displaying a ransom note to the victim. Interestingly, the ransomware does not append a new extension to the encrypted file names, so the files do not look different when viewed in a directory. One of the most significant features of this ransomware that the researchers note is particularly concerning is its compatibility with Cobalt Strike. Specifically, it is capable of being executed by Cobalt Strike's execute-assembly function, which allows a payload to be run through memory from a Cobalt Strike server without dropping a payload onto the victim system. This decreases the chances of detection and analysis. Due to its purpose as a POC tool, the code does not include any capabilities to spread across a network or destroy devices, but its open-source nature could allow a malicious actor to add that functionality. While there is no evidence of this ransomware being used in the wild by malicious threat actors, its public availability presents the threat of such activity. For more information, see the Trend Micro article in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/c/povlsomware-ransomware-features-cobalt-strike-compatibility.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: BlackTech Employing Flagpro in Campaign
A campaign using a new malware dubbed Flagpro and employed by BlackTech is targeting some Japanese companies and has been observed by NTTSecurity.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: BlackTech Employing Flagpro in Campaign
A campaign using a new malware dubbed Flagpro and employed by BlackTech is targeting some Japanese companies and has been observed by NTTSecurity.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Downloader, Dropper/Loader, Exfiltration
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** BlackTech
  *  **Associated Payloads:**
  *  **Targets:** Japanese Defense, Media, Communications
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing Email Attachment
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Download and execute tools, execute OS commands, collect authentication information



# Overview

Since at least October 2020, NTTSecurity has observed a campaign by threat actor BlackTech using a malware dubbed Flagpro targeting various Japanese businesses. Using a phishing email as the delivery mechanism, the malware is used during the initial stages of the attack. During this phase, a second stage malware is downloaded and executed. Attached to the email is a password-protected archive file containing an XLSM file. The password is in the phishing email. The XLSM file is tailored to each victim, lending plausibility to the attacker researching its victims. If macros are enabled in the XLSM file, malware is dropped and an EXE file is written to the Startup directory. This file is the Flagpro malware. Communication takes place with a C2 server and commands are sent from the C2 to Flagpro. Checks are made for furtherance of malicious activity based on the environment being attacked. Should the environment meet the standard for additional manipulation, more malware is downloaded and executed. The main functions of the malware are to download and execute a tool, execute OS commands and report results, and to collect and send Windows authentication information. Further technical details can be found in the analysis located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056637/BlackTech%20Employing%20Flagpro%20in%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641411311047&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction. (M1017)
  * Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc. (M1021)
  * Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts. (M1022)
  * Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries. (M1031)
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking. (M1038)
  * Protect sensitive information with strong encryption. (M1041)
  * Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping. (M1043)
  * Use A/V and IDS/IPS signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software. (M1049)
  * Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data. (M1057)



# References

  * <https://insight-jp.nttsecurity.com/post/102hf3q/flagpro-the-new-malware-used-by-blacktech>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

  
 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1591 - Gather Victim Org Information  
T1592 - Gather Victim Host Information  
T1592.002 - Software  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.002 - At (Windows)  
T1072 - Software Deployment Tools  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1037 - Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts  
T1037.005 - Startup Items  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Supply‑Chain Attack Against a Certification Authority in Southeast Asia
In December, researchers at ESET assessed a supply-chain attack targeting a certification authority site linked to a government in Southeast Asia.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Supply‑Chain Attack Against a Certification Authority in Southeast Asia
In December, researchers at ESET assessed a supply-chain attack targeting a certification authority site linked to a government in Southeast Asia.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

According to researchers at ESET, threat actors exploited two software installers on the Vietnam Government Certification Authority site in order to dupe end-users and implant a backdoor known as, PhantomNet, to imitate malicious attacks. Initial entry of the attack begins once the trojanized installer is downloaded along with the legitimate program to elude malicious intent, a dropper then extracts a Windows file containing the backdoor, PhantomNet malware and lastly the backdoor is utilized to retrieve the victim’s proxy configuration and use it to reach out to the C2 server. According to the researchers, the backdoor is likely utilized for lateral movement and integrating the malicious plugins Invoke-MimiKatz to collect sensitive machine and user account information. Furthermore, signifying PhantomNet's capability to host and utilize complex plugins. Although visibility on the operators behind the attacks remain low, researchers at ESET, have concluded that supply-chain attacks continue to rise as they become more common vectors of compromise for cyberespionage groups. For more information, see the We Live Security article in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

According to researchers at ESET, threat actors exploited two software installers on the Vietnam Government Certification Authority site in order to dupe end-users and implant a backdoor known as, PhantomNet, to imitate malicious attacks. Initial entry of the attack begins once the trojanized installer is downloaded along with the legitimate program to elude malicious intent, a dropper then extracts a Windows file containing the backdoor, PhantomNet malware and lastly the backdoor is utilized to retrieve the victim’s proxy configuration and use it to reach out to the C2 server. According to the researchers, the backdoor is likely utilized for lateral movement and integrating the malicious plugins Invoke-MimiKatz to collect sensitive machine and user account information. Furthermore, signifying PhantomNet's capability to host and utilize complex plugins. Although visibility on the operators behind the attacks remain low, researchers at ESET, have concluded that supply-chain attacks continue to rise as they become more common vectors of compromise for cyberespionage groups. instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: LNKR Malware Spread Through Malicious Chrome Extensions
Netskope Threat Labs have published an analysis of the LNKR malware used to spy on victims and serve potentially malicious ads into their browsers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: LNKR Malware Spread Through Malicious Chrome Extensions
Netskope Threat Labs have published an analysis of the LNKR malware used to spy on victims and serve potentially malicious ads into their browsers.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Adware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** LNKR
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Google Chrome Extension
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Exfiltrate data, Ad injection



# Overview

Netskope Threat Labs have discovered a campaign using malware known as LNKR. First seen in 2019, the malware allows the actors to inject adverts into the victim's browser. In 2021, this campaign is still active and is more malicious than other types of adware. In addition to ad injection, the malware allows the threat actors to exfiltrate search data, redirect the user to any other page, and inject javascript from external sources. This last function is particularly dangerous, as the attacker can inject any script into the page, such as a script to steal credit card data. The malware is normally distributed through malicious Google Chrome extensions. The malware is also able to self replicate by injecting itself into web pages where the user has write permissions. Once the user is infected, the malware collects data on the user's search and shopping habits and exfiltrates that to a C2 server. This information is used to inject ads and to monetize the user's browsing activity. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155229/LNKR%20Malware%20Spread%20Through%20Malicious%20Chrome%20Extensions%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637933733101&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc (M1021).
  * Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries (M1031).
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038).
  * Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software (M1033).



# References

  * <https://www.netskope.com/blog/black-friday-is-coming-and-lnkr-malware-might-be-watching-you>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1176 - Browser Extensions  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: XML Vulnerabilities in Go's Standard Library
Mattermost has responsibly disclosed three XML vulnerabilities in Go's standard library.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

Mattermost, working with Go's security team, has responsibly disclosed three XML vulnerabilities in Go's standard library. These include an XML attribute instability (CVE-2020-29509), an XML directive instability (CVE_2020-29510), and an XML element instability (CVE-2020-29511). In essence, if your application is processing information that has already gone through Go's decoder and encoder functions at least one time before, the application may be processing invalid data, since Go's decoder and encoder does not preserve the semantics of the data. The lack of integrity is a major issue in applications that require absolute semantic integrity in order to be secure, such as SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language). The notification indicates that the Go team cannot, at this time, reliably and reasonably address the issues. Only one of the issues is on the Go roadmap to be addressed in the foreseeable future. Mattermost is releasing an XML validation library that can be used as a workaround until a full patch can be released. For more details, please refer to the disclosure notification in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [XML Vulnerabilities in Gos Standard Library CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35718356/XML%20Vulnerabilities%20in%20Gos%20Standard%20Library%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1608064748127&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * https://mattermost.com/blog/coordinated-disclosure-go-xml-vulnerabilities/
