instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Malicious Redirects via Bogus WordPress Plugin
While investigating a series of WordPress sites performing malicious redirects, Sucuri researchers discovered a redirector and webshell installed the compromised sites.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor, Webshell




# Overview

Sucuri published a blog post analyzing a campaign infecting compromised WordPress sites with two payloads, a redirector, and a webshell. The infection begins with the attackers compromising the wp-admin administration panel, likely via weak passwords. Once on the system, they install their malware via the plugin upload feature. The first plugin is a redirector, masquerading as "PHP Everywhere," that sends visitors of the site to malicious domains. These domains stood out due to their use of punycode characters. The second plugin installed is a backdoored version of the Log HTTP Requests plugin. The modified version includes the addition of FilesMan webshell code, providing attackers with full control of the file system. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2021/06/malicious-redirects-through-bogus-plugin.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Magniber Ransomware Evolving To Infect Chrome and Edge
The ransomware Magniber has historically only infected Internet Explorer. A report by the ASEC analysis team details how the ransomware is now infecting users of Google Chrome and Microsoft Edge.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Magniber Ransomware Evolving To Infect Chrome and Edge
The ransomware Magniber has historically only infected Internet Explorer. A report by the ASEC analysis team details how the ransomware is now infecting users of Google Chrome and Microsoft Edge.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Magniber
  *  **Targets:** Users of Chrome, Edge, and IE.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing Sites
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encyrption and Extortion



# Overview

The ASEC analysis team has been tracking the ransomware known as Magniber and its distribution methods. This ransomware is traditionally spread by exploiting Internet Explorer vulnerabilities and continues to be spread in this way. However, Magniber has recently been seen on both Microsoft Edge and Google Chrome. When the distribution pages are navigated to on these browsers, the user is asked to install an APPX file which is supposed to update the browser. Interestingly, the APPX file for both browsers contains a valid certificate, so the installation is allowed to go ahead. The result of this operation is a malicious executable and DLL file, which work together to download the ransomware and execute it in memory. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056966/Magniber%20Ransomware%20Evolving%20To%20Infect%20Chrome%20and%20Edge%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642174506730&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Ensure extensions that are installed are the intended ones as many malicious extensions will masquerade as legitimate ones (M1047).
  * Application control may be able to prevent the running of executables masquerading as other files (M1038).



# References

  * <https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/30645/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism  
T1548.002 - Bypass User Account Control  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Iranian Government-Sponsored APT Actor Exploiting Vulnerabilities
A joint alert (AA21-321A) from the United State's FBI and CISA, Australia's Cyber Security Centre (ACSC), and the United Kingdom’s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) has been published. The alert warns of ongoing attacks from an Iranian government-linked APT actor.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Other
  *  **Targets:** Vulnerable Fortinet devices and Microsoft Exchange servers.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Mimikatz, WinPEAS, SharpWMI, and possibly other malware.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fortinet vulnerabilities CVE-2018-13379, CVE-2019-5591, and CVE-2020-12812. Microsoft Exchange ProyShell vulnerability CVE-2021-34473.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration, Extortion, Ransomware.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A joint alert (AA21-321A) from Australia's Cyber Security Centre (ACSC), the United Kingdom’s National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC), and the United State's FBI and CISA has been published. The alert warns of ongoing attacks from an Iranian government-sponsored APT actor that has a history of exploiting vulnerabilities in Fortinet devices ( CVE-2018-13379, CVE-2019-5591, and CVE-2020-12812) and a Microsoft Exchange server ProxyShell vulnerability (CVE-2021-34473). The alert notes that the actor is focused on exploiting vulnerable systems rather than targeting specific entities. To date, the actor has exploited systems in multiple U.S. and Australian critical infrastructure sectors. Post compromise activities conducted by the actor can include data exfiltration, extortion, or ransomware. Most recently, the actor has been exploiting the ProxyShell vulnerabilities to gain a foothold in systems for use in later operations. Further details, including CISA's list of mitigations, are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222695/Iranian%20Government-Sponsored%20APT%20Actor%20Exploiting%20Vulnerabilities%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637207733297&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa21-321a>

 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1098 - Account Manipulation  
T1136 - Create Account  
T1136.001 - Local Account  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.005 - Security Support Provider  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1134 - Access Token Manipulation  
T1134.005 - SID-History Injection  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1207 - Rogue Domain Controller  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1003.001 - LSASS Memory  
T1003.002 - Security Account Manager  
T1003.004 - LSA Secrets  
T1003.006 - DCSync  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1552.004 - Private Keys  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
T1555.004 - Windows Credential Manager  
T1558 - Steal or Forge Kerberos Tickets  
T1558.001 - Golden Ticket  
T1558.002 - Silver Ticket  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1550 - Use Alternate Authentication Material  
T1550.002 - Pass the Hash  
T1550.003 - Pass the Ticket  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1560 - Archive Collected Data  
T1560.001 - Archive via Utility  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**

T1048.001 - Exfiltration Over Symmetric Encrypted Non-C2 Protocol  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: HabitsRAT Used to Target Linux and Windows Servers
HabitsRAT is a simple backdoor identified to be targeting Microsoft Exchange servers by exploiting the ProxyLogon vulnerability. Intezer has discovered newer Windows variants as well as a Linux variant.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




Overview

Intezer published a blog post analyzing the HabitsRAT backdoor, which was previously observed exploiting the ProxyLogon vulnerability. With their discovery, they also found a Linux variant of the malware, although the exploit leveraged to deliver this version is unknown. The malware is written in Go, allowing the same main code base to be shared between the variants with separate files to handle operating system-specific code. Once on the system, it attempts to establish persistence via a systemd unit file on Linux or a scheduled task on Windows. C2 communication is rather sophisticated as it uses public-key cryptography for encryption and authentication. The C2 server is polled every 10 seconds to check whether a command should be executed. Along with version 11 of the malware, a version 12 was found for Windows, with a different C2 public key in use and support for multiple C2 addresses. For more information, see the Intezer blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/malware-analysis/habitsrat-used-to-target-linux-and-windows-servers/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Codecov Supply-Chain Attack Hacked
A software company specializing in auditing tools suffered an attack over the course of the the past four months and disclosed this month. Several news outlets have reported on the attack and the vulnerability used to exploit a zero-day vulnerability.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability, Breach




# Overview

An investigation by Codecov led to the discovery of a supply-chain attack that has been occurring since January 2021. The maker of auditing tools stated a threat actor had modified Bash Uploader script and exposed sensitive information contained within customers' continuous integration (CI) environment. The company provide tools used to help developers ascertain how much source code is actually executed during testing. The attackers used a changed script to deliver the sensitive information to a server outside the Codecov infrastructure. Sensitive information exfiltrated possibly includes credentials, tokens, keys, datastores, code, and git remote information. The company has urged customers to re-roll credentials, tokens, and keys in environment variables that relied upon the Bash Uploader. Customers have also been advised to inspect local versions of the script to locate line 525, a copy of which can be found in the links below, and remove any attacker placed code. Searches for the compromised script have been found in several thousand projects using the script. Codecov has provided a new version of the bash script for immediate implementation. Some of the clients affected include Proctor & Gamble, GoDaddy, The Washington Post, and Atlassian Corporation. Atlassian issued a statement that denied any evidence of impact to their company. A complete analysis of this incident has not revealed the impact and may not be known for several days or longer. Further details can be found in the links located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Install latest version of the aforementioned Bash Script provided by Codecov.



# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/popular-codecov-code-coverage-tool-hacked-to-steal-dev-credentials/>

  * <https://www.reuters.com/technology/us-investigators-probing-breach-san-francisco-code-testing-company-firm-2021-04-16/>
  * <https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-cyber-codecov-idUSKBN2C62XI>
  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/hundreds-of-networks-reportedly-hacked-in-codecov-supply-chain-attack/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Coinbase Phishing Attacks
Coinbase is a cryptocurrency exchange platform that is exponentially gaining users with the increased popularity in cryptocurrency. With this increased usage, Inky has discovered threat actors targeting Coinbase credentials in phishing attacks.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Coinbase Phishing Attacks
Coinbase is a cryptocurrency exchange platform that is exponentially gaining users with the increased popularity in cryptocurrency. With this increased usage, Inky has discovered threat actors targeting Coinbase credentials in phishing attacks.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Coinbase users
  *  **Lure** : Email from claiming Coinbase account actions are required
  *  **Payload** : Link to compromised site hosting phishing page
  *  **TTPs:** Spoofed sender, phishing link ([T1566.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/002/)), hosting on compromised site
  *  **Compromised data:** Coinbase login credentials

  *  **Post-compromise actions:** Unknown



# Overview

Inky published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign targeting users of Coinbase, a cryptocurrency exchange platform. The phishing email is sent from a compromised account and spoofs Coinbase, claiming that action is needed from the user to prevent their account from being disabled. The link contained in the body of the email leads to a hijacked website hosting a fake Coinbase login page. Submitting credentials via this page will exfiltrate the data to the attacker, giving them access to the Coinbase account, which may include cryptocurrency wallets, financial information, and other sensitive data. For more information, see the Inky blog post in the Reference section. 

# Recommendations

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
  * Enable multi-factor authentication (MFA) where possible.



# Reference

  * <https://www.inky.com/blog/rising-value-and-visibility-of-coinbase-attracts-impersonators>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Citrix Vulnerability Exploited To Deliver Webshell
Crowdstrike recently investigated an incident in which the threat actor PROPHET SPIDER exploited a vulnerability in Citrix software to deliver a webshell. The technical details of this have been published in a report.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Citrix Vulnerability Exploited To Deliver Webshell
Crowdstrike recently investigated an incident in which the threat actor PROPHET SPIDER exploited a vulnerability in Citrix software to deliver a webshell. The technical details of this have been published in a report.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Vulnerability
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** PROPHET SPIDER
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unknown
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Public Facing Infrastructure
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Further Tool Download



# Overview

Crowdstrike has published the details of an incident in which PROPHET SPIDER deployed a web shell. PROPHET SPIDER is a cybercriminal group that has been active since 2017. In this incident, they exploited a vulnerability in the Citrix ShareFile Storage Zones Controller service to upload code that will execute arbitrary commands. After infection, the actors tested the connection and then downloaded a reverse shell tool from GitHub. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/prophet-spider-exploits-citrix-sharefile/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1505.003 - Web Shell  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

Citrix Vulnerability Exploited To Deliver Webshell
Crowdstrike recently investigated an incident in which the threat actor PROPHET SPIDER exploited a vulnerability in Citrix software to deliver a webshell. The technical details of this have been published in a report.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Bidding on Federal Projects Used as Phishing Lure
A report from INKY provides an analysis of a phishing campaign they discovered which uses the lure of bidding on federal projects.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Bidding on Federal Projects Used as Phishing Lure
A report from INKY provides an analysis of a phishing campaign they discovered which uses the lure of bidding on federal projects.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Microsoft 365 and Google Workspace users.
  *  **Lure:** Bidding on federal projects.
  *  **Payload:** Credential harvesting page.
  *  **TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.
  *  **Compromised Data:** User email credentials.
  *  **Post-compromise Actions:** None specified.



# Overview

A threat actor used several lookalike and easily mistaken domains in a phishing campaign that used the lure of bidding on federal projects, according to a report from INKY. The campaign targeted Microsoft 365 and Google Workspace users with recipients receiving emails that were either spoofed to appear to be from the United States Department of Labor (DoL) or from lookalike domains. The emails had an attached PDF file, and both contained DoL branding elements. The link in the PDF led to the actual phishing site which was copied from the real DoL site. The victim would be presented with a set of instructions and if they clicked on the "Click here to bid" they were present with a page that asked them to log in with credentials from their Microsoft or another business email account. No matter what credentials were entered the victim would receive an error message stating their credentials were incorrect. On a second attempt, the victim would be redirected to the real DoL site. Credentials that were entered in the fake login page would have been delivered to the attacker. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057227/Bidding%20on%20Federal%20Projects%20Used%20as%20Phishing%20Lure%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642650172438&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.inky.com/blog/fresh-phish-phishers-lure-victims-with-fake-invites-to-bid-on-nonexistent-federal-projects>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1584.004 - Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: The Chronicles of Bumblebee Malware
Current reporting indicates that a new malware has been discovered. The new malware called “BumbleBee” has been the subject of a detailed report on the tactics, techniques, and procedures utilized to deploy BumbleBee. This malware is currently being utilized with a spearphishing campaign with the goal of injecting Cobalt Strike shellcodes to compromise victims' environments.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: The Chronicles of Bumblebee Malware
Current reporting indicates that a new malware has been discovered. The new malware called “BumbleBee” has been the subject of a detailed report on the tactics, techniques, and procedures utilized to deploy BumbleBee. This malware is currently being utilized with a spearphishing campaign with the goal of injecting Cobalt Strike shellcodes to compromise victims' environments.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type: Loader**
  *  **Associated Threat Actors: Conti Group, Initial Access Brokers**
  *  **Associated Payloads: Cobalt Strike**
  *  **Initial Infection Vector: Spearphishing**



# Overview

Reporting indicates that a new loader called “BumbleBee” is currently being utilized by the Conti ransomware group. There is also reporting that indicates that initial access brokers (IAB) are utilizing BumbleBee as a way to obfuscate activities. IABs are groups of cyber threat actors that gain initial access to vulnerable networks and then offer that access on DarkWeb forums.

In the past, these groups have utilized well-known loaders such as Trickbot, Bazarloader, and Emotet. All of these variants of loaders have been utilized to deliver Cobalt Strike, but Bumblebee is using DLL files to deliver the payload. As part of the campaign, the threat actors create fake employee email addresses, and fake websites, and utilize public storage services to deliver the malicious ISO image file. The ISO image file is responsible for luring the victim to execute the BumbleBee malware. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://elis531989.medium.com/the-chronicles-of-bumblebee-the-hook-the-bee-and-the-trickbot-connection-686379311056>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

####  **Tactics and Techniques:**

####  **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation

####  **Mitigations:**

####  **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

This malware is currently being utilized with a spearphishing campaign with the goal of injecting Cobalt Strike shellcodes to compromise victims' environments.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Linux Distributions Vulnerable to Account Escalation
A vulnerability in Polkit's pkexec component opens Linux distributions to local privilege escalation, Qualys researchers report.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Overview

A local privilege escalation vulnerability exists in nearly every Linux distribution. A memory corruption issue in polkit's pkexec allows for the exploitation of this vulnerability. Polkit is installed, by default, on every major Linux distribution and can allow any user to obtain root privileges on a victim computer. The researchers have verified the vulnerability, developed an proof-of-concept exploit, and executed the exploit. The result was full root privileges on distributions of Ubuntu, Debian, Fedora, and CentOS. Vulnerable for over 12 years, the potential for exploitation is far-reaching. Additionally, a video of the proof-of-concept exploit has been released. Red Hat has released mitigation measures to counter the vulnerability. It is unclear if this mitigation measure works on all affected Linux distributions. CVE-2021-4034 has been given a CVSS v3 score of 7.8 indicating a high security vulnerability. Further details including a code breakdown can be found in the source links located within the Reference section below.

# Vulnerability Details

### Type of Vulnerability (OS, Software, Hardware)

  * OS Vulnerability
  * Most Linux distributions vulnerable



### CVE Details

  * Memory Corruption in Polkit's pkexec utility
  * Can be used to gain root privileges for unprivileged accounts



### Proof of Concept

  * A proof-of-concept is available [here](https://vimeo.com/669715589?embedded=true&source=vimeo_logo&owner=42884007)



# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-4034



# Protection

  * Mitigation measures from Red Hat can be found here: [Red Hat Mitigation Measures.txt](/download/attachments/74057643/Red%20Hat%20Mitigation%20Measures.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1643232626799&api=v2)
    * NOTE: These measures may not work on all Linux distributions
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking. (M1038)
  * Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system. (M1048)
  * Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring. (M1050)
  * Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk. (1051)



# References

  * <https://blog.qualys.com/vulnerabilities-threat-research/2022/01/25/pwnkit-local-privilege-escalation-vulnerability-discovered-in-polkits-pkexec-cve-2021-4034>
  * <https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2021-4034>
  * [https://vimeo.com/669715589?embedded=true&source=vimeo_logo&owner=42884007](https://vimeo.com/669715589?embedded=true&source=vimeo_logo&owner=42884007)
  * <https://www.qualys.com/2022/01/25/cve-2021-4034/pwnkit.txt>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Malvertising Campaign on Top Adult Brand Websites
A recent malvertising campaign discovered by Malwarebytes attempts to redirect users of popular adult websites to browser locker websites.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malvertisting, Browser Locker




# Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post analyzing a malvertising campaign present on popular adult websites. The malicious ads were bought by fraudulent advertisers via TrafficJunky, the advertising company leveraged by PornHub and other popular adult brands. When a user attempts to play a video on an infected web page, they are directed to a fake dating site. The attackers set up a large number of these fake sites, although they provide no real functionality and still contain Lorem ipsum text filler. If users match the criteria specified by the attackers, a browser locker is triggered. This results in pop-ups claiming that spyware is installed on the victim host and that the user needs to call a support line for assistance. Often these support lines request a payment for assistance, leading to fraudulent charges. The message displayed is customized to the operating system, depending on if the visitor is using a Mac or Windows system. By investigating the infrastructure hosting the malicious domains, Malwarebytes was able to find a connection to another malvertiser operating in June 2019, indicating that this threat actor has been operating for an extended period of time. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/cybercrime/2021/02/malvertising-campaign-on-top-adult-brands-exposes-users-to-tech-support-scams/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: State of Texas Impersonation
A phishing campaign observed by Abnormal Security is impersonating the State of Texas in an attempt to obtain stolen goods for resale.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing, Fraud




# Overview

Abnormal Security has published a report of a recent phishing campaign impersonating Texas government agencies. The initial email spoofs the Texas Department of State Health Services (DSHS) and claims to be a request for quotation (RFQ). The researchers note that this email was sent via a VPN service to hide the identity of the attacker. Replies to the email will not be sent to the spoofed DSHS address but instead will be sent to a domain masquerading as the NYC government. The body contains a message requesting a quote for laptops and hard drives along with a PDF containing fake details. The delivery address is left as TBD presumably in an attempt to social engineer the recipient into requesting it. The goal of the attack is to convince the recipient to send the laptops and hard drives to the attacker without payment who would then sell the stolen goods for a profit. For more information, see Abnormal Security's blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://abnormalsecurity.com/blog/abnormal-attack-stories-state-of-texas-impersonation/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Vulnerabilities in Billing System Exploited By Ransomware Group
The Huntress ThreatOps team have traced a detected ransomware attack back to a previously unknown vulnerability in the BQE Web Suite. They have published the process of uncovering this, and more vulnerabilities in a blog post.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Vulnerability
  *  **Targets:** Engineering Firm
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Public-Facing Server
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Lateral Movement, Ransomware Deployment



# Overview

The Huntress ThreatOps team has discovered several vulnerabilities after a number of their ransomware canary files were tripped within a customer's network. Upon investigation, alerts were discovered concerning a service account used for an SQL server. The server in question hosted BQE Web Suite 2020, and the logs indicated that a foreign IP was repeatedly sending POST requests leading up to the initial compromise. With this information, the ThreatOps team downloaded a version of the BillQuick server and managed to recreate the victim's environment. With this, the researchers used the tool 'sqlmap' to test for SQL injection vulnerabilities. With this tool, the researchers discovered many vulnerabilities, including the one that led to the infection of this engineering firm. The researchers were able to use this vulnerability to dump sensitive databases and more severely, execute code remotely. This was how the attackers were able to access the network and deploy ransomware. The Huntress ThreatOps team has been liaising with the developers of BillQuick and is in the process of patching the discovered vulnerability. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [New Vulnerabilities in Billing System Being Exploited CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/68616960/New%20Vulnerabilities%20in%20Billing%20System%20Being%20Exploited%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635430309675&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Web Application Firewalls may be used to limit exposure of applications to prevent exploit traffic from reaching the application (M1050).



# References

  * <https://www.huntress.com/blog/threat-advisory-hackers-are-exploiting-a-vulnerability-in-popular-billing-software-to-deploy-ransomware>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.004 - Exploits  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: The LV Ransomware is Modified REvil Ransomware
A report from the Secureworks Counter Threat Unit provides an analysis of the LV ransomware which is found to be a modified version of the REvil Ransomware.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

A financially motivated threat group that Secureworks refers to GOLD NORTHFIELD is operating a ransomware package named LV. The Secureworks report notes that GOLD NORTHFIELD may begin operating a ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) offering. An investigation conducted by the Secureworks Counter Threat Unit has determined that LV is a modified version of the REvil ransomware. The modifications made to REvil suggest that GOLD NORTHFIELD does not have access to the REvil source code and has made the modifications using a hex editor. LV is packed using a basic crypter which stores the LV ransomware binary as RC4-encrypted data within a section of the code. As has become typical of ransomware operators, the group threatens to leak a victim's data should a ransom not be paid. Tor sites are used for victims to pay a ransom, and also to host leak sites. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.secureworks.com/research/lv-ransomware>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Anglicare Sydney - Ransomware Attack and Data Exfiltration
Breach / Leak Notification: The Sydney Anglican Diocese has reported a ransomware attack that affected Anglicare Sydney. Approximately 17GB of data was transmitted to a remote location during the attack.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Anglicare Sydney - Ransomware Attack and Data Exfiltration
Breach / Leak Notification: The Sydney Anglican Diocese has reported a ransomware attack that affected Anglicare Sydney. Approximately 17GB of data was transmitted to a remote location during the attack.

# Threat Type

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

  
"The cyber attack Anglicare Sydney has experienced is part of increased illegal cyber activity targeting the Australian health and aged care sectors alongside other sectors seeking to obtain funds via ransomware activity. Anglicare Sydney had an incident response plan in place for this type of scenario whereby we could remediate with off-site backup systems and would not entertain engaging with cyber criminals. Once the cyber attack was detected, Anglicare Sydney immediately embarked on remediation and investigation including the engagement of cyber security experts. A formal forensic investigation by third parties is still ongoing. At this stage, there is no current evidence that data has been stolen. We have identified 17GB of data transmission to a remote location and this forms part of the forensic investigation in progress. It is therefore premature to speculate on the impact."

# Reference

  * <https://www.anglicare.org.au/about-us/media-releases/statement-from-anglicare-sydney-19-september-2020/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: SolarWinds Serv-U Software Exploited in the Wild
Microsoft discovered a 0-day vulnerability in SolarWinds Serv-U being exploited in the wild. The vulnerability was reported to SolarWinds who released a hotfix on July 9 that addresses the vulnerability.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * RCE




# Overview

A 0-day vulnerability in SolarWinds Serv-U that was being exploited in the wild was discovered by Microsoft. SolarWinds, who released a hotfix to address the vulnerability on July 9, reports that the vulnerability affects Serv-U Managed File Transfer and Serv-U Secure FTP, all versions, prior to and including, 15.2.3 HF1, which was the most recent version. Successfully exploited, the vulnerability could allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code, with privileges. Microsoft describes the observed exploitation to be of a limited nature that targeted the U.S. Defense Industrial Base Sector, and software companies. The attacks are attributed to a group operating from China that Microsoft refers to as DEV-0322. It's noted that the DEV-0322 infrastructure includes compromised consumer routers and uses services from commercial VPN providers. We recommend that users of the affected versions of Serv-U update to the fixed version immediately. Further information is available from the Microsoft and SolarWinds reports linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2021/07/13/microsoft-discovers-threat-actor-targeting-solarwinds-serv-u-software-with-0-day-exploit/>

  * <https://www.solarwinds.com/trust-center/security-advisories/cve-2021-35211>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: An Analysis of the Buer Loader
A report from Trend Micro Research provides an analysis of the Buer Loader malware.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Loader
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Multiple
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Ransomware, Cobalt Strike, other malware.
  *  **Targets:** Various
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious documents or Exploit Kit
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Payload deployment
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

The Buer Loader was originally written in C has been around since at least late 2019. In the second quarter of 2021, a new variant was observed that has been rewritten in the Rust language. Buer is known to have been used to deliver a range of malware payloads including TrickBot and Ryuk. Buer's deployment options are configurable using its control panel. Since August 2019 and through to the second quarter of 2021, the majority of Buer detections have been in India (40%) and Israel (30%) with the most affected industry sectors being banking, healthcare, and telecommunications. Buer has typically been delivered through malicious documents attached to emails or via an exploit kit such as Fallout. To help avoid detection and make analysis more difficult, Buer uses multiple techniques including obfuscation, time-based evasion, dummy code loops, and checks for sandboxes and analysis tools. In 2021, the most commonly used theme in Buer campaigns was the ubiquitous COVID-19. Perhaps the most common payloads of Buer in 2021 were ransomware or Cobalt Strike. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222342/An%20Analysis%20of%20the%20Buer%20Loader%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636525038521&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/content/dam/trendmicro/global/en/research/21/k/a-review-and-analysis-of-2021-buer-loader-campaigns/TechnicalBrief-An-Analysis-of-Buer-Loader.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1134 - Access Token Manipulation  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1497.001 - System Checks  
T1497.003 - Time Based Evasion  
T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
T1553.002 - Code Signing  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1012 - Query Registry  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1518.001 - Security Software Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1091 - Replication Through Removable Media  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: APT-C-35 Targeting Pakistani Military Personnel
APT-C-35 continues to target Pakistani victims with similar tactics in their most recent campaign. 360 Core Security reports on their updated payloads and the victimology of this campaign.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

360 Core Security has published a blog post analyzing recent APT-C-35 (aka DoNot) activities. Many aspects of the recent campaign align with the TTPs seen in their April 2020 attacks researchers previously reported. The APK analyzed in this blog post is delivered via a fake version of LoveHabibi, a Pakistani dating website. Based on open graph source code within the webpage it appears one method of distribution was via Facebook. Furthermore, install paths seen associated with the malware indicate another infection vector was WhatsApp messages. In terms of the payload, its data stealing functionality remains largely the same. The code, however, has been modified in a couple of aspects. Firstly, it now uses Base64 encoding of strings in the code in order to evade detection. Secondly, it uses retrofit2 and FireBase for C2 communication instead of Socket. The researchers hypothesize there may be hundreds of victims, with the main targets located in Pakistan and the Kashmir region. From what little stolen data could be analyzed, it appears a number of the victims have a military background. Furthermore, the activity aligns with a report from the Pakistani government regarding cyber attacks against the Pakistan Armed Forces. For more information, see the 360 Core Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.360.cn/post/APT-C-35_target_at_armed_forces_in_Pakistan.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Kinsing and NSPPS Malwares are the Same Family
A report from CyberArk looks at Kinsing and NSPPS which were thought to be two different families of malware. CyberArk's research concludes they are both from the same, single family.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Kinsing and NSPPS Malwares are the Same Family
A report from CyberArk looks at Kinsing and NSPPS which were thought to be two different families of malware. CyberArk's research concludes they are both from the same, single family.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

The Kinsing and NSPPS malwares were thought to be from two different families of malware. A report from CyberArk concludes they are both variants of the same family of malware. CyberArk believes the first version of the malware was compiled prior to November 2019, was used as a RAT and was named as NSPPS. When the malware was updated with new packages and included cryptomining functionality, it was named as Kinsing. The CyberArk report provides an analysis of the differences, and commonality between the analysed variants, to support their findings. The report is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.cyberark.com/resources/threat-research-blog/kinsing-the-malware-with-two-faces>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Remcos RAT Delivered via Visual Basic
Remcos RAT is leveraging new tactics in recent campaigns. Malwarebytes published a blog post detailing the new behaviors being observed.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Remcos RAT Delivered via Visual Basic
Remcos RAT is leveraging new tactics in recent campaigns. Malwarebytes published a blog post detailing the new behaviors being observed.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type** : RAT

  *  **Associated Threat Actors** : Unknown

  *  **Associated Payloads** : Remcos ([S0332](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332/))

  *  **Initial Infection Vector** : Finance-themed malspam ([T1566.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/001/))

  *  **Post-Compromise Actions** : Remote control, steal sensitive information

  *  **Additional TTPs** : PowerShell Scripts ([T1059.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001/)) Visual Basic Scripts ([T1059.005](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/005/)), Registry Run Keys/Startup Folder ([T1547.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1547/001/)), communication with Non-Standard Port ([T1571](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1571)), payloads hosted on Archive.org ([T1102](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1102/)), payload injected into aspnet_compiler.exe ([T1055.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055/002/))




# Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post detailing the most recent tactics being used by the Remcos RAT. The threat actors are still leveraging ZIP and IMG attachments on financially-themed malspam emails as an initial infection vector. These archives, however, now contain a Visual Basic script instead of an executable file. This script kicks off an infection chain that involves multiple stages of PowerShell downloading and executing additional obfuscated VB scripts. The final script is responsible for injecting an embedded PE file into aspnet_compiler.exe. The executable is the Remcos RAT, which provides its operator with the ability to fully control the victim system and steal sensitive information. The various Visual Basic scripts were all hosted on the legitimate Archive.org to evade detection. Additionally, all samples of the final payload called back to an IP address and port, but no C2 communication was observed. For more information, see the Malwarebyes blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-analysis/2021/07/remcos-rat-delivered-via-visual-basic/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Magniber Ransomware Now Targeting Windows 11
360 Total Security researchers have been tracking the distribution of Magniber ransomware. They have observed an attack occurring on a Windows 11 system, and a large uptick in attack volumes, which has been described in an article.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Magniber
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake Windows and Chrome updates, cracked software websites, fake pornographic websites.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encryption, Data Theft
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

360 Total Security researchers have reported seeing Magniber ransomware infections on Windows 11 machines. Previously, they reported Magniber ransomware being distributed as fake Windows 10 upgrade patch packages. The researchers also saw other .msi files with misleading names taking advantage of the pandemic to lure users into executing them. The volume of attacks using this method sharply increased in May 2022. Despite the large rise in volume, the malware actually hasn't evolved very much since before this campaign. The main difference in the latest variant is the ability to infect multiple Windows versions, including Windows 11. The malware uses RSA+AES encryption to encrypt files. The group uses the popular double-extortion method where they threaten to leak files as well as encrypting them for financial gain if the ransom isn't paid. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://blog.360totalsecurity.com/en/win11-users-beware-magniber-ransomware-has-been-upgraded-again-aiming-at-win11/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Electronic Arts Local Privilege Escalation Vulnerability
A vulnerability that exists within the Electronic Arts Origin Client was identified by Nettitude Labs. The vulnerability, if successfully exploited, could lead to local privilege escalation.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Electronic Arts Local Privilege Escalation Vulnerability
A vulnerability that exists within the Electronic Arts Origin Client was identified by Nettitude Labs. The vulnerability, if successfully exploited, could lead to local privilege escalation.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Nettitude Labs has disclosed a vulnerability they discovered while conducting a security review of the Electronic Arts (EA) Origin Client. The vulnerability, if exploited, could lead to a local privilege escalation to NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM. The vulnerability has been recorded as CVE-2020-27708. Origin allows 39 million users the ability to download and install games by the parent corporation, EA. In observing procmon from SysInternals, the team was able to see two system level services both looking for a missing directory, c:\platforms. The team created the directory and inspected procmon again. This time, several functions were observed including a directory listing of the newly created directory. Using ProcessHacker, the team inspected a process called "OriginWebHelperService.exe," which was running in the background. This service loads a DLL (qwindows.dll) from the created directory. Several issues arose during this process with the end result being two sections within the qwindows.dll standing out, .qtmetad and .gfids. Using their own malicious DLL, the team was able to escalate privileges using techniques from a white paper by Antonio Cocmazzi on breaking out of Local Service accounts. In essence, this vulnerability requires only a DLL path hijack for exploitation, which is a low-level exploitation technique. Vulnerable versions of the client are 10.5.77.42374 - 763270. The vendor has since patched the vulnerability with version 10.5.87.45080. We recommend applying this patch as soon as possible.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-27708

  * CVE-2020-16091



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://labs.nettitude.com/blog/cve-2020-27708-electronic-arts-ea-origin-local-privilege-escalation/>

  * <https://www.romhack.io/dl-2020/RH2020-slides-Cocomazzi.pdf>
  * <https://www.ea.com/security/news/easec-2020-002-elevation-of-privilege-vulnerability-in-origin-client>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Web Page Archive Files Used in Malware Distribution
Netskope Threat Labs has published a report on a campaign they have observed that is using Web Page Archive files in the distribution of malware.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Backdoor.
  *  **Targets:** Non-specific.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unnamed.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Likely phishing emails with an attached RAR file.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection, and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A campaign reported by Netskope Threat Labs is using Web Page Archive files (.mht, and .mhtml) in the distribution of malware. A .rar file that Netskope believes is likely delivered using phishing emails is the beginning of the infection chain. Inside the .rar file is a .mht file that in turn contains a malicious Word document. The document contains VBA code, which is password protected, and an embedded DLL disguised as a BMP file. Several actions are carried out by the VBA code including dropping the BMP file to disk then copies it to another location and renames it to background.dll. It also creates a new Word document which is a decoy displayed to the user and deletes the original document. The decoy document delivers a message that it cannot be opened due to the file being invalid. The VBA code uses one of two export functions, SaveProfile or OpenProfile, to execute the DLL. The DLL is then executed every ten minutes using a scheduled task named Winrar Update. The DLL unpacks and injects the final payload into another process. The payload in turn collects information about the system and then encrypts it and sends it to its C7C server. The campaign C&C servers are hosted on the cloud service, Glitch. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056994/Web%20Page%20Archive%20Files%20Used%20in%20Malware%20Distribution%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642387016707&api=v2)



# Detection

  * A Yara rule can be found here: [ Yara Rule.txt](/download/attachments/74056994/Web%20Page%20Archive%20Files%20Used%20in%20Malware%20Distribution%20Yara%20Rule.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642387031645&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).

  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).

  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.netskope.com/blog/abusing-microsoft-office-using-malicious-web-archive-files>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.006 - Web Services  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
T1560 - Archive Collected Data  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service  
T1567.002 - Exfiltration to Cloud Storage  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1102.002 - Bidirectional Communication  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: PseudoManuscrypt Malware
PseudoManuscrypt is a malware family being distributed in Korea since May 2021. ASEC has published a blog post detailing the malware's infection chain and functionality.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** RAT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** PseudoManuscrypt
  *  **Targets:** Korean users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake cracking and keygen software installers
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft, remote command execution



# Overview

ASEC published a blog post analyzing PseudoManuscrypt's infection chain and functionality. The malware is distributed in Korea via fake cracking and keygen software installers linked to in search results. The researchers note that this initial infection vector is similar to that leveraged by the Cryptobot malware, with additional overlaps present in the execution flow of the malware. The initial download is an NSIS installer that executes a 7z SFX archive. Within this archive are multiple executables including a dropper that continues the infection process. Ultimately, a loader is used to decode and execute shellcode stored in a .dat file. The shellcode is injected into memory and used to execute the malware. Persistence is established via a service. Once installed, PseudoManuscrypt is capable of gathering system information, network share, clipboard data, audio recordings, and more. This data is subsequently exfiltrated to a C2 server. The attacker can also issue further commands via the C2 server for activities such as file download and cmd command execution. For more information, see the ASEC blog post in the References section. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74059118/PseudoManuscrypt%20Malwre%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645472678600&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/31683/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Unknown Threat Actor Performing Aggressive Password Spraying Attacks
The Microsoft Threat Intelligence Center has outlined a new password spraying campaign seen targeting companies in the Middle East. This activity is being attributed to an unknown Iranian actor.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Reconnaissance
  *  **Targets:** Microsoft Exchange, Middle-East
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** o365spray
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

The Microsoft Threat Intelligence Center (MSTIC) has been tracking a potential new threat group they are currently calling DEV-0343. This group is performing extensive password spraying attacks on Office 365 tenants with a focus on US and Israeli defense companies, Persian Gulf ports of entry, or global maritime transportation companies with business presence in the Middle East. This behavior has led MSTIC to attribute this activity to Iran, as it matches previous techniques and targets of other actors based in Iran. The group tends to target two exchange endpoints - Autodiscover and ActiveSync - as a feature of the password spray tool they are using. The attacks come from an elaborate series of Tor IP addresses to hide their infrastructure and emulate a firefox browser to achieve this. They are seen to be most active between Sunday and Thursday during the daytime in Iranian time. On average, 150 to over 1000 Tor IPs are used in each attack against an organization. MSTIC has noted that accounts using multifactor authentication are resilient to these types of attacks. Due to the use of Tor IPs, IoCs are unavailable for these attacks. However, MSTIC has outlined several methods for detecting this campaign. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Enable multifactor authentication to mitigate compromised credentials (M1032). 
  * Block all incoming traffic from anonymizing services where possible (M1031).
  * Proactively reset accounts that are known to be part of breached credentials either immediately, or after detecting bruteforce attempts (M1018).
  * Set account lockout policies after a certain number of failed login attempts to prevent passwords from being guessed. Too strict a policy may create a denial of service condition and render environments un-usable, with all accounts used in the brute force being locked-out (M1036).



# References

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2021/10/11/iran-linked-dev-0343-targeting-defense-gis-and-maritime-sectors/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1110 - Brute Force  
T1110.003 - Password Spraying
