instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Western Digital My Cloud NAS Devices Security Vulnerabilities
Five security vulnerabilities were discovered by Comparitech researchers in Western Digital network-attached storage (NAS) devices. The vulnerabilities affect a large number of the devices globally.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Western Digital My Cloud NAS Devices Security Vulnerabilities
Five security vulnerabilities were discovered by Comparitech researchers in Western Digital network-attached storage (NAS) devices. The vulnerabilities affect a large number of the devices globally.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

Comparitech researches have published a paper on five vulnerabilities found in Western Digital network-attached storage (NAS) devices. If successfully exploited, the exploitation of these vulnerabilities could lead to remote code execution. Also possible is the ability to compromise data and files on a vulnerable device or allow the installation of malware on the device. An update for the device has been available since late October. A process to automatically update vulnerable devices is not present, so owners must manually apply the firmware update. For affected devices and descriptions of the CVEs, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33982559/Western%20Digital%20My%20Cloud%20NAS%20Devices%20Security%20Vulnerabilities%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1605553801714&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.comparitech.com/blog/information-security/security-vulnerabilities-80000-devices-update-now/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: FakeSecurity Operators Distributing Raccoon Stealer
The operators of the FakeSecurity JS-sniffer malware appear to be distributing the Raccoon stealer this year. Group-IB has published a report detailing four waves of this campaign.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Stealer




# Overview

Group-IB has published a report regarding a Raccoon stealer campaign believed to be tied to the FakeSecurity JS-sniffer operators. They observed four distinct waves of activity based on the TTPs leveraged across the campaign. The first wave uses either attachments with malicious macros or phishing pages created with the Mephistophilus phishing kit to infect users with the Vidar stealer. The second wave solely used Excel spreadsheets with malicious macros designed to download and execute the Raccoon stealer payload. Along with stealing sensitive data, this version of the Raccoon stealer also installed the AveMaria RAT to victim hosts. Notably, Raccoon was seen retrieving its C2 address from a Telegram channel. The third wave continued to use malicious macros in similarly-themed documents and also used Telegram and installed the AveMaria RAT. The distinction of this activity from the first wave is the use of a new set of domain registrations. Furthermore, researchers began to see the threat actor experimenting with the use of loaders, such as Buer and Smoke, to install Raccoon. Finally, in the fourth wave, the actor returned to also leveraging phishing pages built with Mephistophilus to distribute payloads. The targeting, timeline activity, use of Vidar and Mephistophilus (with an Adobe template), and the registrar used for registering the malicious domains leads Group-IB to conclude that the operators of FakeSecurity JS-sniffer are also running the Raccoon stealer campaigns. For more information, see Group-IB's blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.group-ib.com/blog/fakesecurity_raccoon>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Recent SharePoint-Themed Phish
A recent phishing campaign discovered by Cofense is using a SharePoint theme and successfully bypassing security email gateways.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense published a brief blog post discussing a SharePoint-themed phishing email successfully bypassing security email gateways. The content of the email claims someone has shared a document via SharePoint and provides a link to view it. While the content uses fake branding to appear legitimate, the sender and link are clear indicators that the email is not coming from a SharePoint server. Visiting the link leads to a login form on top of a blurred background requesting the user log in to view the document. If a user provides their credentials, the data is exfiltrated to the attacker while the user is redirected to a decoy document. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/sharing-documents-sharepoint/>

# Overview

Cofense published a brief blog post discussing a SharePoint-themed phishing email successfully bypassing security email gateways. The content of the email claims someone has shared a document via SharePoint and provides a link to view it. While the content uses fake branding to appear legitimate, the sender and link are clear indicators that the email is not coming from a SharePoint server. Visiting the link leads to a login form on top of a blurred background requesting the user log in to view the document. If a user provides their credentials, the data is exfiltrated to the attacker while the user is redirected to a decoy document. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/sharing-documents-sharepoint/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ICS-CERT Security Advisories - December 10th, 2020
ICS-CERT has released three security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in ICS-related devices and software.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview



ICSMA-20-345-01 addresses three vulnerabilities in MyCareLink (MCL) Smart Model 25000 Patient Reader devices. Types of vulnerabilities include improper authentication, buffer overflow, and race conditions. If successfully exploited, in combination these vulnerabilities, could allow an attacker to modify data or remotely execute code, allowing control of a cardiac device. Medtronic notes that exploitation must occur within Bluetooth proximity of the device.

ICSA-20-345-01 addresses an improper check or handling of exceptional conditions vulnerability in Mitsubishi Electric MELSEC iQ-F series modules that, if successfully exploited, could allow an attacker to cause a denial-of-service condition.

ICSA-20-345-02 addresses an improper input validation vulnerability in the Host Engineering H2-ECOM100 Module, which could allow an attacker to cause a denial-of-service condition.

We recommend reviewing the advisories in the Reference section for patches and mitigation advice.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35718025/ICS-CERT%20Security%20Advisories%20-%20December%2010th%2C%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1607620840681&api=v2)

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Conti Ransomware Overview
Conti is a new ransomware that is evolving rapidly. A recent Cybereason blog post provides an overview of the ransomware and its evolution.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Cybereason has published a blog post analyzing the Conti ransomware, which first emerged in May 2020. It has quickly increased in prevalence and evolved through three versions since its inception. Contii operates on a similar model to Egregor and Maze, stealing sensitive files as a double extortion attempt. Recently, Conti has partnered with TrickBot gang for distribution, replacing Ryuk as the group's ransomware of choice. The infection chains are the same as before, beginning with a phishing email pointing to a file hosted on Google Drive. This file is the Bazar backdoor, which allows the threat actors to perform reconnaissance, move laterally, and exfiltrate data. Eventually, the Conti ransomware is dropped onto the victim system. Conti's installation occurs through the loading of a DLL stored in the resources section of the initial payload into memory. Once running in memory, Conti leverages multi-threading to rapidly encrypt target files. Furthermore, it attempts to encrypt files on remote hosts by spreading over SMB. A deadline is provided to the users to pay the ransom and if it is not met, stolen files will be leaked on the Conti news website. For more information, see the Cybereason blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.cybereason.com/blog/cybereason-vs.-conti-ransomware>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: XcodeSpy Malware Targets Xcode Developers with EggShell Backdoor
A new macOS malware dubbed "XcodeSpy" is targeting Xcode developers. SentinelOne discovered this malware being used to deliver the EggShell backdoor.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: XcodeSpy Malware Targets Xcode Developers with EggShell Backdoor
A new macOS malware dubbed "XcodeSpy" is targeting Xcode developers. SentinelOne discovered this malware being used to deliver the EggShell backdoor.

# Threat Type

  * nMalware, Backdoor




# Overview

SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing the XcodeSpy malware. This malware targets Xcode developers using a Trojanized version of the "TabBarInteraction" Xcode project hosted on Github. In the build phase of this project, an obfuscated run script has been added to carry out malicious activities. Specifically, a hidden file is created in the /tmp directory to pipe a command via a reverse shell to the attacker's C2. Once C2 communication is established, the EggShell backdoor is dropped on the victim host and executed. It first creates persistence via a user LaunchAgent. When successfully installed on the host, the attacker can use this backdoor to download files, steal information, record the microphone, camera, and keyboard, and more. Based on VirusTotal file submissions and whois data for the C2 domains, this campaign was active from at least July to October 2020 and primarily targeted developers in Asia. SentinelOne believes that since there are associated EggShell backdoor samples that were uploaded to VirusTotal prior to the XcodeSpy malware, there may be additional XcodeSpy samples not yet discovered. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/new-macos-malware-xcodespy-targets-xcode-developers-with-eggshell-backdoor/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Vulnerabilities in Western Digital Replay Protected Memory Block
Western Digital has issued a white paper on two vulnerabilities within its RPMB protocol. The vulnerabilities could allow for the threat actor to make a legitimate host believe the state of the RPMB is different from its true state.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Western Digital's Replay Protected Memory Block is a protocol used to provide the ability for a host to store data in specific memory areas in an authenticated and replay-protected manner. This protocol has been found to have two separate vulnerabilities. The first prompts the host to conclude the data write failed. The data request contains a write value, address, and a MAC on those values. If the actor is able to intercept the request, they can modify it, which, subsequently, causes the MAC verification to fail. This action prevents the request from being committed to the RPMB. The adversary is then able to forward the initial request and intercept its status. The memory contents are updated without notification to the host. The second vulnerability allows the host to believe a portion of the data was, in fact, written. However, a different piece of data was written than initially thought. The attacker could cause the host to lose state, such as cutting power. The uncommitted write is kept with the attacker. Once online again, the host may attempt to issue an authenticated data write request to the previous location with different data. The attacker could intercept the new request and, instead, forward the old request. Further technical details can be found in the white paper and report located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33982541/Vulnerabilities%20in%20Western%20Digital%20Replay%20Protected%20Memory%20Block%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1605553835710&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://documents.westerndigital.com/content/dam/doc-library/en_us/assets/public/western-digital/collateral/white-paper/white-paper-replay-protected-memory-block-protocol-vulernabilities.pdf>

  * <https://www.westerndigital.com/support/productsecurity/wdc-20008-replay-attack-vulnerabilities-rpmb-protocol-applications>
  * <https://kb.cert.org/vuls/id/231329>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Updates to TrickBot's InjectDLL Module
TrickBot has recently updated its web inject module to add support for Zeus-style configurations. Kryptos Logic has published a blog post providing their analysis of this module.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Kryptos Logic published a blog post analyzing the updated version of TrickBot's web inject module. The web inject module previously supported two modes: dynamic and static. The static inject mode would ultimately redirect users to an attacker-controlled copy of the target site. The dynamic mode injected the stealing code into the legitimate website. The updated web inject module now has a single inject mode that performs injects by proxying traffic through a local SOCKS server if the victim accesses a URL on the list of target sites. Self-signed TLS certificates are used in man-in-the-middle TLS connections. Notably, the new web inject config file uses a Zeus-style format, which is widely used by the cybercrime community. While TrickBot previously performed fraud operations, it has more recently focused on targeted ransomware attacks. This update to the web inject module may indicate a return to their banking fraud activity though. For more information, see the Kryptos Logic blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Protection

## Yara Rule
    
    
    rule TrickBot__Webinject  
    {  
        meta:  
            id = "7eKHCSumVp7QRXF0z7BC1i"  
            fingerprint = "8a66f290d84a54e8ee148c461513627e83b8f092acebe8251c6098a88d8c4eba"  
            version = "1.0"  
            first_imported = "2021-07-01"  
            last_modified = "2021-07-01"  
            status = "RELEASED"  
            sharing = "TLP:WHITE"  
            source = "KRYPTOS LOGIC"  
            author = "KRYPTOS LOGIC"  
            description = "Detects TrickBot updated Webinject module"  
            category = "MALWARE"  
            malware = "BOT"  
            hash = "c79f016996b45cd7cc88aa3ce6c4d1ab247a1d803de4b742f64f3bf1e183ffb0"  
      
        strings:  
            $a = "c:\\developer\\webinject\\http-lib\\parser.c" wide  
            $zeus1 = "data_before"  
            $zeus2 = "data_after"  
            $zeus3 = "data_inject"  
            $zeus4 = "data_end"  
            $name = /wbi-x(86|64).dll/  
      
        condition:  
            all of them  
    }

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.kryptoslogic.com/blog/2021/07/trickbot-and-zeus/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Phishing email targeting Portuguese users disguised as COVID-19 Vaccination directions seen disseminating Lampion Trojan
A new version of the Lampion trojan has been seen targeting Portuguese users as part of a COVID-19 phishing email. Once the user executes the attachment, it will collect banking portal data and send it to a C2 server located in Russia.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Phishing email targeting Portuguese users disguised as COVID-19 Vaccination directions seen disseminating Lampion Trojan
A new version of the Lampion trojan has been seen targeting Portuguese users as part of a COVID-19 phishing email. Once the user executes the attachment, it will collect banking portal data and send it to a C2 server located in Russia.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing, Data Theft




# Overview

Recently, a new phishing campaign has been seen which targets Portuguese language users. Emails are disguised as being from the National Health Service with downloadable data to provide the victim information they would need to receive their COVID-19 vaccination. When the user clicks to open the material, it uses DLL side-loading to install the Lampion trojan as a browser overlay. After that, whenever the user connects to any of the banking portals coded into the malware, it will present the overlay to intercept credentials and communicate with a C2 server located in Russia. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://seguranca-informatica.pt/lampion-trojan-disseminated-in-portugal-using-covid-19-template/#.YC17mlNKiHt>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: XLL Files Used To Infect Victims In New Campaign
ASEC Labs has written a report on malicious XLL files that are being used to spread malware by tricking users into opening them. The mechanism for this has been analyzed and published in a report.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware, Infostealer
  *  **Target:** Unknown
  *  **Lure:** Purchase Order Attachment
  *  **Payload:** Malicious XLL files
  *  **Compromised Data:** Unknown
  *  **Post-compromise Actions:** Malware Download



# Overview

ASEC Labs has been tracking the distribution of malware using Microsoft Office. They discovered a campaign that started in 2021 and was using XLL files to distribute malware. XLL files are add-in files that can be opened by Excel, so users may mistake these files for documents when they are actually executable DLL files. The campaign began in July 2021 and the final payload can vary, with final malware including ransomware and infostealers. The XLL files are distributed in phishing emails, with the attachments masquerading as a purchase order document. Although the latest version of Outlook requires a block to be lifted to execute the file, older versions do not require the same manual approval from the user. Upon execution, the file accesses the network to download further malware. In one case, this method was used to distribute Carlos ransomware. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/34756/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1137 - Office Application Startup  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1485 - Data Destruction  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Malvertising Making a Comeback
According to a new report from MalwareBytes, malvertising is on the rise again. New delivery methods have taken the place of the classic drive-by download.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malvertising




# Overview

New statistics observed by MalwareBytes indicates malvertising is, once again, on the rise. Researchers have seen Raccoon Stealer and RIG exploit kit in their observations. The adult website, xhamster.com, has seen the largest malvertising campaign in more than a year. One malvertising actor was offering bids for ads on adult websites with the majority of victims located within the U.S. with 56% of the observed traffic. A popular ad network, ExoClick, was abused with redirection pages. The first domain used in the campaign was disguised as a web design agency; however the page was simply a decoy page. The actor used server-side cloaking to redirect victims to a Fallout exploit kit landing page. This page attempted to exploit CVE-2019-0752 and CVE-2018-15982. These CVEs attack Internet Explorer and Adobe's Flash Player respectively. Nearly two weeks later, a new domain was used and employed a 302 redirect. This instance used the RIG exploit kit to disseminate Raccoon Stealer. A second malvertiser (malsmoke) has been tracked for months and uses Smoke Loader malware. The actor placed their malicious ad on the xhamster.com website. This campaign used a different and more sophisticated redirection technique with client-side fingerprinting and connectivity checks in an effort to target only legitimate IP addresses. For this attack, both Raccoon Stealer and ZLoader were downloaded and deployed. This group has a propensity to switch ad networks with rapid pace to continually perform its malvertising campaigns. Due to the continued use of Internet Explorer, it is suspected that these attacks and campaigns will continue using the aforementioned CVEs. Further information can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/social-engineering/2020/09/malvertising-campaigns-come-back-in-full-swing/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Specter Botnet Using Legitimate Domains Through ClouDNS Service
A report from Netlab 360 provides an analysis of a sample of the Specter botnet client that is using legitimate domains for its C&C servers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Botnet
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Specter
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

An update to the Specter botnet client that Netlab 360 detected in September is using legitimate domains for its C&C servers. One of the legitimate domains used by Specter is api.github.com. The use of the legitimate domain was achieved by using the ClouDNS service. ClouDNS allows users to register arbitrary DNS Zones, and in at least some cases, existing legitimate domains have been registered with ClouDNS. Despite github.com having already been registered with ClouDNS by the Specter operators, Netlab 360 was also able to register it using different name servers than the existing registration. What this means is that those who use ClouDNS for DNS lookups will be returned the IP addresses for domains as they are registered with ClouDNS, rather than the actual legitimate IP addresses for the domains. This could allow an attacker to hide their C&C traffic by making it appear to belong to a legitimate, and often white-listed domain. According to Netlab 360, there are some 300 second-level domains that have been registered with ClouDNS in bad faith. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222797/Specter%20Botnet%20Using%20Legitimate%20Domains%20Through%20ClouDNS%20Service%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637559383770&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/the-pitfall-of-threat-intelligence-whitelisting-specter-botnet-is-taking-over-top-legit-dns-domains-by-using-cloudns-service/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.002 - DNS Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Technique Used by Attackers in NPM to Avoid Detection
Checkmarx’s SCS team has released an assessment of a new tactic being used by threat actors. This technique leverages NPM to load malicious packages.
output:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Malware
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
* **Targets:** Unknown
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Exfiltrate Sensitive Data
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Checkmarx researchers have encountered a number of packages exhibiting the technique of utilizing the Node package manager (NPM} for offensive cyber operations. The technique uses packages constructed by the attackers which have a low major version number, and minor and patch version numbers being high. The objective is to cause dependency confusion which may lead to the attacker's packages being installed by NPM. The attacker's goal is to exfiltrate all the victim machine’s environment variables to the attacker via a webhook of the legitimate service “pipedream”. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* [https://checkmarx.com/blog/new-technique-used-by-attackers-in-npm-to-avoid-detection/](https://checkmarx.com/blog/new-technique-used-by-attackers-in-npm-to-avoid-detection/ "Follow link")

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Resource Development - TA0042**  
 T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
   T1583.006 - Web Services  
 T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
   T1587.001 - Malware  
 T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
   T1608.001 - Upload Malware  

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1195 - Supply Chain Compromise  
   T1195.001 - Compromise Software Dependencies and Development Tools  
   T1195.002 - Compromise Software Supply Chain  

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
   T1059.007 - JavaScript  
 T1204 - User Execution  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
 T1036 - Masquerading  
   T1036.005 - Match Legitimate Name or Location  
 T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
   T1497.001 - System Checks  

**Collection - TA0009**  
 T1005 - Data from Local System  
 T1074 - Data Staged  
   T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  

**Exfiltration - TA0010**  
 T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service  
   T1567.002 - Exfiltration to Cloud Storage  

**Mitigations:**

**M1016:**  Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1046:**  Boot Integrity - Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Exfiltrate Sensitive Data
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Checkmarx researchers have encountered a number of packages exhibiting the technique of utilizing the Node package manager (NPM} for offensive cyber operations. The technique uses packages constructed by the attackers which have a low major version number, and minor and patch version numbers being high. The objective is to cause dependency confusion which may lead to the attacker's packages being installed by NPM. The attacker's goal is to exfiltrate all the victim machine’s environment variables to the attacker via a webhook of the legitimate service “pipedream”. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* [https://checkmarx.com/blog/new-technique-used-by-attackers-in-npm-to-avoid-detection/](https://checkmarx.com/blog/new-technique-used-by-attackers-in-npm-to-avoid-detection/ "Follow link")

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Resource Development - TA0042**  
 T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
   T1583.006 - Web Services  
 T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
   T1587.001 - Malware  
 T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
   T1608.001 - Upload Malware  

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1195 - Supply Chain Compromise  
   T1195.001 - Compromise Software Dependencies and Development Tools  
   T1195.002 - Compromise Software Supply Chain  

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
   T1059.007 - JavaScript  
 T1204 - User Execution  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
 T1036 - Masquerading  
   T1036.005 - Match Legitimate Name or Location  
 T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
   T1497.001 - System Checks  

**Collection - TA0009**  
 T1005 - Data from Local System  
 T1074 - Data Staged  
   T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  

**Exfiltration - TA0010**  
 T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service  
   T1567.002 - Exfiltration to Cloud Storage  

**Mitigations:**

**M1016:**  Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1046:**  Boot Integrity - Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Another LILIN DVR 0-day Used to Spread Mirai
Previously targeted by various botnets, a new 0-day vulnerability has been identified in LILIN DVR devices. 360 Netlab discovered this 0-day as part of Mirai activity and their recent blog post discusses the technical details of the vulnerability.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Exploit, Botnet




# Overview

360 Netlab published a blog post analyzing a 0-day vulnerability in LILIN DVR that was discovered being exploited by Mirai samples. Based on their findings, almost 7,000 devices remain vulnerable to this 0-day, which has since been patched by Merit LILIN. The exploit used by Mirai is leveraged in combination with default credentials for infection. Specifically, the vulnerability allows for remote code execution based on a web service that runs a command line program against provided parameters. However, one of the passed parameters is not validated, so it can be leveraged to pass a shell command of the attacker's choice that will be executed in shared memory. The patch released by Merit LILIN ensures that this vulnerable parameter includes the expected content type. It is recommended that LILIN DVR/NVR users update their devices and ensure strong login credentials are configured. For more information, see the 360 Netlab blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/another-lilin-dvr-0-day-being-used-to-spread-mirai-en/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: SysJoker - A New Multi-platform Backdoor
SysJoker is a new backdoor discovered by Intezer that targets the Windows, Mac, and Linux operating systems.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** SysJoker
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, Collection, and exfiltration of data.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

The SysJoker backdoor was discovered by Intezer in December 2021 during the investigation of an attack on a Linux-based web server. Intezer later discovered there were also Mach-O and Windows PE versions of SysJoker, all are written in C++. SysJoker is reported as masquerading as a system update but it is not clear how it is distributed or executed though Intezer notes a possible method is through distribution as an npm package. SysJoker behaves similarly on all three operating systems, however, the Windows version also uses a first stage dropper which is not found in the Mac or Linux versions. Intezer assesses that the goal of the attack is lateral movement and espionage. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056959/SysJoker%20-%20A%20New%20Multi-platform%20Backdoor%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642138140889&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/malware-analysis/new-backdoor-sysjoker/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: A Deep Dive Into The Ragnar Locker Gang
Ransomware continues to be one of the largest cyber threats faced by businesses. In this report by Cyble Research Labs, the tools, techniques, and motivations of the Ragnar Locker ransomware gang is analyzed.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** North American Businesses
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Ragnar Locker (S0481)
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Yes
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown **  
**
  * **Post-Compromise Actions:** Double Extortion



# Overview

Cyble Research Labs have published an analysis of the ransomware used by the Ragnar Locker gang. this threat actor is one of the most active ransomware groups since activity started in 2019. As is common nowadays, the group uses a double extortion model by encrypting the victims' data and asking for a ransom. If the ransom isn't paid, the group leaks the data on a public site. The group mainly targets North America, but some activity has been seen in Europe and Asia. The malware itself has a standard execution flow, where it starts by collecting and exfiltrating system information. It will also check the host's language setting, and stop execution if certain languages are found, such as Belorussian and Ukrainian. The ransomware then enumerates all disks and uses cryptographic APIs to generate random keys, which are used to encrypt all data on the machine. The ransomware excludes any system-critical directories and browsers to ensure that the victims will get the ransom note and be able to pay the ransom. In this process, shadow copies are deleted, to prevent system restoration. The group claims that they are a group of cyber security enthusiasts and that their motivation is to help organizations improve their network security. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057598/A%20Deep%20Dive%20Into%20The%20Ragnar%20Locker%20Gang%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1643196081533&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2022/01/20/deep-dive-into-ragnar-locker-ransomware-gang/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1134 - Access Token Manipulation  
T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1112 - Modify Registry  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1135 - Network Share Discovery  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1489 - Service Stop  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: AXA Attacked by Avaddon Group's Ransomware
The AXA Insurance company has been the victim of a ransomware and followup DDoS attack by the Avaddon Ransomware Group. Several news outlets have provided information on this attack.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

According to several news outlets, insurance company AXA and, specifically, its operations in Asia have been the victim of a ransomware and DDoS attack by affiliates or the operators of the Avaddon Ransomware-as-a-Service. It is unknown how the attackers were able to gain access to the network, although typical delivery for Avaddon has focused on phishing emails containing malicious attachments as zip archives with malicious JavaScript contained therein. 

At present, more than 3TB of, what is being classified as, “highly sensitive data to include HIV and STD reports, customer and doctor ID documents, bank details, and more" was purportedly encrypted and exfiltrated. Photos obtained by Heimdal Security show several Asia-based passports. These photos may or may not be related to the attack; however, the group has made every effort to prove the demands are real and they are willing to share this information on a larger scale. AXA was given 10 days from May 15, 2021 to comply with the ransom demands or face the prospect of a DDoS attack on its network. The threat group has released passport details in an effort to expedite payment. This is a customary tactic amongst ransomware groups to show the severity of the problem and reasoning behind the payment demand. The threat group posted a “press release” stating the AXA is not willing to comply with the demands. As such, the threat group has stated the data cannot be decrypted without the decryptor. 

First identified in February 2019, the group has attacked more than 100 companies to date. There is no official word on how many of those companies actually paid the ransom. Unlike the DarkSide operators, who claim to have ceased operations, the Avaddon gang is actively searching for targets. 

Some have speculated that the attack was based on AXA’s group statement they will no longer issue cyber-insurance policies in France. While this may seem related to the attack on AXA, X-Force believes this is coincidental and is not part of the reasoning behind the attack. The suspension only applies to France and does not affect existing policies. For this reason, we have concluded these attacks are not related. 

A report from the FBI as well as the ACSC (Australian Cyber Security Centre) states the average ransom demand is 0.73 bitcoin. This translates roughly to $40,000 USD at the time of the report. That number, based on trading today, is about $28,000 USD.

As always, X-Force is keeping a very close eye on this and will bring you further details as the story progresses. Links to information presented above are located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://heimdalsecurity.com/blog/avaddon-ransomware-hits-insurance-giant-axa/>

  * <https://www.infosecurity-magazine.com/news/axa-faces-ddos-after-ransomware/>

  * <https://www.insurancejournal.com/news/international/2021/05/09/613255.htm>

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/ransomware/2021/05/avaddon-ransomware-campaign-prompts-warnings-from-fbi-acsc/>

  * <https://www.cyber.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-05/2021-003%20Ongoing%20campaign%20using%20Avaddon%20Ransomware%20-%2020210508.pdf>

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/insurer-axa-hit-by-ransomware-after-dropping-support-for-ransom-payments/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: R_Evil WordPress Hacktool and Malicious JavaScript Injections
Discovered during a recent investigation, Sucuri researchers report on an interesting custom WordPress hacktool, dubbed "R_Evil," and JavaScript injection activity.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: R_Evil WordPress Hacktool and Malicious JavaScript Injections
Discovered during a recent investigation, Sucuri researchers report on an interesting custom WordPress hacktool, dubbed "R_Evil," and JavaScript injection activity.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Sucuri has published a blog post analyzing a recently discovered WordPress hacktool dubbed "R_Evil." Their analysis pertains to the main PHP file used to load secondary files making up the hacktool. They believe their inability to find samples of the secondary files is due to a self-destruct function in the tool that cleans up associated files. Many of the functions in the tool are similar to most PHP shells, such as those for file modifications, downloading, executing PHP, and scanning files. The researchers highlight several functions that are more unique, including those to update or debug WordPress, restore files, and scan for malware. The malware scanning function in particular is interesting as it appears to scan for a common website malware based on filenames and regex strings. It is possible this is used to remove existing infections in order to reduce the chance of detection. Another interesting aspect of the main PHP file was the presence of a modified version of the hello.php WordPress file. The modification is used to inject malicious JavaScript into the front end of the website. When loaded, this JavaScript redirects users to scam landing page. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/10/r_evil-wordpress-hacktool-malicious-javascript-injections.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Emotet's Lastest Maldoc Analyzed
Emotet has often been spread using malicious macros in phishing documents. A new report by ASEC analyzes the newest incarnation of this method of infection.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Emotet (S0367)
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Maldoc delivered via email
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

ASEC researchers have analyzed an excel file that is part of a campaign to distribute Emotet. This activity can be traced back to last month and the files have been continually used to infect victims since then. The excel file presents itself to the victim with some text instructing them to enable macros and content. The file contains a macro that runs automatically once macros have been enabled. The macro downloads a web page from a C2 server and executes it, which runs the malicious PowerShell scripts contained within. This script contacts several URLs in order, which contains either Emotet or malicious DLL files which are run by the malware. This allows the malware to receive commands and download additional software from the attacker. As has been previously seen in similar campaigns, the initial document is being spread via phishing emails. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057396/Emotet%27s%20Lastest%20Maldoc%20Analyzed%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1643034521601&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).



# References

  * <https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/30850/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.005 - Mshta  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Haywood County School District Victim of Ransomware Attack
Breach / Leak Notification: The Haywood County school district in North Carolina was the victim of a data breach believed to have been conducted by the SunCrypt ransomware operators. Aside from the installation of ransomware, unencrypted data was also stolen by the attackers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Haywood County School District Victim of Ransomware Attack
Breach / Leak Notification: The Haywood County school district in North Carolina was the victim of a data breach believed to have been conducted by the SunCrypt ransomware operators. Aside from the installation of ransomware, unencrypted data was also stolen by the attackers.

# Threat Type

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

  
"A school district in North Carolina has suffered a data breach after having unencrypted files stolen during an attack by the SunCrypt Ransomware operators, BleepingComputer has discovered. The Haywood County School district in North Carolina announced that they had suffered a ransomware attack on August 24th, 2020, but had not stated what ransomware was used. This attack caused the district to shut down its network and halt remote learning, which had started on August 17th."

# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/suncrypt-ransomware-shuts-down-north-carolina-school-district/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: BT Missed Voice Message Phishing Lure
In a new campaign observed by Cofense, British Telecom users are being targeted with phishing emails claiming to be related to missed voice messages.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** British Telecom (BT) customers
  *  **Lure:** BT Landline missed voice message
  *  **Payload:** Link to fake BT login page
  *  **Compromised Data:** Account credentials



# Overview

Cofense published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign targeting British Telecom (BT) users. The body of the email claims that the recipients BT landline has a new voice message that can be played via provided link. Both the landing page for this link and the email use BT branding in an attempt to trick the user. The landing page provides a login prompt requesting the user's email and password in order to play missed voice messages. Any entered credentials are exfiltrated to the attacker while the victim is redirected to the BT Landline help page. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616512/BT%20Missed%20Voice%20Message%20Phishing%20Lure%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635168039384&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/missed-voice-message-phish/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Colonial Pipeline Falls Victim to Attack
One of the top fuel pipeline company's suffered a cyber attack that has forced the company to put its pipeline operations at a full stop. Several news sources and the company itself have confirmed the attack.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Cyber Attack




# Overview

## ** Update May 10 **

Colonial Pipeline has updated its statement on the cyberattack that led to the halting of pipeline operations. The statement confirms that the attack involved ransomeware. No details of which ransomware was used, or which actors are behind the attack, have been provided. Colonial's main pipelines remain offline while some smaller lateral lines have resumed service.

## ** Original Report **

A top U.S. fuel pipeline operator, Colonial Pipeline, has proactively stopped pipeline operations and taken some computer systems offline to contain the cyberattack. There is some speculation the company is the victim of a ransomware attack though that cannot be confirmed at this time. The company, which operates more than 5,500 miles of pipeline, has engaged with a third-party cybersecurity firm and involved law enforcement and other federal agencies. At this time, IBM is not currently involved with this incident and intelligence on the attack is sparse. Specifics of the attack are sparse, however, IBM is keeping a close eye on this situation and we will continue to provide updates as they become available. 

# Reference

  * <https://www.colpipe.com/news/press-releases/media-statement-colonial-pipeline-system-disruption>

  * <https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/08/us/cyberattack-colonial-pipeline.html>
  * <https://www.reuters.com/technology/colonial-pipeline-halts-all-pipeline-operations-after-cybersecurity-attack-2021-05-08/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New RAT in Town Named BIOPASS Can Live Stream Victims’ Screens
Trend Micro discovered a new remote access trojan malware that targets online gambling companies in China using a watering hole attack. Visitors are told they must install Adobe Flash Player or Microsoft Silverlight, which are actually malicious loaders. There are no currently supported versions of Flash Player or Silverlight as they've both been deprecated. Trend Micro has named the malware, BIOPASS RAT.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT, Infostealer




# Overview

BIOPASS RAT, a new trojan discovered by Trend Micro, has all the features found in many other remote access trojans, but it also has something unique. By abusing the framework of Open Broadcaster Software (OBS) Studio, a popular live streaming and video recording app, it can sniff its victim's screen and establish live streaming to a cloud service via Real-Time Messaging Protocol (RTMP). The same cloud service is used to store exfiltrated data from victims. This new malware targets online gambling companies in China using a watering hole attack. In most of the cases Trend Micro observed, the attackers often placed their injection script within their target’s online support chat page. Visitors are told they must install Adobe Flash Player or Microsoft Silverlight, which are actually malicious loaders. The malware will scan a set of predetermined ports to see if the victim is already compromised. If not, it will run python scripts to open an HTTP server that listens on one of a set of defined ports. Further information is available from Trend Micro's blog which is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/g/biopass-rat-new-malware-sniffs-victims-via-live-streaming.html>

There are no currently supported versions of Flash Player or Silverlight as they've both been deprecated. Trend Micro has named the malware, BIOPASS RAT.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Indra - The Attackers Who Targeted Iranian Railway Systems
A report from Check Point attributes the July 9th attack on the computer systems of the Islamic Republic of Iran Railways (IRIR) to a group named Indra. The report also provides information on other attacks Check Point attributes to the group.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Destructive - Disk Wipe
  *  **Targets:** Iranian Government Entities, Businesses with ties to Iran. ****
  * **Malware Family/Families:** Meteor (earlier versions named Comet, and Stardust)
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Deployment and execution of the Meteor disk wiper on multiple systems within the internal network.
  *  ** **Additional TTPs:**** See the Mitre ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

An attack on the Islamic Republic of Iran Railways (IRIR) on July 9th, and on July 10th, an attack on Iran's Ministry of Roads and Urban Development, has been attributed by Check Point to an actor that identifies itself as Indra. In its report, Check Point also identifies earlier attacks in 2019 and 2020 that targeted private entities with relationships to Iran and located in Syria, which Check Point attributes to Indra. The disk wiper used in the Iranian attack is named Meteor. The wipers used in the Syrian attacks were named Comet and Stardust, which are thought to be earlier versions of Meteor with Comet being the earliest identified version. In the Iranian attacks, a combination of .bat and archive files were used to deploy and execute Meteor whereas in the Syrian attacks multiple VBS scripts and archives were used to deploy and execute the wipers. Check Point believes it is unlikely that Indra is a state-sponsored actor. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [Indra — The Attackers Who Targeted Iranian Railway Systems IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/62357816/Indra%20%E2%80%94%20The%20Attackers%20Who%20Targeted%20Iranian%20Railway%20Systems%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1629771412172&api=v2)



# Detection

  * A complete list of Yara rules can be found here: [Indra — The Attackers Who Targeted Iranian Railway Systems Yara Rules.txt](/download/attachments/62357816/Indra%20%E2%80%94%20The%20Attackers%20Who%20Targeted%20Iranian%20Railway%20Systems%20Yara%20Rules.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1629771473552&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2021/indra-hackers-behind-recent-attacks-on-iran/>



# Mitre ATT&CK Framework

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1485 - Data Destruction  
T1561 - Disk Wipe  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer

Tell me everything you know the following threat: Brief Analysis of IceRat Malware
Traces of the malware IceRat were initially discovered on a cybersecurity forum and later investigated by analysts who noticed the malware mostly consists of JPHP files. JPHP is an implementation of PHP for Java VMs.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

The Malwaretips.com forum sparked the interest of a curious contributor and user named McMcbrad, who noticed low detection rates on VirusTotal for IceRat. The malware has mostly been seen in Eastern Europe and Russia. According to analysts, IceRat is a PHP implementation for Java VMs and uses .phb files instead of Java .class files, a type of file usually not supported or noticed by antivirus products. Instead of one large file, IceRat consists of several small files which means the context of the individual files may not be apparent. Initially, the downloader is in a Trojanized dropper within another dropper. Analysts also noted that although the malware is infamously known as a RAT, IceRat is more appropriately described as a backdoor, with the capability of stealing credentials from popular browsers like Chrome and Firefox. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.gdatasoftware.com/blog/icerat-evades-antivirus-by-using-jphp>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Undocumented User Account in Zyxel Products Vulnerability
Eye Control has posted a blog regarding a vulnerability (CVE-2020-29583) in a number of Zyxel products.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

An undocumented user account vulnerability (CVE-2020-29583) in a number of Zyxel products is the subject of an Eye Control blog. Zyxel is a popular firewall product among small to medium-sized businesses. A password was found in plain text in one of the binaries on the system and it appears that the account ID and password can be used to create an SSH connection to a vulnerable device. The account, zyfwp, does have admin privileges and the password can not be changed. Firmware version 4.60 patch 0 is the vulnerable version. Zyxel has released firmware version 4.60 patch 1 that addresses the issue. Vulnerable devices and additional details can be found in the links in the Reference section.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Windows Kerberos Vulnerability Exploited
A new exploit in Windows Kerberos now has a proof-of-concept (POC) showing a bypass vulnerability. Bleeping Computer has information on this emerging threat.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability, Exploit




# Overview

A security bug, tracked as CVE-2020-17049, has been shown to be exploitable with a POC code. The exploit has been named Kerberos Bronze Bit. The attack uses S4U2self and S4U2proxy, which are added as AD Kerberos protocol extensions. This allows the attack to gain access to the service ticket of the target. The forwardable flag in the ticket is set to 1. The ticket is used in the S4U2proxy to obtain the service ticket for the targeted user to the targeted service. With the ticket obtained, impersonation can be used, requests can be sent to the service, and requests processed by the user's authority. This exploit bypasses Kerberos delegation, thus allowing the attacker to escalate privilege. This, then, allows the requests to proceed under the escalated authority. Microsoft is releasing a two-stage rollout. The first was released on December 8, 2020. The second is a forced enforcement on February 9, 2020. Microsoft did release an out-of-band update to fix Kerberos authentication issues. Mitigation suggestions were released the week after CVE-2020-17049 was released. We and Microsoft recommend immediately patch all systems affected by this vulnerability. Further information can be found in the links located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-17049




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/windows-kerberos-bronze-bit-attack-gets-public-exploit-patch-now/>

  * <https://blog.netspi.com/cve-2020-17049-kerberos-bronze-bit-overview/>
  * <https://blog.netspi.com/cve-2020-17049-kerberos-bronze-bit-theory/>
  * <https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/4598347/managing-deployment-of-kerberos-s4u-changes-for-cve-2020-17049>
  * [https://support.microsoft.com/help/4598347](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/4598347/managing-deployment-of-kerberos-s4u-changes-for-cve-2020-17049)
