instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Lazarus Malware Leveraging VBA and LoLbins
Attackers are constantly evolving the techniques they use to distribute malware via Microsoft Office documents. Netskope published a blog post analyzing the most recent developments in Lazarus' malicious documents.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Netskope published a blog post analyzing the most recent developments in Lazarus' malicious Office documents. Specifically, the group has implemented the use of embedded base64-encoded payloads and code injection. Netskope notes that the samples they analyzed are also the first case they have observed of the use of both VBA and LoLbins (Live off the Land binaries) in macros. As is common with lure documents, the Office document contains a message claiming that content must be enabled to access the protected file. Enabling macros leads to the start of the infection chain. First, a base64 string stored as a variable in the VBA code is written to a file. A copy of certutil.exe is made and subsequently used to decode the base64 content and save it to a new file. The new file is the malicious payload that is injected into explorer.exe using the Microsoft Application Virtualization Injector. Once running in memory, the malware is used to retrieve the next-stage payload from a remote server. Throughout this infection chain, various obfuscation and detection evasion techniques are implemented. For more information, see the Netskope blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.netskope.com/blog/not-laughing-malicious-office-documents-using-lolbins>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Epsilon Red Ransomware
Epsilon Red is a new ransomware package that Sophos discovered being used in a targeted attack against a US-based hospitality sector business.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

A Sophos report provides information on a ransomware attack that targeted a US-based business in the hospitality sector. A new ransomware named Epsilon Red was used in the attack. The ransomware executable is named red.exe and is written in Go and contains some code from an open-source project name "godirwalk". It is described by Sophos as being a bare-bones package as it only handles the file encryption process with the other functions such as C&C communication being handled by PowerShell scripts. The report notes that the initial entry point into the enterprise is thought to be a compromised Exchange server. What vulnerability might have been exploited to achieve the compromise was not determined. Sophos describes the actual attack as being hand-controlled and involves more than twelve PowerShell scripts that are obfuscated in a rudimentary manner. A legitimate remote access tool named "Remote Utilities" was installed on some systems. In some instances, the Tor Browser was also installed. Epsilon Red is unusual in some respects in that it blocks access to all TCP ports on a system, except for RDP (3389) and the port used by Remote Utilities (5650). And, in the sample Sophos analyzed, there is no list of targeted or excluded file types, so it will encrypt all the files in a directory it encrypts. Files that are encrypted have the suffix .epsilonred appended to them. The ransom note left by the malware is similar to that left by the REvil ransomware, but there are no other obvious similarities between the two ransomware families. Sophos notes in its report that at least one victim paid a ransom of 4.29BTC (around $149,000 USD) on May 31. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/05/28/epsilonred/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Agent Tesla Attack Uses Hastebin
Paste sites are a popular way for attackers to use a legitimate service to host their malicious code or stolen data. Deep Instinct has discovered an Agent Tesla variant hosted on a paste site not widely used by malware families in the past.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Deep Instinct published their analysis of a new Agent Tesla campaign leveraging Hastebin to host malicious code. Hastebin has not been widely used by malware in the past, unlike the more popular Pastebin, so this was an interesting development. As with most Agent Tesla campaigns, the infection chain begins with a phishing email. Attached to the phishing email is an executable masquerading as a PDF, which the recipient is encouraged to open. This executable acts as a loader for the final malicious payload. On execution it reaches out to pastes on Hastebin that contain the Agent Tesla payload. The loader also has the option of obtaining the payload from Pastebin, but due to Pastebin's closer monitoring of malicious activity on their service, these pastes had already been removed at the time of analysis. With the payload on the system, evasion techniques are implemented, such as anti-VM and anti-debugging efforts. Persistence is established via the Startup folder and three Registry Run keys. Agent Tesla then performs its main functionality of stealing browser and mail client credentials and keylogging. Stolen data is subsequently exfiltrated over SMTP. For more information, see the Deep Instinct blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.deepinstinct.com/2020/10/29/the-hasty-agent-agent-tesla-attack-uses-hastebin/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: What You Must Know About a New Variant of Lorenz Ransomware
Tesorion, a Dutch cybersecurity company, has recently discovered a new variant of Lorenz ransomware.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Lorenz Ransomware Gang
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Lorenz Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing Email
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** File encryption
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Lorenz ransomware has been active since April 2021. Tesorion published an article in July 2021 and made available a free decryptor for the original version via the NoMoreRansom initiative. Tesorion has discovered a new variant of the Lorenz ransomware and this one also has a serious bug. They explain in their latest blog that this latest version has a bug that makes it so the attacker is unable to recover any encrypted files. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://www.tesorion.nl/en/posts/lorenz-ransomware-rebound-corruption-and-irrecoverable-files/>
  * <https://www.nomoreransom.org/en/index.html>
  * <https://www.tesorion.nl/en/posts/lorenz-ransomware-analysis-and-a-free-decryptor/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information  
T1590.003 - Network Trust Dependencies  
T1591 - Gather Victim Org Information  
T1591.002 - Business Relationships  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1586 - Compromise Accounts  
T1586.002 - Email Accounts  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
T1199 - Trusted Relationship  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.002 - SMB/Windows Admin Shares  
T1080 - Taint Shared Content  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1102.003 - One-Way Communication  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
What You Must Know About a New Variant of Lorenz Ransomware
Tesorion, a Dutch cybersecurity company, has recently discovered a new variant of Lorenz ransomware.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Lorenz Ransomware Gang
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Lorenz Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing Email
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** File encryption
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Lorenz ransomware has been active since April 2021. Tesorion published an article in July 2021 and made available a free decryptor for the original version via the NoMoreRansom initiative. Tesorion has discovered a new variant of the Lorenz ransomware and this one also has a serious bug. They explain in their latest blog that this latest version has a bug that makes it so the attacker is unable to recover any encrypted files. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://www.tesorion.nl/en/posts/lorenz-ransomware-rebound-corruption-and-irrecoverable-files/>
  * <https://www.nomoreransom.org/en/index.html>

 **Credential Access - TA0006**

 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services

T1080 - Taint Shared Content  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1102.003 - One-Way Communication  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Emotet Back After 10 Month Absence
Following a 10 month absence of Emotet, it's back. A blog post from Deep Instinct details the new features contained in the resurgence of Emotet.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Malware Botnet
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** N/A
  *  **Targets:** Various
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Usually via infected file from email
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Used for various functions



# Overview

After being dormant for the past 10 months, Emotet is back with a new DLL and other features. Additionally, a new tool called DeMotet automates analysis of Emotet. As with previous versions, this version is a multi-stage malware unpacked in succession. In this version, the DLL is not the payload and doesn't communicate with the C2 servers. According to researchers, the entropy is high and thus most likely contains encrypted data. Using specified resources, a breakpoint is reached and, in turn, triggers the decryption stage that is placed in memory. The next stage is then loaded using a matching file size. Unlike past versions, this version has no imported API functions, very few strings, but does employ the same code obfuscation. Obfuscation is accomplished via Control Flow Flattening. The payload is concealed by hiding information used in static analysis. Using DeMotet, imported functions that have been added to the payload can be seen. The static unpacker can use name hashing and strings decryption algorithms found in previous versions making DeMotet a viable analysis option. Finally, the communication protocol has been changed to HTTPS as opposed to HTTP. More information can be found in the blog post located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74055751/Emotet%20Back%20After%2010%20Month%20Absence%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638888793633&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction. (M1017)
  * Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries. (M1031)
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking. (M1038)
  * Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing. (M1045)
  * Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses. (M1047)
  * Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software. (M1049)
  * Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates. (M1054)



# References

  * <https://www.deepinstinct.com/blog/the-re-emergence-of-emotet>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Version of Apostle Ransomware
Agrius is a suspected Iranian threat actor operating in the Middle East known for deploying ransomware and wipers. SentinelOne has found a new version of their Apostle ransomware being deployed via a loader dubbed "Jennlog."
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Target:** Middle Eastern University
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Apostle
  *  **RaaS Operation:** No
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data encryption



# Overview

SentinelOne published a blog post detailing a new version of the Apostle ransomware found targeting a Middle Eastern university. The ransomware was installed via a loader dubbed "Jennlog." This .NET loader contains an embedded executable. The beginning of the file contains content masquerading as a legitimate log file, but the end of the file contains an obfuscated, compressed, and encrypted executable. The loader has the capability to check for the presence of sandboxes, virtual machines, and debuggers. The sample analyzed in the blog post drops a version of Apostle ransomware that operates the same as previous versions but leverages a new ransom note and wallpaper. The researchers noted that other versions of the Jennlog loader were identified but they instead dropped what appeared to be a test version of the OrcusRAT malware. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129226/New%20Version%20of%20Apostle%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633116432069&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/new-version-of-apostle-ransomware-reemerges-in-targeted-attack-on-higher-education/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1497.001 - System Checks

 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Phishing Campaign Targeting Predominantly Government Entities
A phishing campaign, active since late 2019, and targeting the education, energy, finance, government, and heath sectors in a number of geographies, has been reported by Recorded Future’s Insikt Group. The campaign has leveraged the open source phishing framework, FiercePhish.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Phishing Campaign Targeting Predominantly Government Entities
A phishing campaign, active since late 2019, and targeting the education, energy, finance, government, and heath sectors in a number of geographies, has been reported by Recorded Future’s Insikt Group. The campaign has leveraged the open source phishing framework, FiercePhish.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Primarily targeting governmental entities, as well as the education, energy, finance, and heath sectors, Recorded Future’s Insikt Group has identified a phishing campaign that has been active since late 2019. The most targeted countries have been Canada, India, the United States, and Turkey. Other countries targeted include, Australia, India, Qatar, the Republic of Korea, Turkey, the United Arab Emirates, and the United Kingdom. The campaign has largely been using Russian domains (.ru) and Insikt believes the campaign has been coordinated through the site asherintartrading.com. The site has hosted the management portal for the the open source phishing framework, FiercePhish. A number of IP addresses, including more than thirty belonging to DigitalOcean, have also been used in the campaign, along with more than two hundred domains and URLs. The URLs follow a similar naming convention in most cases. In the email noted in the report, the victim was presented with a fake Gmail login page. In addition, if the victim clicked the unsubscribe link in the email, they were presented with a different phishing page, on a different domain. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://go.recordedfuture.com/hubfs/reports/cta-2020-1027.pdf>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Malicious Code in APKPure App
APKPure is a popular, third-party app store for Android devices. Kaspersky discovered that recent versions of the store contained malicious code due to the implementation of an adware SDK.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Kaspersky published a blog post analyzing malicious code within the popular APKPure Android app store. The malicious code was included due to APKPure's implementation of an SDK from an unverified source that turned out to be adware. The malicious code added by the SDK decrypts and launches a payload when the app store is opened. Device information is then collected and sent to a C2 server. In response, the C2 can issue commands to display ads on the device, intrusively open browser pages with ads, or download and execute additional modules. When executed by Kaspersky researchers, the Trojan attempted to sign the victim up for paid subscriptions and displayed highly intrusive ads. Combined with outdated OS versions, the malware is capable of installing additional payloads on the system partition, resulting in unremovable malware. APKPure has updated their app store to remove the malicious code, but this requires users to install the clean version of the app to rid the device of the malicious code. For more information, see the Securelist blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/apkpure-android-app-store-infected/101845/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Chrome Browser Updates - November 17
Google has released an update to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux, that provides fixes for thirty-three vulnerabilities. Ten of the vulnerabilities are rated as High by Google.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Google has released an update, version 87.0.4280.66, to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux, that provides fixes for thirty-three vulnerabilities. Of the CVE numbered vulnerabilities noted in the update, ten are rated by Google as High, eleven as Medium, and Two as Low. Successful exploitation of the most serious vulnerabilities could potentially allow for the remote execution of arbitrary code.

Google also published a support note advising the users of macOS devices that use an Apple processor, may have issues with the new version of Chrome crashing. Information on resolving the issue are contained in the support note. Further information is available from the links in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Among Us Imposter on Google Play
With the growing popularity of the mobile game Among Us, Zscaler has discovered a fake version of the app used for intrusive advertising.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Adware




# Overview

Zscaler has published a blog post analyzing a fake Among Us app being distributed via the Google Play store. When first installed on a victim device, a video plays in an attempt to convince the user additional features are being downloaded and that is why the game cannot immediately be played. In the meantime, however, details about the user's device, such as SDK version, model, manufacturer, and more, are sent to the attacker's server. After this data has been sent, the device begins displaying highly intrusive advertisements. Notably, the app also contains a fake login/registration page, but at this time no functionality is implemented to send entered data to the attacker, indicating that this feature is likely still in development. Examining the developer profile behind this app reveals fake version of other games and social media apps, many of which are specific to Indian users. They all perform the same functionality as the Among Us app. For more information, see the Zscaler blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/among-us-imposter-google-play>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Threat Actors Paying for Google Pay-per-Click Ads to Target Victims and Deliver Infostealer Software
Morphisec Labs' research investigated the origin of several prevalent infostealers and identified pay-per-click (PPC) ads from Google's search results for popular software package downloads. Users who click the ads and proceed to download what they believe to be one of several popular software packages will find themselves inadvertently installing infostealers such as Taurus or Redline.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Threat Actors Paying for Google Pay-per-Click Ads to Target Victims and Deliver Infostealer Software
Morphisec Labs' research investigated the origin of several prevalent infostealers and identified pay-per-click (PPC) ads from Google's search results for popular software package downloads. Users who click the ads and proceed to download what they believe to be one of several popular software packages will find themselves inadvertently installing infostealers such as Taurus or Redline.

# Threat Type

  * Malvertising, Infostealer




# Overview

As Morphisec Labs' investigated the origin of several prevalent infostealers, they discovered pay-per-click (PPC) ads from Google's search results of several popular software packages. The google ads lead to websites with an ISO image download which is able to evade some scanning solutions based on the large file size. Some of the executables within the ISO images are digitally signed and legitimately verified. The threat actors were targeting victims in certain countries by IP address ranges. By clicking a download button from one of the malicious sites, a script is run that verifies the IP address. If the user is not from the country targeted, they are redirected to a link of the legitimate page that downloads the correction application. For more information, see the Morphisec blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.morphisec.com/google-ppc-ads-deliver-redline-taurus-and-mini-redline-infostealers>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ITG14 Shift To Ransomware With New TTPs
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence has published a report on ITG14 and their shift from Point-of-Sale (POS) systems to ransomware and the emergence of new TTPs for the group.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, Phishing, VBS, PowerShell, Backdoor




# Overview

IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence has published a report on ITG14, which shares overlap with FIN7 and CARBON SPIDER, and its latest shift from Point-of-Sale (POS) systems to ransomware with new TTPs. X-Force analysts have concluded ITG14 has worked as an affiliate of the Sodinokibi (aka REvil) ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) group as well as possibly Ryuk. Additionally, ITG14 is reportedly behind the DarkSide RaaS operation. In this change of focus, the group has shifted from highly targeted, to more indiscriminate targeting of victims. Since March 2020, the group has been using VBS loaders to download the GRIFFON JScript backdoor, the JSSLoader .NET backdoor, and PowerShell loaders called TAKEOUT, SCRAMBLELOADER, and CLEARLOADER. The change in TTPs indicates the probable use of a new underground infrastructure, malware suppliers, and cooperation with other threat groups. The switch from POS attacks to ransomware indicates a decrease in revenue from POS attacks and the opportunity for more revenue through ransomware. The full story and analysis is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Indicators of compromise are available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/e9dc890b-33ee-47eb-b1c4-3f30a16a5918>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Necro Botnet Exploits Vulnerable Visual Tools DVR
The Necro Python botnet appeared on the threat landscape in January 2020, exploiting vulnerable services to run a polymorphic script on Windows and Linux hosts. Juniper published a blog post analyzing the most recent version of the payload.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Botnet
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Necro
  *  **Targets:** Visual Tools DVR
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of vulnerable services
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Execute bot commands, install Monero miner



# Overview

Juniper published a blog post analyzing recent Necro botnet activity and changes to its payload. In terms of initial infection, Necro continues to exploit vulnerabilities in various devices, such as TerraMaster and Genexis products, as well as exploiting a new vulnerability in Visual Tools DVR. Once on a system, the bot connects to its C2 using a domain generation algorithm in combination with dynamic DNS services. Commands can be issued via IRC and provide capabilities such as port scanning, killing and executing processes, downloading additional payloads, and performing denial-of-service attacks. Juniper researchers also observed Monero miners being installed during the exploitation of Visual Tools DVR. For more information, see the Juniper blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [Necro Botnet Exploits Vulnerable VisualTools DVR IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130286/Necro%20Botnet%20Exploits%20Vulnerable%20VisualTools%20DVR%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634153745921&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://blogs.juniper.net/en-us/threat-research/necro-python-botnet-goes-after-vulnerable-visualtools-dvr>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.006 - Python  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1014 - Rootkit  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1568 - Dynamic Resolution  
T1568.002 - Domain Generation Algorithms  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1498 - Network Denial of Service

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: IcedID Malware Delivered via Contact Forms
An investigation into a wave of malicious emails led Microsoft researchers to discover a campaign distributing IcedID through the use of legitimate contact forms.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Infostealer




# Overview

Microsoft published a blog post analyzing an IcedID campaign abusing contact forms for distribution. By using contact forms on legitimate websites, the threat actors can hide behind the email addresses of known contact form services to bypass email security appliances. In this campaign, the content sent via the form contains legal threats and requests the user download the evidence from a provided link. Once again abusing legitimate infrastructure, this link points to a file hosted on Google Sites. If the Google Sites page has been taken down, the visitor is redirected to a malicious .top domain. The downloaded file is a ZIP archive containing an obfuscated JS script. This JS script, in turn, is executed via WScript and uses PowerShell to download the IcedID payload, its loader, and a Cobalt Strike beacon. The Cobalt Strike Beacon provides the attackers with remote access, while the IcedID payload provides infostealing capabilities, allowing the attackers to gather system information and browser credentials. For more information, see the Microsoft blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2021/04/09/investigating-a-unique-form-of-email-delivery-for-icedid-malware/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Watering Hole Attack From Unknown Group Targets MacOS
Google's Threat Analysis Group has reported a new exploit chain targeting Mac devices, starting with a watering hole attack. This attack results in a new, sophisticated backdoor being installed on the victim's machine.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Watering Hole Attack From Unknown Group Targets MacOS
Google's Threat Analysis Group has reported a new exploit chain targeting Mac devices, starting with a watering hole attack. This attack results in a new, sophisticated backdoor being installed on the victim's machine.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Targets:** Mac/IOS Users
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown **  
**
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Watering Hold Attack
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Input Capture, Exfiltration



# Overview

Google's Threat Analysis Group has reported a new exploit chain targeting Mac devices, starting with a watering hole attack. The attack targets unpatched MacOS Catalina, which leads to the installation of a previously unknown backdoor. It is speculated that the group behind this attack may be state-supported, as the malware is high quality and it appears they have a lot of resources with which to set up infrastructure and develop malware. The attack begins on malicious websites that contain iframes that serve the exploits. One targets ios, and the other targets MacOS, with both using a different framework. Once the user navigates to the malicious pages and the remote code execution completes, a heavily obfuscated embedded binary is loaded into memory, patched, and run. This binary then uses an exploit to escalate privilege, allowing the attacker to generate their own sec_token and audit_token. After gaining root, the payload is run in the background of the victim's machine. This payload appears to be highly sophisticated, suggesting that the threat actor has extensive software engineering capabilities. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222567/Watering%20Hole%20Attack%20From%20Unknown%20Group%20Targets%20MacOS%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637069386478&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 



# References

  * <https://blog.google/threat-analysis-group/analyzing-watering-hole-campaign-using-macos-exploits/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1040 - Network Sniffing  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 



# References

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Chaos Ransomware Variant Sides with Russia
Fortinet Labs is reporting on a new variant of ransomware that is being utilized as a part of the Russian/Ukraine conflict. The new variant of Chaos ransomware is being reported as “being on the side” as the attacker using this malware appears to be pro-Russian.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type: Ransomware**
  *  **Targets: Unknown**
  *  **Ransomware Family: Chaos**
  *  **RaaS Operation: Unknown**
  *  **Initial Infection Vector: Phishing**
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions: Data Loss**



# Overview

Fortinet Labs has conducted research on how a new variant of Chaos ransomware is being utilized. Their assessment is that the ransomware may be distributed by email and forum posts that masquerade as updates on the Russian/Ukrainian conflict. Fortinet also assesses that there is a ransomware builder available that the latest version of Chaos came from. Indications are, based on reporting, that the perpetrator(s) of this ransomware have no intent on providing decryption keys. Fortinet believes that Chaos malware is being used to destroy information rather than for monetary gain. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/chaos-ransomware-variant-sides-with-russia>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

#### Tactics and Techniques:

  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1552.001 - Credentials In Files  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1029:** Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: BazarLoader Used to Deploy Diavol Ransomware
The DFIR Report has published their analysis of a ransomware attack that used the BazarLoader to deploy the Diavol ransomware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: BazarLoader Used to Deploy Diavol Ransomware
The DFIR Report has published their analysis of a ransomware attack that used the BazarLoader to deploy the Diavol ransomware.

# Attack Details

  *  **Ransomware Family:** Diavol
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Ransom Demand:** Yes, Unspecified amount.
  *  **Intrusion Vector:** Spearphishing, Malicious link.
  *  **Data Exfiltrated:** Yes
  *  **Data Encrypted:** Yes
  *  **Data Published:** Unknown
  *  **Additional TTPs: **See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

BazarLoader is known for being used to deploy the Ryuk and Conti ransomware. The DFIR Report has published an analysis of an attack in which BazarLoader was used to deploy the Diavol ransomware. The initial compromise was achieved using a spearphishing email that contained a link to OneDrive which directed the victim to a ZIP file that contained an ISO file. Inside the ISO was an LNK file and a DLL, the victim executing the LNK file initiating the BazarLoader infection. Multiple rounds of reconnaissance were conducted using various tools and multiple Cobalt Strike beacons were deployed on the initially compromised host. Eventually, the actor moved laterally via RDP to a host that contained shared files and installed AnyDesk and Filezilla which was used to exfiltrate data. Multiple techniques were used in attempts to obtain credentials and the actor moved on to critical hosts such as domain controllers and backup servers. On many hosts, AnyDesk was installed, and RDP access to all endpoints from the compromised central file server was established. The actual act of encrypting drives took place some 40 hours after the initial compromise and began with the execution of a batch file that stopped all services on a host, removed the Volume Shadow copies, and disabled the Windows automatic startup repair. RDP was then used to copy the Diavol ransomware executable to each system and then executed manually. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056137/BazarLoader%20Used%20to%20Deploy%20Diavol%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639554380135&api=v2)



# Detection

  * A list of Yara rules can be found here: [ YaraRules.txt](/download/attachments/74056137/BazarLoader%20Used%20to%20Deploy%20Diavol%20Ransomware%20YaraRules.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639554402803&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://thedfirreport.com/2021/12/13/diavol-ransomware/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
T1197 - BITS Jobs  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1134 - Access Token Manipulation  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1552.002 - Credentials in Registry  
T1558 - Steal or Forge Kerberos Tickets  
T1558.003 - Kerberoasting  
T1558.004 - AS-REP Roasting  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1069 - Permission Groups Discovery  
T1069.002 - Domain Groups  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1135 - Network Share Discovery  
T1482 - Domain Trust Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.001 - Remote Desktop Protocol  
T1021.002 - SMB/Windows Admin Shares  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service  
T1567.002 - Exfiltration to Cloud Storage  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

Google has released an update to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides a fix for a single vulnerability, which Google has rated as High. An exploit for the vulnerability exists in the wild.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Google has released an update, version 88.0.4324.150, to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides a fix for a single vulnerability. Google has rated the vulnerability (CVE-2021-21148) as High. An exploit for the vulnerability exists in the wild. If successfully exploited, the vulnerability could potentially allow for the remote execution of arbitrary code. Further information is available from the release notes which are linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-21148




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Gacrux Malware and Custom PE Loader
Gacrux is a basic C malware that features a custom PE loader. According to Krabs On Security, the malware has several key features as well as features borrowed from other malware families.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Gacrux is malware featuring anti-debugging and anti-VM tricks. Utilizing jumps in code, IDA will disassemble inaccurately after those jumps. This is easily remedied by inserting NOPs after the jumps. Using pattern scanning, the file can be decompiled quickly and easily. After this fix, fake returns make IDA's function analysis operate incorrectly. This, too, can be circumvented by NOPing the offending returns. Pattern encryption/decryption is also included to further the anti-debugging functionality. These functions make analysis difficult but not impossible. In addition to the above anti-debugging and anti-VM tricks, the code contains functions spread throughout that will crash a given process should a debugger or VM be detected. For instance, if a system has too little RAM or disk space, the malware assumes virtualization and will result in termination of the malware or debugger. A syscall module is implemented from an open-source crypter and persistence is accomplished via a Window procedure that masquerades as explorer.exe. An .LNK file is inserted into the startup directory if it is not already present. The malware can operate on 32-bit as well as 64-bit environments using syscalls. These functions are copied from open-source implementations. The custom PE header and customized loader present, perhaps, the most intriguing feature of the malware. The loader, as with the malware overall, contains some anti-debugging checks. Three APIs are resolved and these APIs are used to process the import table and other functions. Networking is also included in the malware using WinInet after explorer injection. Further information can be found in the link contained within the Reference section below. 

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://krabsonsecurity.com/2020/10/24/gacrux-a-basic-c-malware-with-a-custom-pe-loader/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: IoCs Associated With the Maze Ransomware
The Maze ransomware is known to have been used in attacks against a number of industry sectors including energy, financial, healthcare, IT services, legal, and security. A report from Rewterz provides some IoCs associated with current Maze activity.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: IoCs Associated With the Maze Ransomware
The Maze ransomware is known to have been used in attacks against a number of industry sectors including energy, financial, healthcare, IT services, legal, and security. A report from Rewterz provides some IoCs associated with current Maze activity.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

Maze is well known ransomware and which not only encrypts a victim's files, the operators also exfiltrate data which they then threaten to make public unless the ransom is paid. This technique has been adopted by a number of ransomware groups and is used as a means to increase the likelihood of the ransom being paid by the victim. According to Rewterz, the Maze activity observed begins with a phishing email that has an attached, malicious document. Maze has also been deployed in attacks which used brute force, RDP, and SMB attacks to compromise systems. The document uses embedded macros which in turn use the URLDownloadToFileA() function or PowerShell to download the payload from a URL. The Maze installation process carries out a number of operations that include anti-debugging and anti-analysis checks, and checking the location of the victim system. Once installed C&C communications begin and result in the exfiltration of data and the encryption of files on the victim system. The Maze ransomware is known to have been used in attacks against a number of industry sectors including energy, financial, healthcare, IT services, legal, and security. # Overview

Maze is well known ransomware and which not only encrypts a victim's files, the operators also exfiltrate data which they then threaten to make public unless the ransom is paid. This technique has been adopted by a number of ransomware groups and is used as a means to increase the likelihood of the ransom being paid by the victim. According to Rewterz, the Maze activity observed begins with a phishing email that has an attached, malicious document. Maze has also been deployed in attacks which used brute force, RDP, and SMB attacks to compromise systems. The Maze installation process carries out a number of operations that include anti-debugging and anti-analysis checks, and checking the location of the victim system. instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Iranian APT Identified Obtaining Voter Registration Data
US-CERT published alert AA20-304A to address Iranian APT activity targeting U.S. state governments in order to retrieve voter registration information.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * APT, Exploit, Espionage




# Overview

US-CERT published alert AA20-304A providing an overview of the attack chain associated with recent Iranian APT activity targeting U.S. state governments in order to retrieve voter registration information. The attackers began by performing vulnerability scans using the legitimate Acunetix web scanner. They queried election-related sites for PDF files and URLs containing the words “vote” or “voter” and “registration.” With target websites identified, the actors then attempted to use scripted CURL activity to obtain voter information from these sites. Other attempted methods of access included attempted exploitation of known vulnerabilities, directory traversal, Structured Query Language (SQL) injection, web shell uploads, and leveraging unique flaws in websites. At least one state fell victim to these attacks, and the obtained information was subsequently used in propaganda videos distributed by the APT. This points to the goal of using such information in election-related disinformation campaigns. Additional activity believed to be carried out by this actor was a voter intimidation campaign; this type of campaign could also leverage stolen voter registration data to increase effectiveness. For more information, see the US-CERT alert in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa20-304a>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Royal Ripper Multi-Stage Phishing Attack
Leveraging a multi-stage attack chain, a threat actor, dubbed "Royal Ripper" by PhishLabs, is attempting to steal banking credentials.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

  
PhishLabs reports on a multi-stage phishing campaign being carried out by a threat actor they've named Royal Ripper. The campaign begins with an SMS lure impersonating a government agency, telecommunications company, or online payment service. They specifically analyzed the case of a lure that poses a tax notice from HM Revenue and Customs claiming the recipient is owed a tax return. Visiting the link leads to a fake UK government tax refund form that first requests the victim's name and postcode. After this, it requires further information including credit card details and a bank routing number. This routing number, in turn, is used to identify the corresponding bank and redirect victims to a phishing page masquerading as that associated institution. This page is aimed at harvesting bank account credentials. An open directory contains the various phishing pages, lookups for the routing numbers, and any stolen credentials. The credit card information gathered in the first stage is also saved to this open directory. For more information, see the PhishLabs blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Always be suspicious of unsolicited emails or SMS messages.




# Reference

  * <https://info.phishlabs.com/blog/royal-ripper-multi-stage-phishing-attack-adapts-to-victim-input>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Renewable Energy Sector Targeted
A new blog post from Bushidotoken Threat Intel reports that the renewable energy sector is the target of an intelligence information gathering campaign.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing Email
  *  **Target:** Renewable Energy, Industrial Control Systems Companies and Industries
  *  **Lure:** Password expired email
  *  **Payload:** Malicious link
  *  **Compromised Data:** Usernames and Passwords
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

According to a blog post from Bushidotoken, a campaign is underway that targets renewable energy and industrial tech organizations focusing mainly on Bulgaria. Organizations offering operational technology and industrial control systems from vendors such as Schneider Electric and Honeywell have been noted in the blog. Other companies and universities are also named as targets in the blog. The use of a custom ‘Mail Box’ phishing kit is used to collect the passwords of victims who visit the site. The kits are generic in nature and lead to a second stage of the kit. This stage consists of a "Your Mail Box storage is full" phishing email. This activity is purportedly connected to two APT groups: APT28 (FancyBear) and Konni. Several discovered hostnames and infrastructure similarities led researchers to the conclusion these activities could be related to the above-noted threat groups. For example, APT28 Konni both used Zetta Hosting for the phishing domains as well for C2 domains. At present, there is no hard evidence pointing to a definitive crossover of campaigns with previously noted campaigns. Further information can be found in the blog post located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057285/Renewable%20Energy%20Sector%20Targeted%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642707777195&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction. (M1017)
  * Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc. (M1021)
  * Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries. (M1031)
  * Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personally identifiable information (PII), and restrict the exfiltration of sensitive data. (M1057)



# References

  * <https://blog.bushidotoken.net/2022/01/tracking-renewable-energy-intelligence.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1589.001 - Credentials  
T1589.002 - Email Addresses  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: TeamTNT Targets AWS Instances
TeamTNT is known to attack cloud services with intent to steal credentials, perform cryptojacking, or install backdoors. Trend Micro reports on a specific script used by the group to steal AWS credentials.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Trend Micro has published an analysis of a shell script used by TeamTNT to steal AWS credentials. This script was found hardcoded in a malicious binary dropped onto compromised systems. It was likely dropped onto systems after the threat actor exploited a misconfiguration or vulnerabilities to gain remote access. The script runs on any Linux system, whether it is running an AWS instance or not. The file that stores the stolen credentials is also created and ex-filtrated regardless of whether any data was actually found. The remote server to which the files were uploaded was an open directory, allowing the researchers to see all of the ex-filtrated data. They also discovered cryptocurrency mining tools being hosted on the same server. In the small percentage of cases where the script ran successfully on an AWS instance, it was able to steal AWS related secrets, providing information that can be used to carry out further attacks. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/c/teamtnt-continues-attack-on-the-cloud--focuses-on-aws-instances.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Amazon Prime Day Scams
With Amazon Prime day coming up, Check Point and Trend Micro have observed threat actors using the event as a lure for phishing and scam campaigns.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Amazon Prime Day Scams
With Amazon Prime day coming up, Check Point and Trend Micro have observed threat actors using the event as a lure for phishing and scam campaigns.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing, Scam




# Overview

Check Point and Trend Micro have both published blogs analyzing new scam and phishing campaigns taking advantage of the upcoming Amazon Prime Day event to steal sensitive information. Check Point first notes the major increase in domain registrations that include the word "Amazon," many of which are classified as either malicious or suspicious. Aligning with this domain registration activity, Check Point and Trend Micro researchers have discovered various campaigns leveraging this theme. Some of the campaigns include phishing emails with links, while other campaigns use social engineer over the phone. Trend Micro identified recent PDF submissions on VirusTotal using Amazon branding to redirect users to phishing sites. Whatever method is used, the attackers' goals are to collect sensitive information, such as login credentials, or payment information. Trend Micro briefly mentions the Heatstroke campaign, which has used Amazon-themed lures in the past, and its improvements to its campaigns over the past few years of activity. For more information, see the Check Point and Trend Micro blog posts in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: The Evolution of the FIN7 JSSLoader
Given the lack of historical reporting on the FIN7 JSSLoader infection chain, Morphisec has published a whitepaper describing the malware and its evolution.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

Morphisec has published a whitepaper analyzing the JSSLoader malware, its infection chain, and its evolution over the past year. JSSLoader is a simple .NET RAT leveraged by FIN7, a financially motivated cybercrime group tracked by IBM as ITG14. The group's campaigns typically begin with a phishing email luring visitors to click a malicious link. Hosted at the destination link is a VBScript or WSF file that the user is enticed to download. This script, in turn, executes a second-stage VBScript in memory. Finally, the JSSLoader payload is downloaded and executed on the system. The remote access can then be used for a variety of purposes. In the specific case described by Morphisec, it is used to execute DiceLoader, which is responsible for installing a Cobalt beacon. The researchers note a resemblance between the scripts used in this campaign to load JSSLoader and those used in QBot campaigns. In terms of the evolution of the malware, most of the functionality has remained the same since October 2019. Persistence is still established via a LNK file in the Startup folder, system information is exfiltrated to the C2 server, and the RAT can receive commands from that server. The main changes have been the addition of new commands. For more information, see Morphisec's whitepaper in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.morphisec.com/hubfs/eBooks_and_Whitepapers/FIN7%20JSSLOADER%20FINAL%20WEB.pdf>
