instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: XSS Bug in Google Maps Identified
A security researcher has uncovered an XSS vulnerability in Google Maps. The researcher, Zohar Shachar, twice reported the bug to Google with the second attempt successful in the patching of the vulnerability.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: XSS Bug in Google Maps Identified
A security researcher has uncovered an XSS vulnerability in Google Maps. The researcher, Zohar Shachar, twice reported the bug to Google with the second attempt successful in the patching of the vulnerability.

# Threat Type

  * XSS, Vulnerability




# Overview

Under Google's bug hunter program, a security researcher discovered a bug in Google Maps. The bug starts with the create your own map functionality. Upon building the map, the user is able to export the map in KML. KML is similar to XML with some extra features. In his research, he created a map and exported with KML; however, upon submission of the exported file to the server, some XML responses were received. The culprit in the vulnerability is the inability to close the CDATA tag. Mr. Shachar was able to find a way to close the tag by using special characters at the beginning of the payload. In his case, he used the map name tag. It is at this point where the introduction of arbitrary XML code can be introduced. This leads to the XSS. This discovery and submission of this bug garnered Mr. Shachar a bounty and an email stating the bug had been addressed. In order to check the fix, the researcher performed the same steps and found the only way to close a CDATA tag was to add another CDATA tag. This allowed him to bypass the first fix. This information was passed to Google with the promise of another fix and, for Mr. Shachar, an additional bounty. Further information can be found in the article linked within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.ehpus.com/post/xss-fix-bypass-10000-bounty-in-google-maps>

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
XSS Bug in Google Maps Identified
A security researcher has uncovered an XSS vulnerability in Google Maps. The researcher, Zohar Shachar, twice reported the bug to Google with the second attempt successful in the patching of the vulnerability.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * XSS, Vulnerability




# Overview

Under Google's bug hunter program, a security researcher discovered a bug in Google Maps. The bug starts with the create your own map functionality. Upon building the map, the user is able to export the map in KML. KML is similar to XML with some extra features. In his research, he created a map and exported with KML; however, upon submission of the exported file to the server, some XML responses were received. The culprit in the vulnerability is the inability to close the CDATA tag. Mr. Shachar was able to find a way to close the tag by using special characters at the beginning of the payload. In his case, he used the map name tag. It is at this point where the introduction of arbitrary XML code can be introduced. This leads to the XSS. This discovery and submission of this bug garnered Mr. Shachar a bounty and an email stating the bug had been addressed. In order to check the fix, the researcher performed the same steps and found the only way to close a CDATA tag was to add another CDATA tag. This allowed him to bypass the first fix. This information was passed to Google with the promise of another fix and, for Mr. Shachar, an additional bounty. Further information can be found in the article linked within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.ehpus.com/post/xss-fix-bypass-10000-bounty-in-google-maps>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Microsoft November Patch Tuesday
For November's Patch Tuesday, Microsoft patched 114 vulnerabilities across their various product lines.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

Microsoft patched 114 vulnerabilities across their product lines in their November Patch Tuesday. Overall, Microsoft rated the release as High. The most serious vulnerability, if successfully exploited, could potentially result in remote code execution. In some cases, detailed exploit information is available. Listed below are vulnerabilities of interest.

# CVEs of Note

  * Windows Network File System Remote Code Execution Vulnerability (CVE-2020-17051)
  * Scripting Engine Memory Corruption Vulnerability (CVE-2020-17052)
  * Internet Explorer Memory Corruption Vulnerability (CVE-2020-17053)
  * Raw Image Extension Remote Code Execution Vulnerability (CVE-2020-17078)
  * Raw Image Extension Remote Code Execution Vulnerability (CVE-2020-17079)
  * HEIF Image Extensions Remote Code Execution Vulnerability (CVE-2020-17101)
  * AV1 Video Extension Remote Code Execution Vulnerability (CVE-2020-17105)
  * HEVC Video Extensions Remote Code Execution Vulnerability (CVE-2020-17106)
  * HEVC Video Extensions Remote Code Execution Vulnerability (CVE-2020-17107)
  * HEVC Video Extensions Remote Code Execution Vulnerability (CVE-2020-17108)
  * HEVC Video Extensions Remote Code Execution Vulnerability (CVE-2020-17109)
  * HEVC Video Extensions Remote Code Execution Vulnerability (CVE-2020-17110)
  * Windows Print Spooler Remote Code Execution Vulnerability (CVE-2020-17042)



# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33982226/Microsoft%20November%20Patch%20Tuesday%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1605115618626&api=v2)



# Protection

## IBM

  * CVE-2020-17006: Cross_Site_Scripting
  * CVE-2020-17018: Cross_Site_Scripting
  * CVE-2020-17021: Cross_Site_Scripting
  * CVE-2020-17051: RPC_NFS_Name_Size_Overflow
  * CVE-2020-17053: Script_IE_Memory_Corruption_219
  * CVE-2020-17056: RPC_NFS_Windows_Overflow_01
  * CVE-2020-17061: XML_SharePoint_Info_Disclosure



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/releaseNote/2020-Nov>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: TeamTNT Abusing Legitimate Tools To Control Compromised Hosts
Trend Micro previously reported on TeamTNT using compromised Docker accounts to infect victims with cryptomining malware. They have been able to investigate some victim hosts to discover some of their tools and techniques, including the abuse of a legitimate tool to control compromised containers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Cryptomining
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Threat Actor:** TeamTNT
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining, Lateral Movement



# Overview

Trend Micro previously reported on TeamTNT using compromised Docker accounts to carry out cryptomining activities on unsuspecting victims. The accounts have since been removed, but the researchers were able to investigate the threat actor's activities and discover some of their tools and techniques. One technique the team uses to monitor and control containers is the legitimate tool Weave Scope. This tool is a visualization and monitoring tool for Docker and Kubernetes. The attackers use the tool by making the compromised host a node of the threat-actor controlled Weave Scope Cloud instance, from where they could issue commands to the compromised machine. The attackers were also able to break out from a compromised container into the host. To do this, they were able to fetch Docker hub credentials that are stored in an unencrypted state. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/73465943/TeamTNT%20Abusing%20Legitimate%20Tools%20To%20Control%20Compromised%20Hosts%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638549967780&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Use read-only containers and minimal images when possible to prevent the execution of commands (M1038).
  * Ensure containers are not running as root by default (M1026).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/l/more-tools-in-the-arsenal-how-teamtnt-used-compromised-docker-hu.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

  *  **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1586 - Compromise Accounts  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1552.001 - Credentials In Files  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Xen Advisories - October 2020
Xen has published three advisories, XSA-345, XSA-346, and XSA-346.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

Xen has published three advisories detailing issues that have been patched.

  
XSA-345 describes a race condition within the code that handles the hypervisor's page tables. A malicious guest operating system could use this oversight to cause the hypervisor to write to a page that had been freed. This could potentially cause data corruption, privilege escalation, or a denial of service condition.

  
XSA-346 corrects an issue that occurs when guest pages are coalesced. Due to possible removal of pages from guest pages, the fragmentation may not be accounted for during the coalesced flush. Potential impacts include data corruption, data leaks, privilege escalation, or denial of service condition.

  
XSA-346 addresses an issue with an AMD CPU that updates memory table entries in a step-by-step fashion. This could potentially result in the IOMMU accessing a partially updated table entry. Data corruption, data leaks, privilege escalation, or denial of service condition are potential outcomes.

# CVEs

  * Not assigned yet



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <http://xenbits.xen.org/xsa/advisory-345.html>
  * <http://xenbits.xen.org/xsa/advisory-346.html>
  * <http://xenbits.xen.org/xsa/advisory-347.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Symchanger Malware Installing Backdoor on Unsuspecting Users
Sucuri Labs reports on the Symchanger malware being peddled to bad actors under the guise of free malware for use in campaigns.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Symchanger malware is a "free" malware being distributed by bad to other bad actors under the guise of free malware. In addition to the malware, the compromise tool is being promoted on a Facebook group along with a tutorial video. The malware, however, is distributed with a backdoor installer that allows the authors access to other bad actor's computer systems. The code is obfuscated using differing layers and code checks. Deobfuscation is not an easy feat as it's not just text that is encoded and compressed. Upon deobfuscation of the code, the symchanger.php name is seen. Cross-contamination is accomplished via a popular symlink method so long as the site is hosted by the same user as the compromised website. A tool is used to search for configuration files for various website publication platforms such as WordPress and others. If detected, a .txt file is generated so the file can be downloaded. If /etc/passwd is accessible, the file is read and a list of existing users is gathered. A loop is then used to run the list of users from passwd against the various publication system's configuration files to extract the matching credentials. The malware then reads SQL connection information and connects to the associated database, where it adds a malicious administrative user to any databases to which it can successfully connect. Once the script has finished, the results are displayed to the threat actor. Without deobfuscation, the malware appears to be what the attacker claims it to be. The malware sends five emails to multiple addresses which contain sensitive data for the compromised website(s). Further details can be found in the blog post located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/12/free-symchanger-malware-tricks-users-into-installing-backdoor.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Fake DarkSide Campaign Targets Energy and Food Sectors
Following the DarkSide ransomware attack against Colonial Pipeline, Trend Micro has discovered threat actors attempting to use the event to social engineer companies into paying a fake ransom.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Fake DarkSide Campaign Targets Energy and Food Sectors
Following the DarkSide ransomware attack against Colonial Pipeline, Trend Micro has discovered threat actors attempting to use the event to social engineer companies into paying a fake ransom.

# Threat Type

  * Extortion




Overview

Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing an extortion campaign attempting to use DarkSide's presence in the media to obtain ransom payments. The fraud attempts are carried out via email, either by directly emailing a victim or sending the content through web contact forms. Notably, the emails solely targeted companies in the energy and food sectors, across a range of geographies. The content of the message claims that the email is from the DarkSide operators and that they have hacked the recipient's company. The sender threatens to release sensitive data if a Bitcoin payment isn't sent to a provided wallet address. This wallet address is static across victims and has not yet received any payments. Trend Micro notes multiple inconsistencies indicating this campaign is not actually operated by DarkSide. For example, no ransomware payloads are deployed. Additionally, the ransom email mentions the group being behind the JBS attack, which was instead attributed REvil. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/f/fake-darkside-campaign-targets-energy-and-food-sectors.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: LATAM Banking Trojan – Numando
ESET has published another in its series of articles on Latin American banking Trojans. This time, the focus is Numando.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Banking Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Numando
  *  **Targets:** Bank customers in Brazil.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malspam
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions: Stealing and exfiltration of user information.**
  *  **Additional TTPs: See MITRE ATT &CK Framework below.**



# Overview

The Numando banking Trojan is used primarily to target bank users in Brazil. It has been known on rare occasions to have been used in campaigns targeting users in Mexico and Spain. According to ESET, The actor behind Numando has been active since 2018 however, Numando is not frequently updated and does not appear to be under continuous development. It provides features common to banking Trojans such as overlay windows and backdoor access to an infected system. Currently, Numando is distributed using malspam with a ZIP file containing an MSI installer attached to the emails. Inside the installer is a CAB archive that contains an injector, an encrypted DLL which is the Numando payload, and a legitimate application. The legitimate application is used to sideload the Numando DLL. One other infection chain that was used by Numando starts with a downloader that downloads a ZIP file but ignores its content. Instead, it extracts the ZIP file's comment which is a hex-encoded and encrypted string that when decrypted provides the URL of the actual ZIP file whose contents are used in the infection chain. Numando uses a remote configuration that is stored in either Pastebin or YouTube pages. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64128206/LATAM%20Banking%20Trojan%20%E2%80%93%20Numando%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632197194015&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/09/17/numando-latam-banking-trojan/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.007 - Msiexec  
T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1010 - Application Window Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1132 - Data Encoding  
T1132.002 - Non-Standard Encoding

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Recent Sandworm Activity
Following up on ANSSI's research into recent Sandworm activity, DomainTools reports on their findings related to the infrastructure used by this threat actor.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

DomainTools has published a report identifying Sandworm infrastructure discovered during their investigation into ANSSI's recent report on the threat group. ANSSI's report discussed the exploitation of Centreon to deliver Exaramel, a known Sandworm tool. The report, however, did not detail any network indicators associated with this activity, causing DomainTools to dig further. They began by looking at the Exim exploitation campaign that the NSA reported on as occurring during an overlapping time period with the Centreon activity. The NSA report provided a few network indicators, specifically two IP addresses and a domain. Pivoting to related domains and IP address resolutions led to several new addresses and domains used by the group. They also discovered a couple bash scripts leveraging this infrastructure for communication. These scripts created a new user and associated SSH configuration, executed Python code, and established persistence. Eventually a secondary payload could be executed, but researchers were unable to retrieve a sample. Subdomains tied to the discovered domains indicate that the infrastructure was also used to host credential phishing pages for mail and social media services. Ultimately, DomainTools was unable to identify infrastructure specifically associated with the Centreon activity described by ANSSI, but they we able to find previously unreported on Sandworm network indicators. For more information, see the DomainTools blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.domaintools.com/resources/blog/centreon-to-exim-and-back-on-the-trail-of-sandworm>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: COVID Phishing Scam Targets New Mexico Department Of Labor
A new COVID phishing scam has been reported by the Cofense Phishing Defense Center. The email claims to offer benefits to victims because of the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Targets:** New Mexico Department Of Labor
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Credential Harvesting



# Overview

The Cofense Phishing Defense Center has published details of a new phishing campaign which is using COVID as a lure to steal personal data. This campaign is very targeted, claiming to come from the New Mexico Department of Labor. The email tells victims they are eligible for COVID19 benefits. To determine if they are eligible, and the amount they could receive, the user is asked to fill out an online form with some details. Besides the form link, the email also includes the option to opt-in to updates from the department to boost legitimacy. If the link is followed, they are taken to a page that looks like the New Mexico Department of Workforce Solutions login page. After the user logs in with a username and password, which would be harvested by the malicious actors, they are taken to a second part of the form. Here, their email address and social security number can be entered and is harvested if the user enters them. Once this is submitted, the user is redirected to the real Department of Labor site. The emails in this campaign were successful at getting through secure email gateways and into the inbox of targets. Further technical details can be found within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68617074/COVID%20Phishing%20Scam%20Targets%20New%20Mexico%20Department%20Of%20Labor%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635522266551&api=v2)

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Users can be trained to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Apple Security Updates for macOS February 09 2021
Apple has published security updates for macOS Big Sur, Catalina, and Mojave.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Apple Security Updates for macOS February 09 2021
Apple has published security updates for macOS Big Sur, Catalina, and Mojave.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
Apple has published security updates for macOS macOS Big Sur, Catalina, and Mojave. The updates address three vulnerabilities, only one of the vulnerabilities affects Mojave. The most serious potential impact from successful exploitation of the vulnerabilities addressed in Big Sur and Catalina is the remote execution of arbitrary code with kernel privileges. The vulnerability that affects Big Sur, Catalina, and Mojave is a privilege escalation vulnerability in sudo. Further details are available from the advisories linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-1805, CVE-2021-1806, CVE-2021-3156




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT212177>

I have encountered the following information: New Version of BRATA Android RAT
BRATA has expanded its operations outside of the LATAM region into Italy. Cleafy reports on the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) involved in a recent campaign against Italian banking customers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Android banking Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** BRATA
  *  **Targets:** Italian bank customers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious link via SMS
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft, financial fraud



# Overview

Cleafy published a blog post analyzing a new BRATA campaign targeting Italian banking customers. The infection chain begins with an SMS message containing a link to a website supposedly providing an anti-spam application. The message comes from a spoofed number appearing to be the victim's bank. A human operator will call users who download the app to walk them through the installation process, which involves granting intrusive permissions. With the permissions provided, the malware operator can intercept SMS messages to receive 2FA codes for use in fraudulent transactions. Additionally, the malware is capable of screen recording, uninstalling itself, disabling security defenses, displaying phishing pages, and more. The move from originally targeting Brazilian users to now targeting Italian users may be the result of the malware authors reselling their payloads, according to Cleafy. For more information, see the Cleafy blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74055902/New%20Version%20of%20BRATA%20Android%20RAT%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638980691655&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Install security updates (M1001).
  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).
  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.



# References

  * <https://www.cleafy.com/cleafy-labs/mobile-banking-fraud-brata-strikes-again>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  
  
 **Execution - TA0041**  
T1575 - Native Code  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0029**  
T1401 - Device Administrator Permissions  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0030**  
T1576 - Uninstall Malicious Application  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0031**  
T1411 - Input Prompt  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages  
T1417 - Input Capture  
  
 **Collection - TA0035**  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages  
T1417 - Input Capture  
T1513 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0037**  
T1509 - Uncommonly Used Port

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Spammers Flood PyPI with Pirated Movie Links and Bogus Packages
PyPi is the official Python software package repository. Recently, BleepingComputer has observed the platform being flooded with spam packages.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Spam




# Overview

BleepingComputer has published an article detailing spam activity occurring in the PyPI package repository. The most commonly observed packages had names indicating they were related to free streams of popular movies. Inside the package descriptions were links to pirated movie streaming sites. The publishers of the packages varied, which makes it harder for the PyPI admins to track down and remove the culprits. Analysis of the packages themselves shows that they contain code from legitimate PyPI packages. The spammers simply hijack the description and package name in order to distribute their spam content. For more information, see the BleepingComputer blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Be wary when leveraging packages from public repositories.



# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/spammers-flood-pypi-with-pirated-movie-links-and-bogus-packages/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: PuzzleMaker Attacks with Chrome Zero-Day Exploit Chain
A recent blog post from Kaspersky details an exploit chain involving the abuse of Chrome and Windows 0-day vulnerabilities to deliver malware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: PuzzleMaker Attacks with Chrome Zero-Day Exploit Chain
A recent blog post from Kaspersky details an exploit chain involving the abuse of Chrome and Windows 0-day vulnerabilities to deliver malware.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Exploit




# Overview

Kaspersky published a blog post analyzing an exploit chain involving multiple Chrome and Windows 0-days to deliver malware. The exploit chain was observed being used in highly targeted attacks against multiple companies. It began with a Chrome remote code execution exploit. While the exploit code itself was unable to be retrieved, the time frame of the attack leads the researchers to believe CVE-2021-21224 was exploited. The next stage in the exploit chain uses two Windows vulnerabilities: an information disclosure vulnerability, CVE-2021-31955, and a buffer overflow vulnerability, CVE-2021-31956. In combination, these vulnerabilities can allow the attacker to carry out a privilege escalation exploit, ultimately using the access to inject malware into a system process. In terms of the malware used, a stager is used to download a dropper which, in turn, installs two executables. The first executable is a service that is used as a launcher for the second, a remote shell. From the remote shell, the attacker can upload and download files, create processes, sleep, or self-delete. Kaspersky was unable to attribute this activity to a known threat actor and has dubbed the actor behind this campaign "PuzzleMaker." For more information, see the Securelist blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/puzzlemaker-chrome-zero-day-exploit-chain/102771/>

  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Mushtik, Setag

  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Backdoor installation, C2 Communication



# Overview

Researchers at Fortinet have been tracking a new vulnerability affecting confluence instances. The vulnerability is being tracked as CVE-2021-26084 and enables threat actors to run arbitrary code on unpatched confluence servers and Data Center instances. Since the disclosure of this vulnerability, Fortinet has seen massive scanning across the internet, as well as POC, exploit code. Fortinet has observed several attack attempts using this vulnerability, including cryptojacking attacks, backdoor downloads, and fileless attacks leveraging PowerShell. It has also been seen in attacks spreading the Mushtik botnet. The exploit is used to download malware onto the hosts, and in one case, further reconnaissance tools are downloaded. In another attack, a PowerShell command was used to set up a reverse shell, allowing the attacked access to the machine. The patch has already been released, but public attacks are ongoing. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616634/Confluence%20Vulnerability%20Being%20Exploited%20In-The-Wild%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635248121083&api=v2)



# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616634/Confluence%20Vulnerability%20Being%20Exploited%20In-The-Wild%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635248121083&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).
  * When PowerShell is necessary, restrict PowerShell execution policy to administrators. Be aware that there are methods of bypassing the PowerShell execution policy, depending on environment configuration (M1026).



# References

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/recent-attack-uses-vulnerability-on-confluence-server>

T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1110 - Brute Force  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: ZLoader Distributed via Business Shut Down Warnings
Analysis of a spam campaign analyzed by EST Security revealed its attempt to distribute the ZLoader malware to victims.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: ZLoader Distributed via Business Shut Down Warnings
Analysis of a spam campaign analyzed by EST Security revealed its attempt to distribute the ZLoader malware to victims.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Loader




# Overview

EST Security published their analysis of a spam campaign affecting Korean users. The initial email claims that the recipient's business will be shut down and provides a link to view more details. This link points to a Google Doc containing a secondary link. If the user once again clicks the link, an XLS file is downloaded to their system from a malicious domain. Opening the document and enabling macros leads to the execution of a downloader function that retrieves a secondary file from the same domain as before. This time the downloaded file is the ZLoader payload in the form of a DLL that is injected into msiexec.exe and rundll32.exe. Once running in memory, the loader downloads and executes the Zeus banking Trojan, which can steal sensitive data from victims. For more information, see the EST Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.alyac.co.kr/3322>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Hello Kitty Ransomware Added DDoS Extortion Threat
An FBI Flash notes that the Hello Kitty ransomware operators have in some cases used an additional extortion threat, that of a DDoS attack.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Hello Kitty (S0617), FiveHands (S0618)
  *  **RaaS Operation:** No
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploiting SonicWall vulnerabilities or using compromised credentials.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and Exfiltration of data, Encrypting of files.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.
  *  **Leak Site:** Hello Kitty uses the Babuk leak site.



# Overview

The FBI has published a Flash alert that provides IoCs associated with the Hello Kitty ransomware which is also known as FiveHands. In addition, the alert advises that in some cases, victims have been threatened that a DDoS attack will be launched on their public website should the ransom not be paid within the specified timeframe. The DDoS threat is on top of the typical threat of publication of the victim's sensitive data. The Flash also notes that Hello Kitty is known to have achieved their initial compromises through exploiting vulnerabilities in SonicWall products (CVE-2021-20016, CVE-2021-20021, CVE-2021-20022, CVE-2021-20023) or using compromised credentials. Hello Kitty uses the Babuk leak site for publication. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68617290/Hello%20Kitty%20Ransomware%20Added%20DDoS%20Extortion%20Threat%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635834059601&api=v2)



# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here:[ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/68617290/Hello%20Kitty%20Ransomware%20Added%20DDoS%20Extortion%20Threat%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635865048311&api=v2)

  * <https://www.ic3.gov/Media/News/2021/211029.pdf>

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Lazarus Targeting Covid-19 Related Intelligence
Kaspersky Labs has published a paper indicating that the threat-group Lazarus is specifically targeting organizations with ties to Covid-19.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Threat-group



# Overview

While monitoring the threat-group Lazarus, Kaspersky Labs discovered that they had attacked a pharmaceutical company in September and a government health ministry in October. In the ministry attack, two Windows servers were compromised by a yet unknown infection vector. The malware used in the attack was called wAgent, a memory resident-only application that pulls additional modules, as needed, from a remote server. Persistence is achieved by downloading an additional module for this purpose. In the pharmaceutical attack, the malware package called Bookcode was deployed in a supply chain attack, coming in through a South Korean software company. Although different types of attacks and malware were used, Kaspersky indicated they had enough evidence to tie both attacks to the Lazarus group. For technical details of these attacks, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35719002/Lazarus%20Targeting%20Covid-19%20Related%20Intelligence%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1609172496304&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/lazarus-covets-covid-19-related-intelligence/99906/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Operation Earth Kitsune and SLUB
A report from Trend Micro Research into what they have named Operation Earth Kitsune. The report looks at the evolution of the SLUB malware and the TTPs of the group behind the malware, and their current campaign.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Operation Earth Kitsune and SLUB
A report from Trend Micro Research into what they have named Operation Earth Kitsune. The report looks at the evolution of the SLUB malware and the TTPs of the group behind the malware, and their current campaign.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Watering Hole




# Overview

Operation Earth Kitsune targets Korean speakers interested in Korean issues. Trend Micro Research discovered the operation which uses compromised hosts in watering hole attacks to infect victims. The compromised hosts that were analysed for the report were all running a South Korean CMS named GNUBOARD. It is thought the hosts were compromised by exploiting known RCE vulnerabilities in the CMS. Two different infections chains are used, depending on the victim's browser. In at least some cases, South Korean IP addresses were blocked from accessing a site. If the victim browser is Internet Explorer, the attack begins with attempting to exploit the vulnerability CVE-2020-0674. If successful, a PowerShell loader is run which carries out checks for specific security software and may install up to three different backdoors on the victim system. Privilege escalation may be attempted through downloading a binary which is used to exploit the vulnerability CVE-2019-1458. If successful, the backdoors are executed with system privileges. Another vulnerability, CVE-2016-0189, may also be exploited in the attacks. If the victim browser is Chrome, two vulnerabilities are chained together for exploitation. One is CVE-2019-5782, the second does not have a CVE number assigned to it. The attack code is based on publicly available proof of concept code. Checks are made for specific security software and the infection chain will result in up to three different backdoors being installed on the victim system. One of the changes to the SLUB malware is that instead of using Slack for communications, it now uses an open-source version of Mattermost which has functionality similar to Slack. Five C&C servers are known to have been in use in the campaign. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://documents.trendmicro.com/assets/white_papers/wp-operation-earth-kitsune.pdf>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Sarwent Malware Spreading via Fake Amnesty International Websites
The Sarwent malware is a RAT that has been around since 2014. Cisco observed the malware most recently being distributed via fake Amnesty International websites claiming to provide an anti-Pegasus spyware tool.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** RAT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown Russian-speaking threat actor
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Sarwent
  *  **Targets:** Non-specific
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake AV software download
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Look-alike Amnesty International site to distribute payload



# Overview

Cisco published a blog post analyzing a campaign distributing the Sarwent malware. The payload is hosted on fake Amnesty International websites and masquerades as an anti-virus program claiming to protect users from the NSO Group's Pegasus tool. The malware is customized to look like a legitimate program to avoid raising the suspicions of users. Upon install, however, system information is exfiltrated to a C2 address and the malware waits to receive commands. The attackers can issue command line and PowerShell commands or connect to the desktop directly using VNC and RDP. The researchers believe that the threat actor is a Russian speaker that has been running Sarwent campaigns since at least January 2021. The exact goal of the attacks is currently unknown, as is the method of distributing the malicious links. For more information, see the Cisco blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129253/Sarwent%20Malware%20Spreading%20via%20Fake%20Amnesty%20International%20Websites%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633119807858&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2021/09/fakeantipegasusamnesty.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1592 - Gather Victim Host Information  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1133 - External Remote Services  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1219 - Remote Access Software

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Studying Skidmap's DNS Requests
Netlab 360 has produced a paper showing how they tracked down a mining application, skidmap, using DNS requests.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Mining



# Overview

Netlab 360 has published a paper where they tracked down a mining operation, using a miner named skidmap, based on its DNS requests. They used a tool called DNSMon to analyze DNS data to track down the infrastructure in use. Three domains were discovered in May of 2019, followed by one in November. In September and October of 2020, three more domains were added to their list. Similarities in domain name structure, choice of subdomains, and the consistent nature of the behavior patterns of the DNS requests indicated that they belonged on the list. Sample code from URLs discovered were quite similar to those analyzed by Trend Micro, which were published about four months later. For full technical details of their findings, please refer to the Netlab 360 link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [Studying Skidmaps DNS Requests IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35717368/Studying%20Skidmaps%20DNS%20Requests%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606847829707&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/security-with-dns-data_en/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: FontOnLake is New Sophisticated and Stealthy Malware
ESET researchers have analyzed a new sophisticated malware being used on targets in Southeast Asia. They have named this malware FontOnLake, and it was first seen in 2020.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Southeast Asia
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** FontOnLake
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

ESET researchers have discovered a new piece of sophisticated malware that was first observed in the May of 2020. This malware utilized custom modules and targets Linux systems. It has been named FontOnLake and is being continually developed and includes functionality such as remote access and credential harvesting. Every instance of infection of FontOnLake has been accompanied by a rootkit which serves to conceal its presence. The malware also uses patched legitimate binaries such as the Linux 'cat' command, which are used to load components. The researchers theorized that this malware is only being used in targeted attacks because of the advanced design and low prevalence. FontOnLake consists of three main parts - trojanized applications, backdoors, and rootkits. The trojans are used to load the backdoors and rootkits and are also able to collect sensitive data. Three backdoors have been seen used in FontOnLake infections, and perform functions such as exfiltration, file manipulation, serving as a proxy, and executing shell commands and python scripts. Finally, the rootkit can conceal this behavior by hiding processes and files and hiding network connections, whilst also downloading and executing more malware. The samples of this malware seen in the wild, and the C2 server locations suggest that this malware is being used to target victims in Southeast Asia. All samples used unique C2 infrastructure with varying non-standard ports, which have been taken offline since being uploaded to VirusTotal. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129960/FontOnLake%20is%20New%20Sophisticated%20and%20Stealthy%20Malware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633957567540&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing (M1045). 
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/10/07/fontonlake-previously-unknown-malware-family-targeting-linux/>
  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/eset_fontonlake.pdf>

T1078 - Valid Accounts  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
T1059.006 - Python  
T1106 - Native API  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1037 - Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts  
T1554 - Compromise Client Software Binary  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1014 - Rootkit  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1222.002 - Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
T1564.001 - Hidden Files and Directories  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1556 - Modify Authentication Process  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021.004 - SSH  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1008 - Fallback Channels  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1071.002 - File Transfer Protocols  
T1090 - Proxy  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1132.001 - Standard Encoding  
T1568 - Dynamic Resolution  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Newly-Discovered Chinese-Linked APT
Sentinel One Labs discovered a cluster of activity by a threat group they have named Aoqin Dragon which they believe is a small Chinese-speaking group.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

Summary
=======

 

Threat Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Malware
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Aoquin Dragon, Possibly linked to UNC94
* **Associated Payloads:** Mongall and Heyoka Backdoors
* **Targets:** Organizations in the education, government, and telecommunications sectors
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing, fake removable devices, fake anti-virus installers
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collections and exfiltration of sensitive data
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Sentinel One Labs has been tracking the activities of a newly discovered threat group whose objectives align with those of the Chinese government. The research indicates that the activities of this threat group, which Sentinel One has named Aoquin Dragon, may go back as far as 2013. The activities of Aoquin Dragon are directed at Southeast Asia and Australia. The organizations that this group targets are in the government, education, and telecommunications sectors. These are targets that historically have been of interest to the Chinese Government. Aoquin Dragon has utilized malicious Word documents, fake Anti-Virus installers, and fake removable devices to gain initial access. Once access has been obtained, DLL hijacking is used to load variants of the Mongall and Heyoka backdoors. This threat actor also uses Themida-packed files and DNS tunneling to provide obfuscation. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* [https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/aoqin-dragon-newly-discovered-chinese-linked-apt-has-been-quietly-spying-on-organizations-for-10-years/](https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/aoqin-dragon-newly-discovered-chinese-linked-apt-has-been-quietly-spying-on-organizations-for-10-years/ "Follow link")

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1091 - Replication Through Removable Media  
 T1566 - Phishing  

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1204 - User Execution  
 T1569 - System Services  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  

**Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
 T1055 - Process Injection  
   T1055.001 - Dynamic-link Library Injection  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
 T1211 - Exploitation for Defense Evasion  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
 T1082 - System Information Discovery  

**Collection - TA0009**  
 T1560 - Archive Collected Data  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
   T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
   T1071.004 - DNS  
 T1132 - Data Encoding  
 T1571 - Non-Standard Port  

**Mitigations:**

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1019:**  Threat Intelligence Program - A threat intelligence program helps an organization generate their own threat intelligence information and track trends to inform defensive priorities to mitigate risk.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1025:**  Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1030:**  Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1034:**  Limit Hardware Installation - Block users or groups from installing or using unapproved hardware on systems, including USB devices.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1043:**  Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
**M1044:**  Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1048:**  Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1050:**  Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Scammers Using MalwareBytes Renewals for Phishing
MalwareBytes' Threat Intelligence Team has uncovered a scam using their brand as a lure for phishing. Using fake emails and phone calls, threat actors are targeting users of MalwareBytes' services and products for the scam.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

A series of fake renewal notices and offers to remove security services offered by MalwareBytes has led their analysts to a phishing campaign. Several reports indicate the receipt of an email stating the product for which the customer may or may not have a legitimate license for has been seen in the wild. The email states that a subscription service offered by the company has been renewed at a rate much higher than the actual rate the company charges for this product. The threat actors show a charge of between $300-500. A typical yearly subscription for the product is actually about $100. The scam uses these emails in the hopes the victim will call and try to get the charges reversed. Should victims call, they're pointed to a website wherein a technician will remotely connect to their computer and 'uninstall' the product in question. Once the product is 'removed', the promise of a refund is given. Instead, the actors ask the victim to download TeamViewer and to share their ID and password to connect to the victim machine. The actors then install a second program to achieve persistence. In the same way as a tech support scheme, the threat actors use notepad to concoct a note telling the victim of the risks of not continuing with the product. Using SysKey, the actors place a password known only to them is installed on the computer. Should this be the case, a VBS script is downloaded and placed in the Startup folder. Upon completion of these acts, the scammers attempt to have the victim restart their machine in order to complete the 'uninstall' process. After restart, a Windows license expiration is displayed with a button to click. This button opens many browser windows to give the appearance of a malware infection. The hope is that some of the victims will call the number and ask that their service be reinstated. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/cybercrime/2021/03/software-renewal-scammers-unmasked/>

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Scammers Using MalwareBytes Renewals for Phishing
MalwareBytes' Threat Intelligence Team has uncovered a scam using their brand as a lure for phishing. Using fake emails and phone calls, threat actors are targeting users of MalwareBytes' services and products for the scam.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

A series of fake renewal notices and offers to remove security services offered by MalwareBytes has led their analysts to a phishing campaign. Several reports indicate the receipt of an email stating the product for which the customer may or may not have a legitimate license for has been seen in the wild. The email states that a subscription service offered by the company has been renewed at a rate much higher than the actual rate the company charges for this product. The threat actors show a charge of between $300-500. A typical yearly subscription for the product is actually about $100. The scam uses these emails in the hopes the victim will call and try to get the charges reversed. Should victims call, they're pointed to a website wherein a technician will remotely connect to their computer and 'uninstall' the product in question. Once the product is 'removed', the promise of a refund is given. Instead, the actors ask the victim to download TeamViewer and to share their ID and password to connect to the victim machine. The actors then install a second program to achieve persistence. In the same way as a tech support scheme, the threat actors use notepad to concoct a note telling the victim of the risks of not continuing with the product. Using SysKey, the actors place a password known only to them is installed on the computer. Should this be the case, a VBS script is downloaded and placed in the Startup folder. Upon completion of these acts, the scammers attempt to have the victim restart their machine in order to complete the 'uninstall' process. After restart, a Windows license expiration is displayed with a button to click. This button opens many browser windows to give the appearance of a malware infection. The hope is that some of the victims will call the number and ask that their service be reinstated. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Kimsuky Phishing Hard at Work
A series of attacks by what's suspected to be DPRK's Kimsuky group (aka Velvet Chollima), is underway. The phishing attack is being investigated by ThreatConnect. They provide analysis of this series of attacks in a report.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Targeting everything from journalism to civil society organization, the Kimsuky group is ramping up their phishing efforts. Initial hypothesis indicates the group is harvesting credentials for espionage but also other objectives not yet known. A malicious document discussing North Korean defectors is used to lure victims. The document contains a UPX packed binary. The binary attempts to contact a C2 server. The document closely matches past documents in that it uses the same obfuscation technique, the C2 matches, contains VBA code similarities, and the digital signature signer name is dropped into the file. By all appearances, it looks as though the IP responsible for hosting the domain is dedicated to a single user. A secondary technique is to pivot from similar subdomains using unique strings. According to VirusTotal, the malicious document serves a specific link which is believed to be the pivot point. This pivot point leads to several other domains with each ending in a .work URL. These .work domains lead to several subdomains used in the campaign. Two entries containing rya in the domain are believed to lead to Radio Free Asia - a potential target. Another contains ohchr, believed to be the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights. Additional targets can be gleaned from the list of domains uncovered. Analysis uncovered efforts dating back as far as December 2019 and continuing as recently as August of this year. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://threatconnect.com/blog/kimsuky-phishing-operations-putting-in-work/>

  * <https://www.virustotal.com/gui/url/4444c37c684a628be261cabf8736271e753d883b46f0123fabb753720a2c1a16/details?_ga=2.138046901.482920492.1601397835-577232906.1601397835>
  * <https://threatconnect.com/wp-content/uploads/ThreatConnect-Kimsuky-Phishing-Operations-Putting-In-Work-IoC.csv>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Emotet Spam Abuses Hexadecimal and Octal IP Address Formats
Spam campaigns have to constantly evolve in order to evade detection mechanisms. In one example of this, Trend Micro researchers observed an Emotet campaign abusing abnormal IP address formats for detection evasion.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Emotet
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious email attachment
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Install second-stage malware
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Use of hexadecimal and octal IP address formats



# Overview

Trend Micro published a brief report detailing an Emotet spam campaign implementing an interesting detection evasion mechanism. Operating systems could automatically convert various representations of IP addresses to the traditional dotted decimal quad representation. Trend Micro observed both hexadecimal and octal representations of IP addresses being used in Emotet spam attachments. Both versions used a macro-enabled Excel spreadsheet containing a command to execute a payload from a remote server. Specifically, cmd.exe is invoked to run mshta.exe, which in turn executes a remotely hosted HTA code. Ultimately Emotet is installed with the purpose of infecting a host with a secondary payload, such as Cobalt Strike or Trickbot. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the References section. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057416/Emotet%20Spam%20Abuses%20Hexadecimal%20and%20Octal%20IP%20Address%20Formats%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1643041933921&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/a/emotet-spam-abuses-unconventional-ip-address-formats-spread-malware.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.005 - Mshta  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: IBM Security Guardium Security Bulletins - October 7th, 2020
IBM has published seven security bulletins addressing vulnerabilities in IBM Security Guardium.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview



Security Bulletin 6198350 addresses two SQLite vulnerabilities affecting IBM Security Guardium. One has an unknown impact and attack vector, while the other could allow for a remote attacker to cause an application crash.

Security Bulletins 6152457, 1173364, 6152409, and 6152463, in total, address five Linux Kernel vulnerabilities affecting IBM Security Guardium. Four of the vulnerabilities, if successfully exploited, could cause a denial-of-service condition. The other vulnerability could allow an attacker to escalate their privileges on a victim host.

Security Bulletin 6198351 addresses an OpenSSL vulnerability affecting IBM Security Guardium. If successfully exploited, an attacker could modify default configuration, insert CA certificates, or modify (or even replace) existing engine modules.

Security Bulletin 6189945 addresses eight Oracle MySQL vulnerabilities affecting IBM Security Guardium. Potential impacts include denial-of-service conditions, server takeover, and the ability to update, insert or delete access to some of MySQL Server accessible data.

Patches to address all of these issues are linked to in the advisories. We recommend applying these patches as soon as possible.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/32145757/IBM%20Security%20Guardium%20Security%20Bulletins%20-%20October%207th%2C%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1602527120857&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# References

  * <https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/6198350>

  * <https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/6152457>

  * <https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/1173364>

  * <https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/6152409>

  * <https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/6198351>

  * <https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/6152463>

  * <https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/6189945>
