instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Cisco Security Advisories - November 10th, 2020
Cisco has published two security advisories addressing high severity vulnerabilities in their software.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview



The first advisory addresses CVE-2020-3556, a vulnerability in the interprocess communication (IPC) channel of Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Client Software. Due to a lack of authentication to the IPC listener, if successfully exploited, an authenticated, local attacker to cause a targeted AnyConnect user to execute a malicious script. No patch has been released yet but Cisco plans on addressing the issue in a future update.

The second advisory addresses CVE-2020-26070, a denial-of-service vulnerability in the ingress packet processing function of Cisco IOS XR Software for Cisco ASR 9000 Series Aggregation Services Routers. If successfully exploited, an unauthenticated, remote attacker could cause a denial-of-service condition. This is due to improper resource allocation, specifically when an affected device processes network traffic in software switching mode (punted). An update has been released to patch this issue.

We recommend reviewing the advisories, linked to in the Reference section and identifying applicable patches and workarounds as soon as possible.

# CVEs

A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33982241/Cisco%20Security%20Advisories%20-%20November%2010th%2C%202020%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1605120349836&api=v2)

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-anyconnect-ipc-KfQO9QhK>

  * <https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-xr-cp-dos-ej8VB9QY>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Fake WhatsApp Hacking Users
Vice reports on a fake WhatsApp application in the Apple App Store. The fake version has been used to steal phone, user, and other information.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Threat actors are targeting WhatsApp users in a scheme to steal information for the phone, users, and other important information. The fake app uses the MDM file to install the app containing the spyware. The actors use a phishing web page to direct victims to the fake app within the App Store. Researchers were unable to observe the second stage of the attack making it unclear what information was exfiltrated. The researchers were also unable to determine who the app was specifically targeting as it does not appear to be widespread targeting. Speculation is the application is associated with a "Cyber Electronic Warfare & Intelligence" company. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.vice.com/en/article/akdqwa/a-spyware-vendor-seemingly-made-a-fake-whatsapp-to-hack-targets>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Android Security Bulletin - September 2020
Google has released September's security bulletin for Android operating systems. This release patches a total of fifty-one distinct vulnerabilities.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

For the month of September, Google has patched fifty-one distinct vulnerabilities in the Android operating system. The software updates were supplied to vendor partners at least a month in advance of this bulletin's publication to provide them time to integrate the source into their own code. The most critical issue resolved in this release was in the Media Framework, where a specially crafted, malicious file could potentially allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on the device. For more details, please refer to the link in the Reference section

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/29432899/Android%20Security%20Bulletin%20-%20September%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1599756456264&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://source.android.com/security/bulletin/2020-09-01>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: The IISerpent SEO Trojan
ESET has published a report on a server-side Trojan named IISerpent that carries out a form of SEO fraud.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: The IISerpent SEO Trojan
ESET has published a report on a server-side Trojan named IISerpent that carries out a form of SEO fraud.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** IISerpent SEO Trojan
  *  **Targets:** Microsoft IIS Servers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Manipulating server responses to search engine queries, **** Execution (TA0002, T1569, T1569.002), Persistence (TA0003, T1546), Command and Control (TA0011, T1071, T1071.001)
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Resource Development (TA0042, T1587, T1587.001), Impact (TA0040, T1565, T1565.002)



# Overview

According to a report from ESET, IISerpent is a Trojan that runs as an extension on IIS servers. It conducts a form of SEO fraud by manipulating the server's HTTP responses to search engine crawlers. The manipulation is achieved by intercepting all HHTP requests to the server and modifying the responses to include a list of backlinks, or redirect the search engines to another site chosen by IISerpent’s operators. The backlinks and redirections are controlled by IISerpent’s configuration or through relaying the search engine's request to its C&C server to obtain instructions. The beneficiary of the search engine manipulation is an unrelated third-party site chosen by the IISerpent operators. Normal traffic to and from an infected IIS server is not changed as it is ignored by IISerpent. ESET was unaware of how the infected servers were initially compromised to allow the installation of the IISerpent extension. Further information, including a technical analysis of IISerpent, is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/61374568/The%20IISerpent%20SEO%20Trojan%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1629162112536&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/08/11/iiserpent-malware-driven-seo-fraud-service/>

Tell me about the following threat: Shared Power Banks Used to Take Control of Phones
Yicai Global indicates that shared power banks, used to charge phones in public areas in China, may be infected with malware to either steal victim's data or take control of the device.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Shared Power Banks Used to Take Control of Phones
Yicai Global indicates that shared power banks, used to charge phones in public areas in China, may be infected with malware to either steal victim's data or take control of the device.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan



# Overview

Yicai Global announced in an article that charging stations in China may have been compromised by hackers. They indicate that the compromised station may install a Trojan on Android or iOS devices that are plugged in to recharge the device. One of China's larger shared power bank providers, Energy Monster, stated that their cables are configured only to supply power, not transfer data. Users are warned to take caution when using such public charging stations. When necessary, using your own cable that is known to not be configured to transfer data, is your best option, if possible. For more information, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.yicaiglobal.com/news/hackers-can-take-control-of-phones-via-shared-power-banks-ministry-says->

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: An Analysis of Lokibot
A report from Cisco Talos that is targeted toward reverse engineers looks at the Lokibot infection chain. Lokibot is info-stealing malware which has been around since 2015.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

The Lokibot infection chain is the subject of a report from Cisco Talos. The report is targeted toward reverse engineers and provides information on the more recent tricks used by Lokibot. As is common with malware today, the infection chain begins with a malicious Excel file that contains an obfuscated macro, usually delivered attached to spam emails. The Excel file analyzed uses blurred images to entice the user to click the enable macros button. If the victim enables macros, a second stage downloader is retrieved from a remote server. The downloader is responsible for downloading the third (and final) stage, which contains Lokibot, escalating privileges, and then deploying Lokibot. The report provides an analysis of each stage in the infection chain. Further information is available from the link in the Reports section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2021/01/a-deep-dive-into-lokibot-infection-chain.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Campaign Abusing RFC 8030 - PushBug
Indelible has published a paper detailing a campaign that is abusing RFC 8030 called PushBug. RFC 8030 is the official protocol that delivers real-time events to browser agents over HTTP/2 server push.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Campaign



# Overview

Indelible details a campaign that is abusing RFC 8030 to infect victims. RFC 8030 is an official protocol that details how a push server can connect to a browser agent to deliver real-time events. Indelible has dubbed this campaign"PushBug". The activity is currently using social engineering and bypassing security controls to install a worker service in the victim browser. This allows the attackers to present any message to the victim they choose. In some cases, malicious socially-engineered messages are sent to the victim falsely informing them they have been infected with a virus. Such messages may include a button to "clean the virus" from the system that may actually infect the victim with other payloads. Other fake notifications include fake dating notices and uranium investment opportunities. For more details or access to the PDF whitepaper, refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/33983167/Campaign%20Abusing%20RFC%208030%20-%20PushBug%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606239526290&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.indelible.global/post/pushbug-uncovering-widespread-push-notification-rfc-8030-abuse-in-the-wild>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New Dropper Gaining Increasing Popularity
A new malicious loader, known as BumbleBee, has been observed by SEKIO.IO in multiple ongoing campaigns. First reported by Google TAG in 2022, multiple Initial Access Brokers (IABs) have added this loader to their toolkit. Featuring multiple defense and detection evasion techniques. BumbleBee has been identified as a popular and sophisticated dropper/loader.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Dropper Gaining Increasing Popularity
A new malicious loader, known as BumbleBee, has been observed by SEKIO.IO in multiple ongoing campaigns. First reported by Google TAG in 2022, multiple Initial Access Brokers (IABs) have added this loader to their toolkit. Featuring multiple defense and detection evasion techniques. BumbleBee has been identified as a popular and sophisticated dropper/loader.

Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Loader/Dropper
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Conti, LockBit, AvosLocker, Diavol, NOBELIUM, IcedID, BazarLoader, EXOTIC LILY, FIN12/WIZARD SPIDER
* **Associated Payloads:** Cobalt Strike, Meterpreter, Sliver, Redline
* **Targets:** N/A
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing, Spear Phishing
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Deployment of Additional Malware
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

In the past month, multiple campaigns have been observed distributing a relatively new loader, known as BumbleBee. Many well know cyber-criminal organizations have been observed utilizing this tool to download additional payloads, including ransomware. Researchers have reported ongoing improvement and development of this tool since the initial analysis. SEKIO.IO has been tracking this threat since early April 2022. During this time, a significant increase in active C2 servers has been observed. Analysis of multiple malware samples has identified several versions and improvements. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://blog.sekoia.io/bumblebee-a-new-trendy-loader-for-initial-access-brokers/>
* <https://blog.google/threat-analysis-group/exposing-initial-access-broker-ties-conti/>
* <https://www.cynet.com/blog/orion-threat-alert-flight-of-the-bumblebee/>
* <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/bumblebee-is-still-transforming>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1204 - User Execution  
   T204.002 - Malicious File  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information

 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  

**Impact - TA0040**  
 T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  

**Mitigations:**

**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - On Windows 10, enable Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules to prevent executable files from running unless they meet a prevalence, age, or trusted list criteria and to prevent Office applications from creating potentially malicious executable content by blocking malicious code from being written to disk. Note: cloud-delivered protection must be enabled to use certain rules.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Application control may be able to prevent the running of executables masquerading as other files.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - If a link is being visited by a user, network intrusion prevention systems and systems designed to scan and remove malicious downloads can be used to block activity.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1053:**  Data Backup - Consider implementing IT disaster recovery plans that contain procedures for regularly taking and testing data backups that can be used to restore organizational data.[[73]](https://www.ready.gov/business/implementation/IT) Ensure backups are stored off system and is protected from common methods adversaries may use to gain access and destroy the backups to prevent recovery. Consider enabling versioning in cloud environments to maintain backup copies of storage objects.

BumbleBee has been identified as a popular and sophisticated dropper/loader.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Tmanger RAT
While investigating TA428 activity, NTT Security researchers identified a new RAT, dubbed "Tmanger", being used by the group.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Tmanger RAT
While investigating TA428 activity, NTT Security researchers identified a new RAT, dubbed "Tmanger", being used by the group.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

NTT Security has published a blog post detailing the , which was discovered in use by TA428, a Chinese APT. The attack chain began with the deployment of Poison Ivy and Cotx RAT to gain remote control of the victims host. The threat actor then moved laterally by exploiting the EternalBlue vulnerability. It was at this point they deployed the new . The payload is comprised of three components: SetUp, MloadDll, and Client. First, SetUp decodes various data to be used in later installation steps. The MloadDll is then inflated and saved in System32. To establish persistence the DLL uses either a service, if admin privileges are obtained, or via a Registry Run key otherwise. Either method leads to the execution of the DLL, which begins by generating the RC4 key that will be used to decrypt configuration data. The decoded configuration data is the C2 address and port number. The DLL also inflates and executes the final payload, named Client. The final payload gathers hosts information and sends the information to its C2 server. It can then receive C2 commands that allow for the attacker to perform file operations, start processes, keylog, screen capture, and more. For more information, see the NTT Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://insight-jp.nttsecurity.com/post/102gi9b/pandas-new-arsenal-part-1-tmanger>

I have encountered the following information: NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR20-239B - VIVACIOUSGIFT
A Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) malware analysis report, AR20-239B, has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System. The report is a joint publication from Department of Homeland Security, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and the Department of Defense. The report provides information on the North Korean network proxy tool, VIVACIOUSGIFT.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

 **From the Malware Analysis Report (AR20-239B)**  
 **MAR-10301706-2.v1 - North Korean Remote Access Tool: VIVACIOUSGIFT**

  


This Malware Analysis Report (MAR) is the result of analytic efforts between the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and the Department of Defense (DoD). Working with U.S. Government partners, DHS, FBI, and DoD identified Remote Access Tool (RAT) malware variants used by the North Korean government. This malware variant has been identified as VIVACIOUSGIFT. The U.S. Government refers to malicious cyber activity by the North Korean government as HIDDEN COBRA. For more information on HIDDEN COBRA activity, visit https://www.us-cert.gov/hiddencobra.

FBI has high confidence that HIDDEN COBRA actors are using malware variants in conjunction with proxy servers to maintain a presence on victim networks and to further network exploitation. DHS, FBI, and DoD are distributing this MAR to enable network defense and reduce exposure to North Korean government malicious cyber activity.

This MAR includes malware descriptions related to HIDDEN COBRA, suggested response actions and recommended mitigation techniques. Users or administrators should flag activity associated with the malware and report the activity to the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) or the FBI Cyber Watch (CyWatch), and give the activity the highest priority for enhanced mitigation.

This report looks at the malware samples known as VIVACIOUSGIFT that is used by advanced persistent threat (APT) cyber actors as a network proxy tool. The proxy requires an encrypted command line argument for its source and destination Internet Protocol (IP) addresses and has command and control (C2) functionality to retrieve and set the destination IP. The command line argument can also contain a source proxy IP, port, and password. The source proxy is used as an additional proxy when communicating with the source IP. The library libcurl version 7.94.1 is used when communicating with the source proxy.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. for Yara Rules.



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar20-239b>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Spyder Backdoor Used by Winnti Threat Group Analyzed by Dr. Web Virus Laboratory
Dr. Web Virus Laboratory analyzed a backdoor they've named Spyder after it was discovered at a telecommunication company based in Central Asia in December 2020. The backdoor was loaded into the system using the DLL Hijacking method. It's a modular backdoor and can utilize plug-ins it receives from it's C&C server.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor




# Overview

A new modular backdoor was analyzed by the Doctor Web virus laboratory. It was discovered by a telecommunications company based in Central Asia in December 2020. The backdoor has been named Spyder, due to messages containing the string "Spyder" when communicating with the C&C server. The backdoor exists as a DLL file and is loaded into the system using the DLL Hijacking method. The Microsoft Distributed Transaction Coordinator Service, MSDTC, running as a system service, was used to load the backdoor using this method. The backdoor does not conduct any additional malicious activity until instructed by receiving commands from the C&C server. The backdoor is capable of receiving additional plug-ins from the C&C server. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * [https://news.drweb.com/show/?i=14154&lng=en](https://news.drweb.com/show/?i=14154&lng=en)

  * <https://st.drweb.com/static/new-www/news/2021/march/BackDoor.Spyder.1_en.pdf>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: White Rabbit Evasion Techniques Analyzed
The new ransomware family White Rabbit was first seen in December of 2021. A report by Trend Micro explores some of the evasion tactics used by this new malware.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Fin8 (G0061)
  *  **Associated Payloads:** White Rabbit
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown **  
**
  * **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encryption, Double Extortion



# Overview

White Rabbit is a new ransomware family discovered by Trend Micro with a potential connection to the threat group Fin8. It looks like it could be loaded onto systems using systems already compromised and infected with Cobalt Strike. Trend Micro has published details of the evasion tactics used by the malware. The payload is a small file with no notable strings or activity. The way to activate the ransomware and decrypt the internal configuration is via a command-line password - a technique also used by the ransomware family Egregor. Upon execution, White Rabbit will terminate several processes, including processes related to antivirus. Once complete, the ransomware drops a ransom note which threatens to leak the victim's stolen data if the ransom is not paid. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057151/White%20Rabbit%20Evasion%20Techniques%20Analyzed%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642589352360&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/a/new-ransomware-spotted-white-rabbit-and-its-evasion-tactics.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Samba Security Advisories - October 29th, 2020
Samba published three security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in their software.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Samba Security Advisories - October 29th, 2020
Samba published three security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in their software.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  




CVE-2020-14318 is a missing permission check vulnerability in the SMB ChangeNotify concept. If successfully exploited, an attacker with unprivileged access could obtain file name information. CVE-2020-14323 is an improper input validation vulnerability in winbind that, if successfully exploited, could cause a NULL pointer dereference, which would in turn cause a crash. CVE-2020-14383 addresses an error handling vulnerability with the Samba dnsserver RPC pipe that could allow an authenticated, non-admin user to crash a server by adding invalid DNS records.

Samba has released patches and mitigation advice alongside all three advisories. We recommend reviewing the advisories and implementing their guidance as soon as possible.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/32147079/Samba%20Security%20Advisories%20-%20October%2029th%2C%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1604072909884&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.samba.org/samba/security/CVE-2020-14318.html>

  * <https://www.samba.org/samba/security/CVE-2020-14323.html>

  * <https://www.samba.org/samba/security/CVE-2020-14383.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Malicious Run-Only AppleScripts
Run-only AppleScripts have historically been difficult to analyze. SentinelOne uses the case of a cryptominer campaign that implements these types of files to demonstrate their ability to now analyze samples.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptominer




# Overview

SentintelOne has improved its capabilities with regard to analyzing run-only AppleScripts in order to analyzing a cryptominer campaign that has been operating for at least five years. Since its original appearance, the malware has evolved to use multiple run-only scripts and retrieve additional payloads hosted in the source code of external websites. The first AppleScripts file is responsible for establishing persistence via plist, running, and executing an embedded secondary AppleScripts file, downloading the first stage of the cryptominer, and gathering system information. The secondary AppleScripts file is used for anti-analysis and evasion tasks, such as killing security software and system monitoring processes. The first URL contacted by the parent script for downloading the next stage has a URL embedded in the source code, which points to a payload masquerading as a PNG. The downloaded file is a cryptominer set up script for XMR-STAK-RX, an open source Monero miner. The setup script configures the miner with a pool address, password, and other configuration information. A folder is created that drops config files and a compressed folder. When decompressed, a Mach-O executable is revealed, leading to the download and installation of the final XMR-STAK miner payload. For more information, including how SentinelOne decrypted and statically analyzed the AppleScripts files, see the blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/fade-dead-adventures-in-reversing-malicious-run-only-applescripts/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Malvertising Campaign Delivers Malicious AnyDesk Installer
A report from CrowdStrike provides details of a malvertising campaign that delivers a malicious AnyDesk installer.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Malvertising




# Overview

CrowdStrike discovered a malvertising campaign that targets users who search Google "AnyDesk". The malicious ads have been present since April 2021, and possibly earlier. The CrowdStrike reports notes that geographical targeting may be used as the search results depend on the region a search request originated from. Intermediary sites are used to redirect users who click on the malicious ads to a site that is cloned from the legitimate AnyDesk website and provides a link to download the malicious installer. If a victim executes the malicious installer, a PowerShell implant is then executed. The implant contacts a C&C server and uploads certain information obtained from the victim system. Persistence is achieved through adding an entry to the Startup folder which executes the malicious AnyDesk installer. Further information can be obtained from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/falcon-complete-disrupts-malvertising-campaign-targeting-anydesk/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Golang Worm Drops XMRig Miner on Servers
Continuing with the trend of cross-platform compatibility, a new Golang worm was identified by Intezer. The worm is being used to distribute the XMRig miner to victim servers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Worm, Cryptomining




# Overview

Intezer published a blog post analyzing a Golang worm being used to distribute the XMRig miner to victim servers. Since it is written in Golang, a cross-platform language, it is capable of infecting both Linux and Windows systems. Specifically, it targets MySQL, Tomcat, and Jenkins servers by brute-forcing weak credentials. In addition, older versions supported the exploitation of a WebLogic vulnerability as an initial infection vector. Once on a system, the worm checks for existing infections and, if not present, installs the miner. The miner is embedded within the Golang binary. To spread across infected networks, the worm performs a scan to identify servers running MySQL, Tomcat, or Jenkins and carries out its brute force functionality. Once access is obtained, exploitation of vulnerabilities on the server are used to execute either a bash script or PowerShell script that retrieves the worm payload. This cycle repeats in an attempt to infect as many hosts as possible in order to increase mining profits. For more information, see the Intezer blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/research/new-golang-worm-drops-xmrig-miner-on-servers/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Hentai Oniichan Ransomware
VMRay has published a blog detailing a ransomware package called Hentai Oniichan. Two variants of this family, King Engine and Beserker, were observed in the wild during their investigation.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Hentai Oniichan Ransomware
VMRay has published a blog detailing a ransomware package called Hentai Oniichan. Two variants of this family, King Engine and Beserker, were observed in the wild during their investigation.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware



# Overview

In a blog based on the research of a ransomware package called Hentai Oniichan, VMRay reports on their analysis of one of the two variants, Berserker, they found during their investigation. Berserker examines running processes in an effort to terminate any matching programs that are on its internal list. It also attempts to terminate any processes that might interfere with its encryption of files, such as backup software, monitoring software, or software that may hold files open like database applications. Information, such as user name, computer name, and client key, is sent via email to its command and control server. In addition to deleting shadow copies and disabling recovery mode, Beserker goes the extra mile by attempting to remove backup files based on a list of backup extensions. This does leave open the possibility of deleting data that cannot be restored, such as non-backup data on virtual drives. After a file is encrypted, a ".HOR" extension is added to the name. When the system has been encrypted, two types of ransom notes are delivered. For more details on Beserker, please click on the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35718906/Hentai%20Oniichan%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=2&modificationDate=1608664538114&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.vmray.com/cyber-security-blog/hentai-oniichan-ransomware-berserker-malware-analysis-spotlight/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Oracle CPU - October 2020
Oracle has released their quarterly Critical Patch Update (CPU) for October of 2020. Included are updates that fix 421 security vulnerabilities across the Oracle product line.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Oracle CPU - October 2020
Oracle has released their quarterly Critical Patch Update (CPU) for October of 2020. Included are updates that fix 421 security vulnerabilities across the Oracle product line.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

For their quarterly patch update, Oracle has patched 421 security vulnerabilities across their product line. The next Oracle CPU is scheduled for January 19, 2021. Starting with the October, Oracle has changed how their CPU advisory is published. The new default version does not list updates in the Risk Matrix that address vulnerabilities in third party components that are not exploitable. Also provided is the traditional advisory. We suggest reviewing the individual product advisories and applying updates to installed products as soon as possible.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.oracle.com/security-alerts/cpuoct2020.html>   
<https://www.oracle.com/security-alerts/cpuoct2020traditional.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: X-Force Executive Update – Oldsmar Water Treatment Facility Hack
X-Force Threat Intelligence has published an executive update providing insights into a recent hack of a water treatment facility and the lessons it provides.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Hacking




# Overview

On Friday, February 5, 2021, an unknown hacker used TeamViewer remote management software to gain access to the computer network of a water treatment plant in Oldsmar, Florida. The hacker then increased the amount of sodium hydroxide, or lye, to be released into the water by a factor of 111. A supervisor that was working remotely observed the change being made in the system and immediately reversed it, so the hacking operation ultimately had no effect on the water supply. X-Force analysts consider this event to provide some valuable lessons for organizations with operational technology networks, including risks posed by remote access programs and weak authentication policies. The full story and analysis is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.




# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/5ffa489f-fc94-4376-ba51-6cbb7d631662>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: IoT Malware EnemyBot Evolving To Target Android Devices
AT&T Alien Labs has been tracking the spread of the EnemyBot botnet. The malware has been expanding its capabilities to exploit new vulnerabilities and target more devices. These developments have been described in a report.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Botnet
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Keksec
  *  **Associated Payloads:** EnemyBot
  *  **Targets:** Linux Devices, IoT Devices, CMS systems, Android
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Common Vulnerabilities
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

AT&T Alien Labs has been following the development of the EnemyBot botnet, which was first discovered in April 2022. This is distributed by the threat actor known as 'Keksec' and is continually expanding its capabilities. The source code of the malware can now be found on Github, making it available to anyone who wishes to use it. The source code contains snippets from other popular botnets, such as Mirai, Qbot, and Zbot. The latest variant contains a web scanner that can search for vulnerable systems and use 24 different exploits to gain access to devices and web servers. This includes the Log4j vulnerability, as well as more recent vulnerabilities, demonstrating the rapid development the botnet is under. The malware has also been adapted to target content management systems, such as WordPress, by searching for vulnerabilities in popular plugins. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://cybersecurity.att.com/blogs/labs-research/rapidly-evolving-iot-malware-enemybot-now-targeting-content-management-system-servers>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1584.005 - Botnet  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
T1040 - Network Sniffing  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1120 - Peripheral Device Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1210 - Exploitation of Remote Services  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1019:** Threat Intelligence Program - A threat intelligence program helps an organization generate their own threat intelligence information and track trends to inform defensive priorities to mitigate risk.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Baka JavaScript Skimmer
Baka is a new JavaScript skimmer identified by Visa Payment Fraud Disruption (PFD). It is relatively advanced for a skimmer and leverages unique loading and obfuscation techniques.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Skimmer




# Overview

Visa Payment Fraud Disruption (PFD) has published a report analyzing the Baka JavaScript skimmer. This skimmer has some advanced components making it relatively sophisticated for a credit card skimmer. Its loader is dynamically added to a victim site and is responsible for decrypting and executes remotely-hosted JavaScript code. The C2 URL from which is loads the JavaScript is encrypted and hardcoded in the loader code. Five scheduled functions are run by the skimming malware in order to carry out its purpose. First, it looks for target field names and, if identified, captures any data entered by the victim into those fields. If data has been captured, it calls an exfiltration function. To exfiltrate the data, it is encoded and stored in the GET parameters of the gateway URL, which masquerades as an image. The malicious code performing these functions runs only in memory on the victim's machine, and after data has been exfiltrated, the malware cleans itself up by removing the skimming code from memory. The researchers note that the use of an XOR cipher to encrypt the malicious code and avoid detection is unique and not previously seen in JavaScript skimming malware. For more information, see the Visa report in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://usa.visa.com/content/dam/VCOM/global/support-legal/documents/visa-security-alert-baka-javascript-skimmer.pdf>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Subway TrickBot Phishing Attack
A massive attack involving Subway restaurants in the U.K. is underway and delivering TrickBot malware to phishing email recipients, according to a report from Bleeping Computer.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing




# Overview

The Subway restaurant chain in the U.K. is being used a phishing lure in an effort to deliver the TrickBot malware. The email is purportedly an order confirmation and includes the victim's first name. The campaign is highly targeted with some users reporting only emails used for Subway orders being sent these phishing emails. The attack may be indicative of a data breach but nothing has been confirmed. The emails contain subjects such as "Your order is being processed" and "We've received your order" and are from Subcard. One item of note is the inclusion of links to order documents being ready for confirmation. The links contained within the emails take victims to a 'FreshBooks' phishing page. The pages request the user download a file, which turns out to be an Excel spreadsheet. The spreadsheet may or may not be password protected. In order to view the spreadsheet, the victim must either Enable Editing or Enable Content. If the content is enabled, malicious macros embedded in the file will install the latest version of TrickBot. This version is a DLL that injects into Window's warmer.exe or Windows Problem Reporting from memory using code from the MemoryModule project. This could allow for avoidance of detection by security software and will appear as a legitimate task in Task Manager. More information about this attack can be found in the report located within the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/massive-subway-uk-phishing-attack-is-pushing-trickbot-malware/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Cryptojacking Malware Disabling Threat Detection Tools In Cloud Instances
Cryptojacking attacks succeed by being as stealthy as possible while the malware steals computer resources from the victim machine. This article from Trend Micro explores the common feature where malware will attempt to disable features inside cloud service providers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Cryptojacking Malware Disabling Threat Detection Tools In Cloud Instances
Cryptojacking attacks succeed by being as stealthy as possible while the malware steals computer resources from the victim machine. This article from Trend Micro explores the common feature where malware will attempt to disable features inside cloud service providers.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Cryptojacking
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining



# Overview

Cryptojacking malware aims to sit on victim computers for as long as possible without being noticed, so they can utilize as many resources as they can. To achieve this, the malware employs techniques to reduce the possibility of detection and competition. Trend Micro has reported on functionality that appears in multiple samples - the ability to disable features of the cloud service provider. These particular attacks target the Alibaba Elastic Computing Service, which comes with a preinstalled security agent. Upon infection, many cryptojacking samples will attempt to uninstall this to avoid detection. This is not uncommon behavior for malware, but in this example, specific code was identified which creates firewall rules to drop packets coming from internal Alibaba zones and regions. Alibaba ECS also makes a good target as it provides root access to the instance, which many cloud providers do not. Since the threat actor can gain the highest possible privilege, the possibility of advanced payloads such as kernel module rootkits and system service persistence can be established. There is potential for a large financial impact for victims of this malware, as cloud autoscaling can mean victims get charged more for the increased resource usage. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058339/Cryptojacking%20Malware%20Disabling%20Threat%20Detection%20Tools%20In%20Cloud%20Instances%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644318133034&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Ensure containers are not running as root by default (M1026).



# References

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Cryptojacking Malware Disabling Threat Detection Tools In Cloud Instances
Cryptojacking attacks succeed by being as stealthy as possible while the malware steals computer resources from the victim machine. This article from Trend Micro explores the common feature where malware will attempt to disable features inside cloud service providers.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Cryptojacking
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining



# Overview

Cryptojacking malware aims to sit on victim computers for as long as possible without being noticed, so they can utilize as many resources as they can. To achieve this, the malware employs techniques to reduce the possibility of detection and competition. Trend Micro has reported on functionality that appears in multiple samples - the ability to disable features of the cloud service provider. These particular attacks target the Alibaba Elastic Computing Service, which comes with a preinstalled security agent. Upon infection, many cryptojacking samples will attempt to uninstall this to avoid detection. This is not uncommon behavior for malware, but in this example, specific code was identified which creates firewall rules to drop packets coming from internal Alibaba zones and regions. Alibaba ECS also makes a good target as it provides root access to the instance, which many cloud providers do not. Since the threat actor can gain the highest possible privilege, the possibility of advanced payloads such as kernel module rootkits and system service persistence can be established. There is potential for a large financial impact for victims of this malware, as cloud autoscaling can mean victims get charged more for the increased resource usage. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058339/Cryptojacking%20Malware%20Disabling%20Threat%20Detection%20Tools%20In%20Cloud%20Instances%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644318133034&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Owlproxy Malware Used in Attacks Targeting Taiwanese Government
Continuing their discussion of the April 2020 attacks against the Taiwanese government, CyCraft has published an article on the Owlproxy malware and use of skeleton keys for authentication.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

CyCraft has expanded on their previous research into attacks against the Taiwanese government by delving into the Owlproxy malware and use of skeleton keys. The Owlproxy malware, its name based on a PDB file project name, acts as a tunnel to bridge the internet and intranet so that the threat actor could have backdoor functionality. It allows the attacker to send backdoor commands over HTTP (port 80). The second part of the blog posts discusses an interesting TTP - the use of skeleton keys to gain network-wide authentication. This technique starts with an executable that, in turn, drops three files. The first file is an DLL that installs itself and deletes the original executable. A custom version of Mimikatz is then executed and injects the Skeleton Key into lsass, leveraging a kernel driver install to unprotect lsass if necessary. With this technique, Active Directory authentication can be bypassed. For more information, see the CyCraft blog post in the Reference section.  


# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://medium.com/cycraft/taiwan-government-targeted-by-multiple-cyberattacks-in-april-2020-3b20cea1dc20>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Mindware and SFile Ransomware Technical Breakdown
Sentinel One has posted an analysis of the ransomware used by a threat group that refers to themselves as Mindware. This group has beenactive since March of this year.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Ransomware
* **Targets:** Healthcare, Finance, Engineering, and Manufacturing
* **Ransomware Family:** Mindware
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** File encryption and exfiltration
* **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Below

Overview
========

Sentinel One analyzed the ransomware used by the Mindware group. The group is known to gave targeted victims in the healthcare, finance, engineering, and manufacturing sectors. The Sentinel One analysis notes that there are similarities between the SFile ransomware and Mindware's ransomware. There are no indications in the analysis of how the ransomware gains access to victim networks. The Mindware ransomware uses a less common technique, Reflective DLL Injection, to obtain handles to API functions. For more information, please see the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* [https://www.sentinelone.com/blog/from-the-front-lines-another-rebrand-mindware-and-sfile-ransomware-technical-breakdown/](https://www.sentinelone.com/blog/from-the-front-lines-another-rebrand-mindware-and-sfile-ransomware-technical-breakdown/ "Follow link")

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
   T1027.002 - Software Packing  
 T1112 - Modify Registry  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1007 - System Service Discovery  
 T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
 T1082 - System Information Discovery  

**Impact - TA0040**  
 T1485 - Data Destruction  
 T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  

**Mitigations:**

**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1053:**  Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Unattributed Threat Actor Targeting the Finance and Investment Sectors
A report from Red Alert provides insight on a campaign that has been targeting the finance and investment sectors for at least a year.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Unspecified though likely an infostealer.
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unattributed, though has similarities to a known state-sponsored group.
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unspecified
  *  **Targets:** Finance and Investment sectors.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Word documents and template injection.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unspecified, though likely stealing financial related information.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A campaign that has been targeting the finance and investment sectors for at least a year had its beginnings around August 2020. Users within an organization are sent spear-phishing emails with an attached Word document. Various lure documents have been used, mostly purporting to be financial information from various legitimate companies. At least some of the documents, if opened by a victim, popup a notification that the document has been "secured by Kaspersky" and the victim is asked to click "Enable Content" to view it. Clicking Enable Content enables macros and results in a remote template being downloaded and injected into the document. No information on the actual payloads is provided in the report. The campaign's C&C servers use domain names that relate to businesses such as those involved in blockchain, coin exchanges, energy innovation, investment, and software. The C&C traffic is secured using SSL and free multi-domain certificates that are valid for 90 days. Once a certificate has expired the actors obtain new certificates and make any required changes to the included domains. While the actor behind the campaign is not attributed to any known entity, the report does note that the actor shows similarities with a known state-sponsored group. The objective of the campaign is believed to be stealing financial information or transaction details. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222121/Unattributed%20Threat%20Actor%20Targeting%20the%20Finance%20and%20Investment%20Sectors%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636432249461&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://redalert.nshc.net/2021/11/04/threat-actor-targeted-attack-against-finance-and-investment-industry/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1106 - Native API  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1221 - Template Injection  
T1564.003 - Hidden Window  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1119 - Automated Collection  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Smokeloader Updates
Focusing on the encryption of C2 server URLs, Telekom analyzes the newest versions of the Smokeloader malware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Smokeloader Updates
Focusing on the encryption of C2 server URLs, Telekom analyzes the newest versions of the Smokeloader malware.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Loader




# Overview

Telekom has published a blog post analyzing new samples of Smokeloader, specifically discussing its C2 server URL encryption technique. Smokeloader is a malware loader that has been sold via Russian underground markets since 2011. Purchasers are provided with the bot malware, a PHP-based C2 panel, and a user manual, with the ability to purchase additional modules for expanded capabilities. The malware implements extensive anti-analysis techniques to avoid detection, with multiple layers of obfuscation involved. One of the most recent changes observed in samples from November and December 2020 is an update to how the C2 URLs are encrypted. The previous method used simple XOR encryption in a way that allowed the brute forcing the final XOR key, thus allowing the brute forcing of the C2 URL itself. The newer algorithm in recent samples is still uses XORing, but this time two XOR keys are used in a way that makes it impossible to brute force the decryption. For more information, see the Telekom blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.telekom.com/en/blog/group/article/a-new-way-to-encrypt-cc-server-urls-614886>
