instruction:
I have encountered the following information: FONIX - Ransomware as a Service
FONIX is a relatively new Ransomware as a Service offering from actors who previously specialized in packers. According to a report from SentinelLabs, the service is cumbersome to use and the file encryption process is significantly slower than other ransomware.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, RaaS




# Overview

FONIX is relative newcomer to the Ransomware as a Service (RaaS) market, having appeared around July 2020. A report provided by SentinelLabs notes that currently only a small number of infections attributable to FONIX have been observed. No upfront payment is required to become an affiliate of the service as the operators take a percentage of any ransoms obtained by the affiliate. All communications with the service operators are carried out using email. An affiliate needs to provide the operators files from a victim system and 25% of the ransom in order to obtain the decryptor and key for the victim. The affiliate in turn provides them to the victim. This amounts to a cumbersome and convoluted process for affiliates and may be why the service, at least so far, does not appear to be widely used. The ransomware payload uses a combination of AES, Chacha, RSA, and Salsa20 to encrypt a victim's files, encrypts all but system files, and adds a .XINOF extension. The use of multiple encryption protocols makes the encryption process significantly slower than that of other ransomware. If the payload is executed with administrative privileges, changes are made to certain system settings, such as disabling the task manager and manipulating the Safeboot options. Several files are copied to the system including an HTA-formatted ransom note that provides instructions and the affiliate's email address for communications. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/the-fonix-raas-new-low-key-threat-with-unnecessary-complexities/>

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
FONIX - Ransomware as a Service
FONIX is a relatively new Ransomware as a Service offering from actors who previously specialized in packers. According to a report from SentinelLabs, the service is cumbersome to use and the file encryption process is significantly slower than other ransomware.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, RaaS




# Overview

FONIX is relative newcomer to the Ransomware as a Service (RaaS) market, having appeared around July 2020. A report provided by SentinelLabs notes that currently only a small number of infections attributable to FONIX have been observed. No upfront payment is required to become an affiliate of the service as the operators take a percentage of any ransoms obtained by the affiliate. All communications with the service operators are carried out using email. An affiliate needs to provide the operators files from a victim system and 25% of the ransom in order to obtain the decryptor and key for the victim. The affiliate in turn provides them to the victim. This amounts to a cumbersome and convoluted process for affiliates and may be why the service, at least so far, does not appear to be widely used. The ransomware payload uses a combination of AES, Chacha, RSA, and Salsa20 to encrypt a victim's files, encrypts all but system files, and adds a .XINOF extension. The use of multiple encryption protocols makes the encryption process significantly slower than that of other ransomware. If the payload is executed with administrative privileges, changes are made to certain system settings, such as disabling the task manager and manipulating the Safeboot options. Several files are copied to the system including an HTA-formatted ransom note that provides instructions and the affiliate's email address for communications. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/the-fonix-raas-new-low-key-threat-with-unnecessary-complexities/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Top Alexa Sites Infected With Malicious Coinminers and Web Skimmer
The Alexa top 10,000 websites are websites ranked based on popularity as determined by visitor interactions. Palo Alto performed a threat hunting campaign against this list of website to identify malicious activity, such as cryptomining and web skimming.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Top Alexa Sites Infected With Malicious Coinminers and Web Skimmer
The Alexa top 10,000 websites are websites ranked based on popularity as determined by visitor interactions. Palo Alto performed a threat hunting campaign against this list of website to identify malicious activity, such as cryptomining and web skimming.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Coinminer, Skimmer




# Overview

Palo Alto published their findings from a threat hunting campaign against the Alexa top 10,000 websites. One of their findings was related to malicious coinminers, which were found being implemented via multiple methods. The first involved injecting Coinhive mining code directly into a compromised site. Unlike most attackers who typically configure coinminers to use a minimal amount of CPU in order to avoid detection, these actors barely throttled the mining activity, leading the battery of the victim device to be drained quickly. Another method of coinmining activity involved redirecting users from a legitimate used car website to a malicious link hosting the JSEcoin miner. Since the JSEcoin miner shut down, the scripts will run but the operators will not receive any currency. The same method of redirecting users from a legitimate commerce site to a malicious web page was used in a web skimmer attack. Redirecting users to a supposed reseller's site instead leads to website hosting a large number of obfuscated skimming code that is capable of collecting credit card numbers and exfiltrating them to the attacker. For more information, see the Palo Alto blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/malicious-coinminers-web-skimmer/>

Tell me about the following threat: Floral Park-Bellerose School District Systems Compromised with Ransomware
Breach / Leak Notification: According to a media report, the Floral Park-Bellerose school district suffered a ransomware attack. After the attack was reported, Nassau County BOCES shut down at least some of the school districts systems. Online education was affected by the attack.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Floral Park-Bellerose School District Systems Compromised with Ransomware
Breach / Leak Notification: According to a media report, the Floral Park-Bellerose school district suffered a ransomware attack. After the attack was reported, Nassau County BOCES shut down at least some of the school districts systems. Online education was affected by the attack.

# Threat Type

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

  
"Floral Park-Bellerose school district officials announced at their Board of Education meeting Monday that the district’s computer system had been infected with a type of malware known as “ransomware,” impeding its progress in delivering virtual education to students ... School officials have reported the attack to the FBI, Homeland Security and the police forces of Nassau County and the Village of Floral Park. The FBI is conducting an investigation, the board reported."

# Reference

  * <https://theislandnow.com/new_hyde_park-108/floral-park-bellerose-school-district-hit-with-ransomware-attack/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Apple Security Updates March 8 2021
Apple has published security updates for Safari, macOS Big Sur, watchOS, iOS and iPadOS. The updates all address the same, single vulnerability, in WebKit.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Apple has published security updates for Safari, macOS Big Sur, watchOS, iOS and iPadOS. All the updates address a single vulnerability in WebKit, CVE-2021-1844. The vulnerability is caused by a memory corruption issue. A remote attacker, who could convince users to open maliciously crafted web content, could potentially execute arbitrary code on an affected system. Updating to Safari 14.0.3, macOS Big Sur 11.2.3, watchOS 7.3.2, iOS 14.4.1, and iPadOS 14.4.1, mitigates the vulnerability.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-1844 




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT201222>

  * <https://support.apple.com/kb/HT212223>

  * <https://support.apple.com/kb/HT212220>

  * <https://support.apple.com/kb/HT212222>

  * <https://support.apple.com/kb/HT212221>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: HMRC Phishing Scam Abuses Mail Service
A security researcher named TheAnalyst discovered and shared information about a continuous HMRC phishing campaign leveraging SendGrid’s features to support malicious attacks, according to BleepingComputer.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: HMRC Phishing Scam Abuses Mail Service
A security researcher named TheAnalyst discovered and shared information about a continuous HMRC phishing campaign leveraging SendGrid’s features to support malicious attacks, according to BleepingComputer.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Threat actors continue to abuse and exploit the legitimate email delivery service SendGrid to collect sensitive credentials. By utilizing some of SendGrid’s features, threat actors are able to bypass spam filters and email security products. The malicious webpages in a specific campaign analyzed by BleepingComputer mimic the HMRC and GOV.UK appearance, requesting information such as: UTR number, NINo number, passport number and expiry dates, driving license number, name, DOB and, address information. According to the information BleepingComputer received, what made this campaign so successful was the spoofed “From email” field with an outgoing address likely designed to trick the victim. For more information, see the BleepingComputer article in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/hmrc-phishing-scam-abuses-mail-service-to-bypass-spam-filters/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Ransomware Masquerades as Mobile Version of Cyberpunk 2077
With the release of Cyberpunk 2077, attackers are using its much-anticipated release to trick users into installing malware. BleepingComputer reports on a specific campaign distributing ransomware to Android devices.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Ransomware Masquerades as Mobile Version of Cyberpunk 2077
With the release of Cyberpunk 2077, attackers are using its much-anticipated release to trick users into installing malware. BleepingComputer reports on a specific campaign distributing ransomware to Android devices.

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

BleepingComputer has published an article regarding a fake Cyberpunk 2077 mobile app being used to distribute ransomware. The payload is hosted on a domain that appears to be legitimately related to the game. The webpage looks like the legitimate Google Play store with numerous fake reviews and ratings. After encrypting the device, a ransom note is displayed on the device screen explaining that the victim must pay a ransom to a Bitcoin wallet in order to receive the decryption key. In the note, the ransomware operators claim the family is called "CoderWare," but the Windows version of this malware, which also masquerades as Cyberpunk 2077, has been identified as a variant of the BlackKingdom ransomware family. It was discovered that the malware uses RC4 encryption with a hardcoded key. The presence of the key in the code means that it is possible to decrypt files without paying the ransom. For more information, see the BleepingComputer article in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/ransomware-masquerades-as-mobile-version-of-cyberpunk-2077/>

  * <https://twitter.com/sh1shk0va/status/1338999532701577216>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Android Surveillanceware, Hornbill and SunBird Released by Pro-India APT Named Confucius
New Android surveillanceware has been discovered by the Lookout Threat Intelligence team. It is targeting Pakistani users in an effort to ex-filtrate data and audio communications recordings. Domains used in the campaign point to the campaign being carried out by APT group, Confucius.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Data Theft, RAT, APT




# Overview

The Lookout Threat Intelligence team has discovered two new android malware packages they named Hornbill and SunBird. Both have the purpose of ex-filtrating data, which includes data and audio recordings of communications, from the android device. The Lookout team analyzed over 18GB of ex-filtrated data which revealed locations of the infected devices. Notable targets included individuals in the Pakistani military and government. It is believed the advanced persistent threat group (APT) Confucius is behind the campaign. Confucius has been known to to be pro-India actor pursuing Pakistani and other South Asian targets since 2013. The group has been known to name their malicious apps similar to legitimate phone chat apps. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
  * Do not install phone applications from unofficial app stores.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.lookout.com/lookout-discovers-novel-confucius-apt-android-spyware-linked-to-india-pakistan-conflict>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Cryptominer Exploiting ProxyLogon
The ProxyLogon vulnerability affecting Microsoft Exchange has been exploited for a wide variety of purposes. A report by Sophos details the case of a cryptominer spreading via exploitation of this vulnerability.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptominer, Exploit




# Overview

Sophos has published a blog post analyzing a cryptominer spreading via the ProxyLogon exploit. The payload being distributed is itself hosted on a vulnerable Microsoft Exchange server. The infection chain begins with the attackers exploiting ProxyLogon in order to execute a PowerShell command. This PowerShell command downloads and executes a batch script masquerading as a ZIP archive. The batch script, in turn, uses certutil to download two files hosted on the same server, a base64-encoded executable and a .dat file. The decoded executable extracts the miner and its configuration from the .dat file, injects it into a system process, and then deletes the downloaded files, leaving the miner running in memory only. The miner in use is xmr-stack and is capable of mining Monero. The Monero blockchain indicates that the wallet has been receiving funds with fluctuations due to patching of servers followed by further infections on other servers. For more information, see the Sophos blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/04/13/compromised-exchange-server-hosting-cryptojacker-targeting-other-exchange-servers/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Evaluating Cookies to Hide Backdoors
During an investigation, Sucuri discovered a novel use of cookies by an attacker to gain backdoor access to a victim WordPress server.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor




# Overview

Sucuri published a blog post analyzing a technique to gain backdoor access seen in a recent incident. In order to reduce the amount of malicious code injected to a victim server, the attacker used cookie content to store the majority of the code. The initial code is injected into a file that will load on all pages on the WordPress site, such as wp-load.php. It first evaluates the presence of a cookie value defined by the attacker to ensure the backdoor web panel is not presented to regular users. If the correct cookie is present, a second cookie is checked. This second cookie contains the malicious PHP code to be executed. Since HTTP access logs don't record cookie data by default, it is unlikely a victim would be able to recover the malicious code, as was the case in Sucuri's investigation. Any PHP code under 4096 bytes of the attacker's choice could be executed with this method though, such as retrieving a payload from a remote server. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2021/01/evaluating-cookies-to-hide-backdoors.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Silver Sparrow - macOS Malware With No Current Payload
An unusual piece of macOS malware has been reported by Red Canary. The malware is named Silver Sparrow, has infected almost 30,000 systems but, as of yet, has no actual payload.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Silver Sparrow is macOS malware, two versions of which have been analysed by Red Canary. The first version surfaced in August 2020, the second version appearing a month later. Both versions contained Mach-O binaries. However, the Mach-O binary in the second version is compiled for the Intel x86_64 and M1 ARM64 architectures. Silver Sparrow has been distributed using malvertising with links that lead to malicious DMG or PKG installers. Between them, the two versions of Silver Sparrow are reported to have infected almost 30,000 systems. Once installed, Silver Sparrow contacts its C&C every hour. As of yet, no actual payload is known to have been delivered to the infected systems. Silver Sparrow can completely remove itself from infected systems. While the actual purpose of Silver Sparrow is unknown, and there is no current payload, the operators of Silver Sparrow could issue instructions to the malware at a time of their choosing. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Silver Sparrow - macOS Malware With No Current Payload
An unusual piece of macOS malware has been reported by Red Canary. The malware is named Silver Sparrow, has infected almost 30,000 systems but, as of yet, has no actual payload.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Silver Sparrow is macOS malware, two versions of which have been analysed by Red Canary. The first version surfaced in August 2020, the second version appearing a month later. Both versions contained Mach-O binaries. However, the Mach-O binary in the second version is compiled for the Intel x86_64 and M1 ARM64 architectures. Silver Sparrow has been distributed using malvertising with links that lead to malicious DMG or PKG installers. Between them, the two versions of Silver Sparrow are reported to have infected almost 30,000 systems. Once installed, Silver Sparrow contacts its C&C every hour. As of yet, no actual payload is known to have been delivered to the infected systems. Silver Sparrow can completely remove itself from infected systems. While the actual purpose of Silver Sparrow is unknown, and there is no current payload, the operators of Silver Sparrow could issue instructions to the malware at a time of their choosing. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Web Scrapers Using Facebook's Link Preview Feature
Researchers from DataDome have published a proof-of-concept about how the Facebook Crawler could be used to gather information on webpages previewed that may be used for nefarious purposes.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Proof-of-Concept




# Overview

DataDome has published a blog detailing a POC about how the Facebook Crawler could be hijacked by threat actors to gather information on webpages used in the preview link function of Messenger and many other platforms. Since Facebook is a large consumer of user traffic, there are many threat actors seeking to use the whitelisting of the Facebook Crawler to extract large amounts of data from websites disguised as Facebook. The hijacking is done via providing a token linked to a Facebook account. Web scrapers could make thousands of requests per minute and many performed that action. Messenger, like many other platforms, provides a preview of links within the program using the Messenger preview API. The data presented in these previews could contain information about the pages purporting to be Facebook since the request is sent as FACEBOOK AS. The reverse DNS shows the IP address as that belonging to Facebook regardless of the actual IP address of the preview. The requestor could test product availability or presence, which could be of importance to sneaker bot operators as well as scalper bots. This technique has been seen in the wild by the DataDome researchers. The API used showed the data call came from Facebook rather than the scalper or other bot being used for the nefarious purposes. More information can be found in the POC located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://datadome.co/bot-detection/how-facebook-was-used-as-a-proxy-by-web-scraping-bots/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Recent Formbook Activity
The use of packers to protect malware and legitimate cloud services for hosting payloads has been on the rise. Yoroi discovered Formbook, a malware family around since 2016, implementing both of these techniques in a recent campaign.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Stealer




# Overview

Yoroi published a blog post analyzing a recent Formbook campaign, specifically focusing on its use of a packer. The infection chain begins with the download of a binary masquerading as a PDF from the Discord CDN. Analysis reveals that the downloaded file has been packed using NSIS. The installer script indicates that upon execution two files will be extracted to the TEMP path. The first one is a malicious DLL while the secondary is an encrypted file. The DLL acts as a decoder for the second file. A custom algorithm is implemented for encryption and decryption. Ultimately, the Formbook payload is decrypted and injected into memory, at which point it can be used to steal credentials and information from the victim host. For more information, see the Yoroi blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Protection

## Yara Rules
    
    
    rule Formbook_NSIS_Packer {  
    meta:  
    description = "Yara rule Forbook NSIS Packer"  
    hash = "90c968905405e89ebb8aece8656238dae5aabd40acf795587d3c918b2d8df284"  
    author = "Yoroi Malware ZLab"  
    last_updated = "2021-02-23"  
    tlp = "white"  
    category = "informational"  
      
    strings:  
    $a1 = { E6 50 47 D2 BD 73 77 D2 E3 50 47 D2 }  
    $a2 = { 3B FD C7 44 24 10 04 A1 40 00 72 65 }  
      
      
    $a3 = "nsis.sf"  
    $s1 = "54GB"  
    condition:  
    uint16(0) == 0x5A4D and all of ($a*) and #s1>2   
    }  
      
      
    rule Formbook_DLL_Loader {  
    meta:  
    description = "Yara rule Forbook DLL Loader"  
    hash = "cf0911773f848ae94f448984266ebb2b77bf0c32439d3062ffc136c893e07bb9"  
    author = "Yoroi Malware ZLab"  
    last_updated = "2021-02-23"  
    tlp = "white"  
    category = "informational"  
      
    strings:  
    $a1 = { B1 DE 32 C3 02 C3 F6 D8 32 C3 2A C8 80 F1 93 2A CB 80 F1 ?? 2A CB F6 D1 80 E9 ?? 88 8B }  
    condition:  
    uint16(0) == 0x5A4D and all of them   
    }

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://yoroi.company/research/yes-cyber-adversaries-are-still-using-formbook-in-2021/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: ICS-CERT Advisories February 11 2021
The ICS-CERT has published two advisories that affect Multiple Embedded TCP/IP stacks and Rockwell Automation DriveTools SP and Drives AOP.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarised below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-042-01 - Multiple Embedded TCP/IP stacks**  
CVE-2020-27213 - Nut/Net software relies on highly predictable source values and has consistent increments when generating initial sequence numbers (ISN), which may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27630 - uC/TCP-IP ISN generation relies on a linear congruential generator (LCG), which is reversible from observed output streams as the algorithm is seeded with publicly recoverable information. This defect may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27631 - CycloneTCP ISN generation relies on a linear congruential generator (LCG), which is reversible from observed output streams as the algorithm is seeded with publicly recoverable information. This defect may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27632 - NDKTCPIP software is initialized with a consistent value and has consistent increments when generating initial sequence numbers (ISN), which may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27633 - FNET software is initialized with a consistent value and has consistent increments when generating initial sequence numbers (ISN), which may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27634 - uIP, Contiki-OS, and Contiki-NG software is initialized with a consistent value and has consistent increments when generating initial sequence numbers (ISN), which may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27635 - PicoTCP PicoTCP-NG software ISN generation relies on a linear congruential generator (LCG), which is reversible from observed output streams as the algorithm is seeded with publicly recoverable information. This defect may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27636 - MPLAB software ISN generation relies on a linear congruential generator (LCG), which is reversible from observed output streams as the algorithm is seeded with publicly recoverable information. This defect may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-28388 - Nucleus NET and Nucleus ReadyStart software ISN generation relies on a combination of values that can be acquired from capturing network traffic, which may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:L).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-042-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-042-02 - Rockwell Automation DriveTools SP and Drives AOP**  
CVE-2021-22665 - DriveTools and Drives AOP both contain a vulnerability that a local attacker with limited privileges may be able to exploit resulting in privilege escalation and complete control of the system.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:H/PR:L/UI:R/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-042-02>

# CVEs

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories>

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  


APSB20-69: This bulletin addresses reflected cross-site scripting vulnerabilities in Adobe Connect. A remote attacker may be able to exploit the vulnerabilities to execute arbitrary JavaScript within the context of the victim's browser.

ASPB20-71: This bulletin addresses a single vulnerability in Adobe Reader Mobile for Android. Successfully exploited, the vulnerability could allow an attacker to obtain sensitive information.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Rinfo is Back and More Dangerous Than Ever
An old botnet family is making a comeback with new capabilities. Netlab reports on the Rinfo family of malware and its latest activity in a blog post.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet




# Overview

A new, more aggressive version of the Rinfo family of malware is making high traffic appearances in honeypots. As of February 6, 2021, the botnet has been observed by Netlab researchers increasing it's scanning, mining, and C2 domains. At publication, nearly 12,000 scans, 1,800 miner samples, and 3,200 C2 domains have been observed. This uptick in activity has put Rinfo back on the map. Overall, the structure of the family remains as it has been. The family runs scans in an effort to form a mining botnet. This version still relies on ngrok.io to distribute samples. Ports and services previously used have been changed. Apache CouchDB and MODX have been removed and Mongo, Confluence, and vBulletin have been added. The new variant is spreading at a rapid pace. Both the scanner and miner are written in bash with no code seen to download or execute the miner module in the scanner module and vice versa meaning the two modules are not linked. It is thought that the scanner module locates a target and then the attacker can choose to implant the scanner or drop the miner. Other functionality could also be implanted though no specific modules have been identified. The increase in scan numbers is most likely due to reporting URLs having been changed from one domain to two. Additional technical detail can be found in the blog located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/rinfo-is-making-a-comeback-and-is-scanning-and-mining-in-full-speed/>

# Threat Type

# Overview

A new, more aggressive version of the Rinfo family of malware is making high traffic appearances in honeypots. As of February 6, 2021, the botnet has been observed by Netlab researchers increasing it's scanning, mining, and C2 domains. At publication, nearly 12,000 scans, 1,800 miner samples, and 3,200 C2 domains have been observed. This uptick in activity has put Rinfo back on the map. Overall, the structure of the family remains as it has been. The family runs scans in an effort to form a mining botnet. This version still relies on ngrok.io to distribute samples. Ports and services previously used have been changed. Apache CouchDB and MODX have been removed and Mongo, Confluence, and vBulletin have been added. The new variant is spreading at a rapid pace. It is thought that the scanner module locates a target and then the attacker can choose to implant the scanner or drop the miner. Other functionality could also be implanted though no specific modules have been identified. Tell me about the following threat: Free Steam Game Scams on TikTok
Social engineering occurs on a diverse number of social media platforms and leverages various techniques. Recently, Malwarebytes has observed TikTok being used as a distribution vector for a scam site.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Free Steam Game Scams on TikTok
Social engineering occurs on a diverse number of social media platforms and leverages various techniques. Recently, Malwarebytes has observed TikTok being used as a distribution vector for a scam site.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Malvertising, Scam
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unknown
  *  **Targets:** TikTok Users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Link distributed via TikTok
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Redirect to malvertising content



# Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post detailing free game scam campaigns seen on TikTok. In these campaigns, a profile advertising free Steam games is created with various videos directing users to a website that claims to provide the free Steam games. On this website, a secondary link is provided to download the game, but attempting to do so will lead to a pop-up requesting identity verifications. If a user falls victim to this lure, they are redirected to a new site that has been associated with malvertising campaigns. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616205/Free%20Steam%20Game%20Scams%20on%20TikTok%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634748750660&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/scams/2021/10/free-steam-game-scams-on-tiktok-are-among-us/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Simps Botnet Tied to Keksec Group
The Threat Research Team from Uptycs has discovered a new botnet, dubbed Simps, that has focused on DDoS-type activities.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet




# Overview

In May 2021, threat researchers from Uptycs discovered a shell script and Gafgyt malware downloading Simps binaries from a common C2 server. The script is used to download several payloads for *nix architectures. These payloads are stored in the same directory ('Simps') as the shell script used to download them. Using Wget, payloads are downloaded into the tmp directory, permissions are changed using chmod, and rm is used to delete the payloads. A log file is dropped that states the machine has been successfully compromised. Simultaneously, Gafgyt was also downloading the Simps binary. The payload was then delivered via the exploitation of multiple RCE vulnerabilities in IOT devices. The owners/operators of the botnet have a YouTube channel and Discord server where a demo of the Simps botnet is shown in action. Attribution to the Keksec Group was accomplished by examining a log named "keksec.infected.you.log." Within the log was the username of the individual(s) responsible for the infection, "urmommy." The Discord server contained the same "urmommy" user name. Further information can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.uptycs.com/blog/discovery-of-simps-botnet-leads-ties-to-keksec-group>

I have encountered the following information: An Update: The COVID-19 Vaccine’s Global Cold Chain Continues to Be a Target
In December 2020, IBM Security X-Force released a research blog disclosing that the COVID-19 cold chain - an integral part of delivering and storing COVID-19 vaccines at safe temperatures - was targeted by cyber adversaries. Continued research led to additional evidence and insight, including new sample files and domains, along with expanded targeting.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

In December 2020, IBM Security X-Force released a research blog disclosing that the COVID-19 cold chain - an integral part of delivering and storing COVID-19 vaccines at safe temperatures - was targeted by cyber adversaries. After that first report, we recently discovered an additional 50 files tied to spearphishing emails that targeted 44 companies in 14 countries in Europe, North America, South America, Africa and Asia. The expanded scope of precision targeting includes key organizations likely underpinning the transport, warehousing, storage and ultimate distribution of vaccines. Spearphishing attempts were associated with multiple executive activities and other roles. The campaign impersonates an executive from Haier Biomedical, a major Chinese biomedical company that is purported to be the world’s only complete cold chain provider. For more information, see the Security Intelligence blog post in the Reference section. For more in-depth analysis surrounding this campaign, IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients can view the extended report in Trustar at the link below.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Crytominer and DDoS Bot Malware Loaded Onto Docker Image
Trend Micro is reporting that Alpine Linux Docker images are being attacked and loaded with crytominer and DDoS bot code. A similar attack in May of this year was also reported by Trend Micro.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Crytominer and DDoS Bot Malware Loaded Onto Docker Image
Trend Micro is reporting that Alpine Linux Docker images are being attacked and loaded with crytominer and DDoS bot code. A similar attack in May of this year was also reported by Trend Micro.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptominer, Bot, DDoS



# Overview

Reminiscent of an attack Trend Micro reported on in May of this year, they are now reporting on a similar attack. Docker images, based on Alpine Linux, are being attacked. Should the attack be successful, the server is infected with a cryptominer and DDoS bot malware. Infection begins on an exposed Docker server by creating a Docker container and running a script that retrieves an XMI file, which is really a bash script inside the container. This script then attempts to move laterally across the network, targeting hosts listed in the known_hosts file in the .ssh directory. Hosts listed in this file are systems this host / user has connected to in the past over an SSH connection. In some cases, the remote host might have this system's public key in their authorized_keys file, thus a connection could be made without knowing login credentials. The XMI script also downloads and executes other commands, such as those needed to set up cron jobs and services for persistence. Other commands in the script were commented out, such as one that appears to attempt to connect to SSH servers through brute-forcing the password. Trend Micro noted that the cryptocurrency wallet was the same one seen in campaigns that attempted to exploit a Confluence vulnerability (CVE-2019-3396) and an Apache Struts vulnerability (CVE-2017-5638). The XMI script then drops a cryptominer malware package and the DDoS bot. For more technical details, please see the Trend Micro article in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/29431538/Crytominer%20and%20DDoS%20Bot%20Malware%20Loaded%20Onto%20Docker%20Image%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1599672212428&api=v2)



# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/29431538/Crytominer%20and%20DDoS%20Bot%20Malware%20Loaded%20Onto%20Docker%20Image%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1599672176075&api=v2)



# Protection

  * CVE-2019-3396: HTTP_Confluence_JSON_Injection
  * CVE-2017-5638: HTTP_Apache_Jakarta_Multipart_Exec



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/20/i/exposed-docker-server-abused-to-drop-cryptominer-ddos-bot-.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Brazilian Bank Users Targeted in Phishing Operation
Clients of Banco Itau Empresas who use Itaú Internet Banking are being targeted by a phishing operation that is set up to take advantage of the new PIX payment method.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

PIX is a payment method implemented by Brazil's Central Bank that provides several benefits over the old systems, such as faster completion of transactions. A phishing operation is targeting business customers of Banco Itau Empresas online banking service, which uses an app. The lure is a fake diagnostic page for the app that informs the user their version of the app is out of date and provides a link to update the app. If the link is clicked, the victim is presented with a fake login page. The login page uses PHP sessions and AJAX calls to provide the attacker real time control over the responses and requests sent to the victim. While a victim awaits responses, the bank's legitimate loading GIF is presented to the victim. The aim of the attacker is to obtain the victim's credentials and QR code, which allows the attacker to then access and manipulate the victim's account. Further details, including a split screen animation showing the victim's screen and the attacker's dashboard, are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * None provided.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2021/01/real-time-phishing-kit-targets-brazilian-central-bank.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Largely Undetected PRISM Variants Used in Multiple Campaigns
A report from AT&T Alien Labs provides information on variants of the open-source PRISM backdoor that have remained largely undetected for at least 3.5 years.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Multiple unnamed actors
  *  **Associated Payloads:** PRISM, WaterDrop
  *  **Targets:** Various
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Detection evasion, Data Exfiltration
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See Mitre ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A report from AT&T Alien Labs describes the open-source PRISM backdoor as simplistic and its binaries as being easy to detect. Additionally, PRISM's C&C communications are HTTP-based and clearly identifiable. Despite this, AT&T Alien Labs has discovered a number of PRISM variants that have been used in multiple smaller campaigns, by multiple actors, over a period of more than 3.5 years, which have remained largely undetected. They have named one of the variants WaterDrop, named for the string "waterdropx" which is used in the C&C domain name, and the User-Agent in its HTTP communications with its C&C server. The domain was registered in 2017 and remained online in August 2021. Other PRISM variants were also observed using the WaterDrop C&C server. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127041/Largely%20Undetected%20PRISM%20Variants%20Used%20in%20Multiple%20Campaigns%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1630462096059&api=v2)



Detection

  * A Yara rule can be found here: [ Yara Rule.txt](/download/attachments/64127041/Largely%20Undetected%20PRISM%20Variants%20Used%20in%20Multiple%20Campaigns%20Yara%20Rule.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1630462112377&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://cybersecurity.att.com/blogs/labs-research/prism-attacks-fly-under-the-radar>



# Mitre ATT&CK Framework

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1014 - Rootkit  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Largely Undetected PRISM Variants Used in Multiple Campaigns
A report from AT&T Alien Labs provides information on variants of the open-source PRISM backdoor that have remained largely undetected for at least 3.5 years.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Multiple unnamed actors
  *  **Associated Payloads:** PRISM, WaterDrop
  *  **Targets:** Various
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Detection evasion, Data Exfiltration
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See Mitre ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A report from AT&T Alien Labs describes the open-source PRISM backdoor as simplistic and its binaries as being easy to detect. Additionally, PRISM's C&C communications are HTTP-based and clearly identifiable. Despite this, AT&T Alien Labs has discovered a number of PRISM variants that have been used in multiple smaller campaigns, by multiple actors, over a period of more than 3.5 years, which have remained largely undetected. They have named one of the variants WaterDrop, named for the string "waterdropx" which is used in the C&C domain name, and the User-Agent in its HTTP communications with its C&C server. The domain was registered in 2017 and remained online in August 2021. Other PRISM variants were also observed using the WaterDrop C&C server. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127041/Largely%20Undetected%20PRISM%20Variants%20Used%20in%20Multiple%20Campaigns%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1630462096059&api=v2)



Detection

  * A Yara rule can be found here: [ Yara Rule.txt](/download/attachments/64127041/Largely%20Undetected%20PRISM%20Variants%20Used%20in%20Multiple%20Campaigns%20Yara%20Rule.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1630462112377&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://cybersecurity.att.com/blogs/labs-research/prism-attacks-fly-under-the-radar>



# Mitre ATT&CK Framework

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1014 - Rootkit  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Silently Running Facebook Ads with Exploits
At this year's Virus Bulletin international conference, which was virtual, researchers from FaceBook presented the findings of their research into a malware family they’ve named "SilentFade". The name is short for "Silently running Facebook ADs with Exploits".
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Facebook researchers believe that malware named SilentFade, and the creators and operators of it, came onto the scene in early 2016. Since then, the SilentFade malware has been consistently improved with additional features and has been expanded to target other social networks and services. SilentFade is typically installed through a downloader that is bundled with pirated software. There are usually three or four components, including the downloader, that make up the SilentFade package. The downloader installs the payload as either a standalone component, or as a Windows service. Successfully installed, SilentFade will obtain the victim's Facebook credentials along with cookies from various browsers. As the name says, the objective of SilentFade is to run ads and pay for them using the stolen account credentials. Facebook attributes SilentFade to a Chinese company and filed a lawsuit against the company in December 2019. SilentFade has so far resulted in payment and ad fraud worth more than 4 million USD. See the report linked in the Reference section below for further details.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://vblocalhost.com/uploads/VB2020-Karve-Urgilez.pdf>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Buer and Bazar Malware Being Delivered in Phishing Campaign
Using fear tactics, threat actors have launched a phishing campaign at employees of companies. Using the guise of terminating employment, the actors are distributing Buer and Bazar malware, reports Zscaler.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing




# Overview

Using intimidation tactics, threat actors are sending phishing emails containing information about termination of employment in order to implant malware into unsuspecting users' computer systems and networks. Initial infection is accomplished through said phishing email, which contains a Google document link, presumably, from the TrickBot gang. This link leads to the Bazar backdoor as well as the Buer loader. Trickbot has previously used different botnets, including Emotet, for the carrying out of its mission. Unlike most phishing emails, this contains no attachments, only a link to the aforementioned Google documents links. The body of the email states the recipient has been terminated and a link to the termination reasoning is included. In one such email, the reason for termination was positional redundancy. The link actually redirects to a URL used to download the malware payload. Most of the cases analyzed were instances where Bazar malware was downloaded; however, in some cases Buer loader was used. The packer for both is identical. The packed binaries contain an export function that is responsible for decryption and injection. First, a shell is deployed to decrypt a leaderless PE loader which contains the final payload. Using memory allocation, the payload is mapped into memory, given permissions, and transfers control. No self-injection is used. The Bazar backdoor is new malware and is part of TrickBot's toolkit. This is reserved for almost exclusively high profile targets. The Bazar loader is used to download and execute the backdoor, which, in turn, is used to execute binaries, scripts, modules, kill processes, and self removal. Control flow is obfuscated to hinder analysis. The Bazar loader is used to download the backdoor from a C2 using a URI format. This download was captured and analyzed. As with other Trickbot certificates, the certificates for Bazar were created in the same manner. It was also seen that the backdoor downloaded and executed the Cobalt Strike pentesting and post-exploit toolkit. It is hypothesized this is done so ransomware could be deployed, data stolen, or network access could be sold. Buer loader is sold on Russian underground forums. Most of its strings are encrypted and APIs are loaded by hash. Further information can be found in the links located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/spear-phishing-campaign-delivers-buer-and-bazar-malware>

  * <https://www.vkremez.com/2020/04/lets-learn-trickbot-bazarbackdoor.html>
  * <https://krabsonsecurity.com/2019/12/05/buer-loader-new-russian-loader-on-the-market-with-interesting-persistence/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: BHUNT - A New Family of Cryptostealer
A new whitepaper by Bitdefender explores a new family of cryptostealer malware they are calling BHUNT. The paper details how the researchers unpacked the sample and explores the execution flow of the malware.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Cryptostealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** BHUNT
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Fake Installers **  
**
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Bitdefender has discovered a new family of malware they are calling BHUNT. This malware functions as a cryptostealer, that can exfiltrate wallet contents, stored passwords, and clipboard contents. The samples seen by the researchers were heavily obfuscated, and so the code had to be dumped from memory before it could be analyzed. Machines infected with BHUNT tended to have some form of crack for windows on their system, so the researchers speculate that this could be how the malware was introduced to the victim systems. Once installed, the malware checks for the existence of various crypto wallets, and sends this to the C2 server, along with victim host information. The malware has several methods for stealing data. It can read the contents of a wallet and directly exfiltrate it. It can also search for Firefox profiles that contain account tokens and exfiltrate them, before killing any Firefox processes. The C2 server used by the sample used a dynamic DNS server, meaning that the researchers can't obtain a persistent IP address used by the attackers. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057234/BHUNT%20-%20A%20New%20Family%20of%20Cryptostealer%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642685080186&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 
  * Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing (M1045). 



# References

  * <https://www.bitdefender.com/files/News/CaseStudies/study/411/Bitdefender-PR-Whitepaper-CyberWallet-creat5874-en-EN.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1036.001 - Invalid Code Signature  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
T1564.001 - Hidden Files and Directories  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1115 - Clipboard Data  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Business Email Compromise Disruption via Cross-Domain Threat Data
Microsoft Defender researchers have reported on a business email compromise (BEC) campaign that they subsequently thwarted.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing, Business Email Compromise




# Overview

An investigation by the Microsoft Defender team researchers has uncovered a BEC campaign in which attackers are conducting phishing and compromised mailboxes attacks. Using multiple web services, the attackers were able to operate under the radar. Different IPs and timeframes made for difficult for analysts to correlate activity that does not appear related. Microsoft 365 Defender's cross-domain feature was able to assist in the identification of this BEC campaign. A minimal footprint makes the cross-domain feature a necessary part of the identification process. Microsoft's Threat Intelligence Center (MSTIC) reported the activity to multiple cloud security teams and they, in turn, suspended the accounts used by threat actors thus eliminating the infrastructure. By employing multi-factor authentication (MFA), most of these types of attacks are thwarted since the attackers cannot log into those protected accounts. A phishing email sent to potential victims contained an HTML file as well as a voicemail lure. Shortly after these emails were sent, forwarding rules were created, presumably, by the threat actors. JavaScript within the HTML attachment showed an imitation of the Microsoft sign-in page. Upon entering a password, the user is shown animations and, after that, a "File not found" message. Credentials were sent to the attackers through a redirection to a cloud service provider not related to the attacker. Persistence was obtained via email forwarding rules. Further information can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2021/06/14/behind-the-scenes-of-business-email-compromise-using-cross-domain-threat-data-to-disrupt-a-large-bec-infrastructure/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Cisco Security Advisories - November 18
Cisco has published nineteen Security Advisories. Of the advisories, three are rated as Critical, three are rated as High, and thirteen are rated as Medium. The advisories apply to Cisco's Expressway Software, IoT Field Network Director, DNA Spaces Connector, Telepresence CE Software, Integrated Management Controller, Webex Meetings and Webex Meetings Server, and the Secure Web Appliance.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
 Please note the Cisco statements on public announcements regarding three of the Webex Meetings and Webex Meetings Server vulnerabilities highlighted in the summaries below.

## Advisories Rated Critical

 **Integrated Management Controller Multiple Remote Code Execution Vulnerabilities**  
cisco-sa-ucs-api-rce-UXwpeDHd - CVE-2020-3470  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-ucs-api-rce-UXwpeDHd>

 **DNA Spaces Connector Command Injection Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-dna-cmd-injection-rrAYzOwc - CVE-2020-3586  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-dna-cmd-injection-rrAYzOwc>

 **IoT Field Network Director Unauthenticated REST API Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-FND-BCK-GHkPNZ5F - CVE-2020-3531  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-FND-BCK-GHkPNZ5F>

## Advisories Rated High

 **Secure Web Appliance Privilege Escalation Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-wsa-prv-esc-nPzWZrQj - CVE-2020-3367  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-wsa-prv-esc-nPzWZrQj>

 **IoT Field Network Director SOAP API Authorization Bypass Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-FND-AUTH-vEypBmmR - CVE-2020-26072  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-FND-AUTH-vEypBmmR>

 **IoT Field Network Director Missing API Authentication Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-FND-APIA-xZntFS2V - CVE-2020-3392  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-FND-APIA-xZntFS2V>

## Advisories Rated Medium

 **Webex Meetings and Webex Meetings Server Information Disclosure Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-webex-infodisc-4tvQzn4 - CVE-2020-3441  
 **The Cisco Product Security Incident Response Team (PSIRT) is aware of public announcements about this vulnerability.**  
Cisco PSIRT is not aware of malicious use of the vulnerability that is described in this advisory.  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-webex-infodisc-4tvQzn4>

 **Webex Meetings and Webex Meetings Server Unauthorized Audio Information Exposure Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-webex-info-leak-PhpzB3sG - CVE-2020-3471  
 **The Cisco Product Security Incident Response Team (PSIRT) is aware of public announcements about this vulnerability.**  
Cisco PSIRT is not aware of malicious use of the vulnerability that is described in this advisory.  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-webex-info-leak-PhpzB3sG>

 **Webex Meetings and Webex Meetings Server Ghost Join Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-webex-auth-token-3vg57A5r - CVE-2020-3419  
 **The Cisco Product Security Incident Response Team (PSIRT) is aware of public announcements about this vulnerability.**  
Cisco PSIRT is not aware of malicious use of the vulnerability that is described in this advisory.  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-webex-auth-token-3vg57A5r>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: A Detailed Analysis of the Hancitor Loader
A reverse engineer at 0ffset.net has been publishing a series of articles on the Hancitor malware family. In the latest post, the Hancitor Loader was comprehensively analyzed and its methods and functionality described.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Loader
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown **  
**
  * **Associated Payloads:** Hancitor (S0499)
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Infected Maldocs
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Executable Download and Execution.



# Overview

A reverse engineer at 0ffset.net has published a detailed analysis of the main loader of the Hancitor malware family. The sample is a DLL file and was originally packed, requiring dynamic unpacking to retrieve the payload to be analyzed. The malware generates a string containing the victim host's information, which is encrypted and sent to the C2 server. This information includes a unique ID that is generated by the malware, along with information including the hostname, current user, and domain name. The malware contains several hardcoded C2 URLs, which are cycled through to find a URL that is working. Responses from the C2 server are Base64-encoded strings that include an integrity check. The malware sample can perform many functions, depending on what command is received from the C2 server. It can download and execute shellcode and executables, as well as process injection of an svchost process. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056662/A%20Detailed%20Analysis%20of%20the%20HANCITOR%20Loader%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641482046880&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing (M1045). 



# References

  * <https://www.0ffset.net/reverse-engineering/malware-analysis/hancitor-analysing-the-main-loader/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1055 - Process Injection  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Philippines Healthcare Worker Data Exposed in COVID-KAYA App Vulnerability
A platform used by healthcare workers in the Philippines for COVID-19 information contained vulnerabilities in their web and Android apps. The Citizen Lab shares its data regarding the vulnerabilities in a blog post.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

A vulnerability in its authentication logic has been seen in a platform (COVID-KAYA) used by healthcare workers in the Philippines. Both web interface and Android apps have been affected by this. Successfully exploited already, the result was restricted access to API endpoints which exposed the names and locations of health centers and more than 30,000 healthcare providers. Although unconfirmed, the data could have revealed sensitive patient information. The Android vulnerability consisted of hardcoded credentials that allowed access to its internal APIs. This credential can successfully use the APIs, upon authentication, to obtain the same information contained within the web interface. As with the above, it cannot be confirmed about the release of sensitive patient data. The vulnerabilities were disclosed to the makers of the web interface and Android app. The developers issued an update addressing the issue which has been confirmed by the researchers as a closed vulnerability. More information can be found in the blog post located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://citizenlab.ca/2020/11/unmasked-covid-kaya-and-the-exposure-of-healthcare-worker-data-in-the-philippines/>
