instruction:
I have encountered the following information: North Korea Distributing BLINDINGCAN RAT
SentinelOne has published a paper regarding malicious North Korean activity and the distribution of a RAT labeled BLINDINGCAN.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT, Campaign



# Overview

Job offers are the subject of this particular phishing campaign and they carry BLINDINGCAN RAT as a payload, a SentinelOne paper states. The defense and aerospace industries in Europe and the United States are the primary targets of this campaign. An infected system in a key location can provide the attackers with valuable intelligence and key technologies, the article indicated. The attachment attempts to exploit CVE-2017-0199, a vulnerability in the processing of RTF files, which can result in the execution of arbitrary code if successful. Once infected, the malware contacts its command and control servers for additional components, such as a keylogger and clipboard monitor. Information about the system is sent back to the command and control servers. For more details, please refer to the links in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2017-0199



# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/29426391/North%20Korea%20Distributing%20BLINDINGCAN%20RAT%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1598905010014&api=v2)



# Protection

## Yara Rules

  * See here for a list of Yara rules: [ Yara.txt](/download/attachments/29426391/North%20Korea%20Distributing%20BLINDINGCAN%20RAT%20Yara.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1598905065626&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/blog/the-blindingcan-rat-and-malicious-north-korean-activity/>  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar20-232a>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Ngrok Convoluted Attack Chain
Trend Micro writes about an event discovered in one of their customer's networks involving Ngrok.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Ngrok Convoluted Attack Chain
Trend Micro writes about an event discovered in one of their customer's networks involving Ngrok.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Keylogger



# Overview

In July, Trend Micro uncovered a suspicious event inside one of their customer's networks. A registry value had been created that was patterned after a well known security vendor, but there was a misspelling of the name. Also found was an executable, with a randomized name, in the System directory. This led the researchers to dig deeper into the situation. The executable turned out to be a keylogger that delivered the data it gathered to a Gmail account. Upon closer examination of the executable, they found hard-coded information that suggested it was created specifically for that customer. Other information found within the executable led Trend to suspect the attackers had pre-existing knowledge about their customer. Their analysis found that the keylogger had been installed by ntoskrnl.exe, suggesting that this was done either through a network share on the system or by a kernel vulnerability. After discovering a command in the system logs dealing with the SMB port 445, they concluded the tool in question was a copy of ngrok. Ngrok allows a system to be visible on the ngrok website by routing network traffic through the ngrok website. For more technical details of this attack, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * N/A



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/20/i/analysis-of-a-convoluted-attack-chain-involving-ngrok.html

Their analysis found that the keylogger had been installed by ntoskrnl.exe, suggesting that this was done either through a network share on the system or by a kernel vulnerability. After discovering a command in the system logs dealing with the SMB port 445, they concluded the tool in question was a copy of ngrok. Ngrok allows a system to be visible on the ngrok website by routing network traffic through the ngrok website. For more technical details of this attack, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * N/A



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/20/i/analysis-of-a-convoluted-attack-chain-involving-ngrok.html

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: CISA Alert on North Korean APT Targeting Blockchain Companies
The FBI, CISA, and the U.S. Treasury Department have published a joint alert, AA22-108A, regarding the targeting of various entities in the blockchain and cryptocurrency industry by the North Korean APT, the Lazarus group.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Various malicious applications collectively named TraderTraitor.
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** The Lazarus group, also known as APT38, BlueNoroff, and Stardust Chollima.
  *  **Associated Payloads:** AlticGO, CreAI Deck, CryptAIS, DAFOM, Esilet, Manuscrypt, TokenAIS, and various other files.
  *  **Targets:** Entities involved in the blockchain and cryptocurrency industry.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing emails.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration, stealing cryptocurrency.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below for more information.



# Overview

According to a joint alert (AA22-108A) from the FBI, CISA, and the U.S. Treasury Department, the Lazarus group has been targeting entities involved in the blockchain and cryptocurrency industry. Lazarus is believed to be a North Korean state-sponsored APT group that is also known by other names including APT38, BlueNoroff, and Stardust Chollima. The attacks begin with spearphishing emails sent to employees of cryptocurrency companies and use employment offers as the lure. The targeted employees are typically involved in software development or system administration. The emails are intended to lead the recipient to download various applications which are purported to be cryptocurrency trading or price prediction tools and contain malware. The alert refers to the various applications and malware collectively as "TraderTraitor". They are written using JavaScript in combination with the Node.js runtime environment and the Electron framework. There are various applications compiled for Windows or macOS. Further information is available from the alert linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://www.cisa.gov/uscert/ncas/alerts/aa22-108a>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1589.002 - Email Addresses  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1584.004 - Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.003 - Code Signing Certificates  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: ICS-CERT Advisories January 19 2021
The ICS-CERT has published 3 advisories that affect Philips Interventional Workstations, Dnsmasq by Simon Kelley, and Reolink P2P Cameras.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarised below.  
  


 **ICS Medical Advisory ICSMA-21-019-01 - Philips Interventional Workstations**  
CVE-2020-27298 - The software constructs all or part of an OS command using externally influenced input from an upstream component but does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended OS command when sent to a downstream component.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:A/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsma-21-019-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-019-01 - Dnsmasq by Simon Kelley**  
CVE-2020-25681 - A heap-based buffer overflow was discovered in Dnsmasq in the way it sorts RRSets before validating them with DNSSEC data. An attacker on the network could forge DNS replies to be accepted as valid to cause an overflow with arbitrary data in a heap-allocated memory, resulting in code execution.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.1 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-25682 - A buffer overflow vulnerability was discovered in the way Dnsmasq extracts names from DNS packets before validating them with DNSSEC data. An attacker on the network could create valid DNS replies to cause an overflow with arbitrary data in a heap-allocated memory, resulting in code execution.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.1 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-25683 - A heap-based buffer overflow was discovered in Dnsmasq when DNSSEC is enabled and before it validates the received DNS entries. A remote attacker could create valid DNS replies to cause an overflow in a heap-allocated memory and cause a crash in Dnsmasq, resulting in a denial-of-service condition.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.9 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).

CVE-2020-25684 - A vulnerability exists when getting a reply from a forwarded query, where Dnsmasq checks in forward.c:reply_query() if the reply destination address/port is used by the pending forwarded queries. This could allow an attacker to perform a DNS cache poisoning attack.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 4.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:L/A:N).

CVE-2020-25685 - Due to a weak hash, an off-path attacker can find several different domains with the same hash, substantially reducing the number of attempts to forge a reply for acceptance by Dnsmasq. This could allow an attacker to perform a DNS cache poisoning attack.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 4.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:L/A:N).

CVE-2020-25686 - A flaw was found when receiving a query, where Dnsmasq does not check for an existing pending request for the same name and forwards a new request. This could allow an off-path attacker on the network to substantially reduce the number of attempts to forge a reply and have it accepted by Dnsmasq.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 4.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:L/A:N).

CVE-2020-25687 - A heap-based buffer overflow was discovered in Dnsmasq when DNSSEC is enabled and before it validates the received DNS entries. A remote attacker could create valid DNS replies and cause an overflow in heap-allocated memory, resulting in a denial-of-service condition.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.9 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-019-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-019-02 - Reolink P2P Cameras**  
CVE-2020-25173 - An attacker with local network access can obtain a fixed cryptography key which may allow for further compromise of Reolink P2P cameras outside of local network access.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.7 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-25169 - The affected Reolink P2P products do not sufficiently protect data transferred between the local device and Reolink servers. This can allow an attacker to access sensitive information, such as camera feeds.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 9.1 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:N).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-019-02>

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35720736/ICS-CERT%20Advisories%20January%2019%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1611200111817&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Wormable Android Malware Spreading Through Social Media
The auto-reply feature in Android allows users to automatically respond to messages from a variety of applications. Quick Heal researchers discovered this convenient feature being abuse by malware to spread itself.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Wormable Android Malware Spreading Through Social Media
The auto-reply feature in Android allows users to automatically respond to messages from a variety of applications. Quick Heal researchers discovered this convenient feature being abuse by malware to spread itself.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Quick Heal published a blog post analyzing malicious applications abusing the Android auto-reply feature to spread payloads. Links to download the payload often come from a trusted sender who was previously infected by the same malware. The lures claim that the links provide free streaming content or feature upgrades for WhatsApp. In particular, Quick Heal investigated two applications using this method, "WhatsApp Pink" and "Online stream." Based on the code signing certificate, the same developer is behind both of these applications. Once installed, the necessary permissions are requested by the application. With this access in place, the malware begins to monitor for notifications from a variety of messaging apps. If a notification is received, the malware uses the auto-reply feature to send its download links to new potential victims. While the current functionality only includes monitoring of notifications, icon hiding, and auto-reply, it is possible for the developers to add further malicious capabilities in future variants. For more information, see the Quick Heal blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in messages.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.quickheal.com/alert-wormable-android-malware-is-spreading-through-social-media-applications/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Google's Project Zero In The Wild Series
Google's Project Zero has published part one of a six part series on vulnerabilities found in the wild by researchers.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

In part one of a six part series, Google's Project Zero details some vulnerabilities found as part of a "make 0-day hard" goal. Part one focuses on the discovery of a watering hole attack in 2020. This attack, it is hypothesized, was carried out by a highly sophisticated threat actor. In the attack, two exploit servers were delivering exploit chains via this watering hole attack. One server was targeting Windows users and the other, Android users. Interestingly, both used Chrome exploits for remote code execution. Both used 0-day vulnerabilities. The Android exploit was known to the researchers. The researchers believe the actor had access to Android 0-days but discovered no new vulnerabilities. The researchers also discovered two sandbox escape exploits abusing three 0-day vulnerabilities within Windows. Another discovery was that of a privilege escalation kit composed of publicly known n-day exploits which can be employed against older versions of Android. Efficiency and flexibility are seemingly the order of the day for these exploit chains. In future parts of the series, the team will provide detailed analysis of the vulnerabilities, exploit techniques, deep dive into the bug class of the Chrome exploits, and an in-depth teardown of the post-exploitation code for Android. Parts two through six are linked within the Reference section below. All vulnerabilities discussed in this blog post series were patched as of April 2020.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35720836/Google%27s%20Project%20Zero%20In%20The%20Wild%20Series%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1611343213858&api=v2)  




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

Google's Project Zero In The Wild Series
Google's Project Zero has published part one of a six part series on vulnerabilities found in the wild by researchers.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

In part one of a six part series, Google's Project Zero details some vulnerabilities found as part of a "make 0-day hard" goal. Part one focuses on the discovery of a watering hole attack in 2020. This attack, it is hypothesized, was carried out by a highly sophisticated threat actor. In the attack, two exploit servers were delivering exploit chains via this watering hole attack. One server was targeting Windows users and the other, Android users. Interestingly, both used Chrome exploits for remote code execution. Both used 0-day vulnerabilities. The Android exploit was known to the researchers. The researchers believe the actor had access to Android 0-days but discovered no new vulnerabilities. The researchers also discovered two sandbox escape exploits abusing three 0-day vulnerabilities within Windows. Another discovery was that of a privilege escalation kit composed of publicly known n-day exploits which can be employed against older versions of Android. Efficiency and flexibility are seemingly the order of the day for these exploit chains. In future parts of the series, the team will provide detailed analysis of the vulnerabilities, exploit techniques, deep dive into the bug class of the Chrome exploits, and an in-depth teardown of the post-exploitation code for Android. Parts two through six are linked within the Reference section below. All vulnerabilities discussed in this blog post series were patched as of April 2020.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35720836/Google%27s%20Project%20Zero%20In%20The%20Wild%20Series%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1611343213858&api=v2)

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Ransomware Drove Public Data Breaches in 2020
IBM X-force Threat Intelligence has published a brief report following up on findings from the 2020 Threat Index related to public data breaches.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Ransomware Drove Public Data Breaches in 2020
IBM X-force Threat Intelligence has published a brief report following up on findings from the 2020 Threat Index related to public data breaches.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Public breach data reveals several telling trends for 2020. First, ransomware attacks drove data breaches, making up 36% of data breaches as ransomware attackers incorporate data theft and leaks into their arsenal. In addition, manufacturing, government, and media/telecommunications appeared to be hit hardest by data breaches in 2020. Lastly, data breaches in 2020 appeared to peak in March, suggesting that breach trends may be loosely connected to COVID-19 pandemic trends as many organizations made abrupt changes to operations in March 2020. The full story and analysis is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.




# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/f62b5b9d-bddf-4a29-9fd9-864bc8f289b8>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: EKING Ransomware
Although a fairly new ransomware family, Phobos is quickly evolving in numerous ways. Fortinet provides their analysis of the most recent variant, named "EKING" based on the extension appended to encrypted files.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Fortinet has published their analysis of a new Phobos variant seen in the wild. It was delivered via a Microsoft Word document containing malicious macros. If macros are enabled, the malicious code is invoked when the document is closed. At this point, it extracts a base64-encoded block that is saved as an XLS file that, in turn, creates an executable masquerading as a PDF. Finally, it executes the dropped file. The executable acts as a downloader, obtaining a secondary executable from a remote server and subsequently running it. Configuration information for the ransomware is stored in an AES-encrypted block. This information includes the extension string, file exclusion list, ransom note details, and more. In order to gain required privileges, the executable spawns a copy of itself and impersonates the Explorer process. Volume shadow copies are deleted and backup features are disabled, along with the Windows Firewall being disabled. Persistence is established via two Registry Run keys and two autostart folders. When the encryption process begins, multiple threads are created to carry out the required tasks. One thread terminates processes in order to release currently open files. Another scans files across all logical drives to identify what should be encrypted. Lastly, encryption is performed using a custom AES implementation. The ransomware is also capable of monitoring for new logical drives for additional encryption. The ransom note is dropped onto the Desktop and all root folders as both an HTA and TXT file and opened to be displayed to the victim. For more information, see the Fortinet blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/deep-analysis-the-eking-variant-of-phobos-ransomware>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Zero-Day Exploits in SonicWall Email Security Lead to Enterprise Compromise
An investigation into a webshell infection led FireEye researchers to discover three SonicWall Email Security zero-day vulnerabilities being exploited in the wild by an unknown threat actor.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability, Webshell, Exploit 




# Overview

FireEye published a blog post detailing three zero-day vulnerabilities in SonicWall Email Security (ES) that were exploited by an unknown threat actor. The first vulnerability, CVE-2021-20021, allowed the threat actor to create an administrator account on the SonicWall ES appliance via an improperly secured API endpoint. With this access, CVE-2021-20023, a directory traversal vulnerability in the branding feature, was exploited to view two sensitive XML configuration files detailing accounts and credentials, which could later be used for lateral movement. Lastly, the same branding page was vulnerable to arbitrary file uploads (CVE-2021-20022). This was abused by the attacker to upload a ZIP containing the BEHINDER JSP web shell. With this access, the attacker performed additional credential harvesting and lateral movement. At this point, the incident responders prevented further malicious activity, so the objectives of this threat actor remain unknown. FireEye reported these vulnerabilities to SonicWall who have since released patches to address the issues (see patch advisory in Reference section). For more information, see the FireEye blog post in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-20021

  * CVE-2021-20022

  * CVE-2021-20023




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2021/04/zero-day-exploits-in-sonicwall-email-security-lead-to-compromise.html>

  * <https://www.sonicwall.com/support/product-notification/security-notice-sonicwall-email-security-zero-day-vulnerabilities/210416112932360/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Lorenz Ransomware
Lorenz is a ransomware operation that appeared last month. BleepingComputer published their analysis of this operation, which appears to be connected to the ThunderCrypt ransomware.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

BleepingComputer has published a report on a new ransomware operation that began last month. The new ransomware, dubbed Lorenz, appears to be related to the ThunderCrypt ransomware operation; however, it is unknown whether the same actors are behind this new wave of attacks or if a new group purchased the ThunderCrypt source code. Lorenz is human-operated ransomware whereby the threat actors compromise networks and spread laterally, attempting to obtain domain admin credentials. With the intended access, they are able to deploy the ransomware to encrypt the files using AES. Interestingly, encryption is done without terminating processes and services that may prevent certain files from being encrypted. A ransom directs the victims to a Tor payment site. Similar to recent ransomware groups, Lorenz has a data leak site. Instead of solely threatening to publish the data if the ransom is not paid, Lorenz immediately publishes the data in a password-protected archive, which can be purchased by other threat actors. If a ransom is not paid, the password is provided publicly for free. Additionally, access to the victim network is offered for sale. For more information, see the BleepingComputer blog post.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/meet-lorenz-a-new-ransomware-gang-targeting-the-enterprise/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: GuLoader Delivering AZORult
The delivery chain examined by VMRay uses GuLoader to download and install an infostealer called AZORult.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Campaign, Infostealer



# Overview

VMRay examines the delivery chain used by a campaign that utilizes GuLoader to install AZORult on a victim system. GULoader is a downloader that employs advanced anti-analysis techniques that, in the past, has been used to deliver FormBook, NanoCore, LokiBot, and Remcos, as well as other malware. In this campaign, a weaponized RTF document is sent via a spam email. This attachment, if opened, exploits a vulnerability (CVE-2017-11882) in Microsoft Office products. The malware download process consisted of three steps and downloaded two payloads, GuLoader and AZORult. Once GuLoader runs, it uses advanced anti-analysis, sandbox detection, and evasion techniques to ensure a "safe" environment to download and execute its final AZORult payload. AZORult is an information stealer targeting login credentials, cookies, cryptocurrency wallets, and more. Information captured by AZORult is sent back to its command and control servers. For more details, examine the link in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33983058/GuLoader%20Delivering%20AZORult%20CVEs.txt?version=3&modificationDate=1606178217355&api=v2)



# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/33983058/GuLoader%20Delivering%20AZORult%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606149916650&api=v2)



# Protection

## IBM

  * [CVE-2017-11882](https://exchange.xforce.ibmcloud.com/vulnerabilities/134283): [CompoundFile_OLE_Equation_Exec](https://exchange.xforce.ibmcloud.com/signature/CompoundFile_OLE_Equation_Exec)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.vmray.com/cyber-security-blog/azorult-delivered-by-guloader-malware-analysis-spotlight/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: BluStealer Infostealing Malware
A report from Avast provides the results of their analysis of the BluStealer information-stealing malware and notes a spike in activity in early September.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Infostealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** BluStealer
  *  **Targets:** Various
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malspam with an attached .ISO file.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, obtaining, and exfiltrating information.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

BluStealer, also referred to as a310logger, is information-stealing malware that is composed of a core written in Visual Basic a module written in .NET. The core reuses code from another piece of malware named SpyEx, with the BluStealer author adding additional features. The .NET module is known to incorporate code from a number of open-source tools including ChromeRecovery, firepwd, StormKitty, and ThunderFox, with the code being used in different variants. Many variants of BluStealer have been observed. The loaded used is written in .NET has been used by a number of other families of malware including Agent Tesla, Formbook, Oski Stealer, RedLine, and the Snake Keylogger. A spike in BluStealer activity, attributed to a single campaign was observed in early September. The primary distribution method is malspam and a large number of the samples obtained by Avast are sourced to a single campaign. Two sample emails are provided in Avast's report, one is in English and is a DHL-themed email, the other is in Spanish and themed as a Mexican metal company. Both emails request that the recipient fills in the form contained in the email attachment. The attachment is a .ISO file and contains the malware. Various techniques such as obfuscation are used to evade detection. If BluStealer detects it is executing in a VM, it will cease execution. Once installed, the malware will steal information such as certain documents, browser and crypto wallet credentials. The stolen data is staged and then exfiltrated using either SMTP or a Telegram bot. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64128495/BluStealer%20Infostealing%20Malware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632458941081&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/anhho/blustealer/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.001 - Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1497.001 - System Checks  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1552.001 - Credentials In Files  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
T1115 - Clipboard Data  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1029 - Scheduled Transfer  
T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

Various techniques such as obfuscation are used to evade detection. If BluStealer detects it is executing in a VM, it will cease execution. Once installed, the malware will steal information such as certain documents, browser and crypto wallet credentials. The stolen data is staged and then exfiltrated using either SMTP or a Telegram bot. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64128495/BluStealer%20Infostealing%20Malware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632458941081&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/anhho/blustealer/>

T1552.001 - Credentials In Files  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Muhstik Botnet Analysis
Active for at least two years, the Muhstik botnet is targeting certain web applications, in addition to IoT devices, according to a report from Lacework.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Muhstik Botnet Analysis
Active for at least two years, the Muhstik botnet is targeting certain web applications, in addition to IoT devices, according to a report from Lacework.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet, Cryptomining, DDoS




# Overview

The Muhstik botnet, active for at least two years, is reportedly a variant of the Tsunami botnet. Aside from the typical targeting of consumer IoT devices, Muhstik also targets certain web applications. It attempts to exploit vulnerabilities in Drupal (CVE-2018-7600), Oracle's WebLogic Server (CVE-2019-2725) and the WebLogic Server component used in Oracle Fusion Middleware (CVE-2017-10271). The botnet is monetized through cryptomining, typically using the CGminer or XMRmrig miners, or by providing DDoS attack services. A scanning module used to locate other vulnerable hosts is also installed on infected systems. Muhstik uses IRC servers for its command control. Correlations between Muhstik and the Tsunami botnet infrastructure and frequent references to Anime led Lacework to conclude there are a number of operations they can attribute to a single actor, "Wasp 8220". Further information is available from the Lacework report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.lacework.com/meet-muhstik-iot-botnet-infecting-cloud-servers/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Pastebin Used as Command and Control Tunnel for njRAT
Unit 42 indicates that njRAT (aka Bladabindi) is using Pastebin to download and deliver second-stage payloads, possibly to avoid detection by security products.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT



# Overview

Unit 42 covers various incidents where, after the initial infection with a downloader, Pastebin is used to store and deliver a second-stage payload. The secondary payload differs greatly, ranging from traditional base64 encoding, hexadecimal and JSON data, compressed blobs, to plain-text data with embedded malicious URLs. Their first scenario describes a downloader, installed on a victim system, pulling down an encrypted payload, which turned out to be a 32-bit .NET executable that made calls to Windows API calls such as GetKeyboardState(), GetAsynckeyState(), MapVirtualKey(). Such calls are likely indicators of keyloggers and Trojans. Another sample was seen to download encoded and compressed data and then decode and uncompress the data into memory. A call to Load().EntryPoint.Invoke() function was used to begin execution of the malicious downloaded data. One .NET downloader sample used Pastebin to retrieve the URL of the second-stage payload. JSON was used in the next scenario, where the variable for the second-stage was intentionally spelled as "downlodLink," possibly to avoid automated detection. Even HTML code scraping was seen, where the URL for the second-stage payload was embedded in a Pastebin page that turned out to point to Simple+Scraper.zip. This archive contained two files "MaterialSkin.dll" and "Proxy Scraper.exe". For full technical details, please see the Unit 42 link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35717969/Pastebin%20Used%20as%20Command%20and%20Control%20Tunnel%20for%20njRAT%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1607544204112&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/njrat-pastebin-command-and-control/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Similarities Between the ShadowPad and PlugX Backdoors
Using samples from attacks on systems located in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan, analysts from Doctor Web discovered relationships between the ShadowPad and PlugX backdoors.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Similarities Between the ShadowPad and PlugX Backdoors
Using samples from attacks on systems located in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan, analysts from Doctor Web discovered relationships between the ShadowPad and PlugX backdoors.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

According to a report from Doctor Web, the ShadowPad backdoor may be an evolution of the PlugX backdoor. The Winnti APT group are known to use modified versions of ShadowPad. Indicators from the malware involved in attacks on systems in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan suggest that Chinese APT groups may have been involved in the attacks. Based on similarities found in the code of the ShadowPad and PlugX backdoors, Doctor Web analysts conclude that both backdoors may have been created by the same developers and is a more advanced backdoor than PlugX. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * [https://news.drweb.com/show/?i=14048&lng=en&c=23](https://news.drweb.com/show/?i=14048&lng=en&c=23)

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: WooCommerce Skimmer Spoofs Checkout Page
A compromise of a client website led Sucuri to uncover a WooCommerce skimmer spoofing a checkout page to steal credit card details.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Skimmer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Malicious JavaScript code
  *  **Targets:** E-commerce customers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Compromised admin credentials
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft



# Overview

Sucuri published a blog post analyzing a WooCommerce skimmer spoofing a checkout page for the purpose of credit card detail theft. Interestingly, the victim site was not an e-commerce platform; however, due to the skimmer looking for a "my-account" keyword which was present on the site, it successfully loaded. When the keyword condition is met, JavaScript code inserted into the themes header.php file is executed and loads malicious JavaScript from a remote server. The domain hosting this malicious code masquerades as a jquery resource to evade detection. The JavaScript is responsible for rendering a fake checkout form that exfiltrates entered credit card details to the remote server. The incident investigation determined the likely infection vector was brute-forcing of a WordPress admin account. Additionally, a malicious user was found logged into the WordPress database at the time of investigation. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222180/WooCommerce%20Skimmer%20Spoofs%20Checkout%20Page%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636473577897&api=v2)

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use multi-factor authentication wherever possible. (M1032)
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021)

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New RaaS Offering - LokiLocker
A report from BlackBerry's Research & Intelligence team provides an analysis of a Ransomware-as-a-Service (Raas) offering that first appeared in the wild in mid-August 2021.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Windows systems.
  *  **Ransomware Family:** LokiLocker
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Yes
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Trojanized brute-forcing tools.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** File encryption, disk wiping if ransom not paid.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

LokiLocker is a Ransomware-as-a-Service (Raas) offering that first appeared in the wild in mid-August 2021. According to a report from BlackBerry's Research & Intelligence team who named it LokiLocker, it targets Windows systems and has some similarities to the LockBit ransomware. The origin of LokiLocker isn't clear but there are some indicators that suggest it could be of Iranian origin, it's also possible that the developers may simply be trying to distract from its actual originating location. Early versions of LokiLocker were distributed inside Trojanized hacking tools used for brute-forcing credentials. Files are encrypted using AES and LokiLocker also provides wiper functionality that deletes files and overwrites the MBR. The wiper is used if the victim doesn't pay the demanded ransom by the due date. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://blogs.blackberry.com/en/2022/03/lokilocker-ransomware>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1485 - Data Destruction  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
New RaaS Offering - LokiLocker
A report from BlackBerry's Research & Intelligence team provides an analysis of a Ransomware-as-a-Service (Raas) offering that first appeared in the wild in mid-August 2021.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Windows systems.
  *  **Ransomware Family:** LokiLocker
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Yes
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Trojanized brute-forcing tools.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** File encryption, disk wiping if ransom not paid.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

LokiLocker is a Ransomware-as-a-Service (Raas) offering that first appeared in the wild in mid-August 2021. According to a report from BlackBerry's Research & Intelligence team who named it LokiLocker, it targets Windows systems and has some similarities to the LockBit ransomware. The origin of LokiLocker isn't clear but there are some indicators that suggest it could be of Iranian origin, it's also possible that the developers may simply be trying to distract from its actual originating location. Early versions of LokiLocker were distributed inside Trojanized hacking tools used for brute-forcing credentials. Files are encrypted using AES and LokiLocker also provides wiper functionality that deletes files and overwrites the MBR. The wiper is used if the victim doesn't pay the demanded ransom by the due date. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

  * <https://blogs.blackberry.com/en/2022/03/lokilocker-ransomware>

T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.005 - Link Target

T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1485 - Data Destruction  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

I have encountered the following information: Agent Tesla Steals WiFi Profiles
A blog posting from the BlackBerry Research and Intelligence Team provides a Yara rule for a variant of the Agent Tesla info stealing malware that steals an infected system's WiFi profile.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Agent Tesla is information-stealing malware that also provides RAT functionality, it was discovered in 2014. A recent version of Agent Tesla observed by the BlackBerry Research and Intelligence Team provides additional functionality. It provides its operators with an infected system's WiFi profile. The BlackBerry team speculates that this may be to provide a propagation mechanism. Agent Tesla has been used by a number of attackers in various campaigns. It is typically delivered to victims via spam emails. The BlackBerry report is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.blackberry.com/en/2021/06/threat-spotlight-agent-tesla-infostealer>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Cring Ransomware Used in Fortigate VPN Attacks
A series of attacks using Cring ransomware is the subject of a report from Kaspersky ICS CERT. The attacks are a result of a vulnerability in Fortigate VPN servers.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Threat actors have conducted attacks on Fortinet VPN servers using known vulnerabilities in the VPN software. The attacker exploited CVE-2018-13379 to gain access to the targeted network. Once on the VPN Gateway, the actors were able to extract the session file that contains information such as username and plaintext passwords. The vulnerability also offers the opportunity for a directory transversal attack that allows access to system files on the SSL VPN appliance. In the days preceding the attack, actors performed several test connections to test for the vulnerability. It is also thought the attackers could have used IP address scanning to identify a vulnerable device, a list of which could have been purchased on the dark web. Once on the network, the attackers downloaded Mimikatz in order to compromise the domain admin account and began distributing malware across the network using Cobalt Strike. The Cobalt Strike module was loaded using a PowerShell script. A beacon was deployed to provide remote control of the system. Within the beacon coding was the IP address of the C2 server. A cmd script was downloaded to the machine to mask the malware activity and avoid security measures. Further, another file with a .txt extension was downloaded from a URL. The .txt file was, in fact, the executable for the Cring ransomware. The malware stopped services and terminated application processes to encrypt files without much trouble. Backup files were removed and the process of encrypting files began using an AES encryption with the AES encryption key further encrypted using an 8,192 bit RSA key. A ransom note is dropped on the victim machine with instructions on removing the encryption. Further technical details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://ics-cert.kaspersky.com/reports/2021/04/07/vulnerability-in-fortigate-vpn-servers-is-exploited-in-cring-ransomware-attacks/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Darkside Ransomware Decryption Tool
DarkSide is a human-operated ransomware operating since August 2020. Bitdefender has released a free decryptor allowing victims to recover their files without paying the ransom.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Bitdefender has released a free decryptor for the DarkSide ransomware. This ransomware began targeting enterprises in August 2020 with increased activity from October to December. It operates as a Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) with ransom demands ranging from hundreds of thousands of dollars to millions, depending on the size of the organizations. The decryptor released by Bitdefender will recover your files (without removing the encrypted version in case decryption fails). However, like many current ransomware models, the DarkSide ransomware also attempts to steal sensitive data and threatens to publish this data if the ransom isn't paid. This means that even with free file recovery, there is still a risk of a data leak. See the Bitdefender blog post in the reference section for instructions on using their decryption tool.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.




# Reference

  * <https://labs.bitdefender.com/2021/01/darkside-ransomware-decryption-tool/>

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/darkside-ransomware-decryptor-recovers-victims-files-for-free/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Magecart Group 8 Infrastructure
A brief blog post from Malwarebytes provides an overview and indicators of compromise associated with Magecart Group 8 infrastructure.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Skimmer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Magecart Group 8
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Magecart Skimming Code
  *  **Targets:** Retail customers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post analyzing infrastructure tied to Magecart Group 8. This group is believed to be one of the oldest digital skimming groups. Much of the discovery came when researching the new "checkcheck" skimmer, which leverages a string swapping function used by other Magecart Group 8 skimmers. The researchers uncovered two large pieces of infrastructure that they've tied to the group. The first set of infrastructure is hosted on IP addresses owned by Flowspec, a bulletproof hosting providers. Many of these domains were also tied to OVH IP addresses. The second part of the infrastructure is owned by Crex Fex Pex, another bulletproof hosting provider. While investigating this infrastructure, they also found use of ICME as a hosting provider. Many skimming artifacts were found across the infrastructure, including webshells, panels, and other tools. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64128015/Magecart%20Group%208%20Infrastructure%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1631901283933&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2021/09/the-many-tentacles-of-magecart-group-8/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Cryptomining Campaign Targeting Docker Linux Systems
A cryptomining campaign targeting Docker Linux systems was detected, analyzed, and reported on by SentinelOne.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Cryptomining Campaign Targeting Docker Linux Systems
A cryptomining campaign targeting Docker Linux systems was detected, analyzed, and reported on by SentinelOne.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

SentinelOne has published a blog post detailing a cryptomining campaign they observed. The campaign specifically targeted a Docker container running Linux, although the initial access method to that container is not specified. Once on the system, the threat actor executed a shell script that, in turn, downloaded and executed a second-stage script. Performing similar actions, the second-stage attempts to download and execute the final shell script in the sequence. The final shell script is responsible for downloading and executing the final payload. Steganography is used to embed the ELF binary into a JPG image, reducing its detection rate. By extracting and analyzing the payload, the researchers identified the final executable as XMRig, providing the threat actor with a profit via Monero mining. For more information, see the SentintelOne blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/caught-in-the-cloud-how-a-monero-cryptominer-exploits-docker-containers/>
