Tell me about the following threat: CinaRAT Delivered Using HTML File Attached to Phishing Emails
An entry in the SANS Incident Handler's Diary reports the use of an HTML file attached to a phishing email to infect victims with CinaRAT.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: CinaRAT Delivered Using HTML File Attached to Phishing Emails
An entry in the SANS Incident Handler's Diary reports the use of an HTML file attached to a phishing email to infect victims with CinaRAT.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** CinaRAT / QuasarRAT (S0262).
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious HTML file attached to an email.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unspecified
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

An entry in the SANS Incident Handler's Diary reports that an HTML file attached to emails contains an obfuscated payload hidden in the ID attributes of paragraph elements. JavaScript executes when the page is loaded in a browser and it assembles the various elements into an ISO file which is then dropped onto the system. The ISO contains a copy of a Microsoft VBS file that has been modified to act as a downloader that downloads and installs a malicious DLL that has been hosted on the Discord CDN. The DLL has been obfuscated using an unregistered version of a tool named Reactor. The script also copies itself to the Startup folder to achieve persistence. The DLL is believed to be CinaRAT malware which is also known as QuasarRAT. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058688/CinaRAT%20Delivered%20Using%20HTML%20File%20Attached%20to%20Phishing%20Emails%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644893964134&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://isc.sans.edu/forums/diary/CinaRAT+Delivered+Through+HTML+ID+Attributes/28330/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

Tell me everything you know the following threat: VMware ESXi OpenSLP Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
Initially patched on October 20th, VMware has updated the patch for ESXI due to active exploits against CVE-2020-3992 and CVE-2019-5544, Rapid7 announces.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

Rapid7 expands on the ESXI vulnerabilities CVE-2020-3992 and CVE-2019-5544 that Microsoft indicated evidence of active exploitation existed. These two remote code execution vulnerabilities existed in VMware's service location protocol (SLP) service. The initial October patch did not adequately correct the issue and an update was issued on November 4th. VMware has issued a document describing how to disable the CIM server, as well as a workaround document. For more details, please refer to the links in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33982279/VMware%20ESXi%20OpenSLP%20Remote%20Code%20Execution%20Vulnerability%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1605123816723&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2020-0023.html>
  * <https://blog.rapid7.com/2020/11/11/vmware-esxi-openslp-remote-code-execution-vulnerability-cve-2020-3992-and-cve-2019-5544-what-you-need-to-know/>
  * <https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/76372>
  * <https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/76411>

Tell me about the following threat: Internet of Threats: IoT Botnets Drive Surge in Attacks
X-Force Threat Intelligence researchers have published a report on Internet of Things (IoT) attack activity observed over the course of 2020, specifically focusing on IoT botnets.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Internet of Threats: IoT Botnets Drive Surge in Attacks
X-Force Threat Intelligence researchers have published a report on Internet of Things (IoT) attack activity observed over the course of 2020, specifically focusing on IoT botnets.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Vulnerability, Botnet




# Overview

X-Force Threat Intelligence released their analysis of 2020 IoT attack activity, which heavily revolved around IoT botnets. The report details significant trends observed, including the botnet families leveraged, devices exploited, and industries targeted. An overview of the most active botnet malware families is provided. This includes the Mozi botnet, Gafgyt, Echobot, Loli, and ZeroShell. Alongside the report, the researchers provide detailed recommendations on how users can protect their networks and devices from falling victim to such an attack. The full story, analysis, and mitigation advice is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below. 

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/42a63f60-5e7f-492e-bd1d-6661418e860c>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: German Users Targeted with Gootkit Banker or REvil Ransomware
A Gootkit campaign in Germany led Malwarebytes researchers to discover a complex malware loader being used to deliver both Gootkit and REvil.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post analyzing a malware loader targeting German users with Gootkit and REvil payloads. The loader script was hosted on compromised sites such that if visitors matched certain criteria, a download link would be injected into the page in the form of a fake forum post. Clicking this link would download a ZIP containing a malicious script. This malicious script is responsible for connecting to a C2 from which it downloads a second-stage JavaScript. The second-stage then executes an embedded payload. At this point, one of two techniques is implemented. With the first method, a hexadecimal-encoded PE is stored in the Registry and executed to eventually load the REvil ransomware. Alternatively, a base64-encoded payload stored in the Registry executes a series of PowerShell scripts that eventually lead to the installation of the Gootkit banking Trojan. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-analysis/2020/11/german-users-targeted-with-gootkit-banker-or-revil-ransomware/>

Tell me about the following threat: TunnelVision Exploiting VMware Horizon
TunnelVision is an Iranian-aligned threat actor operating in the Middle East and United States. SentinelOne has published a blog post analyzing the group's exploitation of VMware Horizon in recent campaigns.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: TunnelVision Exploiting VMware Horizon
TunnelVision is an Iranian-aligned threat actor operating in the Middle East and United States. SentinelOne has published a blog post analyzing the group's exploitation of VMware Horizon in recent campaigns.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Reverse shell
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** TunnelVision
  *  **Associated Payloads:** PowerShell reverse shell
  *  **Targets:** Middle East, United States
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of VMware Horizon servers
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Remote command execution, credential harvesting, lateral movement



# Overview

SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing TunnelVision and their recent activity. TunnelVision, an Iranian-aligned threat actor operating in the Middle East and United States, is known for their use of 1-day vulnerability exploits and tunneling tools. In recent cases, they have used the Log4Shell exploit to target VMware Horizon servers. The exploit is used to execute PowerShell commands that will download files and return command outputs via a webhook. The group additionally uses PowerShell reverse shells to perform further post-compromise actions. Two different reverse shells were identified that ultimately provided backdoor access, allowing TunnelVision to execute recon commands, add a backdoor user, harvest credentials, tunnel RDP traffic, and deploy further reverse shells. The researchers noted an overlap between this group and those called Phosphorus by Microsoft and Charming Kitten or Nemesis Kitten by CrowdStrike. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74059306/TunnelVision%20Exploiting%20VMware%20Horizon%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645640136017&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Update VMware Horizon to patch the Log4j vulnerability.
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/log4j2-in-the-wild-iranian-aligned-threat-actor-tunnelvision-actively-exploiting-vmware-horizon/>

  *  **Malware Type:** Reverse shell
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** TunnelVision
  *  **Associated Payloads:** PowerShell reverse shell
  *  **Targets:** Middle East, United States
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of VMware Horizon servers
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Remote command execution, credential harvesting, lateral movement



# Overview

SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing TunnelVision and their recent activity. TunnelVision, an Iranian-aligned threat actor operating in the Middle East and United States, is known for their use of 1-day vulnerability exploits and tunneling tools. In recent cases, they have used the Log4Shell exploit to target VMware Horizon servers. The exploit is used to execute PowerShell commands that will download files and return command outputs via a webhook. The group additionally uses PowerShell reverse shells to perform further post-compromise actions. Two different reverse shells were identified that ultimately provided backdoor access, allowing TunnelVision to execute recon commands, add a backdoor user, harvest credentials, tunnel RDP traffic, and deploy further reverse shells. The researchers noted an overlap between this group and those called Phosphorus by Microsoft and Charming Kitten or Nemesis Kitten by CrowdStrike. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74059306/TunnelVision%20Exploiting%20VMware%20Horizon%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645640136017&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Update VMware Horizon to patch the Log4j vulnerability.
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/log4j2-in-the-wild-iranian-aligned-threat-actor-tunnelvision-actively-exploiting-vmware-horizon/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.004 - Exploits  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1136 - Create Account  
T1543 - Create or Modify System Process  
T1543.003 - Windows Service  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1003.001 - LSASS Memory  
T1003.002 - Security Account Manager  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.001 - Remote Desktop Protocol  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1572 - Protocol Tunneling

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Pandemic Malicious Activities Summary
GDataSoftware has published a report about the state of criminal activities that have and continue to occur during the COVID-19 global pandemic.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Cybercriminals have continually used the COVID-19 pandemic as a stepping stone for targeting both industry and work-from-home (WFH) users alike. From phishing emails to malware to ransomware, the attack vectors have remained the same with updates mostly pertaining to some sort of COVID-themed lure. Listed below are a few of the most observed threats.

## Phishing Emails and Payloads

Phishing in the time of the pandemic has evolved to include COVID themes. From targeted geographic areas to fake websites set up for credential gathering, actors take great care in the crafting of these campaigns. The threat actors use language-specific emails to lure users within a given geographic area into clicking on links, downloading infected documents, or providing sensitive information through simple replies. Most of the phishing emails reportedly use COVID within the subject line along with some other form of pertinent information such as protection information, attachments with victim lists, executable files, etc. In their research, GData has analyzed one particular email infected with malware. The malware within the attachment was GuLoader, the malware that downloads its payload from cloud storage services. This particular example downloaded the Parallax RAT, a backdoor used for administrative privileges on a target. The RAT can be used across the spectrum of Windows OS versions. Capabilities of this RAT include keylogging, credential theft, and remote command execution. In addition to Parallax, several other malware families were discovered in the research to include: Remcos, Nanocore, Netwire, Agent Tesla, and other trojans. 

## Wipers and Master Boot Record Modification

Wipers, malicious programs that destroy data on machines have been around since at least 2008. Unlike ransomware, there is no demand for payment in exchange for data recovery, the sole purpose of this malware is to destroy data beyond recovery. This malware is connected to COVID through its name, "coronavirus.exe." By disabling features such as task manager, and User Access Controls, once executed, the machine is at the mercy of the attacker's malware. Before the victim can even respond, the MBR is being overwritten. Other variants of these types of malwares were also observed with slightly different functionality and features. 

## Jokerware

A variant also discovered was a joke malware that tricks a user into thinking their MBR is being overwritten when, in fact, it's not. These types of malware may be harmless but they still cause panic among WFH users and could cause "damage control mode" to kick in. 

## Conclusion

The research conducted by the GData team shows a variety of methods threat actors will employ in an effort to invade unsuspecting user's computers and company networks. As long as the pandemic rages on, these actors will continue to employ any methods necessary to achieve their goal of financial gain, disruption, or even jokes. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.gdatasoftware.com/blog/global-pandemic-remcos-tesla-netwire>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Demise of Cerberus
ThreatFabric acknowledges the passing of Cerberus, an Android-based banking Trojan and one of the more successful services up until August of 2020.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Demise of Cerberus
ThreatFabric acknowledges the passing of Cerberus, an Android-based banking Trojan and one of the more successful services up until August of 2020.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan, MaaS



# Overview

ThreatFabric noted the demise of one of the more successful Android banking Trojan services, Cerberus, as taking place some time in August of 2020. Issues within the malware, both architectural and technical, went unsolved by the threat-actors long enough that Google Play Protect was able to find and remove all of the samples on the store and on infected devices. Unable to resolve the issues, ThreatFabric indicated that the threat-actor attempted to sell off the service and the customer list. By August, the threat-actor had released the source code and refunded active licenses owners their money. With the source code available, those that tried to use the code needed to learn how the back end and builder worked. Also, a number of test samples began showing up on Google Play, but were immediately taken down by Protect - the code base was similar enough to Cerberus it was recognized as malware. Further research lead ThreatFabric to a malware package called Alien that appeared to be a variant of a January version of Cerberus. Alien contains a number of capabilities, such as overlay attacks, control and steal SMS, harvest the contact list, keylogging, install / start / remove applications, notification sniffer, and a RAT. For technical details, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/30770712/Demise%20of%20Cerberus%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1601326284197&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.threatfabric.com/blogs/alien_the_story_of_cerberus_demise.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Apache Struts 2 RCE Vulnerability
The Apache Software Foundation has published an advisory that addresses a vulnerability in Struts 2, which, in some cases, could allow for the remote execution of arbitrary code.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

An advisory from the Apache Software Foundation addresses a vulnerability in Struts 2 that could allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code. The vulnerability is caused by a failure to properly sanitize user-provided input in certain tags. The vulnerability can be exploited if forced Object-Graph Navigation Language (OGNL) evaluation using the %{...} syntax has been applied. A remote attacker could exploit the vulnerability by sending a maliciously crafted request to the application, potentially leading to arbitrary code execution. Versions of Strut 2 2.0.0 through 2.5.25 are affected. A workaround, and an update (version 2.5.26), have been published to address the vulnerability. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-17530




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/WW/S2-061#space-menu-link-content>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: PowerPoint Files and Cloud Services Used to Deploy Malware
A report from Netskope Threat Labs looks at the increasing use of PowerPoint files and Cloud services to deploy malware.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** AgentTesla, AveMaria, and a PowerShell cryptocurrency stealer.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malspam with malicious PowerPoint files attached.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Stealing of information and cryptocurrency.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A report from Netskope Threat Labs notes that since December 2021, Netskope has observed an increase in the use of PowerPoint files to deploy malware. The report itself is focused on an analysis of the infection chain used in one such campaign that also used public cloud services to host payloads. The malicious PowerPoint file is delivered as an email attachment that contains obfuscated VBA code that uses an Outlook COM Object to execute a PowerShell file to download an HTML file that contains obfuscated VBS script. The VBS script carries out a number of functions including creating a scheduled task and registry entries used to persistently execute a number of remote PowerShell scripts that deliver payloads and disable some operating system defenses. The payloads are known to include AgentTesla, AveMaria, and a PowerShell cryptocurrency stealer. Further information can be found in the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057834/PowerPoint%20Files%20and%20Cloud%20Services%20Used%20to%20Deploy%20Malware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1643605115281&api=v2)



# Detection

  * A list of Yara rules can be found here: [ Yara Rules.txt](/download/attachments/74057834/PowerPoint%20Files%20and%20Cloud%20Services%20Used%20to%20Deploy%20Malware%20Yara%20Rules.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1643605128285&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.netskope.com/blog/infected-powerpoint-files-using-cloud-services-to-deliver-multiple-malware>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1584.001 - Domains  
T1584.004 - Server

T1588.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
T1608.004 - Drive-by Target  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: TeamTNT Malware - Hildegard
A wave of activity targeting misconfigured Kubelets was observed by Palo Alto's Unit 42 in January. The activity was attributed to TeamTNT and involved new malware that Unit 42 refer to as Hildegard.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: TeamTNT Malware - Hildegard
A wave of activity targeting misconfigured Kubelets was observed by Palo Alto's Unit 42 in January. The activity was attributed to TeamTNT and involved new malware that Unit 42 refer to as Hildegard.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

TeamTNT are historically known for targeting unsecured Docker daemons and installing malicious container images. In January, Palo Alto's Unit 42 observed activity that targeted misconfigured Kubelets, which they attributed to TeamTNT. Some of the domains and tools used in the new attacks were the same as TeamTNT has used in the past. Aside from being the first time TeamTNT have been observed targeting Kubernetes, new malware was also observed. The new malware is referred to by Unit 42 as Hildegard. The malware uses a library injection technique and encrypts the actual payload inside a binary file, uses a known process name for the payload to help avoid detection, and provides two methods for C&C communications. Once a foothold has been obtained, the attackers then searched for other containers that were operating inside the Kubernetes nodes and attempted to exploit them. A crypto mining script (xmrig) was installed in successfully compromised containers. Unit 42 note in their report that the codebase and infrastructure are incomplete and activity ceased not long after discovery which suggests that the malware and campaign are still in the development phase. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/hildegard-malware-teamtnt/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Version of DanaBot
DanaBot briefly declined in activity after June 2020, but in October 2020 Proofpoint researchers observed its return with a new version.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Stealer




# Overview

Proofpoint has published a blog post analyzing a new version of DanaBot that appeared in October 2020, which they believe is version 4 of the malware. The sample they obtained was being distributed via crack websites that offer premium software that has supposedly been cracked to allow free access. Downloading a program from this site provides a ZIP file containing a password-protected archive, which, in turn, contains the dropper payload. This dropper is an executable that drops a stealer component that provides victim system information to the attacker. A second-stage payload is then downloaded that installs an AutoIT cryptominer and the DanaBot payload to the system. The DanaBot payload includes hardcoded configuration information, including the affiliate ID (two of which were discovered by Proofpoint), a version number, embedded hash values, C2 IPs and ports, and a Tor C2 domain. The malware can run in several alternative modes including a TOR mode, process injection mode, and a module mode. Proofpoint's analysis focuses on running mode 0, which is the main component. Available commands from the C2 response include those to get an updated list of C2 addresses, enable a stealer, change to Tor-based C2 communications, exfiltrate arbitrary information from the victim system, obtain a command shell, download and execute additional modules, and more. For more information, see the Proofpoint blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/new-year-new-version-danabot>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: GOLDBACKDOOR Discovered in Spear-Phishing Campaign
Stairwell, a cybersecurity company, has released details of malware they discovered from a spear-phishing campaign. The NK News has shared multiple malicious artifacts with them from the campaign that targeted journalists who specialize in reporting focused on the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (North Korea). They have named one of the artifacts, which is a new malware sample, as GOLDBACKDOOR.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Journalists who specialize in the DPRK
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** BLUELIGHT, GOLDBACKDOOR
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Remote Command Execution, File Downloading, File Uploading, Keylogging
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

NK News, an organization that focuses on news regarding North Korea, was targeted in a spear-phishing campaign believed to originate from APT37 which is known for targeting journalists. The attackers had gained prior access to an email account of a former director at South Korea's National Intelligence Service (NIS) and had utilized content from past conversations with NK News founder Chad O'Carroll. The attack deployed a backdoor. Artifacts of the malware were provided to the cybersecurity company Stairwell by NK News. Embedded in the backdoor are a set of API keys used with the Microsoft Azure cloud computing service. Stairwell has named the backdoor GOLDBACKDOOR. The key focus of the backdoor is on exfiltrating data with file collection and keylogging. For more detailed information, please see the report in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://stairwell.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/Stairwell-threat-report-The-ink-stained-trail-of-GOLDBACKDOOR.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

#### Tactics and Techniques:

  
 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1591 - Gather Victim Org Information  
T1591.002 - Business Relationships  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1585 - Establish Accounts  
T1585.002 - Email Accounts  
T1586 - Compromise Accounts  
T1586.002 - Email Accounts  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
T1078.004 - Cloud Accounts  
T1199 - Trusted Relationship  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account  
T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1102.002 - Bidirectional Communication  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Cisco Security Advisory - March 17 2021
Cisco has published a Security Advisory which is rated as High.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Cisco Security Advisory - March 17 2021
Cisco has published a Security Advisory which is rated as High.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 In the advisory summarized below, it is noted that Cisco's Product Security Incident Response Team (PSIRT) is "not aware of any public announcements or malicious use of the vulnerabilities" that are described in the advisory.

 **Cisco Small Business RV132W and RV134W Routers Management Interface Remote Command Execution and Denial of Service Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-rv-132w134w-overflow-Pptt4H2p High  
A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of CiscoRV132W ADSL2+ Wireless-N VPN Routers and CiscoRV134W VDSL2 Wireless-AC VPN Routers could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on an affected device or cause the device to restart unexpectedly.  
CVE-2021-1287  
Base 7.2 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H/E:X/RL:X/RC:X  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-rv-132w134w-overflow-Pptt4H2p>

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-1287




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * [https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/Search.x?publicationTypeIDs=1&firstPublishedStartDate=2021%2F03%2F17&firstPublishedEndDate=2021%2F03%2F17](https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/Search.x?publicationTypeIDs=1&firstPublishedStartDate=2021%2F03%2F17&firstPublishedEndDate=2021%2F03%2F17)

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Malicious Docker Image Used To Install Cryptominers
TeamTNT is known for attacking cloud deployments. Researchers at Uptycs have identified a campaign from TeamTNT whereby a malicious Docker image being publicly hosted and used in an attack that propagates itself and installs malicious software onto the victim's machine.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Cryptojacking
  *  **Associated Threat Actors** : TeamTNT
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Xmrig Miner, Tsunami IRC Bot, Diamorphine Rootkit
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Bash Script
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Lateral Movement, Cryptomining



# Overview

Researchers at Uptycs Threat Research have recently identified a campaign where the threat actor TeamTNT is using a malicious docker container image to infect their victims. This image is hosted in Docker Hub under the user 'alpineos', who joined the site in the May of 2021. They currently host 25 images, with the one being analyzed here having over 5000 downloads, but another image from the repository having over 100,000 downloads. This indicates that the malicious image is being actively used in attacks. The attack starts using a malicious bash script that claims to install a crypto-miner. This script includes a command to download and run the malicious docker image on the user's system. Within this image, there is a script called 'pause' which installs several utilities including masscan and zgrab, which are then used to scan for other docker nodes on the victim's subnet. If found, the script will install the image onto that node, and download the initial script to that node to begin the process again. Once this stage is complete, the script will then deploy a cryptominer and a backdoor which will then contact the C2 server. The bash script also includes a command to download a rootkit shell script. There is currently no information on who the victims are for this campaign or where they may be based, but the high download count of the malicious container image shows that many machines have been infected and could be spreading the malware. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130055/Malicious%20Docker%20Image%20Used%20To%20Install%20Cryptominers%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634032623118&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Use read-only containers and minimal images when possible to prevent the execution of commands (M1038).
  * Ensure containers are not running as root by default (M1026).
  * Limit communications with the container service to local Unix sockets or remote access via SSH. Require secure port access to communicate with the APIs over TLS by disabling unauthenticated access to the Docker API and Kubernetes API Server (M1035).



# References

  * <https://www.uptycs.com/blog/team-tnt-deploys-malicious-docker-image-on-docker-hub-with-pentesting-tools>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
T1609 - Container Administration Command  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1036.005 - Match Legitimate Name or Location  
T1070.003 - Clear Command History  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1552.001 - Credentials In Files  
T1552.004 - Private Keys  
T1552.005 - Cloud Instance Metadata API  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
T1219 - Remote Access Software  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Malicious One-Liner Using Hastebin
Sucuri reports on a malicious one-liner that leveraged Hastebin to obtain the ability for command execution on victim servers.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Sucuri has published their analysis of a malicious one-liner written in PHP. With access to a victim server, attackers can execute this one-liner to enable further malicious capabilities. In this case, the script obtains the next stage from Hastebin, an infrequently used paste site, and writes it to a PHP file in the images directory. The downloaded code allows the attacker to issue $_GET requests that will be executed by the file, allowing for arbitrary command execution. The researchers note that the particular one-liner observed would have failed to properly execute due to missing single quotes, but the analysis still provides insight into its intended purpose and can easily be fixed. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/09/malicious-one-liner-using-hastebin.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Evilnum Group Releases PyVil RAT
According to a new report from Cybereason, the Evilnum group has released a new malware dubbed PyVil RAT.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

A new RAT has been observed by Cybereason's Nocturnus team. The RAT, PyVil RAT is being distributed by the cyber group, Evilnum. The group has been active for at least the past two years using a variety of tools. The group has historically targeted the Financial Technology industry and uses the Know Your Customer procedure to begin infection. Included in the new malware are deviations from the infection chain, persistence, infrastructure, and tools observed including modified, legitimate executables, a multi-process delivery of the payload, and the PyVil RAT. The new infection chain begins with spearphishing emails with attached ZIP archives containing LNK files, which drop a JavaScript Trojan. The attached files masquerade as utility bills, credit card photos, and driver license photos. Upon execution, a JavaScript file is written and executed which, in turn, replaces the LNK file with a PDF. This JavaScript is merely a dropper and has no C2 communication capabilities. This is but the first step in the new infection chain that culminates with the delivery of the PyVil RAT. After the PDF is placed, the JS file is copied which leads to the execution of ddpp.exe embedded in the LNK file. A registry key is entered for persistence and a scheduled task is created. The scheduled task is responsible for retrieving payloads. The executable ddpp.exe is a Java Web Start Launcher that has been trojanized to execute malicious code. The functionality of ddpp.exe is that of a downloader for next stage infection. From this point, shellcode is unpacked and connects to a C2 using a GET request. The malware downloads another encrypted executable, saved as fplayer.exe, which is then executed with a new scheduled task. This downloaded executable acts as an additional downloader. The payload is loaded into memory and is a fileless RAT. Again, at this point, the file is executed with a scheduled task named "Adobe Update Task." Several arguments are executed with this EXE file. This particular file appears to be a trojanized version of "Stereoscopic 3D driver Installer." When this file is executed, further shellcode is unpacked and connects to the C2 via a GET request. A final payload is received, which is the PyVil RAT. This RAT is heavily obfuscated to prevent decompiling the payload. The RAT has several functions such as: keylogger, running cmd commands, taking screenshots, obtaining more Python scripts, dropping and unloading executables among others. C2 communications are accomplished by POST HTTP requests and are RC4 encrypted with hardcoded keys. The C2 domain changes frequently but appears to resolve to the same three IP addresses. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.cybereason.com/blog/no-rest-for-the-wicked-evilnum-unleashes-pyvil-rat>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: An Analysis of RedLine Stealer
RedLine Stealer is a widely-used piece of malware, the results of which are a large part of the information being sold on the dark web. Researchers at Recorded Future have published an in-depth analysis of the malware and its history.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** RedLine Stealer
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

RedLine Stealer is an infostealer malware that is currently the largest contributor of stolen information being sold on Russian-speaking sites on the dark web. Researchers from Insikt Group at Recorded Future have analyzed the malware and published a comprehensive report on the malware's capabilities. The infostealer has been distributed since early 2020 by a group known as "REDGlade" or "Glade". According to these actors, there are two subscription licenses available - a lifetime license for 800 dollars, or monthly service for 150 dollars. This malware is normally distributed via phishing emails, as well as over social media. It has also been found masquerading as legitimate programs, including as an installer for Telegram. Once installed, the malware can perform a wide array of functions. At its core, it can steal usernames, passwords, cookies, saved credentials, and credit card information from browsers. It can also gather files from cryptocurrency cold wallets and other locations. Beyond that, RedLine Stealer is capable of performing basic download and execute functions, meaning it can be used as a loader in a multi-stage attack. RedLine is being continually developed by a competent C# developer, and so new versions of this malware are being released regularly. The volume of advertisements for log information stolen by this malware has increased over the past year, which corresponds to the increase in interest across many dark web sources. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130400/An%20Analysis%20of%20RedLine%20Stealer%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634311309492&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Application control may be able to prevent the running of executables masquerading as other files (M1038).



# References

  * <https://go.recordedfuture.com/hubfs/reports/mtp-2021-1014.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1120 - Peripheral Device Discovery  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1614 - System Location Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Kimsuky Using Blog Sites to Deliver Malware
Cisco Talos have published details on a new campaign from Kimsuky, targeting South Korean businesses in an attempt to steal data.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Kimsuky Using Blog Sites to Deliver Malware
Cisco Talos have published details on a new campaign from Kimsuky, targeting South Korean businesses in an attempt to steal data.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Targets:** Aerospace, Think Tanks, Research agencies
  *  **Associated Threat Actor:** Kimsuky
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Drive-by Compromise
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Cisco Talos recently discovered a campaign operated by the North Korean Kimsuky APT group delivering malware to high-value South Korean targets — namely geopolitical and aerospace research agencies. The attackers used Blogspot in this campaign to host their malicious artifacts. These blogs delivered three previously unseen components - an initial beacon script, an exfiltrator, and an implant instrumentor. This instrumentor delivers three further modules, used for internal reconnaissance and keylogging. Although these modules are all previously unknown, they share a large portion of their code with the Gold Dragon/Brave Prince family of implants. This has allowed the researchers to attribute this activity to Kimsuky with high confidence. In this campaign, there is a strong focus on finding documents associated with North Korea. The research also showed that the attackers were targeting aerospace companies with work relating to South Korea. The attackers were focusing on restricted research papers and project design documents to steal. Further details are available from the links in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222464/Kimsuky%20Using%20Blog%20Sites%20to%20Deliver%20Malware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636734869021&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2021/11/kimsuky-abuses-blogs-delivers-malware.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File

T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery

T1005 - Data from Local System

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Mac Cryptominer Uses I2P To Mask Communications
Trend Micro has published a report on a new Coinminer sample. This sample targets Macs and uses the invisible internet protocol to hide communications with the C2 server.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Cryptominer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unknown
  *  **Targets:** Mac Devices
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Trojanized Adobe Photoshop Installer
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining



# Overview

Trend Micro has analyzed a new sample of malware which is a cyrptominer targeting Mac devices. The initial delivery mechanism of this malware is unclear, however, artifacts in the malware indicate that the threat actor may use a malicious Adobe Photoshop installer to trick users into installing it. Upon installation, the malware asks for permission to execute with elevated privileges. If granted, the sample sets up persistence through the creation of a startup process. In the past, the researchers had seen Coinminers using the Tor network for C2 communications. This sample differs as it uses an open-source version of the invisible internet protocol for this communication. This protocol allows for stealthy peer-to-peer communication which is encrypted. Looking for historic versions of this miner allowed the researchers to determine that this miner family has been potentially active since October 2019. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74059144/Mac%20Cryptominer%20Uses%20I2P%20To%20Mask%20Communications%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645525603990&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing (M1045). 



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/b/latest-mac-coinminer-utilizes-open-source-binaries-and-the-i2p-network.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

# Overview

The initial delivery mechanism of this malware is unclear, however, artifacts in the malware indicate that the threat actor may use a malicious Adobe Photoshop installer to trick users into installing it. Upon installation, the malware asks for permission to execute with elevated privileges. If granted, the sample sets up persistence through the creation of a startup process. In the past, the researchers had seen Coinminers using the Tor network for C2 communications. This sample differs as it uses an open-source version of the invisible internet protocol for this communication. This protocol allows for stealthy peer-to-peer communication which is encrypted. Looking for historic versions of this miner allowed the researchers to determine that this miner family has been potentially active since October 2019. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74059144/Mac%20Cryptominer%20Uses%20I2P%20To%20Mask%20Communications%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645525603990&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing (M1045). 



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/b/latest-mac-coinminer-utilizes-open-source-binaries-and-the-i2p-network.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1543 - Create or Modify System Process  
T1543.004 - Launch Daemon  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism  
T1548.004 - Elevated Execution with Prompt  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1036.005 - Match Legitimate Name or Location  
T1222.002 - Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1090 - Proxy  
T1090.003 - Multi-hop Proxy  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: gstaticapi Credit Card Stealing Malware
A new skimmer loaded from a Magento site titled "gstaticapi" was discovered and analyzed by Sucuri researchers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: gstaticapi Credit Card Stealing Malware
A new skimmer loaded from a Magento site titled "gstaticapi" was discovered and analyzed by Sucuri researchers.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Skimmer




# Overview

Sucuri has published a blog post providing their analysis of a new credit card skimmer loading a script from a site titled "gstaticapi." The first piece of JavaScript is inserted into the header of a compromised website. If the string "checkout" is identified, the code calls out to remote URL to execute a second JavaScript blob. Both the string "checkout" and the remote URL are based64-encoded in an attempt to avoid detection. This second-stage JavaScript is heavily obfuscated and acts as a skimmer, identifying and exfiltrating credit card information and billing details to the attacker. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/09/magento-credit-card-stealing-malware-gstaticapi.html>

I have encountered the following information: Mozilla Security Advisory February 05 2021
Mozilla has released a security advisory addressing a critical vulnerability in Firefox and Firefox ESR.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
The Mozilla Foundation has issued a security advisory, 2021-06, which addresses a buffer overflow vulnerability in the Angle graphics library. No CVE number for the vulnerability has been provided at this time. If successfully exploited, the vulnerability could allow the remote execution of arbitrary code. We recommend updating to the new fixed versions, Firefox 85.0.1 and Firefox ESR 78.7.1, as soon as possible. Advisory notes are located within the article linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * None Provided




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/security/advisories/mfsa2021-06/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Ukrainians Targeted By Formbook Spam Campaign
The MalwareBytes Threat Intelligence Team has been monitoring a phishing campaign targeting Ukrainian citizens. The campaign delivers the commercial malware Formbook.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Target:** Ukrainian Citizens
  *  **Lure:** Offer of Money From Ukrainian Authorities
  *  **Payload:** Formbook
  *  **Compromised Data:** Unknown



# Overview

The MalwareBytes Threat Intelligence Team has been tracking a phishing campaign delivering Formbook to Ukrainian citizens. The malware is delivered as an excel file attachment on an email. The email is claiming to be from the authorities offering money to citizens, with the attachment pretending to be a letter of approval. If opened, the file uses an exploit to compromise the machine and download the Formbook payload. Formbook is commercial malware that is sold as a service on the dark web. It is designed to steal personal information and control infected devices remotely. Since this is a widely used piece of malware, attribution is difficult. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/82641067/Ukrainians%20Targeted%20By%20Formbook%20Spam%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1647271312299&api=v2)



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2022/03/formbook-spam-campaign-targets-citizens-of-ukraine%ef%b8%8f/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
T1112 - Modify Registry  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1012 - Query Registry  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: COVID-19 Used to Deliver Zebrocy
COVID-19 phishing lures are nothing in a time of pandemic chaos. Intezer reports on the use of the pandemic to deliver the malware known as Zebrocy.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: COVID-19 Used to Deliver Zebrocy
COVID-19 phishing lures are nothing in a time of pandemic chaos. Intezer reports on the use of the pandemic to deliver the malware known as Zebrocy.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing




# Overview

Zebrocy, malware used against government and commercial organizations engaged in foreign efforts, has been seen being delivered via documents about a COVID-19 vaccine company. A Virtual Hard Drive is the delivery mechanism and requires the victims to use Windows 10 in order to access the malicious files. The malware is heavily obfuscated but attribution was made to the Sofacy threat actor through the use of forensics in samples obtained from prior campaigns. Sofacy, also known as APT28, FancyBear, and STRONTIUM, was responsible for the compromise of the Democratic National Committee. Originally written in Delphi, the malware has since been translated into several other programming languages, thus widening its footprint and possible targets. The malware works by having a user open a VHD which includes two files, a PDF and an executable masquerading as a Word document. The PDF is a copy of slides from a presentation about the Sinopharm International Corporation, a company based out of China and a manufacturer of pharmaceutical products. The company is currently working on a COVID-19 vaccination and presents an attractive lure to unsuspecting users. The second file is the actual malware, and only 9 of 70 anti-virus engines were able to detect it. The malware is obfuscated with gobfuscator and doesn't collect the same information as noted in prior campaigns. Instead, only the hostname and TEMP folder path are gathered. Screenshot code has been implemented by the author and does not use a third-party software to accomplish the task. Additionally, anti-debugging checks are performed through the use of the Windows API, IsDebuggerPresent. If present, the malware enters an infinite sleep. Screenshots are uploaded to a C2 server and, should the C2 return a second stage, the file is written to the target disk and executed. Further information can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/research/russian-apt-uses-covid-19-lures-to-deliver-zebrocy/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Gravity RAT Returns as Chat Application
Gravity is an Android RAT that can provide threat actors the ability to steal sensitive data from victim devices. Cyble reports on a recently discovered sample masquerading as a messaging application.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Gravity RAT Returns as Chat Application
Gravity is an Android RAT that can provide threat actors the ability to steal sensitive data from victim devices. Cyble reports on a recently discovered sample masquerading as a messaging application.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** RAT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Gravity
  *  **Targets:** Android users 
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft



# Overview

Cyble published a blog post analyzing a recent Gravity RAT sample masquerading as a secure chat application named "SoSafe Chat." At this time, the initial infection vector is unknown but the application is likely distributed via phishing links or a compromised site. Once on a device, the malware obtains various permissions that will ultimately allow the operator to steal sensitive data, such as SMS messages, call logs, audio, and system information. A hard-coded C2 address is used for communication and exfiltration of data. Within the source code, the researchers observed a domain name that led to a website advertising the messaging application. The download links on the site, however, were disabled so it is not currently the distribution source of the payload. For more information, see the Cyble blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222505/Gravity%20RAT%20Returns%20as%20Chat%20Application%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636998301767&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Install security updates (M1001).
  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).
  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.



# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2021/11/11/gravity-rat-malware-returns-as-a-chat-application/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**

T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application

 **Execution - TA0041**

T1575 - Native Code

 **Persistence - TA0028**

T1402 - Broadcast Receivers 

**Collection - TA0035**

T1412 - Capture SMS Messages

T1429 - Capture Audio

T1432 - Access Contact List

T1433 - Access Call Log

T1533 - Data from Local System  


 **Command and Control - TA0037**

T1436 - Commonly Used Port

T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0036**

T1436 - Commonly Used Port

T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol

 **Impact - TA0034**

T1400 - Modify System Permissions

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Newhall School District Victim of Ransomware
Breach / Leak Notification: Systems belonging to the Newhall School District were the victims of a ransomware attack. No details have been provided on the ransomware involved in the attack. According to a media report, the attack caused a halt to online classes for at least two days.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

  
"Newhall School District recently learned of an incident involving a ransomware attack on our systems. After we learned of this incident, we took immediate action to protect the District’s system and data. We are working to restore operations and enhance the security of our platforms. A professional third-party forensics firm has been engaged to investigate the ransomware incident and determine the scope of the incident. As our investigation continues, we will continue to enhance our security measures to help protect the student and employee data stored on our systems."

# Reference

  * <https://www.newhallschooldistrict.com/>

  * <https://www.foxla.com/news/newhall-school-district-halts-distance-learning-after-ransomware-attack>
