instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Chinese Threat Group Using Security Software To Load Malware
Sentinel Labs has been tracking a Chinese threat group named 'Moshen Dragon'. They have observed this group attempting to use antivirus software to sideload malicious DLLs. Details of these attempts have been published in an article.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Espionage
  *  **Targets:** Central Asia
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** PlugX, ShadowPad
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Sentinel Labs has observed a threat group known as 'Moshen Dragon' utilizing a trial-and-error process to sideload malicious DLLs. The group is operating in Central Asia and primarily operates as a cyberespionage group. The group attempted to use search-order hijacking to get security software to execute a malicious DLL rather than a legitimate one. This DLL would decrypt a malicious encrypted payload stored in the same folder. The researchers observed the actors attempting to exploit five different security products, showing that they were persistent when the technique did not work the first time, and were not put off by detections from security software. The payloads were variants of ShadowPad and PlugX malware. Once a foothold was established, the threat actors moved laterally using Impacket and installed a backdoor which was used to harvest credentials and exfiltrate data. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/moshen-dragons-triad-and-error-approach-abusing-security-software-to-sideload-plugx-and-shadowpad/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1574.001 - DLL Search Order Hijacking  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1574.001 - DLL Search Order Hijacking  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

Sentinel Labs has been tracking a Chinese threat group named 'Moshen Dragon'. They have observed this group attempting to use antivirus software to sideload malicious DLLs. Details of these attempts have been published in an article.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Vidar Infostealer Spread Via Malicious Windows 11 ISO Files
ZScaler has published a report detailing a new campaign they have been tracking. This campaign uses malicious Windows 11 ISO files to infect the victim with the Vidar Infostealer.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Infostealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Vidar
  *  **Targets:** Windows Users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing Site
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

ZScaler ThreatLabz has discovered a new campaign spreading the Vidar infostealer. The researchers found newly registered domains that were spoofing the official Microsoft Windows 11 OS download portal. From these sites, the victims could download fake Windows 11 ISO files which are very large, and so can evade network security products. These files are signed with an expired certificate that is likely stolen during the 2019 AVAST compromise. The Vidar samples seen in this campaign are all packed with Themida and are very large in size, as they have been artificially inflated with padding bytes. The malware uses hardcoded URLs as dead drop resolvers, which directs them to various social media accounts on Telegram and Mastadon that host legitimate binaries for credential and data harvesting. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/vidar-distributed-through-backdoored-windows-11-downloads-and-abusing>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1585.001 - Social Media Accounts  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027.001 - Binary Padding  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1036 - Masquerading  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1102.001 - Dead Drop Resolver  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Apple Security Update for Safari - Exploitation in the Wild Reported
Apple has published a security update for Safari. One vulnerability is addressed in the update, which is reported as being actively exploited in the wild.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Apple Security Update for Safari - Exploitation in the Wild Reported
Apple has published a security update for Safari. One vulnerability is addressed in the update, which is reported as being actively exploited in the wild.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 If successfully exploited, the vulnerability could potentially allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code. We recommend updating to the latest version as soon as possible. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-30665




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT212340>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Updated XCSSET Malware Targets Telegram and Other Apps
XCSSET is a malware family that targets macOS devices in order to steal sensitive information. Trend Micro reports on the most recent updates to the XCSSET malware and its techniques.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type** : Stealer

  *  **Associated Threat Actors** : Unknown

  *  **Associated Payloads** : XCSSET

  *  **Targets** : macOS users

  *  **Initial Infection Vector** : Infected Xcode Project ([T1204.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204/002/))

  *  **Post-Compromise Actions** : Steal data from application files ([T1005](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1005/)), Exfiltrate app data ([T1041](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1041/))

  *  **Additional TTPs** : Archive collected data into ZIP ([T1560](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1560))




# Overview

Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing the most recent version of the XCSSET malware. As with before, the malware is delivered via infected Xcode projects and is used to steal information from various apps. Since previous reporting, analysts were able to identify the mechanism for stealing this information. The malware steals application files from the Application sandbox directory, which does not require admin privileges. The application files are archived in ZIP format and exfiltrated to a C2 server. Where administrator privileges are needed, a single command is used to prompt users to grant the permissions via a fake dialog box. The scripts leveraged by XCSSET show the capability to steal information from TElegram, Contacts, Evernote, Notes, Chrome, Opera, Skype, and WeChat. The researchers also provide a brief overview of recent C2 infrastructure changes. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/g/updated-xcsset-malware-targets-telegram--other-apps.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: AnyDesk Bundled with Babuk Ransomware
A blog post from Quick Heal details an infection chain involving fake AnyDesk websites distributing the Babuk downloader and Allakore RAT.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** RAT, Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Allakore, Babuk
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake AnyDesk installer
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft, data encryption



# Overview

Quick Heal uncovered fake AnyDesk websites being used to ultimately infect victims with the Babuk ransomware. These sites advertise a free AnyDesk installer that, if downloaded, is delivered to the system as a self-extracting archive. Upon execution, the archive runs the legitimate AnyDesk setup binary, presenting the installer application to the user. In the background, the Allakore RAT, Babuk downloader, and a .reg file are dropped into the Startup folder and subsequently executed using PowerShell. First, the .reg file is used to disable UAC and malware protection. Then the Babuk downloader is executed, which first launches the Allakore RAT to establish a C2 connection back to the attacker. After performing various defense evasion tactics, the downloader ultimately downloads and executes a BAT script and executable. The BAT script performs further defense evasion. The executable file is the final payload, the Babuk ransomware. Files are encrypted and data is stolen with a ransom being demanded in order to restore access and prevent data leak. For more information, see the Quick Heal blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [Anydesk Bundled with Babuk Ransomware IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155276/Anydesk%20Bundled%20with%20Babuk%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638206944295&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).



# References

  * <https://blogs.quickheal.com/anydesk-software-exploited-to-spread-babuk-ransomware/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism  
T1548.002 - Bypass User Account Control  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

A blog post from Quick Heal details an infection chain involving fake AnyDesk websites distributing the Babuk downloader and Allakore RAT.

Upon execution, the archive runs the legitimate AnyDesk setup binary, presenting the installer application to the user. In the background, the Allakore RAT, Babuk downloader, and a .reg file are dropped into the Startup folder and subsequently executed using PowerShell. First, the .reg file is used to disable UAC and malware protection. Then the Babuk downloader is executed, which first launches the Allakore RAT to establish a C2 connection back to the attacker. After performing various defense evasion tactics, the downloader ultimately downloads and executes a BAT script and executable. The BAT script performs further defense evasion. The executable file is the final payload, the Babuk ransomware. Files are encrypted and data is stolen with a ransom being demanded in order to restore access and prevent data leak. For more information, see the Quick Heal blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [Anydesk Bundled with Babuk Ransomware IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155276/Anydesk%20Bundled%20with%20Babuk%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638206944295&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).



# References

  * <https://blogs.quickheal.com/anydesk-software-exploited-to-spread-babuk-ransomware/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism  
T1548.002 - Bypass User Account Control  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: macOS Adware in Rust
Using a new programming language, Rust, threat actors have turned their attention to the creation of adware. SecureList posted a blog detailing the language and its use in the creation of adware.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Adware




# Overview

A new adware program dubbed Convuster has been seen in the wild. The adware is written in a little known programming language called Rust. Analysts were able to identify the language through the use of Rust specific language and the file extension .rs. The malware works by checking for keys needed to run the adware. The program obtains a device ID, system version, fitness and forwards that data to a C2 server. A JSON file is sent and sends a request to the host specified within the JSON file. In response, a Bash script is sent and executed. After the script retrieves the Bash shell, it is removed from the system. Upon analysis of the C2 server, a DMG disk image with the Convuster executable written in Swift was found. The malware is stored in a macOS Gatekeeper security system. This helps to prevent analysis from security professionals. If certain checks are successful, the user is shown a window prompting the installation of FlashPlayer. If the checks fail, the program provides a window informing the victim to try later. The actual malware is run through LaunchAgents but does not write itself to run on startup. Based on the behavior of the malware, SecureList has classified it as malware. Further details can be found in the blog located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/convuster-macos-adware-in-rust/101258/>

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Malicious Android Apps Targeting Users of JIO Telecom in India
Zscaler has identified a threat actor spreading malicious android apps via WhatsApp and SMS. The apps are specifically targeting JIO telecom users in India. Those targeted are tricked into thinking that TikTok is available again in India or that they are installing an app to register to receive a free Lenovo laptop, courtesy of the Government of India.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Malicious Android Apps Targeting Users of JIO Telecom in India
Zscaler has identified a threat actor spreading malicious android apps via WhatsApp and SMS. The apps are specifically targeting JIO telecom users in India. Those targeted are tricked into thinking that TikTok is available again in India or that they are installing an app to register to receive a free Lenovo laptop, courtesy of the Government of India.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing




# Overview

An unnamed threat actor has been identified as actively operating since as early as March 20, 2020. Zscaler says the threat actor has been specifically targeting users of JIO, a telecom company operating in India. Victims may receive a message via WhatsApp or an SMS which contains a shortened URL that leads them to a web page on [weebly.com](http://weebly.com). From there, the user is tricked into downloading and installing a malicious Android APK file. The file is hosted on an attacker-controlled GitHub account. One of the tactics they use is to say that TikTok is available again in India and this is the new app. Another is that they need to install the app to register for a free Lenovo laptop being given out to students in India by the Government of India. The malicious app will display ads that provide revenue to the threat actor. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/android-apps-targeting-jio-users-india>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: UltimaSMS Scam Campaign
A large premium SMS scam campaign, dubbed "UltimaSMS," is being carried out via the Google Play Store. Avast reports on the fake applications and their functionality in a recent blog post.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** SMS Subscription Scam
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unknown
  *  **Associated** **Campaign** : UltimaSMS
  *  **Targets:** Android users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake apps in Google Play Store
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Premium SMS subscription enrollment



# Overview

Avast published a blog post analyzing a premium SMS scam campaign, dubbed "UltimaSMS," that has been active since at least May 2021. Google Play Store links to fake copies of legitimate applications are being shared via TikTok and Instagram. The types of applications vary and include custom keyboards, photo editors, games, and more. Once on the system, the fake app gathers system information to determine the location of the victim, which will determine the language and area code that should be used. Upon opening the app, users are presented with a location-specific prompt requesting a phone number. Entering this information results in the user being enrolled in monthly premium SMS services, with the charge maxed out to the limit of the country they are located in. The app either attempts to enroll them in further subscriptions or becomes non-functional. For more information, see the Avast blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616701/UltimaSMS%20Scam%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635257639416&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Install security updates (M1001).
  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).
  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blog.avast.com/premium-sms-scam-apps-on-play-store-avast>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**

T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application

T1475 - Deliver Malicious App via Authorized App Store

 **Execution - TA0041**

T1204.002 – User Execution: Malicious File

 **Discovery - TA0032**

T1422 – System Network Configuration Discovery

 **Impact - TA0034**

T1448 – Carrier Billing Fraud

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Credit Card Skimmer Evades Virtual Machines
It is not uncommon for credit card skimmers to check geolocation or user-agent strings to filter potential victims. In an interesting case, Malwarebytes observed a skimmer instead performing virtual machine detection via the browser for filtering.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Skimmer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Magecart
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Magecart skimmer
  *  **Targets:** Online retail consumers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Server-side compromise
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Credit card skimming
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Virtual machine detection



# Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post analyzing a new Magecart skimmer that implements virtual machine detection. This is a feature not commonly seen being performed by browser-based malware. The skimming JavaScript code is loaded on a compromised checkout page, masquerading as an Angular library. The WebGL JavaScript API is used to identify the victim machine's graphics renderer. If a software renderer, which is a common fallback for virtualization software, is identified, the skimming activity will not take place. If the checks pace, any data provided in the checkout form, such as contact information and credit card details, is exfiltrated to the attacker via an HTTP POST request. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70221868/Credit%20Card%20Skimmer%20Evades%20Virtual%20Machines%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636038054341&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2021/11/credit-card-skimmer-evades-virtual-machines/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**

  *  **Targets:** Online retail consumers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Server-side compromise
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Credit card skimming
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Virtual machine detection



# Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post analyzing a new Magecart skimmer that implements virtual machine detection. This is a feature not commonly seen being performed by browser-based malware. The skimming JavaScript code is loaded on a compromised checkout page, masquerading as an Angular library. The WebGL JavaScript API is used to identify the victim machine's graphics renderer. If a software renderer, which is a common fallback for virtualization software, is identified, the skimming activity will not take place. If the checks pace, any data provided in the checkout form, such as contact information and credit card details, is exfiltrated to the attacker via an HTTP POST request. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70221868/Credit%20Card%20Skimmer%20Evades%20Virtual%20Machines%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636038054341&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2021/11/credit-card-skimmer-evades-virtual-machines/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1584.004 - Server  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1497.001 - System Checks  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.002 - GUI Input Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1132 - Data Encoding

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Android Banking Trojan Hydra Distributed Using Fake App
A report from Cyble provides an analysis of a fake app that was being distributed through the Google Play store. The app is being used by a threat actor to download the Hydra banking Trojan.
output:
Summary
=======



Attack Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Android Malware
* **Targets:** Android users
* **Malware Family/Families:** Hydra banking Trojan
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake app
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

The Hydra banking Trojan that infects Android devices was discovered in early 2019. Since then multiple campaigns have been observed distributing it. A report from Cyble provides an analysis of a recent campaign that was distributing Hydra through a fake Document Manager app that was available from the Google Play store. When the app is installed the victim is presented with a fake update prompt which is used to trick the victim into giving the app permission to download the Hydra Trojan from a remote location. It will then ask the victim for permission to access Accessibility Services. Hydra has in the past been used to target European and Columbian users. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://blog.cyble.com/2022/06/13/hydra-android-malware-distributed-via-play-store/>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Initial Access - TA0027**  
 T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
 T1475 - Deliver Malicious App via Authorized App Store

**Defense Evasion - TA0030**  
 T1406 - Obfuscated Files or Information

**Credential Access - TA0031**  
 T1409 - Access Stored Application Data  
 T1412 - Capture SMS Messages

**Discovery - TA0032**  
 T1421 - System Network Connections Discovery

**Command and Control - TA0037**  
 T1571 - Non-Standard Port  
 T1573 - Encrypted Channel

**Mitigations:**

**M1001:**  Security Updates -Install security updates in response to discovered vulnerabilities. Purchase devices with a vendor and/or mobile carrier commitment to provide security updates in a prompt manner for a set period of time. Decommission devices that will no longer receive security updates. Limit or block access to enterprise resources from devices that have not installed recent security updates. On Android devices, access can be controlled based on each device's security patch level. On iOS devices, access can be controlled based on the iOS version.  
**M1005:**  Application Vetting - Enterprises can vet applications for exploitable vulnerabilities or unwanted (privacy-invasive or malicious) behaviors. Enterprises can inspect applications themselves or use a third-party service. Enterprises may impose policies to only allow pre-approved applications to be installed on their devices or may impose policies to block use of specific applications known to have issues. In Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) environments, enterprises may only be able to impose these policies over an enterprise-managed portion of the device. Application Vetting is not a complete mitigation. Techniques such as Evade Analysis Environment exist that can enable adversaries to bypass vetting.  
**M1006:**  Use Recent OS Version - New mobile operating system versions bring not only patches against discovered vulnerabilities but also often bring security architecture improvements that provide resilience against potential vulnerabilities or weaknesses that have not yet been discovered. They may also bring improvements that block use of observed adversary techniques.  
**M1011:**  User Guidance - Describes any guidance or training given to users to set particular configuration settings or avoid specific potentially risky behaviors.  
**M1020:**    SSL/TLS Inspection - SSL/TLS inspection can be used to see the contents of encrypted sessions to look for network-based indicators of malware communication protocols.  
**M1030:**    Network Segmentation - Properly configure firewalls and proxies to limit outgoing traffic to only necessary ports for that particular network segment.  
**M1031:**    Network Intrusion Prevention - Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

A report from Cyble provides an analysis of a fake app that was being distributed through the Google Play store. The app is being used by a threat actor to download the Hydra banking Trojan.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Ukrainian Government Targeted with Covid-21 Lure
Fortinet analysts have reported on a campaign using Covid 21 as a lure against Ukrainian government targets. The lure leads to a malicious link within the email.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Spearphishing




# Overview

The Ukrainian government has come under attack from threat actors using a fictitious Covid 21 variant based phishing and malware delivery email. Using this Covid 21 variant in the subject line is designed to entice users into clicking the link within the email itself. The report states the infrastructure used in the attacks originates in Russia. Additionally, the threat actors used an email that contained a, likely, fictitious conversation between two arms of the U.S. Government. Specifically, the conversation is between a WHO official and the U.S. Department of State. The analysts have speculated the email is targeting government-specific communication and not random companies. This particular campaign does not use malicious attachments but links embedded in the actual email that lead to the download of a .ZIP file. The contents of the zip file are a DOC file, two shortcut files, and a PDF file. Only the PDF file is legitimate and not malicious. The shortcut files launch cmd.exe to launch PowerShell to download and execute another malicious file. The DOC file is a malicious document that exploits CVE-2017-11882. This allows for arbitrary code execution. By exploiting this, the document downloads and executes another malicious file. A complete breakdown of the capabilities of these files can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/spearphishing-attack-uses-covid-21-lure-to-target-ukrainian-government>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Spearphishing Campaign Using Short-Lived Domains To Steal Credentials
The DomainTools Research team has published details of a spearphishing campaign that is targeting major organizations to steal SharePoint credentials.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Spearphishing Campaign Using Short-Lived Domains To Steal Credentials
The DomainTools Research team has published details of a spearphishing campaign that is targeting major organizations to steal SharePoint credentials.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Spearphishing
  *  **Target:** Major Corporatins in the Middle East
  *  **Lure:** Finance Themed PDF
  *  **Payload:** Phishing Link Via False Invoice PDF
  *  **Compromised Data:** SharePoint Credentials



# Overview

The DomainTools Research team has discovered a spearphishing campaign that uses a SharePoint template to target employees at major corporations. The campaign seems to focus on companies in the Middle East. The campaign was originally identified when a malicious PDF document was discovered containing a legitimate email address, suggesting that it was part of a larger spearphishing campaign. Upon further investigation, the researchers discovered over 70 versions of this document, where each document had a unique email address and link. The one connection between all of these links was that it linked to a file named 'red.htm', hosted on different subdomains of 'glitch.me'. Glitch provides a tool for web application development that allows for the five-minute hosting of web applications. The temporary nature of this site makes it perfect for serving malicious content. The researchers were able to find a live site that displays the phishing site, attempting to steal SharePoint credentials. Once the credentials are stolen, the user is redirected to the legitimate site. The earliest document from this campaign found by the researchers dates back to September 2021. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155166/Spearphishing%20Campaign%20Using%20Short-Lived%20Domains%20To%20Steal%20Credentials%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637768906769&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction (M1017).
  * Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc (M1021).
  * Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries (M1031).



# References

  * <https://www.domaintools.com/resources/blog/seeing-red>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: DDoS Attacks Targeting Ukrainian Websites Analyzed
A Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack targeting Ukrainian government organizations and banks caused temporary outages from February 15-16th.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Ukrainian Financial and Government Organizations
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Katana bot (derivative of Mirai) 
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Botnet 
  * **Post-Compromise Actions:** DDoS
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Cado Security reports that between February 15-16th a number of Financial, Government, and Military websites fell victim to a Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack. Network traffic to bank sites - Privat Bank and Oschad Bank - was seen spiking as the the attack commenced along with customer reports of the websites being unavailable. Some Privat Bank customers in the Ukraine received SMS messages crafted by adversaries warning that ATMs would not work on February 15th. In addition, a BGP hijack against the Privat Bank's IP space caused traffic routing issues for users. The report also mentions other components to the attack such as DDoS attacks against .gov.ua DNS servers. The news outlet, tsn.ua, named zsu.gov.ua and mil.gov.ua as specific Ukrainian government victims. The Ukrainian Ministry of Defense also confirmed the attack via Twitter. The report calls out Mirai and derivative Katana as likely botnets used to launch the attack. It goes on to name exploited Avtech network cameras as the launch point for the attacks. Overall, Cado Security's report calls these attacks moderately impactful. They were not particularly successful but the combination of methods suggests there is a base level of sophistication coordinated by the adversary. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/81133648/DDoS%20Attacks%20Targeting%20Ukrainian%20Websites%20Analyzed%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645985381594&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root (M1026).
  * Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic (M1037).
  * Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038).
  * Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040).
  * Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses (M1047).
  * Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software (M1049).
  * Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques (M1056).



# References

  * <https://www.cadosecurity.com/technical-analysis-of-the-ddos-attacks-against-ukrainian-websites/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.005 - Botnet  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1498 - Network Denial of Service

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Android Security Bulletin - May 2021
The Android Security Bulletin for May has been released and provides information on the forty-two vulnerabilities that are addressed in this bulletin.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

The April security bulletin for Android has been released. In it, forty-two vulnerabilities are addressed. Some of the potential impacts of successful exploitation of the vulnerabilities are information disclosure, privilege escalation, and remote code execution. Four of the vulnerabilities were rated as Critical, and thirty-seven as High, and one as Moderate. For details on the issues addressed in this bulletin, refer to the link in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/48038223/Android%20Security%20Bulletin%20-%20May%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1620102774790&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://source.android.com/security/bulletin/2021-05-01>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Cuba Ransomware Updates Analyzed
Trend Micro has analyzed Cuba ransomware and published the analysis in a new article. Their research shows that the malware is being continually developed, with new variants being seen almost monthly.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Ransomware
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
* **Associated Payloads:** Cuba Ransomware (S0625)
* **Targets:** Unknown
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encryption, Data Theft
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Cuba ransomware was first detected in February 2020 and has regularly resurfaced since then with new updates. Trend Micro has reported that the threat group has started using a custom downloader called BUGHATCH to install the ransomware. The newest variant contains changes allowing the ransomware to terminate a wide range of processes relating to databases and storage. It is also optimized to speed up its execution and provide technical support to compliant victims who want to negotiate. The new variant has expanded its whitelisted directories and file extensions to avoid impacting the underlying operating system. Looking at the updated ransom note, it appears that the threat group are moving towards a double extortion model as it includes a specific threat that wasn't there in samples from March 2022. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/f/cuba-ransomware-group-s-new-variant-found-using-optimized-infect.html>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
   T1059.001 - PowerShell  
   T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
 T1106 - Native API  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1543 - Create or Modify System Process  
   T1543.003 - Windows Service  

**Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
 T1134 - Access Token Manipulation  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
   T1027.002 - Software Packing  
 T1036 - Masquerading  
   T1036.005 - Match Legitimate Name or Location  
 T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
   T1070.004 - File Deletion  
 T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
   T1564.003 - Hidden Window  
 T1620 - Reflective Code Loading  

**Credential Access - TA0006**  
 T1056 - Input Capture  
   T1056.001 - Keylogging  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1007 - System Service Discovery  
 T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
 T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  
 T1057 - Process Discovery  
 T1082 - System Information Discovery  
 T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
 T1135 - Network Share Discovery  
 T1614 - System Location Discovery  
   T1614.001 - System Language Discovery  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  

**Impact - TA0040**  
 T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
 T1489 - Service Stop  

#### Mitigations:

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1015:**  Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1029:**  Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
**M1030:**  Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1039:**  Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1041:**  Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1053:**  Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: WIRTE Phishing Campaign Targets The Middle East
SecureList has discovered a new phishing campaign targeting organizations in the Middle East. This has been attributed to the group known as WIRTE.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: WIRTE Phishing Campaign Targets The Middle East
SecureList has discovered a new phishing campaign targeting organizations in the Middle East. This has been attributed to the group known as WIRTE.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** WIRTE
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Ferocious Dropper, LitePower
  *  **Targets:** Financial institutions, Law firms, Military organizations, and Technology companies mainly in the Middle East. **  
**
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

SecureList researchers have published details of a phishing campaign that is targeting businesses in the middle east. This has been attributed to the lesser-known WIRTE group, which uses relatively simple TTPs to remain undetected for a long time. The campaign starts with spearphishing emails with an attached office document (either Word or Excel). The office documents contain malicious macros to allow the next stage of the attack to continue. Once the user has enabled macros on the document, the macros perform several activities. firstly, the documents perform checks to confirm that it is not running in a sandbox. If these tests pass, the document establishes persistence using the registry and then downloads the next stage of the attack, which is an implant called LitePower. This implant establishes communication with the C2 server and can accept and execute commands sent by the attacker. It can also download and execute further malware at the attacker's discretion. The researchers were able to discover multiple C2 domains used by this malware, with some being hidden behind CloudFlare to conceal the true source domain. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155397/WIRTE%20Phishing%20Campaign%20Targets%20The%20Middle%20East%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638275886794&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction (M1017).
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://securelist.com/wirtes-campaign-in-the-middle-east-living-off-the-land-since-at-least-2019/105044/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Malicious Attack Campaign Targeting Jetpack Users Reusing Passwords
A malvertising campaign detected by Wordfence was determined to be the result of compromised WordPress login credentials on sites connected to Jetpack.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malvertising




# Overview

Wordfence published a blog post detailing a malvertising campaign abusing compromised WordPress login credentials on sites connected to Jetpack. Jetpack is a popular plugin for WordPress that requires administrators to connect their sites to a WordPress.com account. This WordPress.com account can then be used to perform administrative tasks on any WordPress site connected to Jetpack via that account. In the campaign observed by Wordfence, this administrative access was abused to install plugins that check to make sure a visitor to a website is not logged in and, if not, redirects the visitor to a malvertising website. Wordfence notes that this is not the first time Jetpack access has been used in combination with WordPress.com credentials to install malicious plugins. For more information, see the Wordfence blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.wordfence.com/blog/2021/06/malicious-attack-campaign-targeting-jetpack-users-reusing-passwords/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Recent Hive0016 Infrastructure and Use of NorthStarC2 Pentest Framework
X-Force identified a series of phishing pages likely used by the suspected Iranian threat actor Hive0016, also known as APT33 and Elfin. Additionally, X-Force identified evidence that Hive0016 is using the open source pentest framework NorthStarC2.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing




# Overview

X-Force identified a series of phishing pages likely used by the suspected Iranian threat actor Hive0016, also known as APT33 and Elfin. X-Force identified several domains likely used to phish credentials for Microsoft and other accounts. Additionally, X-Force identified evidence that Hive0016 is using the open source pentest framework NorthStarC2. Hive0016 has leveraged other open source pentest frameworks previously, such as PoshC2 and Kodiak.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Indicators of compromise are available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.



# Recommendations

  * Use complex account passwords that are at least 12-14 characters in length and are a combination of letters (upper and lower case), numbers and special characters
  * If possible, enable MFA.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IOCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IOCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/a8e02d9a-492e-4ea0-b7cd-bec989aeb2c7>
  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>
